HEADLINE: Mussolini Medallions Turn Up at Ranch

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: SHELDON, Mo.

 BODY:
A collection of large copper medallions created for one of Mussolini's principal Fascist shrines in Rome and missing since American troops occupied the Italian capital in World War II has come to light at a cattle ranch here in southwestern Missouri.
Jay H. Anderson, who operates the 800-acre ranch near the Kansas border, said his father, a major in the United States Army who died in 1976, said that he had removed nine medallions from a marble map on the side of a building when his unit, part of the 45th Infantry Division, became one of the first to occupy Rome in June 1944. Maj. James H. Anderson then mailed the medallions to his home in Kansas City, his son said. 
 After his father's death, Mr. Anderson explained, he divided the medallions with his sister, Nancy Ekern, who lives in Mexico, Mo., and he and his sister have been using them, unaware of their significance, to decorate their homes.
Mr. Anderson said that his father had told him that he had asked his commanding officer if he could have the medallions, and the officer had said: "Yeah, if you want them, get them!"
"My dad then got an extension ladder and pulled them off the wall," Mr. Anderson said. "He told me he just tied them up with cord, and didn't even wrap them in anything. He put his address on them and mailed them home. And when he got back from the service, they were on our porch in Kansas City just the way he had tied them up."
Mr. Anderson said that he and his sister have yet to decide what to do with the medallions now that their historical significance is known.
It is possible, although unlikely because of their limited monetary value, that the Italian Government will try to recover the medallions by filing a civil suit against the Andersons in Missouri.
The Andersons could be prosecuted under the National Stolen Property Act, which makes it a crime to knowingly possess stolen property. That is unlikely because the Andersons, until recently, were unaware of the importance of the medallions. The Andersons were contacted by a New York Times reporter who had learned of the existence of the medallions through a letter from a third party.
Scholars say that although the medallions are the work of Antonio Munoz (1884-1960), a prominent Italian artist of his time, and have artistic merit, their chief value is as historical artifacts that reveal Mussolini's carefully cloaked lust for empire.
"They're very important documents," said Denis Mack Smith, an emeritus professor of modern Italian history at Oxford University's All Souls College and the author of a biography and other works on the Italian dictator. "Mussolini talked about imperialism in deliberately confusing and contradictory terms, but here you have exact illustrations of what he was thinking."
The medallions, made of finely hammered sheets of copper, measure about 3 feet by 4 feet. They depict industrial, agricultural and maritime scenes, and were highlights on a wall-sized marble map of Mussolini's Fascist empire in 1936, when it dominated the Mediterranean and extended into North Africa through Libya, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia.
The medallions included place names, like Cairo and Suez, leaving no doubt that Mussolini intended to wrest Egypt and the Suez Canal from the control of Britain, an objective he would not acknowledge until at war with Britain in 1940.
The marble map on which the medallions were fastened was one of a series of five marble wall carvings facing the broad avenue Via dei Fori Imperiali between the Colosseum and the Palazzo Venezia where Mussolini used to address huge rallies.
The first four maps were constructed by Munoz on the wall of the Basilica Constantine in 1934 as Mussolini was preparing to conquer Ethiopia. They depict four stages in the growth of ancient Rome, from its supposed founding in 754 B.C. to the reign of Emperor Trajan (A.D. 96-117) when the Roman Empire reached its zenith, encircling the Mediterranean and reaching as far north as Scotland, the Rhine, the Danube and the Black Sea.
"The message was that modern Italy could do this, too, but Mussolini wouldn't come out and say it," Professor Smith said.
Shepard Stone, a European specialist for The New York Times in 1935, reported that year that copies of the marble maps in Rome were appearing "throughout Italy."
They were a powerful propaganda tool, Mr. Stone reported, used by Mussolini to excite his followers to near hysteria with the belief that fate had chosen them to restore the glory that was Rome.
Many European statesmen scoffed at Mussolini's posturing because Italy lacked the industrial, economic and human resources necessary to sustain a great power like Britain or France, not to mention a colossus like ancient Rome. But Mussolini's supporters shrugged off the criticism and took delight in chanting their leader's singsong slogan "Roma doma," Rome dominates.
In the 1930's and early 1940's, the maps and medallions were a backdrop for military spectacles, and the site became revered by Italian Fascists much as the Nuremberg stadium in Germany was cherished by the Nazis.
Mario Bondioli Osio, chief of the Italian Government agency concerned with the recovery of cultural objects lost in World War II, said that after Mussolini's downfall and the collapse of his empire in 1943, the fifth map showing North Africa in the grip of Fascist Italy was destroyed. It has long been thought that the gleaming copper medallions were destroyed as well.
The four maps of ancient Rome still adorn the basilica of Constantine, where they are seen by throngs of tourists every year.
Mr. Osio said the discovery of the medallions had created "great excitement" among local art historians, and that if the objects are returned to Italy they would be placed in the Museo di Roma.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Giving Credit Where Blame Might Be Due

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
HOW can the world be saved from financial disaster without helping the very people who caused that disaster? The world's financial doctors think it can't be done.
The currency collapses in Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea differ in some ways, but the similarities are significant. "The Asian crisis," said Paul Krugman, a professor of international economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "was mainly about bad banking and its consequences." 
 He'd get little argument from Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary and longtime investment banker who headed Goldman, Sachs & Company before joining the Clinton Administration. In all the Asian countries in trouble, Mr. Rubin said in a speech last week at Georgetown University, "close links between governments, banks and corporations led to fundamentally unsound lending by banks." Foreign investors, he added, "injected an extraordinary amount of capital into these flawed systems, without due regard for the risks."
In Korea, said You Jong-Keun, an economic adviser to President-elect Kim Dae Jung, banks made loans based on politics, family relations and even bribery. That, he said, has to change.
And yet it appears that the foreign (primarily American) banks that lent large sums to Korean banks will escape relatively unscathed. While several large foreign banks said last week that Asian problems had caused earnings problems, they have not yet had to write off significant amounts of bad loans, and may never have to do so.
Stock market investors, including those who invest in mutual funds that specialize in emerging markets, have taken huge losses, but the lenders whose easy credit let the problem get out of hand may avoid real red ink, simply because international bailouts will also save them. Bankers negotiating with South Korea have already won a tentative agreement that calls for the Korean Government to take over the bad loans made to Korean commercial banks. A lot of details remain to be negotiated, but it appears that the foreign banks, because their cooperation is needed to avert a collapse, are in a good negotiating position.
That is not a situation that anyone professes to like. "We would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor," Mr. Rubin said in his speech. But, he added: "Any action that would force investors and creditors involuntarily to take losses, however appropriate that might seem, would risk serious adverse consequences. It could cause banks to pull money out of the countries involved. It could reduce the ability of these countries to access new sources of private capital. And perhaps most tellingly, it could cause banks to pull back from other emerging markets."
 
Paging Dr. Pangloss
One can argue that such a pullback might not be a bad idea, assuming it was gradual. Mr. Krugman, reaching back to Voltaire's "Candide," said the history of bailouts might have encouraged banks to lend on the basis of "Pangloss values." Normally, the thinking goes, an investment might make a huge profit, but there is always a risk of a big loss if things go wrong. Under normal circumstances, such an investment might be avoided. But in the best of all possible worlds, investors believe a bailout will rescue them, and they may invest as if that best outcome were a sure thing. But Mr. Krugman agrees that the risk of not mounting bailouts right now is too great.
Mr. Rubin said in his speech that it was "critically important that we work toward changing the global financial architecture so that creditors and investors bear the full consequences of their decisions to the greatest extent possible." But he doesn't appear to have a real grasp of just how to rebuild that global system.
In fact, there are some easy answers in theory, albeit tough to impose in practice. Since most of the bad Asian loans were made to companies and banks, and not to Governments, the companies and banks could be judged on a case-by-case basis. Some would be allowed to fail, leaving the creditors with big losses. Others might be salvaged, making the creditors whole. And those in the middle might survive with the aid of debt-for-equity swaps, in which the foreign banks give up some or all of their loans in return for companies' stock.
"If they were really playing hardball," said Hugh Patrick, a professor of international business at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, the International Monetary Fund and the United States Government could tell the banks that they would only bail out the Koreans if the banks agreed to make some substantial sacrifices. But the banks are in a strong negotiating position, he added, and "it is more important to maintain the system even if we bail out the banks."
Another suggestion came from James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, who noted that one reason Asian countries are in such trouble is that they borrowed dollars (getting lower interest rates) rather than their own currencies, which have since collapsed. Perhaps, Mr. Grant said, banks could only be allowed to collect the original local currency value of their loans. So an Indonesian company that borrowed $1 million six months ago when that sum was worth 2.6 billion rupiahs, for example, would now have to pay back 2.6 billion rupiahs, or, in dollars, about $168,000.
There is precedent for that idea, Mr. Grant noted. During the Depression, President Franklin D. Roosevelt devalued the dollar against gold. Nearly every corporate bond outstanding then specified that if such a thing happened, the company would have to repay more dollars to match the original gold value. That would have caused even more companies to go broke than were already failing, so Congress passed a law saying that those bond contracts were unenforceable and that companies could meet their obligations in devalued dollars. The law was upheld by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 vote.
 
A Rosy Future
That won't happen this time around, because the banks seem to be in far too strong a negotiating position.
Instead, the Asian countries will most likely get stuck with many of the bad loans run up by their companies. That won't do the foreign banks any immediate good, because the countries are in no position to pay them back. But if the loans are stretched out for years, eventually the countries will probably be able to pay them. The banks will end up with long-term loans that work out acceptably in the end; they might even be able to negotiate high interest rates while they wait.
And the countries? Their economies will face what amounts to a tax to repay the bankers, since it will be tax revenues that in the end make the banks whole. That won't seem fair to a lot of people in the affected countries, but it looks like the most probable outcome.

HEADLINE: United Ways Report Rise In Donations

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Donations to many United Ways rose significantly last year, reversing a trend in which donations fell from 1991 to 1996, preliminary figures obtained from large United Ways show.
But the United Ways in Los Angeles and Chicago may bring in less money than they did in 1996, which may mean further cuts in financing for social service charities in those cities. 
 At 11 of the 13 largest United Ways, each of which raises more than $50 million annually, pledges for 1997 rose an average of 3 percent over 1996. Those figures, like all those in this article, are adjusted for inflation. Nationwide, about 95 percent of pledges typically materialize as cash.
Detailed national figures will not be available until August.
The biggest increase was at United Way of King County in Seattle, where pledges rose 14.2 percent to $60 million.
Midsize United Ways have reported strong gains as well. At United Way of Central Carolinas in Charlotte, N.C., which is in the second tier of large United Ways, pledges rose more than 19 percent to $26.5 million.
"In Charlotte we expected 10 percent because the economy is booming," said Betty Beene, president of United Way of America, "but we had no right to expect double that growth." She said that "for the first time in a very long time we are seeing double-digit growth in communities across the country."
Though United Ways historically depended on workers who authorize modest deductions from their paychecks for most of their revenue, the growth in pledges comes almost entirely from business owners and executives making pledges of $1,000 or more, say officials of United Ways across the country.
United Way of New York City said that pledges so far to its local campaign, which provides nearly a quarter of its finances, are up more than 10 percent, to $19 million for 1997 from $17.1 million in 1996.
But the Los Angeles United Way, where donations fell 43 percent from 1991 to 1996, is encountering resistance from donors. Its advertising campaign, which says city residents have plenty of money for breast implants, cafe lattes and "other necessities of life" but are stingy givers, is the subject of widespread debate.
Joseph Haggerty, president of the Greater Los Angeles United Way, said the group might fall "a tad short" of its $59 million goal, which would be a slight decline from 1996.
The Chicago United Way/Crusade of Mercy has extended its campaign, which was to have ended on Dec. 31, to April 1, said its spokeswoman, Carolyn Placko. The organization has not released its figures.
Tri-State United Way, which raises money at 137 large New York area corporations on behalf of 31 local United Ways in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said it expected to report in April that total pledges rose more than 5 percent over 1996. (The United Way of New York City gets about 40 percent of its money from Tri-State.)
All 1,300 local United Ways reported raising $3.25 billion in 1996, which was 11 percent less than in 1991, the last year before a disclosure that William Aramony, who was then the president of United Way of America, had stolen charity funds. Mr. Aramony, convicted on fraud charges, is in prison.
United Way donations have also been declining because widespread layoffs reduced its primary base of support -- workers in large factories and offices -- by 20 percent. The drive was also hurt by stagnant wages and a shift in giving away from social service charities and toward higher education, religion and the arts.
United Way's growing reliance on wealthy donors, rather than modest deductions from paychecks, was evident in Minneapolis, where donations rose more than $3 million, or 6 percent, to $54 million. Pledges of $5,000 or more accounted for 30 percent of the increase, said Jim Boyle, the Minneapolis United Way spokesman.
Not all of the growth in donations will benefit social service charities like Boys and Girls Clubs, Y.M.C.A.'s and Family Service Associations that belong to United Way. That is because some United Ways allow donors to designate that their gifts, after United Way deducts an overhead charge that is typically about 10 percent, be passed on to charities that are not part of United Way. Some United Ways have started to encourage major donors to funnel all their charitable gifts through United Way.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:

BIG GAME, PART 1
Play Along at Home
Yes, it's that Sunday again. Ads, ads, ads, ads, football, ads. As a public service to the soon-to-be-numb, here is a fun way to take part in the annual marketing Bacchanal called the Super Bowl without leaving your Barcalounger. Get yourself a shoe box and, starting with this sentence, toss a thousand-dollar bill into it for each word you read. (That's $21,000 so far.) Why? You'll see shortly. ($29,000.) Meanwhile, regardless of their personal loyalties, superstitious Wall Streeters all take delight in this year's point spread: As everyone knows, a win today by the heavily favored Green Bay Packers, the N.F.C. champions, would predict a rising Dow for the rest of the year, not to mention six more weeks of winter. 

ASIAN TURMOIL
Getting On With It
The Continent That Ate Your Newspaper may soon be relaxing its stranglehold on the headlines. Though it pains their governments visibly, Indonesia and South Korea are beginning to fall into line with the I.M.F.'s recovery prescriptions. In Jakarta, a bunch of teetering banks are to merge into one institution that might just survive; in Seoul, the biggest of the chaebol conglomerates announced (somewhat sketchy) plans to pare down their higgledy-piggledy empires. The Japanese Government's efforts at crisis management have persuaded investors to bid Tokyo stock prices up sharply from the depths of two weeks ago. No such luck in Indonesia, though, where investors don't like President Suharto's choice of a running mate (and possible successor) or the corporate sector's chances of coping with immense debts; stocks and the currency both plunged.
 
DEALS
Fever Unabated
Last year, the total value of mergers and acquisitions involving American companies topped $1 trillion for the first time, and 1998 looks to be continuing the trend. Two drug giants, American Home Products and SmithKline Beecham, are talking about what would be the biggest merger ever, though they have not yet struck a deal; product liability problems with two American Home diet drugs are one obstacle. A couple of takeover firms -- Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts -- agreed to combine the movie-theater chains they already own with another, Regal Cinemas, that they will buy, forming the nation's largest chain. Ciba Specialty Chemicals won a weeklong bidding war with Hercules to take over Allied Colloids, a British specialty chemical maker, for $2.3 billion.
 
MICROSOFT
Busy, Busy, Busy
What didn't Microsoft do last week? On successive days, the company announced (along with its consortium partners, Intel, Compaq and the Baby Bells) a new standard for ultra-high-speed Internet connections over ordinary phone wires. (Article, page 4.) Then it reported strong quarterly earnings, hinted at sweeping layoffs in one of its struggling on-line content businesses and settled a contempt-of-court complaint with the Government over the intertwining of its Windows 95 operating system and Internet browser software. Microsoft agreed to comply with a Dec. 11 court order by allowing computer makers to ship machines with Windows 95 intact but without a visible way of using Microsoft's browser, while the Government's antitrust action and Microsoft's appeal of the court order move forward. The stock rose $4 on the week, enough to make Bill Gates $1.08 billion richer.
 
JETLINERS
Braced for Turbulence
America's other Washington State-based near-monopoly is in a rough patch caused by its own success. Boeing said it expected to report its first annual loss since 1947 next week, courtesy of $4 billion in charges. Absorbing its last domestic rival, McDonnell Douglas, will cost Boeing a bigger-than-expected $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter, on top of $2.6 billion in previously announced charges born of nasty production snags that developed when Boeing's order book got fatter than its factories could handle. Softening the blows of recent cancellations from Asian carriers was a new $2.5 billion plane order from thriving Southwest Airlines. (If you've lost count, that brings the shoe box to $630,000 so far.)
 
OIL
A Refiner's Market
North America is awash in cheap crude. The Energy Department reported surprising jumps in crude oil and refined product stocks, sending already slumping spot and forward markets to new four-year depths below $16 a barrel. Low crude prices have proved more boon than bane for a few of the big integrated oil companies: Exxon, Chevron and Texaco rode fat refining margins to big profit increases in the fourth quarter, and Amerada Hess trimmed its loss. But the price trend cut the other way for Amoco and for oil-service companies like Schlum-berger and Diamond Offshore, whose fortunes depend on crude prices high enough to make drilling new wells economical. Article, page 5.
 
HIGH FINANCE
Typhoon Season
Foul financial weather in Asia did not soak all American financial institutions equally in the fourth quarter. J. P. Morgan, which depends much more than the other money-center banks on trading and derivatives business, saw profits fall by more than a third and set aside $587 million to cover potential losses on currency swaps. Good results at home kept Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and BankAmerica in the growth column over all, but each said it took a battering abroad. In contrast, the big brokerage houses bobbed along nicely in the fourth quarter in spite of the market turmoil, with Merrill Lynch; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Paine Webber all reporting solid profit growth. And Republic New York made big money in foreign exchange and commodity trading in the quarter.
 
ECONOMY
Funny Bounce
The statistic hawks in Washington and on Wall Street, straining their eyes looking for signs that Asian turmoil is affecting the American economy, were blinking in disbelief when the Commerce Department reported last week that the United States trade deficit shrank in November. All hands continue to expect the deficit to balloon one of these months on cheap Asian imports and soft demand in Asia for Yankee exports. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" report on regional economic conditions found the beginnings of an Asian slowdown effect across the country.
 
BIG GAME, PART 2
Ad Infinitum
Back to our experiment. By the end of this sentence you should be up to 1,047 thousand-dollar bills spilling out of the shoe box and mingling with the pretzel crumbs and cat hair on the family-room carpet -- but it's still not enough to buy a single 30-second commercial during today's Super Bowl. Advertisers are paying an average of $1.3 million a pop to reach what is usually the biggest, and always the malest, mass television audience of the year, pitching beer, cars, gadgets, beer, movies, snacks, beer, chili, hot sauce and beer. Joining the perennial Bud Bowl will be a multiple-ad stunt from Intel encouraging viewers to log on to the company's Web site during the game to "vote" for one of two suspects in a make-believe mystery involving its mylar-suited "Bunny People." Safest Super Bowl bet: Next year, ad time will cost even more.

HEADLINE: Looking Back (Again) on '97;
Foes of Brooklyn Junction Are Repeating Earlier Error

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The opponents of Brooklyn Junction -- people like Marie Cantoni, Carmel Lopez and Peter Morisi -- are the same people who thought the sky was falling when Pathmark was being built ("The Biggest Little Stories of 1997: The Showdown at Brooklyn Junction," Dec. 28). Pathmark is here, and the world didn't come to an end. But it did bring a better day for those elderly who found reasonably priced quality goods within walking distance. It opened up jobs for many others who formerly spent their day at the unemployment office. 
 The proposed site for the Brooklyn Junction shopping center is now a deep, weedy canyon where the thundering metal of a railroad echoes on the streets above. The people above are in fact separated from neighbors much like the Berlin Wall in years past. By building this shopping center over the railroad we will unify the community physically as well as strengthen our economic tax base.
 
ISRAEL BERKOWITZ
Borough Park, Brooklyn

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thank you for the article "Trouble in the House" (Jan. 4), about the Palestinian-American woman and the difficulty she is experiencing with her American-born and -raised children. 
 Her struggles echo my parents' struggle when we came here from Egypt in 1970, Christian Egyptians who left to evade religious persecution and pursue a better economic life in the United States; I am one of four daughters and two sons, ranging in age from 18 to 6 years old when we arrived. (I was the youngest daughter, age 7.)
The most delightful thing about the article is the absence of Israeli issues -- that is while the woman was born and raised in Palestine/Israel, her reality was one of academic excellence and being a "good daughter." There is no mention of the Arab-Israeli conflict. The only slight reference is the pendant in the shape of Palestine that she wears along with the Koranic verse against the evil eye.
This article will humanize Arabs and show that we are not all busy concocting bombs and terrorist plots against "the Americans." We are Americans and we have chosen to make our lives here.
 
MARY HANNA FARAG
Grymes Hill, Staten Island

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXXII: THE FANS;
A Slice of Life: Cheeseheads Are More Than Cute

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
It is a piece of foam weighing three quarters of a pound, but don't think for a Super Bowl second that the Cheesehead is just something silly to wear.
The Packers fans beneath those yellow wedge-shaped emblems have become the very embodiment of the team itself. Green Bay's players relate to the Cheeseheads, not the other way around. 
 "I don't play for the Cheeseheads," said Packers safety Eugene Robinson. "I feel like we all play the game together. I run into those people in the grocery store during the week and it's like running into somebody else on the team. Those people are with us. They're up when we're up, down when we're down, nervous about a game when we're nervous about a game. I'm proud of those people.
"A big part of playing for the Packers is accepting the Cheeseheads and being accepted by them."
Said Packers Coach Mike Holmgren: "Other areas are maybe too big or too diverse to have a situation and a fan base like ours. The team is the bond of the community, and somehow, as players and coaches for the Packers, you come to feel a part of that community and feel a responsibility to it.
"Our players feel our fans' loyalty, and it makes them loyal to the fans."
Like the Cheeseheads, the Packers like to think of themselves as throwbacks, as homespun, as a team true to its roots.
"In a small town, people care about each other -- they have to or the town doesn't survive," said Packers quarterback Brett Favre, who grew up in Kiln, Miss. "And that's the way it is in Green Bay: a small city where people care about each other. We live there, and you know, we become a team like them, watching out for each other.
"We've got a team that doesn't really operate on a star system. I get a lot of the attention because I'm the quarterback, but what makes us win? We pick each other up. Our starting running back, Edgar Bennett, gets hurt in the preseason and Dorsey Levens steps in and has a great year.
"That's the kind of team we are."
The Packers see themselves as a dedicated bunch of hard-working traditionalists, which may just be a byproduct of living and working in Wisconsin. It is a state that aggressively took on welfare reform even though the state unemployment rate is just 3.4 percent.
The Cheeseheads like to cast themselves as simple, unsophisticated folk, but Wisconsin's state university system is considered among the best in the nation. The median household income in Green Bay is $31,437, significantly higher than the median household income in Denver, which is $27,453.
The Packers are publicly owned, though not run and operated by as many small investors as team mythology would have you believe. The Packers are big business now. Last year, they passed the Dallas Cowboys as the top seller of official team merchandise in the National Football League. The Cowboys had held that spot since 1992, but it hardly seems fair to call Dallas America's Team anymore.
As portrayed in a television commercial, the departure from the community of Packers season-ticket holders is big news. But it does not cause fans to queue up outside the ultimate Packers shrine, Lambeau Field, because the Packers' season-ticket waiting list is about 40,000 names long. The team estimates that on average five to seven season tickets become available each off season.
Do the math: at that rate, some people will not be getting their season tickets until the year 8000.
But if Packers fans cannot get tickets, they can pick up a Cheesehead for about $15 almost anywhere in the state. Formation, Inc., the Wisconsin company that makes these ungainly signs of Packers fans' devotion, has a staff of 25 producing the head coverings year-round.
"Sure I have one," Favre said of the Cheeseheads. "I must have 20 of them."
Said Eugene Robinson, "Of course I have one."
Added tight end Mark Chmura: "We all have one. We are one."

HEADLINE: The State of the Presidency

 BODY:
This normally festive and frivolous Super Bowl Sunday is a somber time for America. This newspaper reported yesterday that Monica Lewinsky has offered in immunity bargaining to testify that she had sex with the President. By other accounts, physical evidence of intimate contact may exist. When the Cabinet and top White House aides try to defend Mr. Clinton, they speak of what they hope and believe, not what they know. Those hopes have been strengthened by lawyers' assertions that Ms. Lewinsky is so far refusing to testify that Mr. Clinton and his friend Vernon Jordan urged her to lie. The White House has also hinted that Mr. Clinton may eventually produce a mitigating explanation for any contact he may have had with Ms. Lewinsky.
For all that, it is, at best, a mess. Moreover the mess goes beyond Mr. Clinton's habitual failure to manage his personal life so as to produce admiration rather than dismay. Two days from now, the holder of the world's most important elective office will step into the House chamber to deliver the State of the Union address. Traditionally, this is the moment when Presidents summon the nation to new goals. But in the second year of this term, the nation's immediate concern must be the state of the Presidency. 
 The optimistic citizen can pray for Mr. Clinton to break free of the entangling advice of his lawyers and embrace the central Presidential task of shaping the nation's political climate. If the allegations of low and possibly illegal behavior prove to be unsupported by solid evidence, comparisons with Watergate will quickly dissipate. But in these initial days of turmoil in Washington, there is a need to understand the difficulties and dangers of crisis-bound governance. The great danger is that domestic policy can be paralyzed or, more dangerously, crucial foreign policy actions distorted by a President's need to show control or by the anxieties of allies or adversaries.
At this moment, for example, the era of budget deficits is giving way to a new debate about how to distribute surplus revenues. The Republicans will be pushing a variety of tax cuts, many regressive and unsound. Without a powerful stand from a Democratic White House, it is hard to imagine another agenda gaining ground that would stress investment in education and infrastructure. Almost by reflex, Americans worry that embattled Presidents may be tempted into foreign adventures. There is also a danger that reckless nations will test American resolve, convinced that Mr. Clinton is weakened and distracted.
Despite the turbulence in Washington last week, Mr. Clinton managed to nudge the Middle East peace effort forward. But if Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, come to doubt Mr. Clinton's political endurance, they are unlikely to close a deal that depends on American brokering.
Iraq, of course, is the most urgent issue, and the one that could be most easily misplayed. Saddam Hussein has now rebuffed a United Nations Security Council demand for unfettered inspection of sites that may contain chemical or biological weapons. He demands a freeze on inspections, followed in the spring by the lifting of economic sanctions.
That position is unacceptable and should be rejected by the Security Council. If defiance then continues, deciding on an American response is an exercise that must be insulated from the pressures now bearing down on Mr. Clinton. That requires Mr. Clinton to calm this political hurricane by explaining his assertions that nothing happened in regard to a sexual liaison or subornation of perjury.
The American system of government is a wonder of carefully balanced, complementary parts, but there is no substitute for the stabilizing weight of effective Presidential leadership. Without it, Washington wobbles and international relations become tentative. A worried nation is waiting to see what steps President Clinton takes toward a steadier balance.

HEADLINE: A West African Border With Back-to-Back Wars

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BO WATERSIDE, Liberia

 BODY:
Just visible at the far side of the bridge that links this Liberian town with Sierra Leone, the region's newest militia can be seen patrolling recently conquered territory.
The Nigerian soldiers who guard this sleepy border town are ostensibly peacekeepers in a regional effort to end years of fighting in Liberia. But under cover of nightfall they have reportedly undertaken another mission, arming and training the fighters across the bridge for what is shaping up as this devastated corner of Africa's latest civil war. 
 The militia members, traditional hunters of the Mende ethnic group known as the Kamajors, say they are fighting to restore Sierra Leone's only democratically elected President, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, who was overthrown in a military coup in May and who monitors events in his country from exile in nearby Guinea.
Since the coup that forced Mr. Kabbah from Sierra Leone, Nigeria has tried one thing after another to return him to power: a naval blockade; aerial bombardments of military bases, and enforcement of an international isolation so complete that not even foreign mail arrives in the country anymore.
But the military leaders in Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, shrugged off even pressures like these. So, diplomats say, Nigeria seems to have decided the only course is to back ethnic allies of the deposed President in a military campaign.
In less than 10 years, wave after wave of just this type of militia warfare has taken Liberia and Sierra Leone from the relative comfort of concrete houses and electricity back to straw huts and storm lanterns.
In both countries' capitals, even the downtown streets go unlit at night, so badly have basic utilities like power grids been damaged by the years of war. And through the countryside, the roads that remain passable cut through an endless succession of abandoned, bullet-strafed villages.
The instability that has made this one of Africa's most strife-ridden regions is fed by a complex shadow play of intrigue. Foreign diplomats, Sierra Leoneans and Liberians say that countries both near and far are competing for influence here, and for a rich slice of the region's readily exploitable natural resources.
Over the years, the jumble of players here has included Western powers like the United States and France, as well as Libya, Taiwan, South Africa, ragtag national armies and a multitude of warring militias.
But at the center of the action, almost from the start, has stood the region's one true power, Nigeria. Depending upon who is speaking, that nation is viewed as either the only serious force for stability or a mischievous and determined plunderer of weaker states.
For many experts, the key to the recent history of Sierra Leone and Liberia lies in Nigeria's push to extend its political and economic influence along the West African coast. At virtually every step of the way, these analysts say, France has maneuvered to keep the Nigerian giant in check. The French motivation: eagerness to retain a hold on heavily dependent former colonies.
"It is a West African version of the Great Game," said one African diplomat, referring to the secret 19th century British-Russian struggle for mastery of Central Asia. "They have almost never gone at it directly," added the diplomat, who has spent his career watching Nigeria and France compete for influence in the region. "So it goes unnoticed most of the time. But both countries see the stakes as very high."
International rivalries have existed in the area since colonial times. But they accelerated sharply in 1989, when Ivory Coast and Burkina Faso, reportedly with French encouragement, helped Charles G. Taylor launch an invasion of Liberia to topple the United States-backed Government of Samuel K. Doe.
With the United States evacuating its citizens from Liberia because of the intensifying violence, Nigeria, whose military Government had strong business ties with Mr. Doe, rallied several other West African nations behind a regional military intervention. The action relied heavily at first on Nigerian jets and gunboats to stop Mr. Taylor's advance.
Mr. Taylor, furious to see his offensive foiled, then began arming a guerrilla movement, the Revolutionary United Front, to punish Sierra Leone for joining the Nigerian drive against him.
Sierra Leone's Government initially relied on Nigerian help for its defense, ceding control of several diamond-rich mining zones to the Nigerians in return. But the rebels steadily gained ground, so Sierra Leone turned to South African mercenaries for help. This left Nigeria doing little more than guarding the airport in Freetown.
For years the situation festered, with the Liberian stalemate producing some of the bloodiest warfare in Africa and the Revolutionary United Front waging a campaign of terror in Sierra Leone.
Nigeria and Mr. Taylor appeared to reach a tenuous reconciliation shortly after his third disastrous attempt to storm the Liberian capital, Monrovia, in April 1996. They continued to work well enough together for Liberia to pull off surprisingly free national elections last July, which Mr. Taylor won in a landslide.
But Mr. Taylor wasted little time in seeking the departure of the Nigerian-led peacekeepers who had frustrated his war efforts. He has also been criticizing Nigerian-led efforts -- a combination of sanctions and force -- to bring down the Sierra Leonean junta.
"It was never clear how the marriage between Nigeria and Taylor could continue to work," said one international relief official who has spent most of the decade in Liberia. "Nigeria clearly wants to dominate this region, starting with Liberia. And Taylor wants as much power for himself in this region as he can get."
Diplomats in Liberia say Mr. Taylor may be betting that by opposing Nigeria's efforts to restore the elected Government in Sierra Leone he can extend his influence there. The Sierra Leonean military junta has now joined forces with the Revolutionary United Front's rebellion, the one that Mr. Taylor once helped arm.
"A lot of people think that Taylor is in league with the Revolutionary United Front, and perhaps in bed with Libya," a Western diplomat said. "What appears clear is that he is rocking the boat already and wants to make any Sierra Leone peace deal fall through and keep the R.U.F. in power."
The payoff is potentially great for Mr. Taylor, who continues to enjoy the diplomatic support of France's closest allies in the region. But many say the price of failure could be equally high for Liberia, which is just emerging from its prolonged war.
When Nigerian troops begin leaving Liberia in the thousands, as expected next month, it will be left without a properly trained national army. Mr. Taylor's enemies -- or for that matter Nigeria, in its struggle to consolidate a foothold in Sierra Leone -- could easily use neighboring territory to attack Liberia.
"One doesn't see any easy way out of this cycle of building up external alliances and using them to undermine your neighbor," a West African diplomat said. "Perhaps when all of your fingers have been burned you learn to stop playing with fire."

LENGTH: 1167 words

HEADLINE: A South Korean's Rise to Free Market Evangelist

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
It was a long journey for You Jong Keun from the dirt-floor hut where he grew up in a Korean mountain village to his office as an economics professor at Rutgers University.
But Mr. You's return voyage, since he gave up his American citizenship and went back to South Korea in 1994, has perhaps spanned an even greater distance. He has gone from teaching in a classroom to trying to rescue the South Korean economy. 
 Mr. You, 53, is chief economic adviser to Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's President-elect, and his presence in Mr. Kim's inner circle has been enormously reassuring to foreign bankers and Western officials. A fervent evangelist for free markets and foreign investment, Mr. You insists that South Korea must open itself up to the world not just because the International Monetary Fund says so, but because that is the only way for the nation to thrive.
"Toward the end of the 19th century, our ancestors tried to isolate ourselves, and the consequences were ruinous," he said, referring to Korea's refusal to open up, enabling a modernizing Japan to force itself on Korea and colonize it.
When Mr. Kim was elected in December, the stock market plunged on concern that he was a populist who would pander to labor unions. Some experts worried that Mr. Kim would tackle South Korea's economic crisis with first-rate loyalists and third-rate economists.
But Mr. Kim has in fact surrounded himself with a core of advisers who, like Mr. You, are widely respected and in many cases trained in America. Since the election, following the advice of Mr. You and the others, Mr. Kim has repeatedly emphasized the need for mass layoffs and other painful steps, and the stock market is rising again.
"I think people should rest assured that Kim Dae Jung is totally committed to a free market economy," Mr. You said. During the campaign, Mr. Kim got some "bad advice," Mr. You said, and Mr. You is credited with helping to persuade Mr. Kim to make tough pronouncements about the need for far-reaching restructuring.
Mr. You's own credentials as a fan of markets are clear, for he is also the elected Governor of North Cholla Province, one of the poorest and most backward regions of the country. If his efforts there are any indication of how South Korea may develop in the coming years, the nation is in for a tumultuous shake-up and an ardent welcome to foreign investment.
"At the time of his inauguration, everyone thought that he had almost no chance of fulfilling his dream of getting foreign investment," said Cho Sang Jin, a newspaper editor in North Cholla. "But now, because of his wide contacts through his years in the U.S.A., he is accomplishing a lot of his objectives."
North Cholla's exports are increasing faster by far than those of any other province in the country, and foreign tourism has tripled since Mr. You took office. One of those foreign visitors was Michael Jackson, the singer, whom Mr. You is wooing to invest in a resort and entertainment park in North Cholla.
In 25 years in the United States, Mr. You picked up not just contacts, but also a direct style that has antagonized some Koreans. And leftists criticize him as a traitor for his calls for layoffs and foreign investment.
Koh Sung Jae, president of the student council at Chonbuk University in North Cholla, accused Mr. You of giving away too many concessions to lure foreign investors.
"We don't approve of restructuring Korean businesses to the point where we have to cut out our livers and hand them over to foreign businesses," Mr. Koh said.
Mr. You's policies are striking because South Korea remains wary of foreign investment. A poll last year indicated that only 4 percent of Koreans thought that foreigners should definitely be allowed to own small shops or restaurants, and even fewer approved of allowing foreigners to own land or large factories.
"Two of the messages I have been trying to tell people are that layoffs are essential and that there is no nationality of capital," said Mr. You, who acknowledged that he still sees himself as an educator, just with a larger classroom. "When I took office as Governor, I tried my best to make myself available for special lectures, telling people that we have to open up our markets, we have to open up to foreign investment."
Mr. You's odyssey began in a tiny mountain village where his father farmed in North Cholla. The village, of thatched-roof shacks with dirt floors, has since been abandoned because it is far from any road.
His father, who attended school up to the sixth grade, had the passionate belief in education that is common in South Korea, and he saw to it that Mr. You worked hard in school and eventually made it to university in Seoul. From there Mr. You went off to the State University of New York in Binghamton in 1970, to earn his doctorate in economics.
Mr. You taught at Rutgers and worked for a decade as an economist in the New Jersey Governor's office, writing a book about the regional economy. He married and raised a family and might have stayed in America if he had not gotten a phone call from his mother in 1978. She told him that his younger brother, a democracy campaigner, had been arrested by the dictatorship.
That led Mr. You to become active in the Korean democracy movement, and he became still more involved when Mr. Kim -- who is from South Cholla -- was sentenced to death by the Korean Government in 1980. In what turned out to be an excellent career move, Mr. You formed a "Save Kim Dae Jung" campaign in New Jersey.
Ultimately, Mr. Kim was spared and exiled to America in 1982, and the two men met and became close. After democracy returned to South Korea beginning in 1987, Mr. You became increasingly restless to return.
He made longer and longer visits to his homeland, and by his own account he neglected his family. His American wife was horrified by the idea of moving to Korea, and they divorced in 1992.
"I was not a very good husband -- not a very good father," Mr. You recalled. "I feel very badly about that."
Remarried to a Korean woman, Mr. You renounced his American citizenship and returned to South Korea in 1994. A year later, he ran for Governor of North Cholla.
In the end, helped by his relationship with Mr. Kim, Mr. You won by a whisker. To bring in fresh blood, Mr. You put help-wanted ads in Korean-language newspapers in the United States and recruited young scholars with fresh American Ph.D's.
Mr. You and his team have begun a dazzling series of economic projects in the province, often locking horns with the central Government in Seoul -- which responded last year by starting a corruption investigation into Mr. You's affairs. But there was never any evidence of wrongdoing, and Mr. You has become so popular in North Cholla that there were howls of protest that forced Seoul to back off.
"Governor You is a unique person," said Song Yong Nam, an economics professor in North Cholla. "He is full of ideas that no one else had thought of."

Map of South Korea showing the location of North Cholla Province: A son of North Cholla Province has revived its economy.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Westphal, Coach Out of Style

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
When Paul Westphal was interviewed for the Dallas Mavericks' head coaching job two seasons ago, he made sure he told the new owner, Ross Perot Jr., about a skeleton in his closet. He said he was friends with Rush Limbaugh, the political commentator who goes harder to his right than Michael Jordan and often had fun at Ross Perot Sr.'s expense.
"Rush called his dad a hand grenade with a bad haircut," Westphal said, laughing. "He thought it was funny. I started to wonder if my friendship has hurt me, but that's ridiculous. I'm no political activist. Really, I don't know what the rap on me is." 
 In the emerging era of the National Basketball Association disciplinarian, the greatest rap on the 47-year-old Westphal may be simply that he treats his players like people. For reasons far beyond his politics, Westphal did not get the Dallas job. He has been in the running for other jobs, but he has yet to reappear in the league more than two years after he was relieved of his coaching duties with the Phoenix Suns.
As impressionable owners keep getting wooed by high-strung coaches who promise to turn their franchises around in less than two seasons, some of the best offensive minds in the business -- not to mention some of the best people in the business -- continue to wait for a phone call.
Westphal, K. C. Jones, who is coaching an American Basketball League team. Rick Adelman, fired last season by the Golden State Warriors and replaced by P. J. Carlesimo.
"A lot of jobs, I didn't want to get my brains beat out," Westphal said, adding that he has not been interested in every opening. "They were pretty much doomed not to be good jobs for a long time. I wanted to be in a position where I at least have a chance. My feeling is, if you're asked to build, you better be able to hang around and see the end of the construction."
Employing a wide-open scheme that relied on spacing and ball movement, Westphal led the Suns to a 62-20 record in the 1992-93 season, which culminated with a six-game loss to the Chicago Bulls in the finals. The next two seasons Phoenix went 56-26 and 59-23. The Suns, who endured 26 lineup changes and had players miss a combined 296 games to injury or illness the following season, were 14-19 when Westphal was replaced by Cotton Fitzsimmons in January 1996. His record: 191-88, a .685 winning percentage.
"Whatever it is, maybe somebody will look at the numbers and see we lost to the champions and two seven-game series to Houston the next two seasons," Westphal said. "Maybe somebody will look at the record, and say, 'He didn't mess them up too bad.' "
Like most unemployed coaches, Westphal has had time to spend with his family. He coached his son's high school team last year in Phoenix and has been able to travel abroad and visit old friends. Like a lot of unemployed coaches, he would also like to return to the N.B.A.
"Maybe we're just caught in a cycle where everyone wants that one consistent voice that has authority," he said. "I think Larry Bird is proving you can be reasonable and successful. You don't have to be some out-of-control, angry guy. But those kind of things go in cycles."
Westphal recalls the night in 1996 that he and Don Nelson, then the Knicks' coach, had dinner with Limbaugh in New York. Less than two months later, both he and Nelson lost their jobs. Nelson eventually wound up as the general manager in Dallas, with the blessing of Ross Perot Jr., and replaced Jim Cleamons as coach this season.
Said Westphal, "I told Rush he ought to invite some more of these visiting coaches in and open up some jobs in the N.B.A."
 
A Finely Focused Defense
 P. J. Carlesimo's coaching tactics may eventually come under scrutiny, but it appears the N.B.A. Players Association plans to take the high road in its defense of Latrell Sprewell this week in Portland, Ore. At issue are Sprewell's one-year suspension by the league and the termination of his contract by the Warriors.
Rather than trot out a plethora of Carlesimo's former and current players at the hearing solely to attack the coach's methods, the defense may focus on issues of due process and constitutionality under the collective bargaining agreement between the players and owners.
Johnnie Cochran sat at the same table as Sprewell during his December news conference after he was suspended by the league and his contract was terminated for choking and punching Carlesimo in a practice. But the prominent defense attorney will not be a part of Sprewell's defense team when the hearing begins on Tuesday.
The Players Association and the league are expected to hold a three-way conference call over the weekend with John D. Feerick, the Dean of Fordham University School of Law who will serve as the arbitrator. In keeping with most arbitration procedures, Feerick is expected to close the hearing to all news media.
 
Losing and Losing and . . .
 On their way to N.B.A. infamy, the Denver Nuggets had a chance to tie the longest losing streak in league history -- 24 games -- against the Los Angeles Clippers last night at the L.A. Sports Arena.
Whether the Nuggets break that record may be immaterial. As it stands, they have a better chance to finish with the league's worst record ever -- the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers finished 9-73 -- than any team over the last 25 years.
 
Shimmying and Head-Shaking
 Larry Bird might have been one of the league's more intimidating trash talkers during his heyday, often whispering to his defender how and when he would score on him. But as a coach, he has a hard time understanding why Mark Jackson has to shimmy and shake his body for all the world to see after a big play. And why Reggie Miller must talk to the opposing bench and point fingers.
Realizing his stars need to express themselves, however, Bird is coping.
"He says he loves that as much as anybody, he can appreciate it, that he has a little kid in him that wants to do the dance also," Jackson said. "But at the same time, it's going to spark somebody, it's going to get people angry and give them a reason to want to come at us even harder the next time we face him.
"We understand his point. But that's part of me and Reggie. And if you take that away, I don't know if I'm the same player and I know that we're not the same team."
Bird said: "I don't like it, but I really do feel it can wake teams up. I just wish they'd wait till the game was over to celebrate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Westphal has not coached an N.B.A. team since the middle of the 1995-96 season. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. LISTS OPTIONS ON USE OF FORCE IN IRAQ STANDOFF

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers met today to weigh military and political strategies against Iraq, among them a sustained attack on suspected biological and chemical weapons sites that Saddam Hussein has hidden from United Nations inspectors, White House officials said.
"There'll be one final round of diplomacy, and then an ultimatum, and then we act," a National Security Council official said. 
 White House officials said a countdown to a military strike could begin as soon as Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting, ends on Friday. A senior Administration official said of the prospect of military action, "We're focused more on weeks than months or days."
Members of Mr. Clinton's national security team briefed the President later today on their discussion.
The participants in the meeting included Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright; Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen; the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; the Director of Central Intelligence, George Tenet, and the chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson. They left the White House without deciding on their ultimate course, an Administration spokesman said.
The White House meeting came as a consensus emerged in the President's national security staff that Iraq would never comply with the United Nations inspectors, and that smart bombs and cruise missiles may be needed to destroy President Hussein's hidden potential to build crude weapons of mass destruction.
With the White House enveloped in a miasma of sexual and legal scandals, Administration officials said they were painfully aware that they might be accused of using an attack on Iraq as a diversion to sustain political and popular support for an embattled President. But they took pains to point out that the military plans they are weighing were drawn up two months ago, in November, during the last standoff with Iraq over the United Nations inspections.
The Administration plans to devote next week to convincing skeptical American allies and members of Congress that military action is the only way to stop Iraq from building a biological and chemical arsenal.
"We have never put the question directly: 'We're going in. Are you with us or not?' " the National Security Council official said.
So far, only Britain is clearly supporting a hard line. Seven years after it came together to drive the Iraqi Army out of Kuwait, the international coalition that fought the Persian Gulf war under the United Nations banner has splintered.
Two United States battle groups in the gulf -- including warships, fighter jets, hundreds of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs -- will soon be joined by a British battle group. Together they will form the largest military deployment in the region since the gulf war.
But no other allies are likely to join. Washington is in a poor position to rebuild the worldwide coalition that it assembled to fight Iraq in 1991. The United States has been politically weakened at the United Nations by its failure to pay its dues, and Russia, France, China and some Arab allies are unlikely to openly support a military attack on Iraq.
Nonetheless, the momentum propelling the United States toward bombing Iraq appears inexorable.
Iraq continues to defy the United Nations inspectors who are charged with identifying and helping to eliminate Baghdad's ability to build nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. A senior United Nations official, Richard Spertzel, said on Friday that there was "tantalizing information" that Iraq is operating a secret biological weapons plant despite United Nations inspections and in defiance of an international ban.
The chief of the inspection team, Richard Butler, told the Security Council on Friday that Iraq was continuing to mislead the inspectors.
Diplomacy, jawboning and continuing economic sanctions have not moved President Hussein.
Mr. Clinton warned on Wednesday that diplomacy might be approaching a dead end. "Something is going to have to give here," he said. Administration officials strongly suggested that after going an extra mile down this diplomatic route in the coming week, military action might lie at the end of the road.
The military plans drawn up in November were originally aimed at compelling Baghdad to comply with United Nations' attempts to rid Iraq of its ability to build weapons of mass destruction. But diplomacy and threats have failed to persuade President Hussein to cooperate.
Now a crucial question for the United States is whether Washington can or should destroy his suspected weapons plants with bombs and missiles -- and whether force will change his behavior, a strategy that has not worked well in the past.
The commander of United States forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. Anthony Zinni of the Marines, said two months ago that if called to battle, he would attack "the things that mean most to Saddam."
The general defined those targets as the forces that "enable him to inflict the kind of pain he does on his own people and on others in the region." He said those forces include the "Republican Guard units that keep him in power, his own infrastructure and command and control systems," and his ability to build and use biological and chemical weapons. That ability is thought to be concealed in dozens of sites, including presidential palaces.
"The intent is to deny him the capability to continue to threaten his neighbors and his own people and to threaten the world with his capability," General Zinni said.
Three new teams of United Nations technical experts are scheduled to begin a series of meetings in Baghdad on Feb. 1 to weigh Iraq's compliance on missile warhead, germ warfare and chemical weapons issues. The meetings are expected to continue throughout February; it is unclear whether the United States can attack while the teams meet in the Iraqi capital.
A United States attack on Iraq, Administration officials said, will create more questions: whether to forbid Iraq from flying any planes within its borders and whether to force Iraq to open the suspected weapons sites -- assuming such sites are still standing after what may become the biggest bombing campaign against Iraq since the war.

HEADLINE: When the Credit Bubble Bursts

BYLINE: By BILL KENT

 BODY:
FOR eight Federal court judges, 150 staff members and 700 bankruptcy lawyers, February used to be the calm before the storm of New Jersey bankruptcy filings.
"We had grown accustomed to a little breathing space during the winter," said William Gindin, chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Trenton. 
 That's no longer the way it is. Around New Jersey, asaround the country, more people are going broke, and they are doing it year round, not just in March, April and May, traditionally the busiest time for bankruptcy activity. About four years ago, Judge Gindin noticed a change in the number of cases on his docket. "They started to pick up," he said. "And up. And up. There are no more seasonal lulls. There are no more breathing spaces. It's become rather frightening."
What's to blame? Various fingers have been pointed at too easily available credit, legal loopholes, profligate spending, corporate downsizing, expensive divorces, inadequate insurance coverage, New Jersey's gambling industry and a desire to avoid responsibility.
In any case, bankruptcy, while it may run counter to old-fashioned middle-class values, remains a cherished, constitutionally protected right. America's Founding Fathers, in an effort to do away with the debtors' prisons that doomed so many British citizens, provided protection for debtors in the form of Federal bankruptcy laws. The laws were designed to guard the debtor's liberty and a few essential assets, as well as to provide a manner in which debts could be scheduled for repayment, reduction or elimination.
By all available evidence, debtors are not shy about seeking the laws' protection. New Jersey's bankruptcy courts are averaging 800 filings each week, with a total of 50,000 anticipated in 1998. Of the 1.4 million bankruptcies in the United States last year (an increase of 23 percent from 1996), 42,672 were filed in New Jersey. The state currently ranks 20th in the nation for bankruptcies. (Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama and Nevada rank No. 1, 2, 3 and 4.)
"It's become a growth industry for lawyers, though not an especially lucrative one," said Judge Gindin, who sets the fees that New Jersey bankruptcy lawyers charge for their services. "The money is in the Chapter 11's, the business bankruptcies, which have decreased considerably since 1992. There isn't as much to be made in the consumer bankruptcies, the Chapter 7's and 13's, but the filings have increased to an alarming extent."
So alarming have these increases been that the banking industry is using them to urge the passage of two bills in Congress, HR-2500 in the House of Representatives, and S-1301 in the Senate, designed to make it more difficult for bankruptcy filers to eliminate debt.
"I think those bills, if passed, will turn the tide," said Kenneth Crone, an executive with VISA USA, America's largest credit card company. "The bank card industry lost $15 billion because of bankruptcies in 1997. The laws are flawed."
Mr. Crone attributed his industry's losses to a 1979 revision in the Federal bankruptcy law that permits bankrupt individuals and married couples to eliminate most, if not all, unsecured debt. That means they can write off money owed to credit card companies, gambling casinos, hospitals, retailers and contractors, as well as debts resulting from court judgments, while retaining as much as $30,000 in home equity, an automobile and retirement savings plans. Payments for secured loans, such as mortgages, home equity loans, automobile loans and, since 1994, student loans, can be revised to lower a debtor's monthly burden.
Judge Gindin disagrees. "My view has always been that bankruptcy is driven by the availability of credit. In the case of consumer bankruptcy, the relationship is direct. Expansions in the availability of credit are reflected 18 months after those bankruptcies."
Traditionally, those who filed for bankruptcy protection could not obtain credit for as long as 10 years from banks and other lending institutions. Not any more, said James Waldron, clerk of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Newark.
Beginning in 1993, at the end of the national recession when bankruptcies went down in the state by 5 percent, Mr. Waldron's office was increasingly pestered by finance companies for lists of recent bankruptcy filers -- not because they wanted to avoid them as potential customers but because they wanted to solicit their business.
"There are more of them calling now than we've ever had," Mr. Waldron said. "They want the names and addresses so they can hit these people up for new loans."
 
Where Problems Start
A report released last November by S.M.R. Corporation of Hackettstown linked an aspect the state's bankruptcy boom to its gambling industry. Atlantic County, where casinos thrive, had "a 1996 filing rate 18 percent higher than filings in counties with no gambling," the report said.
Nona Ostrove, an Atlantic City bankruptcy lawyer whose office is one block from the Sands Casino (which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy earlier this month), disputed this finding.
"I see some people come through that have gambling problems," Ms. Ostrove said, "but is it the main reason? No. The main reason is still credit cards, followed by a lost job, medical bills or a divorce."
Indeed, the numbers of bankruptcies filed in 1997 show Atlantic County, with 2,209, about average in the state. Neighboring Camden County, with its Garden State Race Track, had the most filings, at 4,021. Salem County, whose residents are closer to slot machine gambling at Delaware's Dover Downs Race Track than they are to Atlantic City's casinos, had 426 filings, the lowest in the state.
Still, the availability of gambling of any kind -- lotteries, simulcasting, casinos, even bingo, can be devastating for the growing number of people with compulsive disorders and problems with substance abuse.
"People who have had a history of drug or alcohol abuse have a tendency to become compulsive gamblers," said Roberta Crotts, an alcohol and drug counselor with the Raritan Bay Medical Center in Perth Amboy. "It can lead to bankruptcy because these people have great difficulty managing their money. It's not a matter of knowing when to quit -- they simply can't quit until it's too late."
Samuel J. Gerdano, executive director of the American Bankuptcy Institute, a Virginia-based national bankruptcy-industry tracking organization, said gambling is probably a factor contributing to the increase in bankruptcy. "But gambling hasn't shown up in the survey data," he said. "As a rule, gaming institutions don't show up as creditors."
Mr. Gerdano doesn't think the new bills before Congress "will make even a small dent in the number of filers, because the underlying cause is still an economic one. People declare bankruptcy because of debt. How they accumulated that debt is different for every situation, every household. Even though the bank card industry sent out 2.5 billion credit card solicitations in 1997, there are still cases in which credit card debt is not a factor. There is certainly some fraud going on; some people are exploiting the law to run away from their creditors. But a change of the law would not affect individual balance sheets. You could make bankruptcy less available to people, but it doesn't mean that creditors would be paid more. The fact is that the majority of people and businesses that file for bankruptcy are doing this as a last resort."
According to Robert Wood, a Manasquan lawyer who, as a bankruptcy trustee, supervises debt payment for Chapter 13 filers, paints this picture of those who file for bankruptcy:
"It's everybody and anybody. Most of them tend to be middle class, with at least one spouse employed, with a house with $100,000 in equity, a car loan or two, and a pile of bills they just can't pay. Some may be temporarily relieved that filing stops their creditors from harassing them, but they are well aware, by the time I see them as a trustee, that the process is designed to get the debts paid, to the penny, if possible. Bankruptcy is not a free ride. Nobody who is bankrupt is having any fun."
The major difficulty with the current Federal bankruptcy laws, Mr. Wood said, is that people need money to go bankrupt. "I don't see many of the poorer people because you need a few hundred dollars for the bankruptcy filing fees and they don't even have that," he said. "Even with more lawyers doing pro bono work in the bankruptcy field, the law doesn't reach many of those it's supposed to help."
Equally troubling, Mr. Wood said, is the fact that debtors who might otherwise be able to avoid bankruptcy fall prey to unscrupulous finance companies that consolidate debts into high-interest home equity loans that end up depleting what little savings the debtors have. Some debtors also become entangled with so-called bankruptcy mills that entice them to file for bankruptcy by making misleading claims about what the law provides.
 
An Alternative to Court
The burden of educating debtors about bankruptcy -- before they file -- has fallen on a handful of consumer credit counseling services operating within the state.
John Scott, a spokesman for the Maryland-based National Foundation for Consumer Credit, which represents the majority of the 1,400 nonprofit credit counseling services currently operating in the United States, estimated that two million Americans sought some kind of credit counseling in 1997. More than half of them managed to stay out of bankruptcy.
"Of course," Mr. Scott added, "We only hear about our successes. The failures don't come back."
Among the successes is Tracy Rosenthal of Neptune who in 1994 was referred to the consumer credit counseling division of Family and Children's Services of Oakhurst in 1994. Burdened with "enough debt to put a healthy down payment on a house" accumulated from the use of 10 credit cards, Ms. Rosenthal said she didn't want to declare bankruptcy "because I didn't think it was right. I didn't believe in it then and I don't now."
Ms. Rosenthal did consider bankruptcy, however, as an alternative to the calls and letters she was getting from credit card collection agencies. Under Federal law, collection agencies and other creditor representatives must cease such tactics once an individual or household files for bankruptcy protection.
"It got to the point where I just wanted some peace," she said. "One afternoon I got 15 calls in 15 minutes. They just keep at you and they threaten you with taking your house, your clothes, anything. If you get an answering machine, they just tie it up. I told them I wanted to pay my bills, but they would not let up, even after I sent them some money."
As soon as Ms. Rosenthal enrolled in a credit counseling program at Family and Children's Services, her credit counselor contacted her creditors and the harassment stopped. "The collection agencies would not believe me when I said I wanted to pay them what they were owed, but they believed the counselor," she said.
The reason that most, though not all, collection agencies give credence to credit counseling services is that the creditors support them. From 7 to 13 cents of every dollar of debt paid through a credit counseling service goes back to the service. Services also charge their clients monthly fees, ranging from $3 to $50, though these can be waived at the counselor's discretion.
"Creditors know that, with our clients, there is a higher likelihood that they'll get paid," said Carolyn Tarrant, one of four credit counselors employed at Family and Children's Services.
In addition to putting clients on a debt payment schedule, Ms. Tarrant enrolls clients in credit education classes.
"We don't tell them what to do, but we lay out the various choices available to them," she said. "With some creditors, we're successful in reducing the amount of interest our clients owe, so our clients can pay their debts faster."
Some counseling agencies, such as Consumer Credit Counseling Services of New Jersey in Cedar Knolls, can handle problems with secured loans, like mortgages, though most cannot. Nonprofit counseling services cannot halt legal proceedings against their clients, offer legal advice or offer their clients additional loans.
"We don't fix credit," said Sylvine Marabott, counseling director at Consumer Credit Counseling Services of New Jersey. "We give creditors a way to get paid and people a way to stay out of bankruptcy. We also educate our clients about credit and spending so they can understand where their problems came from and how they can stay out of debt in the future."
For Ms. Rosenthal, who expects to be debt free in June, credit counseling "was my salvation. Without these people, I probably would have had to go bankrupt."
She added that she only has one credit card now, "for emergencies." "Anything else," she said. "I pay cash."
Such services "seem to be helping people," said Chief Judge Gindin of the bankruptcy court in Trenton. "If they have, in fact, kept a million people out of bankruptcy, then they must be doing a terrific job. But with the number of filers going up every month, I'm still disturbed, as a judge and a human being, that no one has, to my knowledge, taken a really close, comprehensive look at the social problems that are driving bankruptcy. Until that happens, I'm afraid, the situation will only get worse."
 
Bankruptcy Law: A Debtor's Options
 There are a lot of ways to go bankrupt. Here is how cases fit into the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
 
 CHAPTER 7 -- A debtor's non-exempt assets, if any, are liquidated and proceeds are distributed to creditors. Individual debtors may receive a discharge of their debts. A majority of Chapter 7 cases are "no asset" cases in which there are no assets available for liquidation.
 
CHAPTER 11 -- A business or individual debtor petitions for reorganization. The debtor generally is permitted to continue its operations under court supervision until an initial plan of reorganization is approved by the court. If a plan is not approved, the case is either converted to a Chapter 7 or dismissed.
 
CHAPTER 12 -- Special debt repayment relief is provided for a family farmer whose annual income is sufficiently stable and regular to enable the farmer to make payments to creditors under an approved plan.
 
CHAPTER 13 -- An individual debtor with regular income proposes a plan to pay all or part of his debts over a period of time.
