HEADLINE: Health Gap Grows, With Black Americans Trailing Whites, Studies Say

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
A robust economy and years of Government pressure have helped move minority groups closer to the mainstream. But when it comes to health, studies show a stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity between black and white Americans.
For decades, blacks have suffered higher death rates from nearly all major causes. Although life expectancy has increased for all groups, differences persist. And Government and academic research shows a widening gap between blacks and others in the incidences of asthma, diabetes, major infectious diseases and several forms of cancer. 
 The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that from 1980 to 1994 the number of diabetes cases rose 33 percent among blacks, three times the increase among whites. The gap in cases of infectious diseases has grown by the same magnitude.
With breast cancer, the C.D.C. reports that from 1990 to 1995 the death rate for all women fell 10 percent, from 23.1 per 100,000 to 21. But black women's higher rate did not budge from 27.5 per 100,000.
The erosion of black Americans' health in relation to Americans at large stands in stark contrast to many blacks' advances in areas like jobs, education and housing that three decades of civil rights laws have helped promote.
In the economy of the 1990's, poverty among blacks has shrunk, and gaps in income have narrowed. Sociological barriers to economic progress like a high teen-age pregnancy rate have receded, too.
But blacks often receive less, and worse, health care than whites, analysts say, meaning that they are sicker than whites and typically die at about 70, six or seven years earlier than whites.
"We have a two-tiered health care system," said Dr. Randall Morgan, an orthopedic surgeon and a former president of the predominantly black National Medical Association.
Limited education, violence and addiction remain partly to blame. But Clinton Administration officials and analysts of health systems say they are finding growing evidence that race, discrimination and social and cultural factors influence the care people receive and, consequently, their health.
The chief White House adviser on health issues, Chris Jennings, said economic status was a big source of the gap. "But even if you control for that, race is huge," Mr. Jennings said. "If you pull out education, race is still huge."
The White House is grappling with new ways to address the problem, most likely in the President's budget proposal early next month. In response to a White House request, officials of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Health Care Financing Administration said they were compiling proposals to try to eliminate the gap after 2000.
Dr. Donald M. Berwick, a pediatrician in Boston and a member of President Clinton's commission on health care quality, said: "Tell me someone's race. Tell me their income. And tell me whether they smoke. The answers to those three questions will tell me more about their longevity and health status than any other questions I could possibly ask. There's no genetic blood test that would have anything like that for predictive value."
The growth of managed care, experts said, has had little effect. "The more we hear about the problems in the health care delivery system and managed care, the more the issues of minorities stand out," said Bailus Walker, health policy director for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, which focuses on blacks.
Administrations since the 60's have been aware of the gap and have started dozens of programs, committees and conferences to tackle it.
The Department of Human Services has an Office of Minority Health, which among other activities publishes a newsletter, Closing the Gap. The department compiles ambitious annual reports on progress toward goals for 2000 to prolong healthy lives and reduce the disparities.
But the results are mixed. For many conditions that disproportionately touch blacks, including asthma, obesity, homicide, maternal mortality, diabetes and fetal alcohol syndrome, the report published in October shows the incidences not only falling short of the goals but also slipping in relation to the conditions in the late 80's and early 90's, on which the goals were based.
Dr. Morgan said Government attempts to reduce the gap were modest and subject to sporadic financing. "We get a program, and then it's over," he said. "We can't get a sustained effort. The tragic thing is it's costing America more and more every day to have the premature babies -- not the ones who die -- who go on to drain the health system's resources."
Public health programs begun in Mr. Clinton's tenure have made little more headway against the gap than those of prior Administrations, including Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor, and Medicare, the program for the elderly.
Programs that pay for prenatal care for mothers and nutrition and immunization for children have helped many additional children survive infancy. But deaths of black mothers in childbirth, although rare, jumped 48 percent from 1987 to 1995 (the rate soared in the late 1980's), compared with 7.6 percent for all mothers. And blacks still have two times the infant mortality rate of whites, a gap that has not changed in at least a decade.
Since the early 60's, the American Cancer Society said, black men's death rate from cancer rose 62 percent, compared with 19 percent for all American men. A gap in the incidence of prostate cancer has narrowed. But the incidence is 30 percent higher for black men, and 66 percent survive for five years, compared with 81 percent of white men.
In general, the nation has realized declining death rates from leading killers like heart attack, stroke and cancer. But blacks still suffer those and other disabling conditions sooner than whites.
 As a result, new research sponsored by the National Institute for Aging shows that blacks enjoy 56 years of reasonably good health, 8 years fewer than whites and Hispanic-Americans. In an institute survey, one-third of all blacks from 51 to 61 described their health as fair to poor, compared with one-fifth of all whites of the same ages.
 Kenneth G. Manton, director of the Center for Demographic Studies at Duke University, who wrote an analysis of the survey, said: "If you look at the total population, you find a significant decline in chronic disability and institutionalization for people 65 and older. But if you break it down among blacks and whites, you find almost all the improvement is among whites."
 Concern about the gap has entered White House planning for Mr. Clinton's last two years in office. It has risen with experts' doubts that the enactment last year of a five-year $24 million plan to provide care to half the 10 million uninsured children would help reduce the disparities.
 Administration officials expect Mr. Clinton, in his budget message, to ask for additional money to improve minority groups' health. In addition, the officials say, he could ask for revisions of Government health programs so that additional people like nurses and physicians in minority communities join in working on the stubborn roots of the gap.
 The issue is also entering other arenas. The President's advisory board on race, which has been dwelling mostly on discriminatory barriers to economic opportunity, has begun soliciting testimony on health.
Dr. Berwick said he and other members of the health commission were urging the commission to include a proposal to close the gap in the panel's final report in March.
 To curry support to close the gap, the President is likely to define the issue in terms of minority health, not simply black health.
 Other minority groups suffer from some diseases more than blacks. Indians have higher levels of diabetes. Hispanic-Americans tend to suffer more fatal and disabling strokes. Puerto Rican children have the highest incidence of asthma.
The C.D.C. reports that in 1996, tuberculosis among Asian-Americans was nearly 15 times higher than among whites and nearly twice the level for blacks.
But as the largest minority group and the one with the highest death rates from most diseases, blacks arouse the most concern.
"There is a minority group that is very disadvantaged with respect to health, and that's African-Americans," said Samuel H. Preston, a demographer and dean of the School of Arts and Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania. "It's not a minority problem. It's a black problem."
The intractability of the gap is stirring searches for explanations beyond the conventional one of disproportionately low income. Hispanic-Americans, too, are relatively poor and are much less likely to have health insurance than any other group. Yet the C.D.C. finds that they stay healthy longer than non-Hispanic whites, as well as blacks.
 Research has shown slight, apparently genetic, predispositions among blacks for prostate cancer, sickle cell anemia and underweight births. But analysts say the major disparities arise less from inherent differences among races than from attitudes toward the races and unequal care.
A study in October in The New England Journal of Medicine suggested something peculiarly American to being black and unhealthy beyond genes. For the study, two neonatologists in Chicago, Drs. James Collins and Richard David, surveyed the birth weights of all children born in Illinois from 1980 to 1995. They isolated the lowest-risk group of mothers, from 20 to 39, who were college educated, married to college-educated men, had prenatal care in their first trimesters and had no prior miscarriages or stillbirths.
The researchers found that 2.4 percent of the 12,361 American-born white mothers delivered underweight babies, compared with 3.6 percent of 608 mothers living in Illinois and born in sub-Saharan Africa, and 7.4 percent for American-born black mothers.
"These findings discredit the genetic theory of race as it applies to birth weight," the doctors said in a paper presented in November to the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association. "To understand this thing called race, we must turn our attention to the institutions and attitudes which perpetuate and justify unequal treatment of people on the basis of their physical appearance, language or culture."
 In hospitals and clinics, said Sara Rosenbaum, director of the Center for Health Policy Research at George Washington University here, blacks often receive worse care than whites. "When you take black and white Americans," Ms. Rosenbaum said, "and exactly the same situation like being hospitalized for a heart attack and having the same insurance, the chance that the black patient will get the advanced care is much less than it is for the white patient. The medical system appears to treat them differently."
Analysts say solutions require attention to the health conditions of the very young, before the effects of poverty, toxic environments, bad diets, violence and untreated disease.
 "Policy that only deals with people in their 50's is going to have a minor impact on eliminating differences because a series of health shocks has happened already," said James P. Smith, a senior economist at the Rand Corporation who testified this month before the race commission.
Policy goals should also change, said Dr. Berwick in Boston.
"It isn't enough to say we're going to close the gap by equalizing services," he said. "I don't think that's the heart of the problem. It's not equality of access. It's equality of result that we should seek."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
State Study Concludes Casinos Benefit Citizens

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
In a report that praised the state's gambling industry, state officials said Atlantic City's casinos had generated more than $7 billion in Federal, state and local tax revenue over the last 20 years and currently employ nearly 50,000 workers.
The study, by the State Casino Control Commission, was released to officials of the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, a Federal panel that visited Atlantic City last week to study the social and economic impact of legalized gambling. 
 The state commission's report said Atlantic City's casinos, which have an annual payroll of more than $1 billion, had increased local property values to more than $6 billion from $319 million since casino gambling was established in New Jersey in 1976.
The nine-member Federal commission, which made Atlantic City the first stop on its nationwide fact-gathering tour, also heard a report on the negative effects of gambling from critics of the industry. Kevin O'Neill, deputy director of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, told the commission that there are an estimated 4.4 million pathological gamblers nationwide, and argued that neither the casino industry nor state officials are doing enough to help problem gamblers.

HEADLINE: Separate Jobs for Blind Spur a Spirited Debate

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
On the fourth floor of a factory in Long Island City, Queens, Clifton Harrell deftly handles heavy machinery to trim, bend and assemble toilet bowl brushes, 150 dozen a day. His hands are a blur; his body, a study in efficient motion.
"It's a lot of work, but once you get used to it, it's like clockwork," said Mr. Harrell, wiping a bead of sweat from his forehead. Then, cocking his head toward the ground, he added, "And I got Austin here." 
 Austin is Mr. Harrell's seeing-eye dog.
Mr. Harrell is an employee at the only factory in New York City that, with the exception of some supervisors, hires only people who are legally blind. The factory, run by a nonprofit organization called New York City Industries for the Blind, produces mops, brooms and reflector vests for numerous clients, including the city's Housing Authority and Police Department.
Inside the factory, there are the same monotonous sounds associated with any production line. But there is also a clearly marked path snaking around the factory floor, a path painted in bright black and yellow stripes, showing workers who can distinguish bright colors how to proceed. Over the path is a clothesline on which people can hook their canes as they walk. And scattered about the workplace are seeing-eye dogs who stay next to their owners.
The factory has grown since its founding in March 1996, with revenue of $7.5 million in its first year and an expected $8.5 million in its second. It has grown from 30 blind employees to more than 50 today. But with that expansion has come some protest, from other organizations serving the blind.
"I think that segregated facilities of any sort, be they schools for minorities or work environments for people with disabilities, are detrimental to the participants," said Betty Bird, senior vice president for rehabilitation programs and services at the Lighthouse Inc., a nonprofit organization in New York City. "It sets up reverberations in people's minds that the only place blind people can work is in a blind environment, and it's an archaic message from the 19th century."
Those who support what are sometimes called sheltered workshops say that however noble the idea of blind and sighted people working side by side, the reality is that mainstream jobs are hard for the blind to obtain.
"I applaud those organizations for wanting to aim as high as we can," said Carl Augusto, president of the American Foundation for the Blind, alluding to the Lighthouse and other groups. "But the reality is that there are too many blind people who are unemployed who want to be employed."
The debate over how to help the blind find work without seeming patronizing or hard-hearted is important to the estimated 1.1 million people in the United States who are classified as legally blind: people with vision of 20/200 or less.
Of the 115,000 people in New York State registered as legally blind with the New York Commission for the Blind and Visually Handicapped, about 50,000 live in New York City. The city, with its intricate subway and bus routes, has a comprehensive transportation system accessible to the blind. And it is home to several national organizations serving the blind.
"Clearly and quite obviously, New York City is a major population center, with the largest organizations serving the blind in the country," said Thomas Robertson, associate commissioner of the Commission for the Blind and Visually Handicapped. "Do they lead the parade on many of these issues? I suspect that they do."
Sheltered workshops began appearing in 1938 after Congress passed the Javits-Wagner-O'Day Act to assist blind people who wanted to work. Some organizations for the blind then opened factories that produced brooms, mops and other products using simple, repetitive methods. And for years, New York City was home to several such workshops, run by organizations such as the Jewish Guild for the Blind, Helen Keller Services for the Blind and the Lighthouse.
But by the early 1990's, with the widespread use of walking canes and voice-activated computers, most organizations had phased out the workshops, feeling that the blind had become better equipped to get mainstream jobs.
Now, Marc Maurer, president of the National Federation of the Blind, a nonprofit organization, believes that job-training programs and increasing understanding of the blind are more effective tools in integrating blind workers into these jobs. Some blind people agree.
"If you're all segregated, no one gets an impression that we're people just like anyone else," said John Kolnsberg, 32, who lost his vision after he was shot in 1995. Now he works as a radio dispatcher for Consolidated Edison, in an office with about 30 people, none of them blind. "Of course they know I'm blind, but we work well together, and it's an education for everyone."
But Richard C. Bland, president and chief executive of the New York City Industries for the Blind, described that approach as the function of a "social worker" mentality and said he believes that his organization's approach is more realistic.
Only 45.6 percent of people between the ages of 21 to 64 who are visually impaired, or about 2.1 million people, are employed. So to give the blind more opportunities, Mr. Bland founded the Long Island City factory.
"This is not a charity," said Mr. Bland, a businessman who had worked as a marketing executive for packaged goods and liquor companies. "It's not, 'Oh my, let's help them out.' This is a business. They come. They work. They grumble like everyone else."
The average wage is $6.25 an hour, with a high of $9.50 an hour -- above minimum, but well below what unionized workers would make. The 50 or so blind employees also get disability, life and health insurance.
As a nonprofit organization, New York City Industries for the Blind benefits from a Federal law that designates such organizations as "preferred providers" when seeking contracts. At the same time, these organizations must provide products of equal or better quality for a competitive price or lose the contract. Workplace conditions are also inspected by the United States General Services Administration and the New York State Labor Department.
Phyllis Callender, a seamstress at the Long Island City factory, said, "It beats sitting home and doing nothing." And Mr. Harrell says he gets to work early, at 7 A.M., to have coffee and chat with his co-workers.
"We share a bond because we're in the same position and we need help here and there," he said. "But to tell you the truth, I don't miss my eyes that much because I can handle myself in the dark. And some of the things that's happening out there -- frankly, I don't want to see."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Indonesia Introduces Key Banking Changes

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With Indonesia's banking system slowing almost to a halt, the Finance Ministry announced a package of measures today that is intended to restart the flow of money into the economy.
The package included guarantees on bank deposits, an end to all curbs on the foreign ownership of banks, and the creation of a special agency that would rehabilitate ailing banks. Those banks would then be merged or sold. 
 "Over the last several months, the waves of economic difficulties have been taking a heavy toll on the health of the banking system," Finance Minister Marie Muhammad said in a statement. "Foreign banks have become increasingly reluctant to accept Indonesian letters of credit, making it difficult for the country to obtain vital imports. Even domestic banks have become reluctant to lend to each other."
Advance word of the package on Monday received generally positive reaction from financial analysts here, though some concerns were expressed on greater foreign ownership of banks. "There is the possibility of foreign banks ending up dominating the banking system here, which would be unacceptable, I think," said Gus Papanek, a Boston-based economist now in Jakarta.
The banking changes were not considered a cure-all for the deep economic damage that has also become a political crisis here, causing a widespread loss of confidence.
Investors have retreated from doing business with Indonesia because of uncertainty about the political future of President Suharto, who appears intent on a seventh five-year term in March, despite wide dissatisfaction with his 32-year rule.
Investors are also waiting to see how the country grapples with $65 billion in dollar-denominated foreign debt owed by private companies, which has grown ever more expensive for the companies as the value of the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, deteriorates.
A new austerity program that Mr. Suharto signed two weeks ago in connection with the International Monetary Fund's $40 billion rescue package failed to restore market confidence. These continuing worries have been put in sharp focus by a near shutdown of the banking system.
"Everything has been cut off," a foreign banker here said. "People have been having their lines of credit cut off for the last month and a half. All foreign banks are scared stiff that there may be a debt moratorium, and they are doing all they can to cut, cut, cut, and get back everything they can. But they still don't have a grip on who owes what to whom."
The problems in banking originated with an easing of regulations in 1988 that enabled poorly schooled financiers to open banks as sources of cash for their private projects.
Economists have warned that Indonesia's 200 banks are far too many for the size of the economy, but their consolidation had been politically difficult until the current financial crisis set in.
When the economy began to sour last year, the banking system began to buckle under the weight of the sharply falling currency and fewer and fewer payments on the private dollar debt. Overseas banks retreated, reducing or ending rupiah transactions, and in some cases, cutting Indonesian banks out of the interbank trading system that allows cash to move through the system.
With their flow of dollars reduced, many banks have stopped making loans and curtailed other kinds of banking transactions. Capital levels are dangerously low. Credit is almost impossible to obtain, causing economic activity to stagnate.
"Local banks like ours need the money because of phenomenal cash withdrawals at all our branches," an Indonesian bank manager said last week. "If we are unable to honor our depositors' obligations, that will create a chain reaction within the system."
The rupiah continued falling Monday, dropping 15 percent but then rebounding to close the day at 12,950 to the dollar, down 1.5 percent from its price here late Friday and down more than 50 percent since the start of 1998. This morning, it eased again, trading at 13,300 to the dollar.
Indonesian stocks were up more than 2 percent at the opening early today.
I.M.F. officials said Indonesia had about $20 billion in foreign currency reserves, enough to keep the economy from collapsing in the short run but not enough to address the larger problems.
In recent days, the nation's central bank has been purchasing rupiah with dollars to help slow the domestic currency's descent, in the process reducing the supply of rupiah in circulation.
But this has done little to strengthen confidence in the currency.
"What is its value?" the foreign banker said. "It's meaningless. It's worth one thing Monday, and it changes five times during the week. It may be 50 percent higher or lower on Friday. If you're going to buy anything, how do you reach a price?"
The near cutoff of loans and other forms of credit have hobbled Indonesian exports at a time the country is relying on them to revive the economy. "The export sector is paralyzed," said Linda Lym, a specialist on Southeast Asian economies at the University of Michigan. "They can't import materials. It's not just a question of the exchange rate; it's a question of credit. So it all comes down to the banking system." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Denver's Dot on Map Swells in the Afterglow

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Cow town no more, Denver today was the Broncos' town.
A stylized stallion with its flame-orange mane reigned over the city as residents savored their first Super Bowl victory, a civic boost after 20 years of humiliations, including four losses in National Football League championship games. 
 Bronco-mania, which tinted orange and blue everything from hair to sneakers, swept Mile High Stadium this afternoon as thousands of fans vanished from work or school to greet players from the Broncos' 31-24 victory over last year's champions, the Green Bay Packers.
"This just changes everything," said Daniel Munoz, a barber who has held season tickets to the team since 1968. "We have seen some terrible teams, some real heart breakers."
Between clips, he added, "I have never seen so many happy, grinning faces on a Monday morning."
During the game, a cliffhanger, several pregnant women in Denver went into premature labor, perhaps aided by the excitement.
John Elway, the 37-year-old Bronco quarterback, enjoys such exalted status that he could have a seat in Congress if he wanted it, one Republican National Committee official said today. Representative Dan Schaefer, a Republican who has represented West Denver's suburbs for 15 years, announced today that he would not run for re-election this fall.
This morning, some downtown store owners complained that the euphoria went overboard.
"Today, everyone is so calm, but yesterday they were so wild," Wonnie Geam, manager of the Colorado Souvenir Shop, said as she cleaned up broken glass and arranged a table of Broncos' T-shirts, the only remaining memorabilia from a few frenzied minutes of looting.
In a replay of violence seen here two years ago when the Colorado Avalanche won hockey's Stanley Cup, football fans spilled out of sports bars Sunday night, setting bonfires, overturning cars, throwing bottles at the police and smashing two dozen store display windows.
Chief David Michaud of the Denver police, who was hit in the throat with a rock, estimated about 40 people were injured and 20 arrested. With about 10,000 fans clogging a downtown area, police used so much tear gas to clear the streets that they had to ask for fresh supplies from neighboring police departments.
Up and down the foothills of the Rockies, in Boulder, Colorado Springs, Fort Collins and Greeley, the victory of the underdog Broncos sparked wild street parties.
Today, Coloradans seemed to walk a littler taller in the winter sunshine.
"Because we won, people won't look at us as the dumpy team in the N.F.L.," said one long-suffering fan, Jennifer Googins, as she shopped here for Broncos souvenirs. "This puts Denver on the map."
Putting Denver on the map has been a civic goal since the town was founded during the gold rush of 1858.
Five hundred miles from the nearest major city and 1,000 miles from the nearest seaport, Denver, an English visitor wrote a century ago, looks like a city carried by angels who got tired and just dropped it in the middle of nowhere.
To fight isolation, Denver's early promoters published fictional steamship timetables for the landlocked city and drilled through the Rockies to create an artificial railroad hub. In the last decade, they made sure the Federal Government spent billions of dollars building the nation's most modern airport and the final segment of the 43,000-mile interstate highway system.
"I call it bypass phobia," Thomas J. Noel, a University of Colorado history professor, said. "The Super Bowl victory draws national attention, in a positive, happy way, to a city that always hungered for attention, that always was afraid that, because of its isolation, it would get lost."
On Tuesday afternoon, a parade to celebrate the victory will travel down 17th Avenue ("the Wall Street of the Rockies") and through United Nations Plaza, a failed marketing ploy by the Chamber of Commerce to lure the United Nations headquarters here after World War II.
The Super Bowl victory dovetails with modern Denver's civic ambitions to jump from "capital of the Rocky Mountain empire" to world-class city.
And evidence of Denver's new prominence abounds. In 1993, nearly 400,000 people attended a World Youth Day Mass here led by Pope John Paul II; in 1995, the city's new baseball stadium and $5 billion airport opened to wide acclaim; and last year, the city smoothly handled the two Oklahoma City Federal bombing trials and the annual summit of leaders of the world's eight most powerful nations.
In a city with a booming high-technology economy and a population of migrants, major league sports have provided much of the civic glue.
"The Broncos, like many of us in this fast-growing region, are relative newcomers to Colorado," The Denver Post wrote in an editorial today about players on a team that has been here for 38 years. "In this state of transplants, our sports teams promoted a sense of community."
Far from couch potatoes, Denverites participate in sports as much as they watch them. About 23 percent of the two million people in the Denver metropolitan area ski or snowboard regularly. The region is the nation's largest market for winter sports.
With all the skiing, hiking, rock climbing and mountain biking, Coloradans are, on average, the thinnest people in the nation, according to a recent study by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Only 19.9 percent of Coloradans are overweight, compared with 26.7 percent of all Americans.
"This is a very sports-oriented city," said Doug Morton, president of Gart Sports Company.
Mr. Morton returned today from the game in San Diego to find that people had started lining up in front of his stores at 3 A.M. to buy Broncos championship caps and shirts.
"The Super Bowl win will help identify Denver as the premiere pro-sports city in the nation today," he said, citing the Broncos, the Avalanche and the Rockies, the baseball team. The only fly in the ointment is the Nuggets, which rank at the bottom of the National Basketball Association, with a season record of 3 victories and 38 losses.
The Super Bowl victory gives a boost to a plan by Broncos' owner, Pat Bowlen, to ask Denver voters later this year to approve a $180 million sales tax contribution to build a $300 million football stadium.
With a half-million fans expected to turn out for the parade, Mr. Morton said, "based on what has happened in the last 24 hours, I can't imagine the city turning down the stadium."

About 40 people were hurt and 20 arrested in the exuberance of the victory's aftermath. Fans delighted in the victory of Denver's perennial bridesmaid quarterback, John Elway, No. 7. HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Character Suicide

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I understand that Paula Jones is not a choir girl. I understand that Linda Tripp is motivated by an intense dislike for the President. I understand that Lucianne Goldberg was seeking more than just truth. I understand that Kenneth Starr is a partisan Republican out to get the President. I understand that Monica Lewinsky was a naive 21-year-old intern who may have exaggerated her relationship with Bill Clinton.
I understand, and detest, all the putrid smoke surrounding this story. But what I don't understand is the spark of fire that ignited it. I don't understand how someone entrusted with the opportunity to lead this country at such a great time, how someone whose political agenda was so substantively appealing -- on issues from abortion to education to the global economy -- could risk it all on a dalliance with a White House intern. 
 Yes, I know we don't know the full story. I know we haven't heard the President's full disclosure. But I've heard enough non-denial denials to know that whether this was an "emotional" relationship, a "special" relationship, a "not improper" relationship or some sort of backroom clothes-on relationship, the President was involved with someone in a way he should never have been and by doing so he has let down all of those who believed, if not in him personally, in the policies he was elected to implement.
Those who identified with many of the domestic, and some of the foreign, policies of the Clinton agenda made a Faustian bargain. We overlooked Mr. Clinton's past indiscretions -- he was hardly the first politician with testosterone overload -- on the condition that he pursue his agenda and postpone his next dalliance until after he left the White House. But he broke the bargain. I knew he was a charming rogue with an appealing agenda, but I didn't think he was a reckless idiot with an appealing agenda.
You feel that you just don't know this President anymore. You feel that you had a read on him, and that when you weighed his personal warts against his policy convictions, and then compared those same strengths and weaknesses against Bob Dole or George Bush or Ross Perot, the Faustian bargain with Mr. Clinton came out ahead. But now you really have to wonder. Who is he? He has clearly crossed some line that one always assumed would never be crossed in the bargain.
And that's why what worries me now is not that he is going to be impeached for high crimes and misdemeanors, but that he has impeached himself with low crimes and Miss-demeanors. It is one thing for a President to have low poll ratings. A President with low poll ratings can change policies to reverse his standing, or wait until his policies vindicate him. But what do we do with a President whose character is impeached, but who is himself not impeachable? What do we do with a President whose policies are still critically important, but who is so personally discredited they become difficult to sell or sustain?
That is the real question we are about to face. I am sure that those who argue that the country cares a lot more about Dow Jones than Paula Jones are right. But what happens if the two collide? What happens if the President can't rally the nation in the next Dow Jones crisis, because he's had one too many Paula Jones crises? What happens if he can't restrain Saddam because he couldn't restrain himself?
The President is planning to give his State of the Union speech tonight on one of the most important issues of his era: how the global economy is reshaping our lives, our workplaces and our communities, and how we need to design more effective institutions to cushion those most brutalized by that economy and to prevent its worst excesses -- like the Asian contagion -- from lapping up on our shores. But you can be sure that all anyone will remember from this speech is how Hillary looked when the camera panned to her in the gallery, or how loudly the Congress applauded when the President rose to speak.
It is hard to really hear what a President has to say when you are too embarrassed to look him in the eye.
As I said, there are a lot of things here we thought we knew and it turns out that we didn't. But there is one thing I was sure of before and am still sure of now: Supporters of Mr. Clinton's agenda deserved better from him -- a lot better.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Rally After Friday's Sharp Selloff as Dollar Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond prices rallied yesterday and the dollar rebounded a little as investors seemed to shift their attention to the positive economic fundamentals supporting both markets.
But this shift came only after a sharp selloff of both bonds and dollars last week. While much of the selling followed a strong rally the previous two weeks and was set off by the kind of reassessment that is normal after such a quick run-up, President Clinton's sex scandal appeared to accelerate the selling, analyst and traders said. 
 Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond jumped 1 1/4, to 103 1/4, as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.89 percent, from 5.96 percent on Friday. But the 30-year yield is still well above the recent low of 5.69 percent Jan. 12. Yields on shorter-term Treasury securities also declined.
The dollar rose 1 percent against the German mark, finishing at 1.7956 in late New York trading, compared with 1.7774 on Friday. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar was 1 percent higher at 126.85 from 125.57. But the dollar is still off 2.3 percent against the mark and 5.5 percent against the yen since its recent highs.
The rebound in bonds yesterday was in part just a bounce from the sharp selloff. "The market got way ahead of itself on Friday on issues that don't look as scary on Monday," said Russ Sheldon, senior economist at MCM, a market research firm.
He said that although some investors were selling last week because the economy had yet to show signs of an expected slowdown, the outlook for inflation was still so positive that it should be "enough to keep bonds from topping 6 percent for the time being." If he is right, that made the yield of 5.96 percent quite attractive.
On the dollar, the rally was also partly just a bounce after a sharp fall. But President Clinton's strong denial yesterday of an affair with a former White House intern or any attempt at a cover-up also helped the American currency, traders said.
"His statement was something the market wanted to hear," said Robert White, a senior vice president at Standard Chartered Bank. "It is important for this market to see the President in command."
"There is only so much a market can discount something like this before it has a correction," Mr. White said, especially when the scandal is based on allegations and the President has denied them. "We are doing this all on hot air," he added.
But as the Clinton scandal continues to unfold, analysts were lengthening their lists of reasons why the scandal could affect bonds, stocks and the dollar. One comes from Michael P. Andrews, a director in the government relations office of Salomon Smith Barney in Washington. The possible impact is worrisome enough for him to conclude: "We are in for a bumpy ride, so we recommend fastening the seat belts."
He said the crisis could diminish the chances for approval of so-called fast track authority to facilitate Congressional approval of trade agreements. It could undermine the effort to strengthen Asia by making it difficult for the President to win more assistance for the International Monetary Fund. The crisis could make it harder for him to limit the spending, either for tax cuts or new Government programs, of expected budget surpluses. And the President may now be less likely to focus on the restructuring of Social Security.
"When he has a hostile Congress and you throw this on top of it," said Mr. White of Standard Chartered of the Washington scandal, "that has an effect in markets."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Charting a Life's Course With the Help of a Suit

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
Like many 17-year-olds in New York City, Jayson Mines favors oversize trousers and clunky sneakers that look as if they house rocket boosters. But when it came time to find a part-time job last month, Jayson, a high school junior, knew his street clothes might not impress potential employers.
"You can't exactly go on interviews wearing this," he said, glancing down at overalls so expansive they could be mistaken for maternity wear. 
 As one of four children sharing a two-bedroom apartment on East 102d Street, Jayson did not ask his mother, an unemployed correction officer, to outfit him for his job search. "She has enough trouble putting food on the table," said the lanky, soft-spoken teen-ager, who gathers his crown of meticulously woven braids in a ponytail. "My mom would buy me whatever I want, but I hate to be a burden."
Last month, a job-training counselor at the Children's Aid Society took Jayson shopping on 106th Street, where he picked out a navy suit, black loafers and two conservative ties. The clothes cost $250 and were paid for by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which supports the Children's Aid Society and six other charities in the city.
Midge Caparosa, who runs the society's job-readiness program in East Harlem, has been teaching Jayson and other teen-agers the A B C's of finding work. The program helps them write crisp resumes, offers them interviewing tips and makes sure they know how to knot their ties properly. "It's amazing the way clothing transforms a kid," said Ms. Caparosa, explaining that a suit and tie can bolster a teen-ager's self-confidence. "It really makes them feel and act grown up."
Equally important is the effect a well-tailored suit can have on how teen-agers like Jayson are perceived. "If a young black man wears a suit, you can bet he'll get more respect," said his mother, Carol Lilly.
When a nattily dressed Jayson showed up for his interview at the Rainbow Pharmacy at Third Avenue and 29th Street, Tom Accomando, the manager, was awestruck. "I asked him if he was coming in to interview for my job," he said jokingly.
The suit apparently had the desired effect. Jayson landed the stock clerk position that very day. It also helped that he had a polished resume and that the report card he brought along had an unbroken string of A's. "I told him he ought to be tutoring my kids," Mr. Accomando said.
A year ago, Jayson might not have made such a favorable impression. He had stopped going to classes at the High School of Art and Design and was spending his days playing basketball or watching television at a friend's apartment. "I guess I just lost interest in school," Jayson said. "I get distracted easily."
Those distractions included several peers who had recently dropped out. "He thought playing hooky would be a lot of fun," said his mother, who was initially unaware of his truancy because Jayson had intercepted notices that arrived in the mail.
But after five months he lost interest in idleness, too. With encouragement from Ms. Caparosa and other counselors at the East Harlem Children's Center, he returned to school last fall. To make up for lost time, he enrolled in night school as well. These days he is maintaining a 93 average and works afternoons and weekends at the pharmacy, where he makes $5.15 an hour. He has already earned $700, more than half of which he has saved.
"Jayson is heading in the right direction, but he's not out of the woods yet," said Ms. Caparosa, who has come to know him well during the five years he has gone to the center. "There are a lot of negative pulls in that neighborhood."
More than ever, Jayson says he is clear about his goals. He wants to go to college for computer science (inspired, he said, by the I.B.M. computer the center gave him last year). He knows he has to keep up his grades if he wants his pick of schools. "I also know I'll never be a bum on the street," he said.
Asked what kind of career he wants, Jayson shrugged. "That I don't know yet," he said. "But at least I know that whatever it is, I want to work in an office and wear a suit."

HEADLINE: Home Resales Off in December, Up for Year

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Home resales declined in December for the second consecutive month but set a record for the full year, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Resales are expected to remain strong this year, aided by low mortgage rates, healthy job growth and rising incomes. 
 In December, resales fell 2.1 percent, to an annual rate of 4.29 million, after a decline in November of two-tenths of 1 percent. In the year, though, resales rose 3.1 percent, to a record 4.22 million, from 4.09 million in 1996, the previous record.
Home resales last month rose in the Northeast, fell in the South and West and were unchanged in the Midwest. The resales are an important measure of the housing industry's health. Previously owned homes account for about 85 percent of all single-family home sales.
"Home sales in January should be taking off," judging from the recent strength in mortgage applications, said Russ Sheldon, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. "The housing industry could scarcely have stronger fundamentals."
That helps other parts of the economy. Jonathan Basile, an economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York, said. "Consumers who purchased these homes will likely be spending for furniture and home furnishings," he said. "This will be an engine for consumer spending growth in 1998."

HEADLINE: Teacher Groups to Merge, Creating Largest U.S. Union

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The nation's two largest teachers' unions announced a preliminary merger plan yesterday that would create the largest union in the nation's history, with 3.2 million members.
The leaders of the National Education Association, with 2.3 million members, and the American Federation of Teachers, with 950,000 members, said the merger was intended to give teachers a more powerful voice when the nation's public schools and public school teachers are under heavy attack. 
 "As forces unite to undermine our foundation of democracy -- public schools -- defenders of public education must unite as well," said Bob Chase, president of the National Education Association.
Under the merger plan, Mr. Chase and Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, would both be called "founding presidents" of the new union, whose name has yet to be determined.
The National Education Association is currently the nation's largest union, with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters No. 2, at 1.4 million members. In the teamsters' heyday in the 1970's, it was the largest union in the nation's history, with 2.5 million members.
"This merger is very, very important," said Marjorie Murphy, a Swarthmore College history professor who has written a book on the two unions. "It's the biggest union merger in history. The leaders of the two unions have sought such a merger since 1972 because they know they would be stronger if they unite."
The merger plan comes after Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate in 1996, angrily accused teachers' unions of having too much power and opposing educational overhauls. The plan comes at a time when the teachers' unions feel besieged by criticisms that public schools are failing and by the conservative push for school vouchers to help move students from public schools to private ones.
Ms. Feldman became the A.F.T's president last year after the death of Albert Shanker, the longtime president who turned the union into a powerhouse. Some union leaders said Mr. Shanker had set up numerous roadblocks to completing a merger.
Ms. Feldman, who recently announced that she was stepping down as president of New York City's teachers' federation, said the merger would enable the union to devote more resources to defending public education and improving schools and devote fewer resources to inter-union squabbles.
In the past, the two unions have often fought head-to-head and spent liberally to recruit teachers in the same school districts.
Teachers' union officials also pointed to another form of what they called destructive competition: many times leaders of one of the unions would be reluctant to back controversial changes, like making it easier for school districts to ease out poorly performing teachers, for fear that they would be undercut by officials from the competing union.
In an interview, Mr. Feldman said, "Instead of using resources that we now use fighting each other, we can do a lot more in the way of helping our locals that are trying to do something about failing schools, about safety, about improving public education."
Under the plan announced today, delegates from the two unions are scheduled to vote at conventions this summer on whether to approve the merger. The accord calls for the merger to take place in 2002, and for 15 members from each union to sit on a new executive board.
Although both Mr. Chase, who is 55, and Ms. Feldman who is 58, would be called presidents, the plan states that Mr. Chase would have the constitutional duties of president during an interim period, while Ms. Feldman would have the duties of executive vice president.
Officials from the two unions said many details remained to be hammered out before a formal merger agreement is put to a vote. The two unions have to agree on language for a constitution, on how to merge the state and local affiliates of the two organizations, on what the national dues rate should be and on how to elect delegates to conventions.
"We still have a lot of issues to resolve," Mr. Chase said.
A major sticking point was whether the new organization would affiliate itself with the 13 million-member A.F.L.-C.I.0. The American Federation of Teachers belongs to the umbrella group, and the N.E.A. does not, but the plan calls for the merged union to join, a move that is expected to significantly expand the labor federation's power and reach.
The merger plan calls for the union to pay dues to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for just 1.4 million of the new organization's 3.2 million members. Under the plan, the new union would pay dues for more than 1.4 million members as local and state affiliates of the education association decide on their own to join local and state A.F.L.-C.I.O. units.
For decades, many N.E.A. members have been happy to remain outside the A.F.L.-C.I.O. They did not want their dues going to the federation, and many felt uncomfortable with being in a federation with teamsters, laborers and other unions with a corrupt past.
The National Education Association was founded in 1857, and for decades its members looked askance at unions, seeing them as groupings of lowly manual workers. Instead, the group's members considered themselves professionals and modeled their association after the American Medical Association.
From its inception in 1916, the American Federation of Teachers had a different concept; it fought from the start to win teachers the right to form unions and bargain collectively.
It was in the 1960's, when the A.F.T., led by its chapter in New York, won the right to bargain in many cities and won some impressive contracts, that many members of the National Education Association warmed up to the idea of collective bargaining. In the early 1970's, the N.E.A. began calling itself a union, as it saw the more militant teachers' federation repeatedly trounce it in contests to recruit teachers from dozens of school districts.
In 1968, some N.E.A. members grew uncomfortable with the A.F.T.'s approach when Albert Shanker, the forceful leader of the federation's New York City affiliate, led a racially divisive 55-day strike over school decentralization. Mr. Shanker became president of the teachers' federation in 1974, and many members of the N.E.A. viewed him as too combative a figure.
Despite doubts among some of the rank-and-file, leaders of the two unions began calling for a merger in the 1970's, seeing little benefit from having the two organizations compete with each other.
Often, when one union signed a contract with a school district, the rival group would boast to teachers that it could obtain even better wages and fringe benefits. This sometimes caused the teachers to sign on with the new union, which, after making extravagant promises, had to lead its members out on strike because school boards refused to agree to its tougher demands.
Formal merger talks began in 1993, but some union officials said that the negotiations had been stalled for several years, partly because Mr. Shanker, the A.F.T.'s longtime president, threw up obstacles to an accord that would result in his union being subsumed by a larger grouping. Union officials said the merger talks picked up momentum after Mr. Shanker died last year.
In New York State, the American Federation of Teachers represents the lion's share of teachers, so the proposed merger is expected to have little effect on reducing competition between the two teachers' unions. Nonetheless, teachers' federation officials predict that the merger will give them a more powerful political voice in New York by putting the N.E.A.'s considerable treasury behind their political efforts.
In this way, the merger is expected to help the teachers counter critics like Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who has run recent television advertisements attacking the teachers' unions and accusing them of being a selfish lobby that blocks change.
The vast majority of public-school teachers in Connecticut and New Jersey belong to the N.E.A., although the A.F.T. represents teachers in some big cities, including Newark.
The teachers' announcement merger is part of a growing trend within the labor movement. While both teachers' unions have been growing, most mergers have involved unions with declining memberships that agreed to combine in order to increase their flagging clout and to create economies of scale in representing their members.
The biggest previously announced merger involved the 1995 decision of three unions that have been losing members: the United Auto Workers, the United Steelworkers of America and the International Association of Machinists. The merger, which has not yet been finalized, would form a union with two million members.
Another major merger was announced last month when 1199, the National Hospital and Human Service Employees Union, announced plans to join the Service Employees International Union.

HEADLINE: Alter Law on Contractors, Giuliani Urges Legislators

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a compromise today to a burdensome and widely unpopular law among some politicians that requires government officials to hire at least four separate contractors for certain construction projects.
For decades, local officials have railed against the statute, known as the Wicks Law, arguing that it inflates the cost of construction projects, but its defenders in the State Assembly, backed by politically powerful trade unions, have always saved it from repeal. 
 Under the 77-year-old law, government agencies must hire at least four separate contractors for any project worth $50,000 or more: one each for general construction, heating, plumbing and electrical work. In most other states, such jobs are awarded to a single general contractor, who can then hire subcontractors.
Economists and local officials say that the Wicks Law results in construction costs that are 10 to 30 percent higher than necessary, a waste of hundreds of millions of dollars a year statewide.
Speaking today at a joint Senate-Assembly hearing on the 1998-99 state budget, Mr. Giuliani proposed that the Legislature allow local governments to escape the Wicks provision, on the condition that they devote half of any savings to renovating and building schools for perhaps 10 years. He estimated that the change would provide New York City with $60 million a year for school construction.
"It would be an influx of dollars that is badly needed right now," Mayor Giuliani said.
Gov. George E. Pataki was quick to endorse the idea. And the Mayor tapped into an issue that is foremost in the mind of the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, who has said that seeking more state money for school construction will be his highest budget priority this year. Last year, Mr. Silver championed a $2.4 billion bond act for building and repairing schools, but it was defeated at the polls, leaving him searching for other ways to obtain that money.
In past years, Mr. Silver advocated a weakening of the Wicks Law but was unable to win enough support to pass.
The law is fiercely defended by the building trade unions, which fear that fewer contractors would mean fewer jobs and that general contractors would be able to coerce subcontractors into lowering their bids, which would mean reduced wages.
Union officials also contend that with a general contractor directly overseeing each part of the work, rather than a government agency, there is greater room for shoddy work, kickbacks and other unsavory practices.
"It would be the state abdicating its responsibility to arrange, police and inspect these jobs," said Denis M. Hughes, executive assistant to Edward Cleary, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. He noted that New York City's trouble-plagued School Construction Authority has been exempt from the Wicks Law since 1989.
Labor unions, which are generally allied with the Democrats, who control the Assembly, are one of the most powerful interest groups in the state, and lawmakers of both parties have been reluctant to defy them. Small construction companies also favor the Wicks Law, which they see as a guarantee that they will not be frozen out of large projects.
Mr. Pataki, who has long favored a repeal of the law, called Mr. Giuliani's proposal "very creative," adding that it "will help increase support for those of us who want to see the law changed."
Some Assembly Democrats said they, too, thought the Mayor had seized on a way of dealing with the issue that might make changes to the Wicks Law more likely. But they questioned whether the changes would save as much money as Mr. Giuliani predicted. Mr. Silver, while not commenting directly on the Mayor's proposal, said the city and state "must commit real dollars, not hypothetical dollars."
Mr. Giuliani and the Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, made the annual political pilgrimage to Albany today to comment on the Governor's proposed budget and to begin lobbying for city projects.
Mr. Vallone, who would like to challenge Mr. Pataki this fall, criticized his budget as risky, and noted that by Mr. Pataki's own projections the state faced large deficits in 1999 and beyond.

HEADLINE: A Look at Trimming Aid to Israel by U.S.

 BODY:
The Israeli Finance Minister will meet with Congressional and Administrative officials this week to discuss phasing out America's $1.2 billion in economic aid to Israel starting in the year 2000, according to Congressional officials and Jewish organizations. 
 Israel is the largest recipient of American foreign assistance. Israeli officials on both the left and right have occasionally raised the possibility of weaning themselves away from it, both to free the country from dependence on American largesse, and as recognition of the fact that Israel has prospered.
 Article, page A7.

HEADLINE: At AT&T, Taking News Of Cutbacks in Stride

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 26

 BODY:
From the unionized crews who dig the holes to lay AT&T's fiber optic lines to the executive secretaries in plush corporate offices, the announcement today by AT&T's chairman that the company would cut its work force by 15,000 to 18,000 jobs over the next few years was not nearly as traumatic as has been the case in the past.
In fact, some employees at the company's headquarters here reported that there was some giddy laughter of relief and even a few cheers from veterans who had gathered around televisions or speaker phones for a closed-circuit telecast of the announcement by AT&T's new chairman, C. Michael Armstrong. What was different about this round of job cuts, the workers said, was that the buyout packages were generous and the job market strong. 
 "I feel better today than I did yesterday because at least I'm being offered something," said a 41-year-old manager who has been with the company for 20 years but spoke only on condition of anonymity. "If the buyout wasn't decent, we would all be just sitting around waiting for the ax to fall. Of course, if I take it I would still have to get another job, but at least they aren't throwing us out through the back door."
Pat Kelly, a vice president for education and training with AT&T's wireless division based in Redmond, Wash., said the fact that Mr. Armstrong linked the company's plans to reduce its work force with announcements of new products and plans to promote new business areas like wireless phones, did much to calm people's fears. She said it showed that he had developed an understanding of the industry after just four months on the job, and had a strategy that involved more than just streamlining the payroll.
"I was here two years ago when they announced 40,000 layoffs and that's when I switched to the new wireless division," she said as she left the headquarters here after a visit for business meetings. "This was different."
When the last round of job reductions was announced, the mood was distinctly different. New Jersey was just emerging from a recession, jobs were scarce and insecurity among workers high. This time, said James Hughes, dean of the Edward Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, the state's unemployment rate is below 5 percent and 78,000 new jobs have been created in the state in the last year.
"They are making the buyout packages attractive enough and people will be jumping on them because they know they can go out there and get another job in this market," he said.
Still, Mr. Hughes was critical of AT&T, which he said has been going through bouts of downsizing since deregulation in 1984. He said the company's success in the effort has looked to be slow and he said that what was the proverbial 800-pound gorilla in the days of regulated utilities "still looks like a dinosaur trying to adapt."
But workers generally said they were pleased with the way Mr. Armstrong delivered the news. In preparation for today's announcement the company had set up 390 locations where employees could watch. The company also set up a toll-free number that workers could call and hear a live feed of the announcement. Some workers, however, bitterly complained that the more than 4,000 ports for the telephone lines were repeatedly busy.
In addition, AT&T posted details of the announcement on its in-house Web site.
"We learned from previous announcements, and it is part of Armstrong's philosophy that we tell employees what is happening before we tell the rest of the world," said Dick Martin, executive vice president for public relations.
The buyout packages included a provision that would allow a large group of workers to take lucrative buyouts or retire with full pensions. In the past, employees needed 30 to 35 years in the company to get a full pension. But under the new provisions announced yesterday, anybody whose age plus time on the job totaled 65 years would be eligible for the full pension.
Mark Burkhart, a 41-year-old worker with the engineering and construction unit for 18 years, considered himself a "rookie" compared with some who have been with the company for 30 or more years. As he listened to the announcement over a speaker phone he saw smiles on the faces of many of his co-workers.
"They liked the buyout package," he said. "The company has been the poster boy for downsizing for a while now and these guys are just tired and they want out."

HEADLINE: Endgame on Iraq

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein's efforts to keep United Nations inspectors away from his biological weapons programs have brought the United States to the edge of military action. Clinton Administration officials warn that a series of punishing air strikes could begin in a matter of weeks, if a last-minute campaign of intensified diplomacy and sanctions fails to force Iraq to obey U.N. Security Council resolutions. With a British aircraft carrier joining a powerful American naval task force in nearby waters, a credible capacity for heavy and sustained air attacks is already in place.
This threat is necessary and appropriate. But a little time still remains to see what can be accomplished with the application of less deadly military force and intensified diplomacy and economic sanctions. Mr. Hussein has so overreached that previously sympathetic countries, like France, are now distancing themselves from Iraq. Russia's position is more ambiguous, as President Boris Yeltsin publicly opposes the use of force while dispatching an envoy to Baghdad to try to persuade Iraq to back down. 
 Security Council members can move beyond words by shutting down Iraq's lucrative contraband coastal oil trade through Iranian waters and the Persian Gulf to the United Arab Emirates, which provides a hefty share of Baghdad's current revenues. The Security Council can also extend existing no-flight zones to cover all the airspace over Iraq.
Washington should take one other important diplomatic step in advance of possible military action. Under the cease-fire resolution that ended the Persian Gulf war in 1991, once U.N. inspectors have destroyed all of Iraq's biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs and established a reliable long-term monitoring system to prevent their revival, oil export sanctions would be lifted. Yet for most of the past six years, the United States has said it will not agree to end sanctions before other cease-fire terms, like the return of Kuwaiti prisoners and property, are met, or perhaps not until Mr. Hussein is driven from power.
That American position reduces Iraq's incentives for cooperating with the inspectors and has divided the Security Council. The Administration should now make clear that Iraq can indeed speed the end of sanctions, but must begin by letting the weapons inspectors do their work. If the Security Council eventually is satisfied that all mass-destruction weapons have been eliminated, all programs for making them have been shut down and reliable monitoring is in place, sanctions should end. Unfortunately, it seems increasingly clear that what Mr. Hussein really wants is not relief for Iraq but an operational germ warfare program. Washington is rightly determined to thwart that ambition, even if it comes to military force.

HEADLINE: The State of New York City's Parks

 BODY:
New York City's Parks Commissioner, Henry Stern, delivered a State of the Parks address last week and concluded that the state was very good. Thanks to thousands of workfare participants, cleanliness is up. Broken playground equipment has been replaced. The backlog of dangerous dead trees along city streets has dropped dramatically. Rollerblade Inc. has donated $1.6 million in cash and equipment to become the official in-line skate of New York City parks. The list goes on. 
 There is, however, an unreported downside. During the past decade of fiscal restraint, public funding for the parks is down 31 percent. Right now there are only 1,700 permanent park employees struggling to maintain a system of 1,400 parks and playgrounds on 27,000 acres.
Under both Mayors David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani, the city has relied more and more on volunteers and private benefactors to support the parks, and contracted out services that used to be done by city workers. Those initiatives have paid off, but they cannot fill the entire gap. Playgrounds may be in good shape, but most of them do not have attendants on duty to hand out recreational equipment, shoo dogs away from play areas and make sure bathrooms are open and safe.
Private support has been a boon to Central Park and Bryant Park in Manhattan, and to a lesser extent to Prospect Park in Brooklyn. But donations to the other large parks barely make a dent in the lost city funds. Illegal dumping is a serious problem in some places. Trails and picnic areas are becoming overgrown and unusable. Large structures like the Rotunda at Riverside Park are deteriorating for lack of maintenance. The number of park gardeners is down 40 percent since the 1980's, and their loss cannot be made up by workfare forces or weekend volunteers.
In its eagerness to benefit from privatization, the department seems to be allowing businesses to set the agenda. For instance, it plans to turn a huge chunk of Dreier-Offerman Park near Coney Island over to a private driving range, miniature golf course and in-line-skating facility. The department was inspired not by a study of the neighborhood's needs or its own internal priorities, but simply by a company's making the offer.
The fact that the city is enjoying good economic times does not mean that the Giuliani administration should rush to bring the Parks Department budget or work force up to its old level. Gains from efficiency and innovation have made a difference. But the park system, a city jewel, is not getting all the attention it deserves.

Brazil released a report saying that destruction of the Amazon rain forest nearly tripled between the start of the decade and the 1994-95 burning season. The destruction surpassed the worst years of deforestation that caused an international outcry to save the rain forest. A3

HEADLINE: Israelis to Discuss Phasing Out 1.2 Billion U.S. Economic Aid

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Israeli Finance Minister will be meeting with Congressional and Administration officials in Washington this week to discuss phasing out America's $1.2 billion in economic aid to Israel starting in the year 2000, according to Congressional officials and Jewish organizations.
The mission of the minister, Yaakov Neeman, which was first reported today in the newspaper Haaretz and has not been officially confirmed by the Israeli Government, grows out of a pledge that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made in his address to the United States Congress in July 1996 to start cutting Israel's dependence on American aid by the end of his first four-year term. 
 Since then, Israel has been increasingly reminded of that pledge as Congress has slashed billions from the foreign aid budget. Representative Sonny Callahan, an Alabama Republican and head of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, has been an especially insistent voice in Congress for reducing aid to Israel and holding Mr. Netanyahu to his pledge. Though Mr. Callahan has not succeeded in cutting the Israeli aid, the Appropriations Committee this year for the first time set a $5.4 billion cap on foreign aid to the Middle East. An aide to Mr. Callahan acknowledged that any cut in Israeli assistance would probably lead to a corresponding cut in aid to Egypt.
For many years, Israel has received $1.2 billion a year in economic aid and $1.8 billion in military aid, making it by far the largest recipient of American foreign assistance. Though Israel's special relationship with the United States has so far precluded any cut in those sums, Israeli officials on both the left and the right have occasionally raised the possibility of weaning themselves from it, both as a way of freeing the country from dependence on American largesse, and as recognition of the fact that Israel has prospered.
According to Haaretz, Mr. Neeman plans to discuss a package by which Israel would phase out the economic aid over 10 years or so, starting with the fiscal year beginning October 1999. Under the proposal, the aid would be pegged closer to the debt Israel owes the United States from weapons and equipment bought in the 1960's and 70's.
David Makovsky, the Haaretz diplomatic correspondent, wrote that one goal of Mr. Neeman's mission was to strengthen Mr. Netanyahu's support in Congress as a counterbalance to his low standing in the White House, and to improve his image with the American public at a time when he is being accused of stalling peace efforts with the Palestinians.
An aide to Mr. Callahan said the Congressman had been approached by the Israeli Embassy about a meeting with Mr. Neeman, and would see him on Wednesday. Officials in Washington said the Finance Minister would also see Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee, as well as the ranking Democrats on the committee and subcommittee, David R. Obey of Wisconsin and Nancy Pelosi of California.
"Given that we didn't request the meeting, it's hard to predict what the items on agenda will be," said Jo Bonner, Mr. Callahan's chief of staff. "It's certain that the Finance Minister will find a receptive ear not only with Congressman Callahan, but also other representatives who recognize the importance of the peace process and our strong allegiance to the state of Israel, and are also committed to reducing foreign aid wherever and whenever feasible and practical."
Mr. Bonner added, however, that Mr. Callahan was not aware of any plan to start phasing out aid in 1999.
Mr. Neeman met with Mr. Callahan late last summer in Washington, but without reaching an agreement. In fact, Congressional officials said Mr. Callahan had been irked by Mr. Neeman's presumption that Israel was entitled to the American money. "His initial visit did not make a stellar impression with Mr. Callahan," a Republican aide said.
According to Haaretz, Mr. Callahan put forward three alternative plans for consideration.
Under one, the American aid would be used to pay off Israel's multi-billion dollar debt, and then halted. Israel's payments on the debt's interest have dropped from $1.2 billion a year to below $1 billion in recent years, and the difference between the aid and the interest payments, or $200 million, would be applied to paying off the billions in principal owed by Israel. The difference would grow as the debt shrank, until the debt was paid off, when the economic aid would be halted.
A second option was to reduce the economic aid by $200 million in the first year, and to work out a timetable to continue cutting the assistance until it is stopped. Under a third option, part of the economic aid would be cut, and part transferred to the military budget.
Mr. Neeman's mission was evidently to discuss these plans, but with the hope of starting only in late 1999, and stretching it over about a decade. As Finance Minister, Mr. Neeman only recently fought a bitter battle with Mr. Netanyahu's fractious coalition over the 1998 budget, and was evidently reluctant to lose any American income soon.
"The idea would be to develop a plan, a glide path, for Israel to bring its economic assistance down to zero, maybe over a decade," said an official of a Jewish organization who is familiar with the plan.
Starting the reduction in October 1999 would not make a significant dent in the Israeli budget before Mr. Netanyahu's current term ends, in May 2000, but would enable the Prime Minister to maintain to his voters that he was weaning Israel off American money.
In Jerusalem, David Bar Illan, Mr. Netanyahu's communications director, said it was "very possible that Mr. Neeman wants to discuss the possibility that in fiscal year 2000 a step will be made in the direction Mr. Netanyahu promised in his speech to Congress in the joint meeting of July 1996, that before the end of his first term there would be a move toward reducing and ultimately eliminating the U.S. civilian aid."
The aid package for Israel dates in part from the 1973 peace with Egypt, when both countries received pledges of American aid.
