HEADLINE: Private Group Offers Bonus Pay As a Spur to City's Public Schools

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Borrowing an idea from the boardroom to help New York City's troubled classrooms, one of the city's largest business groups announced yesterday that it would offer $30 million to fatten the salaries of hundreds of superintendents, principals and teachers if they are able to raise students' academic performance.
The plan, which could mean up to $30,000 more a year for superintendents, $15,000 for principals and $2,000 for teachers during the next five years, relies on a simple tool widely used by businesses: bonuses for bosses who make their employees and organizations more productive. 
 "We really believe, borrowing from the corporate model, that there has to be good leadership at the top," said Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, which proposed the plan with the support of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew. "We have to look at this as the principal acting as the C.E.O. of each school."
The group has raised only $2 million for the program so far, but organizers said they were confident they would come up with the amount needed to begin the plan next fall.
The idea is relatively new and has never been used in New York City. But in Kentucky, which has had a bonus program for three years, disputes have broken out between teachers and principals over who deserved the bonuses, teachers have cheated to increase student test scores and schools have inflated grades. The problems there and with a similar program in Texas raised questions yesterday about whether lessons learned from profits and stock prices can be so easily transferred to test scores and graduation rates.
"Schools should be run in a businesslike way, but you can't run them like businesses," said Thomas Sobol, a former State Education Commissioner. "These plans just mean that you end up rewarding the good people, which is socially a nice thing, but it does not change the problems with the school system."
The plan will reward educators in 2 underperforming school districts, chosen from the city's 32. So far, just one, District 19, which encompasses East New York, Brooklyn, has been chosen, officials said. A third school will be added the following year.
Under a complex system intended to monitor improvement in the schools, the districts will be trying to increase students' scores on two kinds of standardized tests. One shows whether they are learning at or above their grade level when their school is compared with similar schools each year, and another shows how much students, even those doing badly, are improving.
Officials said the dual tests would provide a more accurate yardstick of schools' progress than simple year-end, systemwide tests. The bonuses are also strictly tied to the test results, with no subjective judgment by school officials or the New York City Partnership that could give rise to accusations of favoritism or corruption in the awards.
Theoretically, if students in all the district's schools reach all the necessary goals on those tests, the bonuses for educators could add up to $10 million a year for each district.
But even if districts collectively receive less, the financial impact for those who earn the bonuses will be great. Superintendents now receive about $128,000 a year. Principals, whose performance and recruitment are the primary aims of the plan, make between $70,000 and $80,000. Teachers, who school officials said would receive less per person because bonuses would be given to every teacher in a successful school, make between $29,000 and $70,000.
"The top bonuses can add a lot, and it's going to get people's attention," said Robert E. Riccobono, the superintendent of District 19, which has 28 principals and 1,600 teachers. "It's going to get them to work hard and smart."
He added: "Everybody likes money, and there is no reason why people shouldn't accept it as long as the environment is set up correctly."
The plan is described by business and school officials as a long-awaited carrot to go with the stick handed to Dr. Crew in late 1996, when the State Legislature gave him new powers, including the right to pick superintendents and greater power to dismiss principals and other officials in poorly performing districts.
"You need to have ways to intervene, and have consequences if people fail," Dr. Crew said yesterday of the bonus plan, "and you also have to be equally demonstrative in the other direction if people are successful. I think this will have a really important and substantial impact on the climate of accountability toward children in the schools."
Critics of the plan warned that such incentive programs can encourage teachers or principals to cheat in administering tests or recording results. But a more common and troubling problem is the tempation for schools to "teach to the test," gearing classes not for a rounded education but simply to anticipate multiple choice questions on the standardized exams.
Mr. Kiley and schools officials said the Board of Education would conduct stricter auditing of test scores to guard against cheating. Dr. Crew said other accountability programs and evaluations planned for principals and teachers are intended to discourage the "test-prepping phenomenon."
"But I do think it's something we are going to have to keep our eyes on," he said.
Another criticism leveled against the plan -- one that has surfaced in independent studies of Kentucky's program -- is that competition for bonuses can actually lead to lower morale and motivation among educators who receive less, or narrowly miss test goals.
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers, said that when the bonus plan was first presented to the union, it included incentives only for principals. "We warned them that it would be absolutely counterproductive to reward principals for what had to be the result of a team effort," Ms. Amlung said. "You would set up a kind of tension there that could be disastrous."
Mr. Riccobono, who met with his principals yesterday to announce the plan, said it is a pitfall he has already begun to worry about. "Teachers will be upset if they think it is their work that a principal is being rewarded for," he said. "And I think it's our job at the district to see that the incentives are not being rewarded on the backs of the teachers."
While the plans in Kentucky and Texas, and similar ones in South Carolina and Indiana, allocate money to high-performing schools, giving them the option of using bonuses for salaries, special programs or equipment, New York's appears to be the only one designed to raise academic results solely by increasing educators' paychecks.
Mr. Kiley said that Goldman, Sachs and Chase Manhattan were the first companies to agree to provide money for the bonuses, about $2 million together, and he now hopes to raise more by drawing attention to the plan.
"This is a very, very good way to the get the business community more deeply involved in New York City schools in a way that they understand well," he said.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE STRATEGIST;
A Veteran Fighter Returns to the Ring, and Finds His Corner With Ease

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
When Gennifer Flowers sent the Clinton Presidential campaign to the precipice in 1992 with her account of a long-running affair with the Arkansas Governor, the candidate dispatched a loyal, pugnacious lawyer with a highly attuned political ear to rescue his drive in New Hampshire: Mickey Kantor.
Now, with his Presidency threatened by accusations of an affair with a young White House intern, Bill Clinton has reached for the same hardened strategist to bring order to his defense and, if possible, find a way out of the toughest crisis of his crisis-filled life in politics. 
A year after he left the Administration, declaring that long battles as the United States trade representative and then Commerce Secretary had taken their toll, the tightly coiled Mr. Kantor is suddenly helping direct what could be the biggest negotiation of his career, although it is still unclear which of several possible opponents will be sitting across the table.
His law firm, Mayer, Brown & Platt, confirmed in a terse statement today that it had been "retained by the President and First Lady to provide legal counsel to them," without ever mentioning Mr. Kantor's involvement.
But long before the announcement was out, Mr. Kantor's return, and its significance, had resonated around Washington.
"You can tell we're in deep, deep trouble," one Administration official said, "when Mickey is called off the bench."
Normally loquacious about even the most sensitive negotiations with Japan or the European Union, and always eager to talk political strategy, Mr. Kantor was uncharacteristically silent today. Through another lawyer in his firm, he offered apologies but said he could not discuss his role in Mr. Clinton's defense.
White House officials, however, made clear that although he would enjoy lawyer-client privilege, he would act chiefly as the legal team's political overseer, meaning that he will be the only political adviser who is not in peril of being forced to testify about his conversations with Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Kantor's associates say they suspect that his first job is to act as a bridge between Mr. Clinton's legal team, which White House officials say has been extraordinarily cautious about letting the President say anything that could be used against him later, and his political advisers, who have been urging him to offer, as quickly as possible, a full explanation of his relationship with the intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.
"Mickey's view of this kind of thing is that it is going to come out sooner or later," one longtime Administration colleague said today. "My guess is that he wants it out, but on our terms."
Mr. Kantor has never been a universally loved figure in the White House: his fiery temper and his absence of patience with those who cross him are legendary.
Those qualities and the enmity they created, especially among some younger colleagues, contributed to keeping him from becoming White House chief of staff in Mr. Clinton's first term. And while he was widely praised for his performance in the trade arena, he left the Administration last year after it had become clear that despite his closeness to the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, he was not destined to become Attorney General or Secretary of State.
But Mr. Kantor has never wandered far from the Clintons' orbit. And no one in the Clinton camp is considered more fiercely loyal or more skilled at smelling where a deal lies and then working backward to figure out how to get there.
He did just that in winning Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, one of the biggest legislative victories of Mr. Clinton's first term.
He did it again with Japan, in a confrontation in 1995 that took the United States to the brink of imposing enormous economic sanctions against one of its closest military allies.
That months-long dance with Tokyo was a classic Kantor concoction: long weeks of threatening public statements, endless nights of negotiation, conciliatory back-channel messages to his opponents and, in the end, a deal laced with ambiguity that enabled all sides to claim a political victory.
And he used all available means: United States intelligence agencies intercepted the telephone conversations of Mr. Kantor's Japanese opponents, which helped very little in the negotiations but caused another uproar after the surveillance was disclosed months later.
"I can't stand to lose," Mr. Kantor once said, musing on his own reputation for combativeness. "I'm the worst loser you ever saw."
Mr. Kantor loved his role as trade representative, in part because he was running a small, lean organization whose staff became highly loyal to him. But he was also able to merge trade to further Mr. Clinton's political fortunes, often overseeing deals that quieted economic discontent in areas of the country where a little managed trade smoothed ruffled political feathers.
"To be successful at this, you need to be political without being partisan," Mr. Kantor said as Commerce Secretary in 1996, when he was steadily on the campaign trail for his old friend. "But are there incidental political benefits in opening markets and creating jobs? You bet there are."
Mr. Kantor is also a man of deep loyalties. He helped Webster L. Hubbell, formerly the No. 3 official at the Justice Department, find consulting work when Mr. Hubbell was driven from the Government by scandal and needed a source of income. Mr. Kantor has said that whatever help he extended came out of friendship; he testified on the issue in front of a grand jury last month.
When he negotiated with foreign countries, it was usually clear who Mr. Kantor's interlocutors were, and what he needed to get from them. In this case, that is a much more difficult issue.
Will Mr. Kantor be dealing with Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel who has expanded his Whitewater investigation to embrace possible perjury charges concerning Mr. Clinton's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky? Or would he deal with Congress, if it threatens investigations of its own? And could he deal with a fellow Beverly Hills lawyer, William H. Ginsburg, who is representing Ms. Lewinsky in the negotiations over immunity from prosecution in return for her testimony?
"No one seems to know exactly what Mickey's role will be," one White House official said tonight. "But he has the busiest speed dialer in town."

HEADLINE: After Steady Start, Romania's Centrist Government Begins to Falter

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Jan. 22

 BODY:
A former geology professor and trade union leader came to power here as President and Prime Minister more than a year ago, riding a popular wave of hope and pride.
Finally, Romanians believed, instead of being relegated as a backwater in Europe, their country might start to catch up with the faster moving nations in the former Communist bloc. 
 But after making important moves like liberalizing prices and slashing spending, the members of the centrist coalition started bickering, or to use Romanians' favorite word -- conspiring -- against each other.
They could not decide what to do about the obsolete industrial plants from the era of the Communist dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu. The Foreign Minister had to resign last month after he said there were spies in important positions, but could not prove it.
Viktor Ciorbea, an indecisive Prime Minister, held 18-hour Cabinet meetings, leaving Government members walking around like sleepless zombies. President Emil Constantinescu toured world capitals and some foreign investment trickled in but mostly it stayed away.
At an emergency parliamentary meeting called last Wednesday by Mr. Constantinescu, the Government presented its privatization law. But the future of the shaky coalition remained uncertain, and how aggressive the Government would be in closing or selling loss-making state-run industries as demanded by the International Monetary Fund also remained unclear.
The new Finance Minister, Daniel Daianu, the former chief economist at the central bank who was installed as part of a Government shuffle last month, sounded pessimistic in an interview here.
"To have a privatization law and an investment law is not sufficient," he said. "They have to be implemented."
But implementation was blocked by "red tape and corruption," which he said were "ubiquitous." "The entire society does not see transparency as a virtue. There is a lot of double talk."
Mr. Daianu said that he would like to see the state-owned banks privatized but that the economic environment made it difficult to attract Western banks as buyers. They would be reluctant to "stake their reputation" in the current atmosphere, he said.
He was disappointed, he said, that the only potential buyer so far for one of the nation's seven oil refineries, was Lukoil, a Russian company. "I'd rather an American company, but I don't see many Americans interested," he said.
Romania made a bid last year to be included among the former Communist countries invited to join NATO. It failed to make the list but as a consolation prize, President Clinton came last July for a brief visit. To be courted economically by Russia is seen by many Romanians as an unhappy aftermath to the effort to join NATO.
There were high expectations for Mr. Constantinescu and Mr. Ciorbea because they represented a sharp break from the former Communists who ran Romania for seven years after the violent overthrow of Mr. Ceausescu, one of the most Draconian of Eastern Europe's Communist leaders.
But while they had never been Communists, the two men appear to have been stymied not only by the economic legacy they inherited but also by their lack of experience in managing anything.
They also seem to be haunted by their country's own history, which differs from that of the Central European nations now moving toward NATO. Until 1944, Romania had a monarchy closely linked to the Orthodox Church, the dominant religion here.
King Michael, who was forced to abdicate as a young man, has come back to Romania since Mr. Constantinescu became President.
Now in his 70's, the King seemed largely irrelevant until he announced this month that he was using his "prerogative" to name his daughter as his heir.
An embarrassed Mr. Constantinescu, who has been sympathetic toward the King but always stressed that Romania was a republic, had to distance himself from any notion of a restoration of the monarchy.
Through all of the political machinations, the Romanian people have been patient. "Surprisingly, people still support the Government," the finance minister said. But he wonders for how long.
The average per capita annual income in Romania is $1,200, two and a half times less than in Poland. The economy shrank by 6 percent last year.
Many people with university educations -- teachers, young doctors -- have to think about how to pay for the next meal. Since the freeing of prices last year, meat has become a rare luxury, with potatoes and beans the staple.
Mr. Daianu said the standard of living would drop further before it got better.
Most worrying, he said, was the condition of the miners, a volatile group concentrated in Petrosani, 100 miles northwest of the capital. In the fall, the Government closed mines and paid generous compensation to the workers. The idea was that the men would voluntarily move back to the countryside. But the miners' ties to the rural areas were broken generations ago, and the men have stayed put.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Sends Envoy to Iraq to Try to Finesse Crisis With the U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Angered by what he considers needless intensification of tension between Iraq and the United States, President Boris N. Yeltsin today dispatched a special envoy to Baghdad with orders to end the mounting crisis over weapons inspections.
It will not be an easy task, but officials in the Kremlin today said they were increasingly worried that President Clinton -- enmeshed in a deepening scandal at home -- will attempt to assert his leadership abroad with a rapid military strike on Iraq. 
 "Nobody is saying he is going to bomb Baghdad so that Americans will forget about his problems," said a senior Russian diplomat, who refused to be quoted by name. "But the military option has become more obvious there and there is no question that a strike on Saddam Hussein would be popular in America."
That may be true -- but the main reason that Mr. Yeltsin sent Deputy Foreign Minister Viktor Posuvalyuk to Baghdad today was more closely tied to Russian domestic politics.
It has been a tough few months for Mr. Yeltsin. His recent illness revived worries that he may not be in control of the Government. Economic uncertainties in Asia threaten to spread to the fragile markets here. So have numerous economic scandals involving the reformers who were supposed to rid the Russian Government of corruption.
Mr. Yeltsin displayed his irritation with the situation in Iraq in footage aired this evening on Russian television that depicted him approving the diplomatic mission.
Iraq is among the only places left in the world where Moscow can make a serious difference. The Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, is a Middle East specialist and so is Mr. Posuvalyuk. In 1991 he was the Soviet Ambassador in Iraq and he played a major role in Moscow's fruitless attempts to prevent the Persian Gulf war. In the end, Russians backed the Western alliance in the war.
Since then, Mr. Primakov and his deputy have continued to play a role in Baghdad. Together, they helped ease tensions in November during the last round of conflicts between United Nations weapons inspectors and the Iraqis. But inspectors are still unable to perform their jobs and diplomatic efforts to resolve the dispute seem to have failed.
On Sunday, officials in the United States said Mr. Clinton had decided to consult allies, had made no military decisions, and was trying to determine how to proceed. They made it clear that the military options were being more carefully considered than at any time since this most recent conflict began. Iraq has continued to prevent some United Nations inspection teams from entering sites that may contain nuclear, biological or chemical weapons and materials.
Iraq has banned all United Nations inspectors from eight enormous presidential sites where such materials could easily be concealed. The Iraqis accuse the United Nations of deliberately prolonging the inspection process in an effort to maintain sanctions which were imposed at the end of the gulf war.
Russia has promised to do all it can to help end the sanctions as soon as possible. But that means adhering to United Nations policy, and inspections, which Iraq has repeatedly resisted.
Asked today whether Mr. Posuvalyak's visit had been agreed to in advance with the United States, the Kremlin spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, replied, "Why would that be necessary?"
Mr. Yastrzhembsky declined to provide any details of the mission, who Mr. Posuvalyuk would meet with in Baghdad, or whether Moscow had concrete goals that he was expected to carry out. In an usually blunt statement released here this afternoon, Russian officials made their opposition to any possible military strike in Iraq clear.
"All interested parties have to act in a responsible and balanced manner in order to ease tensions and normalize the situation in the gulf," the statement from the Russian Foreign Ministry said. "All scenarios providing for the use of force are unacceptable and counterproductive."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Police Identify Suspect In L.I. Strangulation

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE

 BODY:
The police in Suffolk County said yesterday that they were seeking a 56-year-old unemployed Long Island man in connection with the strangulation of a mother of two from Islip Terrace last week.
The woman, Donna Bocklet, 41, was found dead in the back of her minivan in a supermarket parking lot in Bay Shore on Thursday. 
 The police identified the suspect as Anthony Libardi, a white male, 5 feet 7 inches tall, 240 pounds with gray hair. They said he wore a mustache until the day of the murder, when it is believed he shaved it off to alter his appearance.
Detective Lieut. John Gierasch, chief of the Suffolk County Police Department homicide squad, said Mr. Libardi was last seen early yesterday morning and was believed to be driving a red, two-door 1988 Dodge Shadow with a New York license plate, EI44BX. The police would not say why Mr. Libardi was a suspect.

HEADLINE: Northwest Air Getting Control Of Continental

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines agreed to buy a controlling stake in Continental Airlines for $519 million yesterday, beating a bid from Delta Air Lines and creating a third domestic and international airline network to compete with the country's biggest carriers, United Airlines and American Airlines.
In an unusual arrangement, Northwest and Continental plan to merge flight schedules and frequent-flier programs but maintain separate identities and managements. 
 The benefit for consumers would be a larger choice of flights from the new alliance to virtually any spot from Latin America to Asia. But it was unlikely to result in lower prices because the two carriers, which do not now compete with each other on many routes, would have little reason to do so.
One airport most affected would be Newark, a fast-growing hub for Continental that would likely receive even more passengers and flights from Northwest and its European partner, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.
"This is very good news for Newark," said John Dasburg, the president and chief executive of Northwest, in an interview yesterday. The deal would also strengthen Northwest's hubs in Detroit and Minneapolis and Continental's largest hub in Houston.
Airline executives and analysts on Wall Street said the alliance, still subject to approval by the Departments of Justice and Transportation, would likely lead to a new round of deals in the booming airline industry as smaller domestic carriers felt more pressure to compete with a growing number of national and international air alliances.
"The consolidation genie has come out of the bottle," said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover in New York. "The dance is starting."
That expectation was reflected on Wall Street, where shares in US Airways rose 5.3 percent, to $60, on expectations it would be the next takeover candidate. Shares of Delta fell 1.5 percent, to $112.3125, on fears it might have missed an important strategic opportunity.
The competition to win Continental illustrates just how frenzied the maneuvering can become. Only a few years ago, the airline was the ugly duckling of the industry, having suffered two tours through bankruptcy court. But since 1994, Continental has become profitable for the first time in more than a decade.
Over the last 18 months, David Bonderman, the Texas financier, whose Air Partners Ltd. controlled 14 percent of Continental's shares but about 51 percent of the voting rights, made clear he wanted to sell.
Continental entered merger talks with Delta in late 1996, but they ended inconclusively. Then last month, an alliance between Northwest and Continental was scuttled, when Northwest's pilots, who have the right to approve joint marketing of flights, demanded more time to consider the proposed deal.
The Northwest deal revived Delta's interest. Leo Mullin, Delta's new chief executive, called Mr. Bonderman, who encouraged him to bid. For the Delta chief, who joined the airline after stints at Unicom, the Illinois utility, and a long career as a banker, it was an unhappy introduction to the world of airline deals. Advised by Goldman, Sachs & Company, he offered to buy Continental for cash and stock. Meanwhile, Northwest, which was advised by Credit Suisse First Boston, proposed a revised offer that did not require immediate approval of its pilots.
Rather than take over Continental, it proposed an alliance. It would buy the Air Partners' stake and put the voting rights in a trust outside its control. The arrangement, which both airlines said would create jobs, turned out to be the deciding factor that convinced Continental's board to reject Delta's offer. Executives involved in the negotiations and union representatives said Delta's offer would have resulted in widespread layoffs and that Mr. Mullin did not seem to realize the disastrous impact that would have.
"They failed primarily because they had no appreciation for the magnitude of labor issues in our industry," said one person involved in Continental's deliberations.
But Mr. Mullin said most of the job reductions in a merger with Delta would have resulted from attrition. He said a confederation like the one proposed by Northwest was much harder to manage and required extraordinary cooperation. "A merger is a much more powerful combination," he said.
Some executives and analysts said losing Continental left Delta vulnerable as it slips to fourth place behind the new Northwest-Continental combination. Delta recently ended an alliance with Singapore Air and has failed to line up as many international partners as United, which has an alliance with Lufthansa, Thai International and others, and American, which is awaiting approval of a broad combination with British Airways. American is a unit of AMR and United is a unit of UAL.
"He runs the risk of having Delta sidelined in this wave of consolidation," said Jeffrey Long, an aviation analyst at J. P. Morgan in New York.
Mr. Mullin said that he was "modestly disappointed" by what happened, but did not consider it a major setback. "We have a lot of momentum going at Delta," he said. "Yes, it would have been very good, but it's not overwhelmingly significant."
Mr. Dasburg, on the other hand, was jubilant. A new air services agreement between the United States and Japan that will most likely be concluded later this week will open up significant competition to Northwest's lucrative Asian routes for the first time. With American Airlines expected to conclude an alliance with Japan Airlines and United talking with All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest airline, Northwest needed more heft.
"Our feeling is that with an alliance you can achieve 80 percent of the benefits of a merger at a fraction of the cost," he said.
Even after combining with Continental, their share of the domestic market would be smaller than Delta's, Mr. Dasburg said. "Therefore, we have got to find a way to make ourselves as attractive to customers as the larger airlines," he said.
Gordon M. Bethune, Continental's chairman and chief executive, said that combining flight schedules, marketing and frequent-flier plans would add at least $500 million in revenues over three years by drawing more customers. "This is a case where two and two make five, or even six," he said.
Northwest must still get pilot approval before it can put Continental labels on its flights, but Mr. Dasburg was optimistic. The pilots have said they now favor the alliance but are withholding approval until they sign a new labor contract. The machinists endorsed the deal yesterday.
Continental does not need formal approval of pilots, but must appease them for the alliance to succeed. Officials of Continental's pilots' union, which is also negotiating a new contract, were livid yesterday because, they said, they were only told Sunday morning that the airline might decide to merge with Delta later that day.
Though they contended that a memo to the board stating their strong objections was instrumental in shooting down the Delta bid, they demanded a job security provision in their contract. Without it, said Len Nikolai, the union's president, "there will be no economic synergies to be realized in the coming together of these two great airlines."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE PUBLIC VIEW;
Clinton Job Rating Remains High Despite Doubts on Moral Values

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
The accusations that President Clinton had an affair with a White House intern have not dimmed the public's view of how he is handling his job, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken over the weekend.
The findings suggest that Americans may be willing to look beyond Mr. Clinton's personal troubles because they are generally satisfied with their lives and pleased with the economy. The President's handling of his job remains high at 56 percent, virtually unchanged from 58 percent in a Times/CBS News Poll in December. His ratings on the economy and foreign policy are the highest of his Presidency. 
 But one disquieting sign for Mr. Clinton is that people are now less likely than they once were to say that he shares the moral values that most Americans try to live by. Forty percent of the respondents said he shares those values, compared with 55 percent in October 1996, just weeks before he was re-elected. Twenty-six percent said Mr. Clinton had more honesty and integrity than most politicians, 30 percent less and 37 percent about the same.
Women have long been more supportive of Mr. Clinton than have men, and they remain more likely to approve of his job performance than men do. In the poll of 943 adults, they also judged the President somewhat less harshly than men did on the accusations about his involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern. That may be because women are more inclined to identify with Mr. Clinton on policy than to focus on his personal life.
Despite the President's robust ratings on issues and job performance, most Americans fear that the scandal will interfere with his future ability to perform his job effectively.
For most people, the troubling dimension was not as much that Mr. Clinton may have had an affair or that he may have been involved with a young intern, but that there may have been a cover-up of his association with Ms. Lewinsky and that the affair may have taken place in the White House.
The Clinton White House has long paid close attention to polls, and indeed, one it had taken in recent days showed a significant decline in favorable attitudes about the President. Other, public surveys have recorded strong disapproval of his alleged liaison with Ms. Lewinsky.
But the Times/CBS News Poll is the first public poll to give a hard look at whether the accusations have affected the President's standing on matters facing the nation. Most striking is that on issue after issue, Mr. Clinton's ratings have climbed sharply in the past two years -- and have not been eroded by the recent but relentless debate over his alleged involvement with the former intern.
Mr. Clinton has said he keeps the personal accusations against him "in a little box" that is separate from his Presidential duties. The American people appear to be doing the same thing.
If it turns out that the President encouraged Ms. Lewinsky to lie, there is far from a consensus that he should resign. Thirty-one percent of Americans say that if the accusations are true, Mr. Clinton should admit it and apologize; 30 percent said he should resign, 18 percent said Congress should begin impeachment proceedings and 16 percent said the entire matter should be dropped. The survey, conducted on Saturday and Sunday, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Public opinion is still plainly in a formative stage. Even though Americans have been inundated with television, radio, newspaper, magazine and Internet reports about the scandal, the full ramifications of the disclosures that began last Wednesday have not sunk in. Many people are reserving judgment about whether Mr. Clinton encouraged Ms. Lewinsky to lie under oath.
"If the allegations are true, I feel that is wrong," Kathy Edwards, a 45-year-old nurse from Ionia, Mich., said in a typical follow-up interview. "But without that information, I believe he is doing right by the country right now. I feel he's done a good job in pulling the country together. Economically, I'm better off than I was five years ago, improvements have been made in education and health care -- and I feel pretty good about where the country is right now."
The percentage who said Mr. Clinton had made progress in significantly reducing the budget deficit has more than doubled, to 63 percent, since January 1996. And 61 percent think the President has significantly improved the economy, up from 35 percent from two years ago. And in the past four years the proportion of Americans who are willing to give him credit on welfare and crime has more than doubled.
While Mr. Clinton is expected to highlight those accomplishments in his State of the Union Message tonight, he will also stand before an American public that views the accusations against him as potentially crippling. Forty-one percent of the respondents said the crisis is of great importance to the nation, although overwhelmingly, Americans said it was unfair to compare Mr. Clinton's problems with those of President Richard M. Nixon in the 1972-74 Watergate scandal.
"I don't feel that this womanizing issue is corruption on the level of Watergate," said one poll respondent, Patricia McGuire, a retired social worker from Covington, Ga. "But I do feel that because he's President, he may feel he can cover up what he does, as other people are not able to do." Yet Ms. McGuire, 59, credited Mr. Clinton for having "advanced programs that have helped us, such as health care reform and welfare."
As for the particulars, 42 percent of Americans said the President probably did have an affair with Ms. Lewinsky, 20 percent said he probably did not and 34 percent said they did not know enough to say.
Even more, 40 percent, said they did not have enough information to assess whether Mr. Clinton encouraged Ms. Lewinsky to lie under oath. Thirty-two percent said he probably did and 25 percent said he probably did not.
The poll suggests that it should be no surprise that the White House has started a campaign to discredit Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel. Half of the people said Mr. Clinton's political enemies were more responsible for the crisis than he, while two-fifths blamed the President. On another question, almost half said Mr. Starr was conducting a partisan investigation that was intended to damage the President. Only 3 in 10 said he was impartial.
While the White House is beleaguered, the two people who rallied around Mr. Clinton at a child-care event yesterday have not been tarnished. Vice President Al Gore's favorable rating stands at 35 percent, up from 19 percent in December. Hillary Rodham Clinton's favorable rating is 45 percent, an increase from 39 percent in December.
Women like Mrs. Clinton more than men: 49 percent of women said they had a favorable view, while 39 percent of men did.
One explanation for Mr. Clinton's enduring popularity is that since he has been President, the public has viewed the road ahead more positively than the road behind. Forty percent of Americans said that in general, things were better now than they were five years ago; 38 percent said they were worse and 18 percent said they were the same. When those same questions were asked in the waning days of the Bush Administration, only 12 percent said they thought things were better and 73 percent said worse.
One respondent, Joe Starr, a journalist from Albuquerque, N.M., said in a follow-up interview that given Mr. Clinton's accomplishments on the issues, it was not appropriate to dwell on his private life.
"A person like the President, who is an all-purpose public figure, still has their own life, and what goes on behind closed doors is their own business," said Mr. Starr, 28. "How he conducts his business as leader of our country is a totally different point. He seems to be taking care of business with welfare reform, for example, cleaning up the mess that's been around for quite a few years."
On education, an issue that Mr. Clinton is expected to highlight in the State of the Union Message, 50 percent of Americans said he had made improvements. The public was divided on race relations; 47 percent said the President had improved things significantly and 46 percent said he had not.
Two areas of weakness in the poll for Mr. Clinton are health insurance and crime. Only 34 percent said he had made progress in insuring all Americans, a figure that has not changed from 1994, when his proposed overhaul of the health care system collapsed.
On crime, only 37 percent said he had improved matters. But that is an increase from 16 percent in 1994.
The poll also found that the public's view of how Congress is handling its job stands at 47 percent, up from 33 percent in December.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich's popularity stands at 23 percent favorable and 39 percent unfavorable.
In their responses to several questions, women were particularly cautious in judging Mr. Clinton's culpability in the Lewinsky matter. Among women, 45 percent said they did not know enough to say whether Mr. Clinton encouraged Ms. Lewinsky to lie under oath, compared with 35 percent for men. Twenty-eight percent of women said this accusation was probably true; 36 percent of men said the same thing.
Sixty-five percent of Americans said the news media had spent too much time covering the allegations swirling around Mr. Clinton, while 27 percent said it had been the right amount. But 62 percent said the media had done a good job in the coverage, compared with 29 percent who said they had not done a good job.
Yet the public may be reaching its collective saturation level. Sixty-two percent of Americans said they were sick and tired of all the coverage.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday and Sunday with 943 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for self-identified Democrats, Republicans or independents taken as a group, it is plus or minus six percentage points.
For the question that asked respondents to rate on a scale of 1 to 10 the way things are going in the United States at the present time, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 0.13; that is, in 19 cases out of 20, a mean rating of 5.84 on that scale would be no lower than 5.71 and no higher than 5.97.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Gov. Wilson's High Energy and Low Prospects

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Pete Wilson may have begun his last year as Governor of California, but he is not going gentle into the night. He still thinks nothing of staying up until the wee hours poring over a speech. His idea of relaxation is still a late-night workout on the Gravitron machine in his garage. His antidote to frustration is still deeper immersion in policy details.
But Mr. Wilson's days are numbered by the California law limiting elected officials to two terms, which voters passed when they elected him eight years ago. Mr. Wilson supported its passage -- and he now makes no secret of his sorrow. 
 "I regret that I have but 11 months more to give to this job, because I'm enjoying it," Mr. Wilson said in a recent hourlong interview in his office here. The truth is that Mr. Wilson, who is 64 and entering his 32d consecutive year in elective office, is all dressed up with no clear place to go politically.
His state is again comparatively flush after a grueling recession and he has money to spend on long-deferred priorities from education to public works. His job-approval ratings are at or near the highest they have been since just after he took office, and he holds sway over a Democratic-controlled Legislature whose leadership has itself been weakened by the turnover brought on by term-limits. He is sponsoring ambitious proposals for the November ballot to restructure education and fight juvenile crime.
"For the next 11 months," Mr. Wilson said, "I intend to make the same kind of full-court press, trying to achieve as much as we can, understanding that this job is endless. I mean, you're part of a continuum."
There is a glittering grail, of course, and it is represented by the picture of a tanned and smiling man that hangs over the Governor's shoulder in the cabinet room of the first-floor suite of offices known as the horseshoe for its U-shaped corridors: "In honor of the first California Governor elected President of the United States," reads the plaque on the portrait of Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Wilson would clearly like to be the second.
"If the question pointedly was, 'Are you going to run,' you know, I would love to," said Mr. Wilson of the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000.
His brief bid for the nomination of 1996 collapsed spectacularly for lack of money and support, amid false rumors that surgery for a benign growth on his vocal chord that left him unable to speak in public for several weeks meant he had cancer.
"If you can't speak for three and a half months, you can't run," said Mr. Wilson, whose reedy Johnny Carson voice still occasionally cracks without warning on consonants. "They were saying, 'Gee, isn't it a shame about poor Pete. Throat cancer. He's going to have to drop out of the race.' The rumors were false, but they were effective."
Now, Mr. Wilson said of a possible Presidential campaign: "I'm going to be realistic. If I can find the money, why I'd say the chances are pretty good that I might. But that remains a huge question mark. It is an immense undertaking, that much I can tell you."
Among Mr. Wilson's friends and enemies alike, there is little doubt that he wants to run again. There is equally little doubt that the Governor thinks such a candidacy is a better idea than almost anyone else.
For starters, there is his political persona, which can sometimes seem both dour and phlegmatic, the result of what even one of his Republican allies in the State Senate calls "a charisma bypass." There is also his firm support for abortion rights, which makes him poison to much of the conservative electorate. The issue dominates Republican primaries and his position left him with only the most token role at the Republican Convention in his own home town, San Diego, in 1996. There is his alienation of black and Hispanic voters over his strong stands against illegal immigration and affirmative action.
And finally, there is no certainty he could even carry the electoral powerhouse that is California, which has always been the principal rationale for any national candidacy. Although his support has edged upward over the last year, he remains far from popular in the state. A survey by the Field Institute late last year found that he is still viewed unfavorably by 57 percent of registered voters in his state, just a bit behind Dan Quayle and Newt Gingrich among a field of nine potential Republican contenders for the 2000 nomination.
"A year from now, he'll be driving his own car," said Bob Mulholland, the tart-tongued spokesman for the California Democratic Party, "and he'll be the loneliest ex-governor in the history of California. He's been in politics his whole adult life, and he has no real friends -- and when he gets out of office, he'll find that out."
Mr. Wilson does lead a remarkably solitary life, and his administration has some of the earmarks of an organization running out the clock. His longtime chief of staff and confidant of nearly 30 years, Bob White, resigned last year to become a consultant. On the personal side, he has no children of his own, though his second wife, Gayle, has grown children. He is not a fixture on the social circuit in a state that includes the world's glamour capital. His indulgences include an occasional cigar and a nightly cocktail and reading history, especially about the Civil War. A former marine, he is intensely disciplined and for years ate an unvarying lunch of plain cooked salmon and steamed vegetables, though aides say he has branched out a bit culinarily.
Personable and relaxed one-on-one, peppering his conversation with an occasional "Oh, hell," he is not a great public speaker or glad-hander. For most of his tenure, he has been forced to preside over the worst economic disaster in California since the Great Depression, and has had to make many unpopular decisions, including raising taxes in his first year in office.
Still, for all his deficits, were it not for his support of abortion rights, most politicians agree that Mr. Wilson would be at the top of the list of Republican contenders for the Presidency -- his poor 1996 showing notwithstanding -- instead of somewhere down among the also-mentioned.
"My own view is that this issue shouldn't be allowed to split the Republican Party," Mr. Wilson said. "Or stand in the way of our appealing to a broad middle ground of Americans regardless of their registration, on the issues on which we are united."
In particular, Mr. Wilson contended, the longstanding Republican platform plank in support of a constitutional amendment banning abortion "has given great aid and comfort to the enemy and not done very much for Republicans."
"The basic purpose of that plank, I think very clearly, is to try to prevent abortions," he added, "and to reduce the number of abortions that are performed in America. I am appalled at the number. I am also convinced that that plank is never going to prevent one, because it advocates a constitutional amendment that I am convinced will never be adopted."
Instead, Mr. Wilson said, candidates who are serious about reducing abortions "have to be determined to change the culture" by supporting mentoring programs for teen-agers to encourage them not to become pregnant out of wedlock.
Mr. Wilson, a former Mayor of San Diego, made one failed run for governor, in 1978, before winning two terms in the United States Senate and then beating out Dianne Feinstein, now a Senator from California, for the governorship in 1990. He is widely credited with learning from that experience, and he insists the lessons of 1996 are not lost on him.
"It is very, very difficult, if not impossible, to be the Governor of a large, complex state and do an adequate job of campaigning," Mr. Wilson said, "because the demands of the office that you're holding as Governor are so great, in terms of consuming time and attention."
That would not be an issue this time.
For now, Mr. Wilson said, it is too early to talk seriously about such options, or other post-Sacramento employment, from being involved in business to running a research group. He said he expected to make appearances around the country this year, and to help Republican candidates from other states raise money in California and work to elect Dan Lungren, the current State Attorney General, as governor this year. Mr. Lungren is the all-but-certain Republican nominee.
"I think until the car drags him away from Sacramento one year from now," said Ken Kachigian, one of California's leading Republican consultants and a longtime Wilson friend, "he's going to be appointing judges, issuing executive orders and probably trying to squeeze one last item out of the budget for the next governor. He has a lot of zest for this."

HEADLINE: Dollar's Rise Is Cited as 3M Profit Falls 5%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that profit fell 5 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt by the dollar's strength.
The company, a diversified manufacturer, said the dollar's rise had reduced earnings by an estimated 11 cents a share, or 12 percent. Earnings at many United States companies have been eaten into as the amount of dollars produced by sales denominated in foreign currencies has declined. 
 "I don't view this as a major disappointment," Jack Kelly, industry analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said about 3M's results.
Earnings in the latest quarter declined to $366 million, or 89 cents a diluted share, from $385 million, or 91 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. The 1996 period included a one-time gain of $10 million related to a discontinued operation.
Analysts had expected earnings of about 91 cents a share. Today, the company's stock fell $1.4375 a share, to $80.5625.
The company said sales rose 2.5 percent, to $3.71 billion from $3.62 billion. Excluding currency changes, the increase was more than 8 percent. Sales volume increased 12 percent internationally and 4 percent in the United States, or 8 percent after adjustment for the divestiture of 3M's outdoor advertising business.
As the year gets under way, 3M said it expected to feel the impact of slower world economic growth as well as the strong dollar.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Boeing Posts $498 Million Quarter Loss

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, still feeling financial pain from difficulties producing commercial aircraft and last year's merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $498 million yesterday, leading to its first annual loss in half a century.
Much of the quarterly loss, equivalent to 51 cents a diluted share, reflected a previously announced $1.4 billion charge related to the merger. But Boeing's operating earnings also came in below Wall Street estimates. 
 Excluding the charge, the company said it earned $290 million, or 29 cents a share, in last year's final quarter, compared with $528 million, or 53 cents a share, in 1996. Revenues grew to $11.7 billion, from $10 billion a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S., a firm that tracks corporate earnings, predicted earnings of 32 cents a share. For the year, Boeing lost $178 million, or 18 cents a share, on $45.8 billion in revenues
Given the financial news from Boeing in the last four months -- $4 billion in charges against earnings -- yesterday's announcement was greeted optimistically by investors. Boeing stock rose 56.25 cents, closing at $45 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Investor expectations have been lowered," said Howard A. Rubel, an aerospace analyst at Goldman, Sachs, & Company in New York. "For any other world-class company this would have been a disappointing quarter."
Boeing stock rose as high as $60.50 a share in July because the booming global airline industry had deluged it with orders. But the company stumbled as it tried to raise production to 43 planes a month from 18 in 1996. Production fell behind schedule because of parts shortages and inexperienced workers, causing the company to take a $1.6 billion charge in last year's third quarter. An additional $1 billion in charges because of the production problems will be deducted from earnings this year. As a result, the profit margin of Boeing's commercial airplane division -- which has only one real competitor, the European consortium Airbus Industrie -- was just 3 percent last year.
"Clearly, the only thing you can say is it seems the opportunity for improvement is substantial," said Wolfgang Demisch, an aerospace analyst with BT Alex Brown in New York.
Speaking to reporters yesterday, Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said the company had made significant progress resolving the production difficulties and expected to deliver 550 planes this year and next compared with 374 in 1997. The increase is expected to raise Boeing's 1998 revenues 20 percent, to $55 billion.
The company also said the economic crisis in Asia, where it expects to deliver 20 percent of its planes over the next three years, would have only a limited impact. Based on revised economic growth forecasts for the region, Boeing predicted Asia would require 60 fewer planes over the next three years than previously estimated. But Harry S. Stonecipher, Boeing's president, said those planes would simply be sold to carriers elsewhere. "We still believe the region will recover quickly and remain the fastest-growing market for air travel," he said. 
Some analysts were not so sure. Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said he believes Boeing will probably sell between 460 and 475 planes this year and closer to 440 to 450 in 1999. Moreover, he said, most of those lost sales will be wide-body planes like the 747 and 777, which are Boeing's most profitable.
The Boeing executives disputed such projections. They said demand was so great for the 747 that they could not fill a new order until the middle of the year 2000.
"If Asia gets stabilized, their perspective is the right one," Mr. Demisch said. "If Asia gets to be very contagious internationally, then their forecast is just flat out wrong."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Gillette, long a favorite of investors, finds itself walking an edge as thin as one of its razor blades.

BYLINE: By Dana Canedy 

 BODY:
THE Gillette Company may nick investor enthusiasm in coming months.
Despite a long string of earnings gains that has made it a stock market favorite, Gillette has hit a rough patch. Its stock is languishing from its high of $106.375 in July 1997. Its domestic sales have been flat. And much is riding on a new shaving system about which little is known. 
 Anyone buying Gillette stock will also be going against the grain of the company's second-largest investor, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. Kohlberg Kravis has filed a registration to sell a third of its Gillette shares. That portion would be worth about $1.18 billion at yesterday's price.
Hanging on to Gillette means taking on more than average market risk. While Gillette's stock rose 29 percent last year -- roughly in line with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- its shares carry a substantial premium. Gillette's stock, which closed at $102.25 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, is trading at about 34 times 1998 earnings, compared with 21 times for the S.& P. 500.
Management must hit all of the right buttons for the stock to maintain that lofty level.
When a stock is trading at that large of a multiple, "you run the risk if there is a disappointment that it can tend to be more volatile on the down side," said Rose Papp, co-manager of the Papp American Abroad mutual fund, which owns a small stake in Gillette.
After posting $9.6 billion in 1996 revenue, Gillette disappointed investors in August by saying that it would not meet earnings estimates for the full year. Stock analysts then reduced their earnings estimate by 5 cents, to $2.55 a share, and sent the stock tumbling, although it has since recovered. The stock rose $2.1875 yesterday ahead of its earnings announcement.
Among the company's problems is the Braun appliance division, especially its electric shavers, which have high profit margins. Weak economies in Japan and Germany contributed to a slight decline in Braun sales in 1997. While Asia accounts for less than 5 percent of Gillette's sales, the economic downturn there threatens to further slow sales. Over all, Gillette now gets about 70 percent of its revenue from abroad. The company says it hedges against currency risk, making a slump in sales more of an issue than currency fluctuations.
Compounding the trouble caused by foreign economic conditions, revenue in Gillette's largest category, blades and razors, has been flat for most of the year. Shaving products account for 29 percent of sales and 52 percent of operating profits.
For the first nine months of 1997, sales rose 3 percent compared with the period a year earlier, although unfavorable exchange rates depressed revenue by 3 percent. Profits rose 14 percent, in part because of greater operating efficiency, like a 2 percent reduction in advertising.
Gillette expects its new shaving system to generate sales and to help the company sustain profit levels. Its last large-scale introduction was of the popular Sensor line about eight years ago. The new product "delivers shaving performance far superior to any blade product now on the market," the company says.
As is often the case, management has closely guarded details about the product, including its name and the technology that makes it so special, with an eye toward the publicity that will accompany its introduction. Even some of the company's biggest fans are a bit nervous about what will happen if the new shaver is not an immediate hit when it lands on store shelves in July.
"You can't afford to be a high multiple stock and not deliver," said Drake Craig, a portfolio manager for the Calvert Managed Growth fund, which has a sizable position in Gillette. "Whenever you have a big event like this, you're concerned about whether or not they can meet expectations," added Mr. Craig, who is nonetheless bullish on Gillette because of its stability and the growth prospects for Duracell batteries.
Some fund managers and stock analysts have also expressed concern about Gillette's timing. They say they expected the shaver to arrive sooner because the company has been saying for more than a year that it is paring inventory in preparation for the rollout. They wonder whether Gillette needed until summer to reduce an inflated inventory.
Gillette says the inventory reduction was always meant to be gradual. "We never said anything previously about the time, and we are on schedule," said Steve Brayton, a company spokesman.
Investors may also be worried about the message Kohlberg Kravis is sending. The buyout firm, after all, is known for taking large positions in companies as a stock is gaining momentum and selling just before it loses steam.
Kohlberg Kravis owned 34 percent of Duracell, which Gillette acquired just more than a year ago for $8.5 billion, and received Gillette shares in that transaction. It held on to its 37.2 million shares as Gillette's stock price soared but has recently asked to register for sale of up to 11.5 million shares. Any sale will depend on several factors, including the price, Kohlberg Kravis said.
Both Kohlberg Kravis and Gillette said that the proposed sale did not signal a concern about Gillette's prospects. Mr. Brayton noted that Kohlberg Kravis would retain more than two-thirds of its stake in the company and that Henry R. Kravis, its general partner, would remain on Gillette's board.
"The company has been advised by K.K.R. that the proposed sale by its affiliated investment partnerships of Gillette stock is designed to provide liquidity for the investment partnerships and does not reflect any change in the view of K.K.R. toward the company's stock," Mr. Brayton said.
Of course, many investors remain enamored of the company's stock. Gillette has achieved earnings growth of 18 percent for the five years ended in 1996. The company has also smartly diversified, most recently with Duracell. But if worldwide sales of razors ebb and the new shaving system does not generate enthusiasm in the United States, Gillette may lose its well-known edge.

HEADLINE: More Prisons Limit Tobacco But See Little Early Trouble

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont., Jan. 21

 BODY:
It sounds like a recipe for trouble. Ban all forms of tobacco in a prison where 80 percent of the more than 1,200 inmates and half the guards smoke or chew tobacco.
But a week after the total ban started at the State Prison in Deer Lodge, officials said last week, there had been no trouble. 
 "It's a little early," said the warden, Mike Mahoney. "We probably don't have all of the tobacco out of the institution. As we do shakedowns and find stashes, we might start seeing more withdrawal."
Some inmates said tensions had increased.
"As with most addicts, the first day or two you cut them off it's O.K.," said Greg Jellison, who has been serving a sentence for robbery for 12 years. "But things are starting to get a little nasty. The guards are nitpicking."
Over several months, officials had gradually reduced the number of cigarettes that inmates could buy at the canteen. Starting on Jan. 1, no tobacco was sold, and inmates were supposed to turn in personal caches.
"We didn't provide any nicotine gum or nicotine patches," said a Corrections Department spokesman, Mike Cronin. "But we did provide counseling, and that seems to have kept trouble from brewing."
The prison physician, Dr. Robert D. Jones, said the prisoners could expect it to take six to eight weeks to overcome withdrawal symptoms.
The Montana ban is part of a national trend toward tobacco-free prisons. California, Florida, Maryland, Texas, Utah and Vermont are among the states with varying prohibitions on smoking in prison.
The primary reason, officials say, is economic. Because the justice system is handing down longer sentences and the prison population is growing larger and older, health costs are increasing.
Another factor is a growing number of inmates' suits against the authorities, contending that they had suffered from exposure to secondhand smoke.
But smoking continues in places, and some prison officials say money that inmates would have spent on illicit drugs is being used to buy tobacco, in effect creating a black market for cigarettes.
Banning cigarettes in prisons has not been easy. In Vermont, officials instituted a ban on all tobacco in 1992 and then partly rolled that back, allowing smoking outside.
"It's difficult for people who haven't been able to conform to the basic rules of society, with negative reinforcement, to give up something they're addicted to," said Michael O'Malley, Director of Security and Operations for the Vermont Corrections Department.
Vermont relented, Mr. O'Malley said, because prisoners "were picking up disciplinary reports and being put into higher levels of custody for essentially smoking in the boys' room."
"The largest number of people in maximum custody were there for smoking," Mr. O'Malley said.
Inmates can possess cigarettes, but not matches and lighters, which have to be kept outside.
Texas, which banned smoking in 1995, has stuck to a hard line with a complete ban.
That does not mean that the institutions are smoke free. Cigarettes are contraband, with a single cigarette selling for as much $5 and a couple of puffs for $1. Inmates smoke on the sly, with one prisoner standing next to an air vent while another watches for guards, in return for a few puffs.
Texas has had one disturbance over the policy. "It occurred over which gang would control tobacco," said a spokesman for the Criminal Justice Department, Larry Fitzgerald. "Tobacco has become very valuable."
Banning smoking also means that the prison workers have to comply. In Montana, around 200 employees at the prison, including guards, signed a petition against the smoking ban, concerned that it would threaten security.
Extending the ban to employees is "the only legitimate way to do it in this kind of environment," Mr. Mahoney said. "Staff will need to be counseled and advised."
One inmate, Dennye Harris, predicted that there would be problems in a month or two. "That's when all the tobacco will be gone," Mr. Harris said. "There will be a lot more confrontations. Right now, when stress builds, people walk away and have a cigarette as a way of calming down. I was addicted to PCP, and kicking PCP was nothing compared to cigarettes."
Mr. Harris, who has been an inmate for 12 years, said he quit smoking four months ago.
Some inmates said they were nervous about the potential effects of the ban.
"Inmates are talking about having sitdowns," said Mr. Jellison, who added that he did not smoke.
"Most people get killed in this prison over stupid things," he said. "It would be a real shame if someone lost their life over a cigarette."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford Reports 4th-Quarter Earnings Surge

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Buoyed by cost reductions and strong sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles, the Ford Motor Company reported today that it earned $1.8 billion in the fourth quarter, up 49.2 percent from a year earlier and surprising Wall Street analysts, who had expected a smaller gain.
Ford also posted record profits of $6.92 billion for 1997, up 55.6 percent from 1996, while sales rose 4.5 percent last year to $153.63 billion. Ford's profits last year were among the highest ever for any American company. Ford earned $1.45 a share in the fourth quarter and $5.62 a share for the year. 
 The company's stock rose $1.625 today to close at $49.875.
"It was a very impressive quarter and year for Ford," said Scott Sprinzen, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency. "There had been cause earlier in the year for skepticism that they would make their targets."
Ford's automotive operations earned record profits of $4.71 billion last year, mainly because profits nearly doubled to $3.7 billion in the United States. But its financial operations were not quite as successful.
Profits at the Ford Motor Credit Company fell to $1.03 billion last year from $1.44 billion in 1996, as a result of cars coming off leases that could not be sold for as much as expected, car loans that could not be collected and higher taxes. John Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said in an interview this afternoon that Ford had set a target for the division to increase profits by 10 percent or more during 1998, and planned to continue its leasing activities at roughly the current level.
Economic turmoil in Asia had little direct effect on Ford because its operations there remain small. While Ford did not provide separate earnings figures for its operations in countries that have recently devalued their currencies, it did say that automotive operations outside Europe and the Americas showed a $99 million loss in the fourth quarter after a $112 million profit a year earlier.
With the dollar rising against Asian currencies, which makes it cheaper to import cars and car parts to the United States, the American auto market is likely to become even more competitive in 1998, Mr. Devine said. Partly as a result, Ford will try to cut another $1 billion from its costs this year.
"We're going to see pricing pressures as far in the future as we can see," Mr. Devine said.
Ford said that by redesigning manufacturing processes, simplifying automobile designs, paying less to auto parts suppliers and taking other steps, it was able to reduce its costs by $3 billion. While estimates of cost savings are often controversial, Ford officials pointed out that they were able to manufacture and sell 290,000 more cars and trucks last year than in 1996, while keeping total costs virtually unchanged. Ford controlled costs despite making bigger, more expensive vehicles, as it phased out production of several cars while stepping up production of Ford Expedition full-size sport utility vehicles and introducing its sibling, the Lincoln Navigator.
Mr. Devine said that while cost reductions were the biggest reason for profit gains, a shift in sales toward more profitable models also helped, particularly rising sales of sport utility vehicles in North America. Jack Kirnan, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, estimated that Ford earned at least $12,000 apiece before taxes on the 241,000 Expeditions and Navigators it sold last year, for a total contribution to after-tax profits of about $2 billion. The Ford Explorer, Mercury Mountaineer and F-Series pickup trucks also contributed substantially to Ford's profits, Mr. Kirnan added.
Mr. Sprinzen said that Ford might be too dependent now on these light- truck sales in the United States. "In terms of profitability, Ford is very much a North American light-truck company," he said.
Mr. Devine strongly disagreed, saying that Ford's small cars have been very successful lately in Europe and South America. Ford's European operations earned $273 million last year and $158 million just in the fourth quarter, compared with a $291 million loss in 1996 and an $88 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1996.
Ford's South American operations earned $40 million last year, an abrupt turnaround after a $642 million loss the previous year. Ford has introduced several new small-car models there, after a joint venture with Volkswagen broke up three years ago and left Ford stuck with mostly larger, slow-selling cars. But the profits last year in South America came despite a $71 million loss in the fourth quarter, as Brazil in particular was forced to raise interest rates steeply, protecting its currency from a sharp devaluation but severely crimping car sales in the process.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Solid Corporate Profit Reports Help Push Share Prices Higher

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices soared yesterday after several blue-chip companies reported solid fourth-quarter earnings, ending a streak of disappointing results.
The winners were the bluest of the blue chips: the Walt Disney Company, Ford Motor and Merck. In the fourth quarter, these three companies alone had profits of more than $3.8 billion -- a boon to what for weeks had been a dreary stock market. Their stocks all rose in response. 
 "Investors went back to the tried and true blue chips," said Robert Freedman, the chief investment strategist at John Hancock Funds in Boston. "We had three companies that beat forecasts and we still have a strong economy."
The resulting gain in share prices yesterday helped lift a market that had been troubled by everything from an economic crisis in Asia to allegations of a sex scandal at the White House.
Just after the opening bell, the Dow Jones industrial average began its ascent. The Dow was up by as much as 130 points late in the day, before closing up 102.14 points, or 1.32 percent, at 7,815.08.
Broader indexes also fared well. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.07 points, or 1.26 percent, to 969.02. And the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index jumped 17.44 points, or 1.12 percent, to 1,578.90.
Robert J. Froehlich, chief investment strategist at the Kemper Funds in Chicago, said the market needed a lift, and investors had been preoccupied with other matters.
"This was a psychological rally," Mr. Froehlich said. "We're finally looking at the fundamentals of this earnings season and not the sex scandal in Washington."
Although the earnings released yesterday were just slightly higher than analysts' estimates, Wall Street strategists said they came at a time when investors were desperate for good news.
Indeed, the fourth-quarter earnings season has been rather lackluster, particularly when compared with the last several quarters.
As of midday yesterday, more than half the companies listed in the S.& P. 500 had reported, with about 49 percent reporting better-than-expected results, according to I.B.E.S. International, which tracks corporate earnings.
In the previous three quarters, between 58 and 65 percent had beaten analysts' estimates.
"This is the slowest growth quarter since 1996," said Joseph Abbott, a research manager at I.B.E.S. "It's not awful. It's decent growth, but there are worries about next quarter."
Because of that weakness, share prices have been largely flat to down this year. While the Dow is down by about 1.2 percent, the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks is about 3.3 percent lower.
The concerns are clear. After three years of spectacular growth, investors are worried that an economic and financial crisis in Asia will damp corporate growth in the United States and force some companies to cut prices to compete with cheaper Asian goods -- meaning even slimmer profits.
There are those on Wall Street who believe that the crisis in Asia will disrupt the bull market here, but most say it will simply mean smaller profits and therefore weaker stock prices.
The growing consensus on Wall Street is that corporate profits will grow by about 5 to 8 percent next year, down from about 11 percent this year. And that should mean more modest stock gains.
Despite those worries, investors are buying up shares of many of the companies that make up the "nifty 50," like Xerox and AT&T, as well as the blue-chip technology companies.
Shares of Intel and Microsoft -- the twin towers of the high-technology world -- are up about 13 percent already this year, and Dell Computer, Compaq and Lucent Technologies are also soaring.
Yesterday, though, share prices may have been aided by weakness in the bond market, which slipped on inflation worries tied to a Government report that labor costs increased sharply in the fourth quarter.
That same report -- which could mean higher costs for United States companies, and therefore thinner profit margins, was ignored by the stock market. But analysts say it is a concern.
 "This is a red flag to everyone," Mr. Froehlich at Kemper said. "There is no way our economy can grow as fast as we did last year. So anything that is going to cost more for corporate America is going to be bad news."

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Positions Slightly Lower on Nasdaq

 BODY:
Investors seem to have begun the year with a little more optimism.
After reaching a record 1.79 billion shares in December, open positions on short sales on the Nasdaq stock market declined slightly, to 1.77 billion shares, as of mid-January, according to figures released yesterday by the market. 
 The latest figures reflect trades reported through Jan. 12 and settled as of Jan. 15. In a short sale, an investor sells borrowed shares in the hopes of repurchasing them later at lower prices.
The Oracle Corporation, one of the technology companies to suffer from the economic turmoil in Asia, showed the largest increase. Its short position climbed by more than 5 million shares, to 14.7 million. The shares of the data base software company, which fell sharply last month when it reported disappointing earnings, closed yesterday at $19. Its stock had reached a high of $42.125 last August.
Phycor Inc., a physician-practice management company whose plan to buy one of its competitors, Medpartners, fell apart earlier this month, had the largest decrease. Its short position fell by nearly 9 million shares, to 6.7 million.
While high short-interest positions are typically seen as a sign of bearish sentiment, they can also result from complex hedging and trading strategies involving options futures and other stock-related derivatives.
