LENGTH: 365 words

HEADLINE: Carole Kent Kneeland, 49, Minimized Crime in TV News

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

 BODY:
Carole Kent Kneeland, vice president for news at KVUE-TV in Austin, Tex., and one of the first television news directors to de-emphasize sensational crime and introduce "truth tests" in news reports about political advertising, died on Monday at her home in Austin. She was 49.
She died of breast cancer, family members said. 
 Ms. Kneeland's Austin station, a Gannett-owned ABC affiliate, attracted considerable attention two years ago when it instituted "community standards" guidelines for deciding when to broadcast a story about a local crime. Under the policy, a crime story is broadcast only if news executives can answer "yes" to such questions as: Is there an immediate threat to public safety? Is there a significant community impact? Do viewers need to take some kind of action?
The approach has been adopted by several stations around the nation with varying results. At KVUE, the station has maintained its top ratings position for news in the Austin area in most ratings sweeps.
The policy developed by Ms. Kneeland and Cathy McFeaters, who is now news director, is not without critics, and at least one competitor has derided the station for "filtering its news." Under the policy, for instance, the station declined to broadcast a story about three drifters who shot and killed one another after a night of heavy drinking.
But Ms. Kneeland strongly defended the decision. "We are asking, 'Why do I care?' about stories concerning money, or the raising and lowering of interest rates, and other subjects," she complained in a 1996 interview. "But for crime stories, we only asked, 'Are the pictures good, and can we go live?' "
In 1990 she initiated a "truth test" format for political advertising, in which the station would prepare news reports analyzing candidates' claims in such ads.
A native of Salem, Ore., she was a graduate of the University of Washington.
She is survived by her husband, Dave McNeely, political columnist for the Austin American-Statesman; her parents, Sandy and Lorrainne Kent of Austin; two stepdaughters, Michelle Mueller of Houston and Candace McGriffy of Austin; and a brother, Gale Kent of Littleton, Colo.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A Mayor's Prerogative: Rethinking the City's Street Furniture

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Talk about waiting for a furniture delivery.
It seemed until yesterday that city officials were close to granting a 20-year citywide franchise to a single company for thousands of pieces of "street furniture" -- bus-stop shelters, newsstands and public pay toilets -- displaying $1 billion worth of advertising. Then Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he was taking another look at the whole idea. 
 "Is there a better and more competitive way to do it?" the Mayor asked. For example, he said, should there be a single contract or several smaller ones? Should it cover the entire city or be broken into boroughs? Should it include all street furniture or be divided into different types of fixtures?
"We haven't made a decision yet," Mr. Giuliani said. Instead, the matter will be reviewed by Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, planning and administration.
The Mayor's remarks at a morning news conference clearly caught off guard the four prospective contractors, three of which are subsidiaries of large European concerns.
Under a comprehensive franchise, one of these companies would build, maintain and operate at least 3,300 shelters, 430 newsstands and 30 public toilets. Advertising panels on these structures would generate revenue of $1 billion or more over the life of the contract, some of which would cover capital expenses and some of which would be paid to the city.
The comprehensive plan has been in the works since 1995, but lost its chief champion at City Hall last February when Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter became Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager.
The comprehensive approach had not been without critics, who feared a blizzard of advertising on city streets, wondered whether City Hall was playing favorites among bidders and doubted whether any company could effectively perform such a sweeping contract for two decades. There was also speculation that Mr. Levine was not especially eager to advance projects initiated by his predecessor, Ms. Reiter.
But Mayor Giuliani said the administration's reconsideration could be traced back "about six months ago when I started thinking that we never had this single plan for the City of New York."
"I think one of the great values of New York City is that it is not planned," the Mayor said. "We have never tried to impose on New York City one idea, one thought, one plan. We don't have the commissar of planning for the city and everything must look the same way."
"Washington, D.C., is a planned city," he said. "It's a beautiful city. But New York City is more famous than Washington, D.C. It is. People come to New York more. And people know New York more all over the world."
The City Council authorized a comprehensive franchise in 1996. Walter L. McCaffrey, the Queens Democrat who heads the Council's zoning and franchises subcommittee, said that the Giuliani administration's new tack would be scrutinized at a hearing on Feb. 10.
"This is such a radical change as to really raise the question of whether New Yorkers are going to get the benefits of an improved type of street furniture," Mr. McCaffrey said yesterday.
The four bidders are Adshel Inc., a division of the More Group P.L.C. of London; JCDecaux New York, a subsidiary of the United States subsidiary of JCDecaux of Paris; Transportation Displays Inc. (TDI), a division of CBS and Wall City Design Inc., which is a subsidiary of Wall Verkehrsanlagen GmbH of Berlin.
After responding to a request for proposals issued last spring by the Giuliani administration, they made follow-up presentations to city officials last month and responded to written inquiries as recently as two weeks ago.
Before yesterday's mayoral news conference, company representatives had expressed doubts about an article that appeared Saturday in The New York Post saying that a change of course might be at hand. Yesterday, they sought to put the best face on this unexpected twist.
"I think it's appropriate for the city to take a second, even a third look," said Douglas E. Watts, president of Wall's United States subsidiary. "I would suggest that they will come to the conclusion that the comprehensive approach is the best. They will also discover, as far as Wall City is concerned, that nobody is offering a cookie-cutter approach."
William M. Apfelbaum, president and chief executive of TDI, said: "I'm glad that the Mayor is looking at it. It's the biggest contract of its kind in the world. I frankly believe that prudence makes sense."
"At the end of the day, it's advertising that makes the whole system work," he said. "To get new shelters, you have to have advertising. To get toilets, you have to have advertising."
A spokesman for Decaux, Martin McLaughlin, said, "No contract has gotten as much scrutiny and evaluation as this one."
"Our approach was to give the city the most diversified program it could possibly have, with different looks for different neighborhoods," he said, adding that Decaux had submitted designs from seven architects in its bid.
None of the prospective contractors have released renderings of models of their proposals.
Currently, the 2,500 or so bus-stop shelters citywide are operated and maintained by Outdoor Systems Advertising of Phoenix. Chris Carr, the general manager of New York operations, said the company "would very much like to continue to operate the bus-stop shelter system."
The recent history of street furniture in New York City has been a troubled one. Efforts during the last eight years to introduce public pay toilets have foundered, although Decaux temporarily installed six prototypes in 1992 and Wall maintains a demonstration model near City Hall.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Tumble on a Report Showing Rising Labor Costs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Labor costs rose at the fastest pace in five years in the last quarter of 1997, bringing the annual increase in total compensation to 3.3 percent. The news, which immediately raised some inflationary fears, was enough to send bond prices sharply lower.
But the stock market seemed to ignore the report, although many economists say higher compensation would lead to lower earnings as many companies swallow the added costs because competition, especially from Asia, would prevent them from raising prices. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 102.14 points, to 7,815.08. 
 "It poses a challenge to both earnings and inflation expectations," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, who, unlike many other economists, is forecasting that the recent wage increases will give inflation an unexpected lift this year.
The Employee Cost Index, which measures increases in wages, salaries and costs for employee benefits of private and state and local government workers, rose 1 percent in the fourth quarter, up from an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous two quarters. Wages and salaries were up 1.1 percent, the largest increase in seven and a half years, while the cost of benefits rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since the third quarter of 1994.
The Department of Labor data seemed to confirm what many economists had been waiting to see: an increase in wages and salaries from the tightening of the labor market with the unemployment rate under 5 percent for seven months last year.
Bond prices fell sharply after the release and recovered only somewhat during the rest of the day, which also saw the auction of a new two-year Treasury note. The 30-year bond's price fell 18/32, to 102 22/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 5.93 percent, from 5.89 percent on Monday.
Many economists on Wall Street had reasons for discounting the report, although some said the increase meant the Federal Reserve could not lower interest rates any time soon. The Fed's policy-making committee meets next week and Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, testifies before Congress tomorrow.
One discounting factor was that approximately one-tenth of the one percentage point increase in total compensation in the fourth quarter was attributable to a surge in commissions paid to people arranging or refinancing mortgages.
This business prospered at the end of the year as long-term interest rates fell and was considered a one-time impact. Without that extra one-tenth of a percentage point, the quarterly increase would have been nine-tenths of 1 percent, the figure most Wall Street analysts had forecast.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, added that without the added commissions for the mortgage business and Wall Street bonuses, the increase for 1997 would have been 3 percent, the same as 1996. "In the broader economy there is no increase," he said, adding that a much less ebullient Wall Street this year would bring bonuses down.
"If there is a problem out of this," Mr. Steinberg added, "it is earnings." Higher wages are "going to put pressure on margins and then on profits," he added. "There is no pricing power out there."
Wayne Shelly, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said most of the bonuses for 1997 were expected to show up in the data for the first quarter of 1998, which could give it a lift. The bureau's survey goes through the first two weeks of December so many bonuses have not yet been counted.
The bureau, Mr. Shelly said, does not calculate its own number for compensation that would exclude the bonuses and mortgage commissions in the category of finance, insurance and real estate, where total compensation for private workers rose 6.7 percent last year.
The other argument is that the economic collapse in Asia will slow the American economy enough to repress wage increases.
"The outlook is so befuddled by the Asian turmoil that the bigger risk going forward is for less growth and less inflation," said Neil M. Soss, chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. That slower growth, he added, would cap the rise in total compensation.
But he did say the index should be reflecting increases in health care costs in coming quarterly reports.
Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley is less sanguine. "When labor costs build up they do not disappear," he said. "They have to show up in higher prices or lower earnings."
In the bond market yesterday, a small rebound from the initial losses came after the Conference Board, a New York business research group, reported that its widely followed consumer confidence survey fell from a record high in January. The index dropped to 127.3 from 136.2. A fall in optimism about the near-term outlook because of the turmoil in Asia accounted for much of the overall decline in confidence, which however, still remains near record highs.
Traders said that yesterday's auction of $15 billion in new two-year notes was a little disappointing. The two-year note was awarded at the high yield of 5.44 percent, with noncompetitive bidding surprisingly strong and the highest since August. On the other hand, bidding was a little softer than expected.
Today the Government will auction $11 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday the securities were offered at a price to yield 5.53 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Partial Halt By Indonesia On Payments

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Wednesday, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Attacking one of its biggest economic challenges, Indonesia on Tuesday announced a "temporary pause" in payments on billions of dollars in private debt to overseas lenders, formalizing a halt on repayment that had already taken effect quietly among most corporations.
The move was cautiously welcomed by the United States, the International Monetary Fund and Asian financial analysts. All said they viewed it as a sign that Indonesia was finally grappling with its financial problems. 
 But fears remained that the Government might yet declare a formal debt moratorium if problems worsened, which would indefinitely delay payments on at least $65 billion that Indonesian companies owe foreign banks. That debt, denominated in dollars, has multiplied for the companies that earn income in rupiah, the Indonesian currency. The rupiah has plummeted in value by roughly 80 percent since July.
Over the last two months, most companies have simply stopped making debt payments. Some have paid in rupiah, but those payments are only a fraction of the amount due because of the currency's losses. As a result, overseas banks have virtually halted all new lending to Indonesia, slowing the flow of cash through the banking system and further hobbling economic activity as the nation heads into recession.
In Washington Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin endorsed the move, and other officials said it was the first step toward developing the rough equivalent of a bankruptcy process, which this country lacks. "We welcome the steps taken by the Indonesian Government over the last several days to put in place the reinforced reform program" of the I.M.F., Mr. Rubin said.
The process established will essentially allow overly indebted Indonesian companies to negotiate as a group with creditors. But it is far from clear that those creditors, chiefly banks in Japan and Europe, will be willing to work out a deal similar to the one now under negotiation with South Korean banks. Because Indonesia's political future is considered uncertain, and because the debts are dispersed, it will likely prove far harder to strike a deal.
The country is grappling with a dangerous mixture of economic and political troubles. Fear of unrest has grown in advance of an electoral convention in March, when President Suharto is expected to gain a new five-year term after 32 years in office. Dissatisfaction with his autocratic rule has grown as Indonesians have begun to doubt his ability to address the economic crisis and as unemployment and rising prices have started to hurt.
The announcement of the freeze on interest payments was made by Radius Prawiro, a former Cabinet minister appointed by President Suharto to manage the country's corporate debt. He estimated that 228 Indonesian companies were unable to service their debts.
"A temporary pause in foreign-currency debt service, both of interest and capital, would be needed for these companies, to allow time for new arrangements to be worked out between lenders and borrowers," Mr. Radius said at a news conference. Those companies still able to service debts must continue to do so, he said.
Mr. Radius insisted that his announcement did not amount to a formal moratorium on payment. "A structure is being developed to encourage borrowers to restore full debt service at the earliest possible date," he said.
Mari Pangestu, an economist with the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, agreed, calling the arrangement a breather that would allow borrowers and lenders to discuss new arrangements. "A moratorium is only the last resort," she said.
The action on debt followed an Indonesian announcement Tuesday morning of banking changes that included deposit guarantees for at least two years, closing of weak banks, plans for stricter supervision and an end to restrictions on foreign ownership.
These changes responded to demands of the I.M.F., which organized a $40 billion rescue package in October and oversaw a revised austerity package announced here this month.
Despite the steps on banking and debt, Standard & Poor's lowered Indonesia's debt rating on Tuesday for the third time in less than a month. It cited a continuing lack of confidence in the country's ability to grapple with its financial and political problems.
Even so, the rupiah rose sharply here on Tuesday, climbing to an exchange rate of 10,450 to the dollar from 12,950 late Monday. But traders said this was mostly the result of rupiah purchases by the Indonesian central bank.
According to the Bank for International Settlements, Japanese banks were the heaviest international lenders to Indonesia as of June 1997. The Japanese held 39 percent of $58.7 billion in foreign debt owed by Indonesian concerns. German banks had 9.5 percent of the total, French banks 8 percent, American banks 7.8 percent and British banks 7.4 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
RJR Operating Profit Rises, But Charges Cause a Loss

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported yesterday that profits from its operations rose 20 percent in the quarter, partly as a result of higher cigarette prices, but the company posted a $197 million net loss primarily because of one-time charges and expenses stemming from its tobacco business.
The financial results were slightly higher than Wall Street's expectations and contained a few surprises. Among them was the increase in domestic tobacco operating profits, which were up 16 percent -- a sharp contrast to recent years of flat or only meager growth. The growth came after a series of price increases for cigarettes, which were far higher than the rate of inflation, said David Adelman, a tobacco industry analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. 
 "In April, the industry took its normal price increase and then there were two more," primarily to finance tobacco litigation settlements, Mr. Adelman said, calling the pricing "an anomaly."
Moreover, RJR Nabisco faces some problems at the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, of which it owns 80.5 percent and which accounts for about a third of RJR's operating profits. On Monday, Nabisco, the food company, reported fourth-quarter earnings that were generally in line with analysts' expectations. But it also warned that 1998 earnings were very likely to be flat because of stagnant sales of some products.
Shares of both companies fell sharply on Monday, with RJR Nabisco losing $2.3125. Yesterday, RJR's share rose 31.25 cents, to $31.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In a statement yesterday, Steven F. Goldstone, the chairman of both companies, called the food company's performance "respectable" but added, "Nabisco's new C.E.O., Jim Kilts, and his team must resolve several significant performance issues -- biscuit sales softness and lingering problems in the sales force reorganization chief among them -- before Nabisco can resume the sales and earnings momentum it has enjoyed in the past."
Make that the distant past, as far as some investors are concerned. "If there's one common theme with Nabisco or RJR Nabisco, it's manana, manana, manana," said John M. McMillin, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "Shareholders have been told manana for about four or five years now. A lot of them have understandably run out of patience."
Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said Monday's stock selloff reflected Wall Street's concerns that Nabisco would need a lot of time to rebound. "It will take them the better part of the year to turn the business around," she said. But she added that she was confident James M. Kilts, the former executive of the Philip Morris Companies' Kraft Foods unit, who took over at Nabisco on Jan. 1, could do it.
In its financial report yesterday, RJR Nabisco said it lost $197 million, or 64 cents a diluted share, in the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $215 million, or 63 cents a diluted share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues in the quarter slipped slightly, to $4.58 billion from $4.63 billion in the 1996 quarter.
But excluding one-time charges in both periods, the company said, operating earnings rose to $297 million, or 87 cents a diluted share, from $248 million, or 72 cents, a year earlier. Wall Street's consensus profit estimate for the 1997 quarter was 83 cents a diluted share, according to I.B.E.S. International Inc., which tracks corporate earnings projections.
RJR Nabisco's financial statement included a total of $494 million in special charges and one-time expenses. Among them was a $313 million after-tax expense to cover reorganization costs in the tobacco businesses, announced last month. That expense cost shareholders 96 cents a diluted share.
Another one-time expense was $85 million, or 26 cents a diluted share, for the costs of a legal settlement with the State of Texas. The state's Attorney General had sued the company over Medicaid expenses tied to treating people with diseases caused by cigarette smoking.
The charges also included $75 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, for inventory reduction at RJR's international tobacco company.
For all of 1997, RJR said, net income fell more than 37 percent, to $381 million, or $1.03 a diluted share, down from $611 million, or $1.74 a diluted share, in 1996, including settlement-related costs and one-time items. Sales for 1997 were flat at $17.06 billion.

HEADLINE: Governor's Inmate Estimates Were Too High, Memo Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
State prison officials said today that they had greatly overestimated how fast the inmate population would grow in the next few years, predictions on which Gov. George E. Pataki based his call for more prison construction.
A year ago, the Department of Correctional Services projected that the prison population would rise by almost 13,000 over five years, to 82,000. But in an internal memorandum written last month, one of the department's chief planners said the increase would probably be less than 6,000. 
 Officials confirmed today that the lower estimates in the memo reflect the administration's current position. A copy of the memo was provided to The New York Times by a Democratic official opposed to the Governor's prison expansion plan.
The numbers were hotly contested during last year's protracted budget debate, with the Governor, a Republican, insisting that much more prison space was needed to keep up with a steadily expanding number of inmates. The Democrats who control the Assembly pointed to a plummeting crime rate and argued that the Governor's figures were inflated.
Mr. Pataki began the budget fight last year by calling for space for 7,000 more maximum-security inmates, and the Legislature eventually agreed to build 3,100, an outcome widely viewed as a victory for the Governor. On top of that increase, Mr. Pataki, who is running for re-election, proposed a new 1,500-bed maximum-security prison, at a cost of $180 million, in the budget proposal he made last week.
A new estimate by the Department of Correctional Services said the prison population, which stood at 69,377 on Dec. 31, would reach 75,000 in 2002, about the same as the estimate offered by Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, in last year's budget talks. In fact, while the Governor was predicting a continued steep rise in the number of inmates, 1997 saw the first decrease since 1972, a drop of 500 inmates.
"Projections are more of an art than a science, and these projections were not that far off," said Katherine N. Lapp, the Governor's director of criminal justice. "I'm actually amazed at how accurate these projections have been."
She noted that the state's prisons are still 30 percent over the capacity for which they were designed, with extra beds installed in dormitory-style buildings, two inmates in some cells designed for one, and rooms that were not originally built as cells turned into cells. "The fact is, the figures show that we need the prison space the Governor has fought so hard for," she said.
Prison construction is always popular with the Governor's allies in the Republican majority in the State Senate, many of whom represent areas upstate where prisons are one of the few sources of economic development and jobs. Each time a new prison is approved, several small upstate towns engage in a fierce lobbying war to be awarded the prize.
But Democratic legislators, who are mostly from New York City, have argued that with serious crime falling steadily since the early 1990's, there would inevitably be a decline in felony arrests, indictments and convictions.
In fact, the number of people being sent to state prison, after soaring during the 1980's, has dropped every year since 1992, but at first the prison population kept rising, in part because longer sentences were being imposed for certain crimes.
"I'm not surprised that we're being proved right because it was so obvious all along," said Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, a Brooklyn Democrat and chairman of the Correction Committee. "No matter what the facts are, they'll find a rationale for more construction. This is about elections and appearing tough on crime."
The Dec. 23 memorandum by Paul H. Korotkin, assistant director for planning, to Glenn S. Goord, commissioner of the state prison system, acknowledges that trend, noting that so far in the fiscal year that began April 1, "indictments are 7.6 percent lower than they were" the year before.
The memo predicts 4,600 fewer people being sent to state prisons each year, beginning next year, than in the projections of a year earlier.
Ms. Lapp said some changes in prison population projections result from a law enacted last year that will allow about 1,000 nonviolent offenders to be released early each year. But so far, that program has cut less than four months off the time served by the average prisoner who qualifies, lowering the prison population by only about 300 at any one time.

HEADLINE: State Splits Use of Orange County Land

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a decision closely watched by environmentalists and business leaders, the Pataki administration announced today that it would allow development of roughly 1,200 acres of state-owned open space near Stewart International Airport in Orange County, while preserving 6,200 more acres for recreation.
In a one-page statement released this evening, Charles A. Gargano, the commissioner of the Empire State Development Corporation, said the administration's plan for the 7,400-acre tract struck a balance between the needs of the environment and the interests of the struggling local economy. 
 "As we set aside this land for the public to enjoy, we will continue our plans to privatize and develop the remaining lands at Stewart to create jobs and economic opportunity for the people of the Hudson Valley," Mr. Gargano said.
The announcement did not entirely satisfy either environmentalists who wanted more land preserved or community leaders who lobbied to have more land returned to the tax rolls.
George J. Meyers, the city supervisor of New Windsor, which holds 90 percent of the state-owned tract, said he was happy that some land was being opened to development, but that he had hoped for more.
"Obviously, I would have liked to have all of it back on the tax rolls," Mr. Meyers said. "But we're pleased that we are going to get some of that land developed so we get people into jobs."
John Stouffer, the legislative director for the Sierra Club's Atlantic Chapter, said that although he was pleased that the bulk of the land was spared, it was a mistake to carve up a valuable expanse of woods, fields and wetlands that draws thousands of hunters, hikers, bird-watchers and cyclists each year.
"It's better than destroying the whole thing," Mr. Stouffer said. "But this is not great news. This will cut 1,200 acres out of an extremely valuable piece of open space that has an important habitat value because it links fields, forests and wetlands."
Gov. George E. Pataki initially proposed selling all 7,400 acres as part of a plan to privatize Stewart Airport, a state-owned airport 60 miles north of New York City. While the Governor had said he wanted some of the land preserved for recreational space, his original sale proposal did not specify how much land would be protected.
But under the plan announced today, the preserved land would be managed by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The agency will be responsible for maintaining trails, protecting wildlife and preserving the wetlands. The administration did not say how the other 1,200 acres would be developed.
"The woods, fields and wetlands west of Stewart Airport will remain available to the people of New York State for recreational uses, including hunting, fishing, cycling, bird-watching, hiking, horseback riding and cross-country skiing," Mr. Gargano said.
Mr. Pataki first proposed selling the airport outright in 1995 as part of an effort to privatize many state assets, including the World Trade Center and a network of former mental hospitals. But the sale of any airport is complicated by stringent Federal regulations and oversight.
Now the administration plans to lease the airport to a private company to run day-to-day operations. In November, the Federal Government gave preliminary approval to that proposal.
The administration says the leasing plan would generate revenue for the state, shift the burden of maintaining the airport from taxpayers to private interests and ultimately make the airport more efficient and profitable.
For years, the state has lost money on the operation of Stewart, about $2 million annually, and is just beginning to break even. Stewart, used by 400,000 passengers a year, has 58 daily flights to airline hubs in the United States.
The administration plans to negotiate a lease that runs between 30 and 99 years. The State Economic Development Corporation is reviewing lease proposals from five companies.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Administration Negotiating for a Jazz Concert Hall on Site of the Coliseum

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is negotiating a deal to create a concert hall for Lincoln Center's jazz programs, in a move that could jump-start the bidding process for the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site, a project that has been mired in a variety of disputes for the last 14 years.
The concert hall, which would serve as a home for Jazz at Lincoln Center, which produces both music and educational programs, and be used by other performing artists, would presumably be incorporated into plans to develop one of the city's most valuable pieces of real estate -- a parcel across from the southwest corner of Central Park. 
 Five finalists are vying for the rights to build a combined residential, hotel and retail complex on the 3.4 acres, a 2.1-million-square-foot project. Bidding has soared well above $300 million.
Efforts by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to sell the parcel, which is now occupied by the Coliseum and an office building, have been stalled since last July, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suddenly vowed to block the proposed high-rise project unless it included a large theater or performance space.
The subsequent seven-month delay exacerbated a longstanding rift between city and state officials and wreaked havoc on plans by some bidders: Donald Trump, who had bid $275 million, said he was dropping out altogether, and Millennium Partners, which had all but won the bidding, lost two key tenants, Westin Hotels and Resorts and Sony Entertainment. Sony has opened talks with rival developers, real estate executives involved in the bidding said.
In the meantime, Related Companies appears to have strengthened its hand, signing nonbinding agreements with Time Warner for all the office space in its proposed complex and with the Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group for a 375-room hotel. The other leading contender, a partnership between the developers Bruce Ratner and Daniel Brodsky, landed tentative deals with Westin Hotels, Sears, and Virgin. Tishman Speyer, the fifth bidder, has adopted a wait-and-see posture toward the project. But as Millennium discovered, any nonbinding agreements or letters of intent can prove ephemeral the longer the process drags on.
City and state officials say that if a deal with Jazz at Lincoln Center is struck some time in the next week it will allow the M.T.A. to finally resume talks with the developers and ultimately select one.
The M.T.A. did not return repeated calls requesting comment, but John S. Dyson, chairman of the Mayor's Council of Economic Advisors, confirmed that a deal with Jazz at Lincoln Center was under discussion.
At the city's request, Jazz at Lincoln Center gave the Giuliani administration a formal proposal on Jan. 22 for a theater with up to 1,200 seats, according to executives involved in the talks. The two sides are now working out the financing for the theater, as well as the role of Lincoln Center in administering the space.
Gordon J. Davis, the chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center, declined to comment, as did Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center.
Charles Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said, "We would like to accommodate the city and the Mayor in what they want to include in the project."
Some officials and developers say that unless the project moves forward soon there is a danger that the economy will slow down and the state will miss a chance to benefit from a hot real estate market. An 11-year effort to sell the site to the developer Mortimer Zuckerman collapsed during the recession in 1994.
"It's important to bring this to a conclusion while the economy is hot," Mr. Dyson acknowledged. "The public will get a better price and a better project."
According to a senior city official who requested anonymity, the winning developer of the Columbus Circle parcel would be expected to build a shell for the proposed theater, which is expected to cost about $20 million. Lincoln Center would raise money to outfit the theater, with the city contributing part of the cost from its capital budget. To offset the cost of erecting the theater shell, however, developers may choose to pare their bids, which have soared to over $300 million, city officials said.
But the sale price has been an ongoing source of friction between city and state officials. The M.T.A. has wanted to reap as much money as possible from the sale for various capital programs. More than two years ago, the city and state jointly resumed efforts to sell the parcel.
But just as the state agency was about to select Millennium Partners as the winning developer last July, Mayor Giuliani accused the state of ignoring planning and esthetic issues, and threatened to invoke his veto.
In keeping with Columbus Circle's role as a public gateway between midtown and the Upper West Side, he demanded that a "very, very large theater" of about 2,000 seats be included in any project on the site.
The Mayor's announcement surprised Lincoln Center, which was negotiating with Millennium Partners over a 600-seat theater for Jazz at Lincoln Center at a proposed project on Broadway several blocks north of Columbus Circle. At the time, Mr. Leventhal said he would consider Columbus Circle as an alternative.
In August, the five developers met with city officials and began incorporating plans for a performance space into their proposals. But, the developers say, they have not heard from the city or state since then.
Mr. Brodsky and Mr. Ratner, for instance, developed a plan for a 2,000-seat theater that would be operated by a joint venture of the Shubert and Jujamcyn theater groups.
Unable to strike a firm deal with Millennium, Westin Hotels defected to the Brodsky-Ratner team. "We've signed a letter of intent," said Jack Van Hartsvelt, Westin's executive vice president. "We're waiting for a little clarity as to who is going to win this."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Covering Asia With Cash;
Banks Poured Money Into Region Despite Warning Signs

BYLINE: By Timothy O'Brien; This article was reported by Timothy L. O'Brien, Edmund L. Andrews and Sheryl WuDunn and was written by Mr. O'Brien.

 BODY:
A little more than a year ago, several European banks helped Garuda Indonesia airlines lease six huge Airbus jets worth $630 million. The Indonesian economy was surging, and Asian airlines were rapidly expanding their fleets.
Now East Asia is engulfed in its biggest financial crisis in decades. And like thousands of businesses, Garuda is in trouble. Air travel is down, and Garuda could not make an $8 million payment owed on the new jets last month. The loans to Garuda may sour. 
 Even as hints of trouble were emerging in Asian economies, many international banks were stepping up their lending to Asian companies and banks. By the time financing was arranged for Garuda in December 1996, international banks had forked over $367 billion to borrowers in Asia, up 20 percent from the previous year, according to the Bank for International Settlements, which coordinates the world's central banks. Six months later, the borrowings had swelled to $389.4 billion, excluding a large amount of lending to Hong Kong and Singapore.
"There was a huge euphoria about Asia and Southeast Asia," said Dennis Phillips, a spokesman for Commerzbank, a big German bank. "It was the place to be."
The place to be, indeed. The roster of Asia's lenders includes the most well-known names in international banking, all of which found Asian growth -- and loan profits -- too seductive to ignore. Japanese banks have long been the leading lenders in the region.
Among American banks, Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, J. P. Morgan, BankAmerica and Bankers Trust have the greatest exposure to the most troubled Southeast Asian economies. Each bank tallies its loans differently, so lending figures are not directly comparable. But J. P. Morgan -- which said last week that payment on $587 million of its loans, mainly in Asia, was seriously overdue -- has obvious problems. Analysts are also casting wary eyes on Chase and Citicorp.
But as the American banks slightly scaled back their lending during the first six months of 1997, some Japanese, German, French and British banks plunged in deeper. Hemmed in by slow growth and sagging profits at home and eager to feed a growing demand for loans in Asia, lending by French and German banks climbed $7.9 billion, or 10 percent, in the first half of last year, and Japanese institutions added $5.3 billion, or 4 percent more, in loans. More recent data are not available.
While the loan problems are not expected to severely damage any of the banks, one bank could have serious problems: Credit Lyonnais, a long-troubled French financial institution.
"We anticipated some problems, but we did not expect to see anything like what has happened," said Andre Levy-Lang, chairman of Banque Paribas, another large French bank, which does not expect significant losses. "The key thing is that the crisis is not over. And it is very difficult to anticipate how it will evolve."
The World Bank, in a report issued yesterday, said that lax regulations and dubious financial practices in Asian countries "were aggravated by undisciplined foreign lending, which led to too much money chasing bad investments." The World Bank noted that Asia's reliance on short-term debt "left the economies vulnerable to a sudden collapse of confidence."
In a more detailed look, Fitch IBCA -- a major international rating agency -- noted yesterday that Japanese banks were the most at risk in Asia and cited Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. as having particularly heavy exposure to Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea.
Fitch said that Citicorp, among all American banks operating in Asia, "has the highest risk exposure in the region, given its large indigenous retail and commercial banking presence." Among German banks, Fitch said that Commerzbank, Westdeutsche Landesbank and Bayerische Landesbank "are the most vulnerable" to Asian losses. Credit Lyonnais was the sole French bank cited by Fitch as being heavily exposed to losses in Asia.
One particular problem fostered by all the global lenders is that most of the loans are short term -- due in a year or less -- and must be repaid in dollars, francs or marks. Banks liked short-term lending in Asia because it seemed to limit their risk and offered tidy profits. But the result was to create a financial time bomb for Asian borrowers because short-term loans left them less room to maneuver if they were unexpectedly pressed for cash. Starting last summer, when local currencies collapsed in Asia, it took more Thai baht and South Korean won to repay those loans, thus crippling borrowers.
The banks have so far been determined to get all their money back, though billions of dollars have been set aside for potential losses. In New York last week, South Korean negotiators asked to stretch out repayment of their loans well beyond a year. Banks now appear willing to appease the South Koreans, although it is unclear whether that includes swallowing some losses.
Germany's Bayerische Landesbank A.G., saddled with about $11 billion in Asian loans, suspended three of its managers in Singapore last week for reportedly making loans without collateral. Societe Generale, another large French bank, said it would set aside "substantial" funds to brace itself from losses on $6.8 billion in Asian loans.
The Asian lending frenzy began because the region's economic promise once seemed limitless.
"All the banks would be standing in line -- J. P. Morgan, Deutsche Bank, Dresdner," said Klaus Friedrich, chief economist at Germany's Dresdner Bank A.G. "We were all standing in line trying to help these countries borrow money. We would all see each other at the same places. We all knew each other."
Indeed, Asia was heaven for loan officers. Sakura Bank Ltd. and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. led a flotilla of Japanese banks that more than doubled their lending to Thailand between 1993 and 1996; Germany's Deutsche Bank A.G., which lent money to Garuda, also made risky, temporary loans across Asia so it could be first in line for corporate bond deals -- loans that may now go unpaid. International lenders bankrolled everything from empty high-rises in Thailand to South Korean companies' speculation in Brazilian bonds.
The first concrete signs of trouble emerged in Thailand when real estate developments failed to fill with tenants. But bigger trouble hit early last year in South Korea when the Hanbo Steel Industry Company collapsed. A few months later, the Sammi Steel Corporation filed for protection from creditors. Still, Japan's lending to Asia kept rising.
Did Japanese bankers see trouble coming? "We didn't think about it," said one Japanese banker who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Not until Korea First Bank, a large bank and a leading lender to Hanbo, sought a bailout from the South Korean Government last summer did this Japanese banker realize something was amiss.
But an American banker, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the warning signs had always been there -- bankers just did not want to see them. "There are problems in Asia now because investors and bankers were overly optimistic about the Asian economies, and then they panicked," he said.
Moody's Investors Service, which rates the creditworthiness of borrowers and has been criticized for overlooking the depths of Asia's problems, still sounded an early alarm in March 1996. Citing risks facing Thailand because of its love affair with short-term loans, Moody's said the country was vulnerable to unexpected economic shocks.
"When we put that report out, everyone said how wrong we were and that we didn't understand the numbers," said Vincent Truglia, a managing director with Moody's.
In fact, all sorts of numbers were overlooked in Asia. Data on Asian airlines indicated that the industry was expanding too quickly at the time the Garuda loan was made. One American banker familiar with Garuda's financial picture referred to the company as "toxic waste." And South Korean conglomerates were stuffed with dangerously high levels of debt.
But loans were often made for more than sound banking reasons. In South Korea, a loan to a large conglomerate, or chaebol, was tantamount to making a loan to the Government. "That was the rule of the game in Korea," said Vivien Levy-Garboua, chief executive of international operations for Banque Nationale de Paris. "It was a Korea Inc. loan."
Many of the banks made some risky loans at first in the hope of building a relationship that would yield more business later. A loan might lead to investment banking fees or a lucrative bond offering later.
And some loans are backed by assets or unusual guarantees. Credit Lyonnais and Deutsche Bank remain sanguine about Garuda because a portion of their loans has Government guarantees, and jets are valuable collateral. Credit Lyonnais said that its Garuda exposure was in the "tens of thousands" of dollars.
Deutsche Bank said its portion of the Garuda loan was guaranteed by the British Government, although the bank acknowledges that an undisclosed portion of the loan does not carry any Government guarantees.
American and European bankers said that while they were aware that South Korean companies were overextended, they thought it would require a unique confluence of events to transform Asia's economic problems into a full-blown disaster. Yet that is what happened.
Short-term loans in South Korea made it easy for banks to rush out of the country, and the traffic jam to exit late last year nearly toppled the economy. As much as $20 billion in loans were pulled out of the country between late last summer and the end of December, according to American commercial bankers. While American banks largely kept their money in the country, a large Japanese bank said that Japan's lending to South Korea plummeted nearly 40 percent between last June and last month. By Christmas Eve, international banking regulators were twisting the arms of lenders to prevent them from abandoning the country.
"A headlong rush for the exits only perpetrated the very event everyone was trying to avoid, which was a wholesale liquidity crisis in which you won't get repaid," said Robert E. Fallon, Asia-Pacific division manager for Chase Manhattan.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Shelving '98 Trade Bill In Favor of New I.M.F. Funds

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With the Asian financial crisis threatening the health of the American economy, the Clinton Administration has decided to make Congressional passage of $18 billion in new contributions to the International Monetary Fund a far higher priority this year than winning authority to negotiate new trade accords, according to senior Administration officials.
Mr. Clinton's top economic and foreign policy aides concluded it would be all but impossible to get Congressional approval for both the I.M.F. commitments and the trade legislation, which was withdrawn late last year after Mr. Clinton could not overcome resistance in his own party. 
 Tonight, in his State of the Union address, Mr. Clinton briefly renewed his request for the trade legislation.
But hours before the speech, a top adviser to the President said that getting authority to strike trade deals "will be neither one of the top priorities or the top international economic priority" this year.
That represents a major retreat for the Administration, which pledged late in 1997 to fight for the negotiating authority again this year before Mr. Clinton attends a summit meeting of Latin American countries in Santiago, Chile, this spring.
Even before the President was caught up in the current scandal, doubts had intensified that he could force through fast-track trade negotiating authority, which would allow the President to strike deals that Congress could approve or disapprove, but not amend.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton dwelled at some length on the need for the United States to provide aid, through the I.M.F., to ailing economies that are among the biggest United States trading partners.
"The American economy remains sound and strong," he said, "and I want to keep it that way. But because the turmoil in Asia will have an impact on all the world's economies, including ours, making that negative impact as small as possible is the right thing to do for America, and the right thing to do for a safer world.
"Preparing for a far-off storm that may reach our shores," he added, "is far wiser than ignoring the thunder until the clouds are just overhead."
At the end of the last session, Congress refused to authorize $3.5 billion in additional I.M.F. funds. This money had been intended to give the I.M.F. new resources to aid ailing economies, but it floundered amid debate about American financing of abortion services overseas.
In the interim, the United States has committed its own funds to bailout efforts in South Korea and Indonesia, and the question of whether it should be aiding the Asian economies at all has taken on broader dimensions. Liberal Democrats say the I.M.F.'s bailouts save big investors and borrowers, at the expense of workers, many of whom suffer layoffs and economic downturns after the I.M.F. orders countries to impose austerity measures.
Conservative Republicans say the I.M.F. meddles in the market, rather than letting the economy sort out winners and losers. But the two ideologically opposed groups are likely to mount a joint campaign to defeat further contributions.
"It's going to be an enormously tough fight," a senior Administration official said today.
Mr. Clinton argued tonight that the nation's security and economic interests hinged on stabilizing its trading partners. "These countries are our customers," he said, "and if Asia sinks into recession, they won't be able to buy the goods we'd like to sell them. Second, they are our competitors, and if their currencies lose their value, the price of their goods will drop, flooding our market and others with cheap goods, which make it a lot tougher for our people to compete."
Nonetheless, the decision to shore up the I.M.F. first is bound to be read in Latin America as another long delay in Washington's commitment to some of its geographically closest trade partners.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Plans Budget Seeking Modest Growth For Spending

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Even though the local economy is expanding and tax revenues are growing, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to announce a relatively austere budget tomorrow that calls for New York City to increase most spending at less than the inflation rate, administration officials said yesterday. Under the Mayor's proposal, the city would squirrel away much of its current budget surplus to help close anticipated shortfalls in the next two years, the officials said.
The Mayor is expected to announce that the city will finish the 1998 fiscal year with a surplus of $1.2 billion, thanks in large part to a surging Wall Street. It will be the second year in a row of good fortune for the city, which was pummeled by the recession in the early 1990's. The city ended its last fiscal year with $1.4 billion more than it expected. 
 But in contrast to the election-year budget that he presented at this time last year, which called for sharply increased spending on education, children's services and other programs, the Mayor is returning to the conservative fiscal stance that he took early in his first term, when he pushed through some of the largest spending cuts since the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
The new budget calls for spending on most programs to increase by roughly six-tenths of 1 percent, well under the annual local inflation rate of about 2 to 2.5 percent, administration officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Mayor also plans to call for cuts in some programs.
"The message of this budget is that we are putting the city on a sound financial course," said a senior administration official. The overall size of the budget, including Federal and state grants, is expected to be $34 billion to $35 billion.
While the Mayor is proposing that the city reserve most of the surplus to deal with shortfalls in the next two years, some independent fiscal experts say he should use the money for more long-term deficit reduction. In other words, he could allocate the surplus in ways that would spread out the deficit reduction over several years, instead of just the next two. He could do that, for example, by retiring some of the city's growing long-term debt, which would reduce city's payments of principal and interest.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit, nonpartisan group, said last night that he had not yet seen the details of the Mayor's budget. But he said that "retiring outstanding debt, generally speaking, is preferable because you get greater savings spread out over a long period."
Instead, mayoral aides said yesterday, Mr. Giuliani plans to reserve from 70 to 75 percent of the projected $1.2 billion surplus in the current fiscal year, or $840 million to $900 million, and use it for the expected budget gaps in the next two years, officials said. They defended this policy, saying that while it might not be exactly the medicine prescribed by some fiscal watchdogs, it was still a departure from past administrations, which often raised spending significantly when the economy rebounded, leaving the city poorly positioned for the inevitable downturns.
In his new budget, Mr. Giuliani is also expected to call for the city to spend about 20 percent of the money, or $240 million, on new programs, including new education proposals and his anti-drug campaign, which he is hoping will be one of the signature initiatives of his second term. The rest of the surplus would go toward making up for revenue lost to new tax cuts.
During his re-election campaign last fall, Mr. Giuliani proposed $70 million in tax cuts for small businesses and families who pay for child care, and those cuts are expected to be part of the new plan, but administration officials declined yesterday to discuss the exact structure of cuts.
The budget that the Mayor announces tomorrow is known as the preliminary financial plan, and it includes a prediction of the city's financial standing over the next four years. In May, he is to detail the final version of the plan, which is known as the executive budget. Approval by the City Council is required for the executive budget to become law. The 1999 fiscal year begins on July 1.
The city had been facing a projected deficit in the 1999 fiscal year of more than $1 billion, but the Mayor's plan for the surplus should help him avoid proposing large budget cuts to close that gap. The city has also projected shortfalls of more than $2 billion in the 2000 and 2001 fiscal years; the plan for the surplus is expected to help winnow the gap for the year 2000. Part of the $1.2 billion surplus projected for this fiscal year comes from a so-called rainy day fund that the Mayor agreed to set up after prodding from the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
The city has been able to end its current and the preceding fiscal years with more money than it expected, largely because the Mayor and the Council have decided to estimate tax revenues as if Wall Street would have a moderately successful year. But because the financial-services sector continues to boom, taxes have climbed and growth in other areas of the economy, like tourism, has also produced added revenue.
While the last two years have been bountiful, the city still must confront many long-term fiscal problems, experts said. Among the most serious is the size of its outstanding debt.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Finance Minister Resigns, Opening Way to a Shift in Policy

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka formally resigned today to take responsibility for a bribery scandal, in a move that raised the possibility of a shift in Government policy to stimulate Japan's economy and help ease the rest of Asia out of its financial crisis.
Mr. Mitsuzuka told reporters Tuesday that his resignation was a response to the arrest Monday of two ministry officials accused of accepting bribes from the banks that they supervised. The arrests have thrown the Finance Ministry, the most powerful arm of the Japanese Government, into turmoil. 
 The officials were arrested in a dramatic display of force when some 100 prosecutors and investigators marched into what has been Japan's most powerful ministry. The officials are suspected of having accepted lavish meals, and then showing favor to the banks that entertained them.
Entertaining government officials and expecting favors in return is an entrenched business practice in Japan. While the episode is being widely described as a bribery scandal, the press has been filled with speculation that Mr. Mitsuzuka's departure is a result of a political deal between Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and opposition parties, which had long sought his ouster.
The arrests were a humiliating blow to the Finance Ministry and promptly led to calls for Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation, even though he personally is not accused of any wrongdoing. After initially resisting, Mr. Mitsuzuka bowed to pressure.
For the moment, Mr. Hashimoto will also hold the post of Finance Minister until a new minister is chosen.
Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation comes at a sensitive time. Japan's banking system, the largest in Asia, has been plagued by problems of bad debts both at home and elsewhere in Asia, where the banks lent heavily, including loans in South Korea and Indonesia.
Major economic policy questions are in the balance. The next Finance Minister will find himself at the vortex of a series of pressures. Legislation intended to stabilize the financial system is pending in Parliament, and a weakened Finance Ministry could have problems getting the bills approved. Japan has committed itself to deregulating its financial system, but it has been pressured by the United States to do far more and do it more quickly, and to stimulate domestic demand in the Japanese economy rather than export its way out of its troubles.
Officials say that Mr. Hashimoto may seize the opportunity of a shuffle at the Finance Ministry to announce a new fiscal stimulus package next month. The Prime Minister has been torn between his desire to stimulate the economy, through such measures as a tax cut or spending increase, and his reluctance to increase the budget deficit. As recently as last month, the Government announced its latest program to cut taxes and stimulate the economy, only to be widely criticized for doing too little too late.
If Mr. Hashimoto does announce an ambitious fiscal stimulus program, the move would be widely welcomed not just in America but throughout Asia, where Japan is seen as the one economy large enough to have the potential to pull the rest of the region back to solid financial ground.
Stock prices in Tokyo rose moderately this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 115.98 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 17,097.60.
To be sure, Mr. Mitsuzuka is hardly the first Finance Minister to resign under a cloud. The step has not always been politically fatal, nor has it led to a fundamental reshaping of the ministry. Among his recent predecessors is Mr. Hashimoto, who stepped down as Finance Minister in 1991 when the ministry was also facing sharp criticism -- then for its failure to prevent widespread scandals in the banking and brokerage industries. Mr. Hashimoto became trade minister and then rose to Prime Minister in 1996.
Mr. Mitsuzuka announced his impending departure at a news conference tonight. "I called upon the Prime Minister at his official residence shortly past 6 P.M. to express my intention to resign," he said. "I feel keenly my responsibility for the scandal. I want to apologize to the public."
The ruling Liberal Democratic Party has already seemed to signal a shift in economic policy, with a top party official saying Tuesday that the party will announce an economic stimulus package, possibly on Feb. 20. That is more than a month before financial institutions close their fiscal year-end books on March 31. Such a stimulus package could give a lift to the stock market at a crucial time for banks, which must meet new rules for capital strength that take effect April 1.
More important, Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation provides a face-saving opportunity for Mr. Hashimoto to redirect the economy.
"The change of the head man is a good reason to change macro-economic policy," said a Finance Ministry official who insisted on not being identified.
Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation, however, could throw into question the speed with which the Parliament will pass major legislation to stabilize the financial system, in particular a tax cut of two trillion yen ($24 billion), a bank bailout costing 30 trillion yen and a supplementary budget package.
Opposition party members have recently voiced dissatisfaction with Mr. Mitsuzuka. They have wanted him to take responsibility for mismanagement of the nation's economic and financial troubles.
"Mitsuzuka's head has been on the block quite a while now," said John Neuffer, political analyst at Mitsui Marine Research Institute, an affiliate of Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance Company in Tokyo. "It's another blow to the Hashimoto administration."
Mr. Neuffer and others said the scandal would also hurt the Finance Ministry, which sets economic policy and has a hand in virtually every major decision about the economy.
It is not clear whether prosecutors will widen their investigation of the ministry, or whether Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation may suggest an end to the inquiries.
"It's possible this could be the tip of the iceberg, of something important," said Craig O. Chudler, a strategist at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "To have the Finance Minister of Japan, the second-largest economy, resigning -- I don't think it's just another day in the life of Japan."
The two officials arrested were bank inspectors but not career bureaucrats -- the cadre of elite men who rise to the top of the ministry and effectively control it. So far, this group has remained essentially untouched by the scandal.
But the credibility of the Finance Ministry has been under attack recently since the financial system suffered a string of institutional collapses that shattered investor confidence. And some critics say that the arrests and Mr. Mitsuzuka's resignation are steps toward diminishing the authority of the ministry.
"In the longer run, we see already that the current system cannot last forever," said Kazuhito Ikeo, an economics professor at Keio University. "Even if it doesn't look like it's changing, this is one frame closer toward the deterioration of the Finance Ministry's authority."
The moves by prosecutors are also shaking up the business community. On Tuesday, prosecutors conducted raids at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Sanwa Bank, Asahi Bank and Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, which shut down last fall. All four are suspected of entertaining the two ministry officials.
Wining and dining clients, business partners and officials has long been a practice of bankers, and so it seemed surprising that prosecutors should suddenly be interested in prosecuting officials for such seemingly petty activities.
One of the arrested officials, Koichi Miyagawa, a 53-year-old chief inspector, is accused of neglecting to act after discovering that a bank had filed a false report on bad loans, according to a leading newspaper.
The scandal took a salacious turn Tuesday with the disclosure that Mr. Miyagawa had asked bankers to entertain him at special shabu-shabu restaurants, according to Asahi Shimbun, a leading Japanese daily. Shabu-shabu is a specially cooked beef, but the restaurants' specialty is actually the scantily clad waitresses.

Scandal Forces Resignation Of Japan's Finance Minister
The Finance Minister of Japan, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said he would resign, taking responsibility for a bribery scandal. On Monday, two ministry officials were arrested on charges of accepting bribes from the banks that they supervised.
The resignation comes as Japan's banking system is faced with a plethora of problems, including bad debts at home and in other parts of Asia. Page A1. 

Because of Asia's economic crisis, the Clinton Administration has decided to make Congressional passage of $18 billion in new contributions to the I.M.F. a far higher priority this year than winning the authority to negotiate new trade accords, senior Administration officials said. D8.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: DOMESTIC PLANS;
Fixing Social Security Should Come Before Any Surplus Free-for-All, President Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Edging into one of the most politically combustible issues facing the nation, President Clinton urged Congress tonight not to spend any budget surpluses the Federal Government might enjoy in coming years until the two parties solve the Social Security system's looming financial problems.
Mr. Clinton proposed no specific remedies for Social Security, and he stopped short of insisting that the entire fiscal windfall go toward shoring up the retirement program. 
 But he sought to convince Republicans of his intention to avoid partisan warfare over an issue that has economic implications across the generations and a tendency to expose vast ideological divides about the responsibilities of the Government and citizens.
Mr. Clinton pledged to work with Congress to enact legislation next year to deal with the retirement system's potential insolvency. And he argued that the responsible course for the nation would be to address Social Security before indulging in a free-for-all of new spending and tax cuts made possible by the coming era of fiscal plenty.
"Let us say to all Americans watching tonight, whether you're 70 or 50 or whether you just started paying into the system, Social Security will be there when you need it," Mr. Clinton said. "Let us make this commitment: Social Security first. Let's do that, together."
As a symbol of his willingness to tackle the issue and share any political pain, Mr. Clinton said he would lead public meetings around the country this year to discuss why Social Security has to be changed and to stimulate a debate over which of a host of options would be best.
Republicans said they welcomed the President's fiscally conservative approach and his willingness to speak out on Social Security. But they saw a political motive in Mr. Clinton's call to postpone using any surplus for tax cuts.
And with memories still fresh of how Democrats have made political weapons out of previous Republican-led efforts to address financial problems in entitlement programs, they remained wary that the President and Congressional Democrats would turn the Social Security issue against them in this year's elections.
Mr. Clinton's proposals on Social Security were among an array of domestic policy initiatives he outlined, including raising the minimum wage, expanding Medicare health care coverage to people ages 55 to 64 and improving access to child care. He called for a new push to reach a settlement with tobacco companies over liability for the health damage caused by smoking, and he signaled a plan that the Administration will unveil on Wednesday to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service.
Social Security will pay out about $100 billion less in benefits this year than it takes in from payroll taxes and interest income on the Government bonds it holds, and on the Government's books the system has about $650 billion set aside to pay future benefits.
But when the 76 million-member baby boom generation begins retiring in large numbers in 2010, Social Security's financial strength will erode rapidly. By 2019 the system will begin eating into its reserves to pay benefits. By 2029 it will exhaust all its reserves, and the revenues it will take in from payroll taxes are projected to meet only 75 percent of its promised benefit payments, leaving the system technically insolvent.
White House officials have been debating for months how they could use the rapidly improving fiscal situation to begin dealing with Social Security. Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy adviser, said the Administration now expected budget surpluses totaling $200 billion over the next five years.
Allocating the entire surplus to shoring up Social Security could add 8 to 15 years to the system's solvency, studies by the White House have shown. But Administration officials have concluded that solving Social Security's problems would ultimately have to involve a national debate over a variety of possible fixes.
The fixes include increasing payroll taxes, raising the retirement age and cutting benefits. But the debate will also encompass proposals to rethink Social Security's structure and the nature of the Government's commitment to providing retirement security.
One camp, which includes many Democrats and organizations representing the elderly, wants to preserve the current system. Another, made up largely but not exclusively of conservatives, wants to give more freedom and responsibility to individuals for their retirement savings.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have made clear that he will not accept the most radical proposals for changing the system into something like a giant 401(k) program. But they said he had not ruled out a compromise that would allow individuals to put part of their payroll taxes into a personal account.
 
Family Leave
Mr. Clinton asked Congress to expand the reach of a 1993 law to guarantee family and medical leave for 10 million additional workers.
Under the law, an eligible worker may take a maximum of 12 weeks of unpaid leave each year to recover from an illness or to care for a newborn child or a seriously ill relative. The law applies to companies with 50 or more employees, covering 58 percent of the private labor force, or 55 million workers. Administration officials said Mr. Clinton wanted to extend the requirements to companies with 25 to 49 employees.
Donna R. Lenhoff, general counsel of the Women's Legal Defense Fund, welcomed the proposal and said it would not hurt small businesses. But Lonnie P. Taylor, senior vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said: "This proposal is ridiculous. It would impose a new burden, a new mandate, on small employers. The President is responding to the unions. He's throwing them a bone."
 
Health
Saying that America was on the brink of breakthroughs in biomedical research, President Clinton tonight proposed major increases in spending for the National Institutes of Health.
Congress provided $13.6 billion for the agency this year. Mr. Clinton asked for an increase of $1.15 billion, or 8.5 percent, next year. Moreover, Mr. Clinton said he wanted an increase of about 50 percent over the next five years, raising the agency's budget to more than $20 billion in 2003. In Congress, there is bipartisan support for such an increase. Representative John Edward Porter, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee responsible for biomedical research, said he wanted to double spending for the health institute in the next five years, and many lawmakers shared that goal.
Congress has appropriated more than the President requested for the health institute in each of the last few years. Mr. Clinton's request thus becomes a floor on which Congress will build.
"It's very heartening that the President has indicated his support for increased investment in science," said Dr. Jordan J. Cohen, president of the Association of American Medical Colleges. "An even greater investment in biomedical research could be justified."
Within a decade, Dr. Cohen said, the fruits of such research will be available in new drug therapies to treat arthritis, childhood diabetes and multiple sclerosis. Moreover, he said, "we will be able to counteract many of the genetic changes that lead to colon cancer and other major cancers before they accumulate and cause malignancy."
Even as researchers discover new cures, many patients have difficulty getting access to basic medical care. Mr. Clinton said that this year Congress should pass legislation to protect the rights of patients, especially those in health maintenance organizations.
Noting that 160 million Americans were enrolled in H.M.O.'s and other managed care plans, Mr. Clinton said: "These plans save money, and they can improve care. But medical decisions ought to be made by medical doctors, not insurance company accountants."
He urged Congress to enact a bill of rights for patients, stipulating: "You have the right to know all your medical options, not just the cheapest. You have the right to choose the doctor you want for the care you need. You have the right to emergency room care, wherever and whenever you need it. You have the right to keep your medical records confidential."
H.M.O.'s, insurance companies and employers of all sizes have banded together to block such legislation, and they plan a $1 million advertising campaign to publicize their concerns. They contend that the guarantees proposed by Mr. Clinton would increase the cost of health care and health insurance, so that many employers would cut back coverage.
Mr. Clinton challenged Congress to pass comprehensive bipartisan legislation to reduce teen-age smoking. Such legislation, he said, should raise the cost of a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 over the next decade, "with penalties on the tobacco industry if it keeps marketing to our children."
 
Medicare
Mr. Clinton called on Congress to open Medicare, which finances health care for people who are elderly or disabled, to people 55 to 64 years old.
"It won't add a dime to the deficit," Mr. Clinton said of his Medicare proposal, "but the peace of mind it will provide will be priceless."
Under the President's proposal, people 62 to 64 could buy Medicare coverage for premiums of $300 a month. They would have to pay a surcharge of $10 to $20 a month on top of the regular premiums they must pay on reaching 65 to help offset the costs of earlier coverage.
People 55 and older who lose their health benefits because they are laid off from their jobs would also be allowed to buy into Medicare. They would have to pay premiums of $400 a month, considered sufficient to cover their costs, until they reach the current age of eligibility for Medicare, which is 65.
Finally, the President would offer a new insurance option to retirees 55 and older who have lost health benefits promised by former employers. Such retirees could participate in the health plan of the company where they worked, but might be required to pay the full premium paid by the company and active workers, plus 20 percent to 25 percent.
 
Child Care
Mr. Clinton asked Congress to support a package of child care proposals that he unveiled on Jan. 7.
Under the proposals, which would cost $21.7 billion over five years, the Government would increase Federal subsidies for day care, so that two million children would eventually receive Federal aid. That is more than double the number who now benefit from such subsidies.
Mr. Clinton also urged Congress to increase the income tax credit that parents can take for child care expenses. The White House said this proposal would eliminate income tax liability for most families with substantial child care expenses and with incomes less than twice the official poverty level (less than $33,000 a year for a family of four).
The President also asked Congress to provide $800 million over the next five years to finance after-school care for up to 500,000 children a year.
