HEADLINE: Iraqis Must End Defiance On Arms, Clinton Warns

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton sought to intensify pressure on Iraq today, dispatching senior officials to consult with American allies in Europe and the Middle East and warning President Saddam Hussein, in the State of the Union address, that his defiance of the United Nations cannot continue.
In his speech tonight to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Clinton cautioned the Iraqi President: "You cannot defy the will of the world." Mr. Hussein has used weapons of mass destruction before, Mr. Clinton noted, and said, "We are determined to deny you the capacity to use them again." 
 Mr. Clinton said he spoke "for everyone in this chamber, Republicans and Democrats," acknowledging a unity on Iraq today that was missing in Congress before the Persian Gulf war, even after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
"Together," Mr. Clinton said, the United States "must confront new hazards: chemical and biological weapons" that could be obtained "by outlaw states, terrorists and organized criminals."
He added: "Saddam Hussein has spent the better part of this decade, and much of his nation's wealth, not on providing for the Iraqi people but on developing nuclear, chemical and biological weapons -- and the missiles to deliver them."
While the United Nations arms inspectors "have done a truly remarkable job, finding and destroying more of Iraq's arsenal than was destroyed during the entire gulf war," Mr. Clinton said, Mr. Hussein "wants to stop them from completing their mission."
In his speech, Mr. Clinton made no direct reference to joint American and British plans for military strikes against Iraq unless President Hussein capitulates.
But all day long, the drumbeat of military noises -- and the urgent dispatch of American Cabinet members to consult with allies -- gave a sense of moment to Mr. Clinton's words.
Mr. Clinton is considering sending Defense Secretary William S. Cohen to the Persian Gulf early next week to seek backing for a military strike against Iraq if Mr. Hussein continues to block the inspections, and American officials have begun to talk more openly of attacking Iraq.
"There is an increasing feeling that the diplomatic options have exhausted themselves," the Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said today, "and that leaves us little choice to achieve our goals than to look at military action."
Mr. Clinton is also sending Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on Thursday to Europe, where she will confer with the British, French and Russian Foreign Ministers about Iraq. "She will go to explain the stakes involved and her feeling that diplomatic options are becoming exhausted," a senior Administration official said.
Nonetheless, the British are taking the lead in discussing a new resolution to be introduced in the United Nations Security Council that will try to give President Hussein another chance to back down in the face of the military threat, while a Russian diplomat is in Baghdad trying to find a way to avoid a military strike of any kind against Iraq.
The Russians have insisted publicly that the crisis in Iraq be resolved without the use of force, and there will be time for the Russians to try, at least until the Muslim holy month of Ramadan ends on Jan. 30, consultations with allies are finished and the Security Council pursues another round of diplomacy.
To that end, Mr. Clinton is also sending Bill Richardson, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, on a visit to new members of the Security Council to explain what is happening in Iraq, officials said.
But Washington insists that its threat to use military force is credible and that Iraq will be hit hard if it does not allow United Nations weapons inspectors "full and complete access" to all suspected sites, even those labeled presidential palaces, senior American officials say.
If full Iraqi compliance is offered, some Western diplomats said, the United States and Britain are considering a French suggestion to give Iraq at least a symbolic acknowledgment that progress on eliminating some weapons, in particular its nuclear weapons research program, is being made. But British and American diplomats insisted that economic sanctions would not be lifted until all United Nations demands were met.
Ms. Albright will travel from Europe to the Middle East to confer with the Persian Gulf allies most directly threatened by Iraq, who are urging that Washington hit Baghdad hard or not hit it at all, senior Western diplomats and American officials say.
Support from Saudi Arabia will be particularly important, the officials acknowledge. They hope that the Saudi royal family will authorize the use of the country's air bases for any air campaign against Baghdad. Western military officials insist that generalized Saudi political support is essential but the bases are not, given three American and British aircraft carriers in the gulf and land-based bombers in Diego Garcia and Bahrain.
American officials insist that new Security Council authorization is not required and that Washington will act alone against Iraq if necessary.
American and British officials are planning for a military option that would include a three- or four-day intensive bombing campaign aimed at suspected weapon sites, control and intelligence centers and the elite Republican Guard. Those strikes might be followed by a pause to allow Mr. Hussein to back down.
Ms. Albright is also expected to visit Israel and the Palestinian Authority to follow up Mr. Clinton's talks last week with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, with the hope that a concrete sign of progress on the negotiations will make talk of war against Iraq more acceptable to moderate Arab nations.
"They've now had a week to consider their options," a senior State Department official said. "We're expecting a more considered response."
Speaking for the Republicans in response to Mr. Clinton, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, underscored Congressional support for action against Iraq.
"Let me make one thing clear to Saddam Hussein -- or anyone else who needs to be told: Despite any current controversy, this Congress will vigorously support the President in full defense of America's interests throughout the world," Mr. Lott said.
Mr. Lott also used the Iraqi threat to urge Mr. Clinton to work with the Republicans to create a national defense against missiles, which the White House regards as too complicated and expensive.
In his State of the Union address, Mr. Clinton had only one relatively new international initiative: pressing for a new inspection system to detect and deter countries from cheating on the 23-year-old Biological Weapons Convention. "The rules are good, but the enforcement is weak," he said.
Officials said Washington wanted "more rigorous and frequent inspections," both voluntary and mandatory, to prevent Russia, China and countries formerly part of the Soviet bloc from continuing banned biological weapons programs. Mr. Clinton wants signatories to submit annual declarations about installations and activities that could be used for a biological weapons program.
Mr. Clinton also made an appeal for Congressional support on key foreign policy questions, including approval of the applications of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to join NATO.
"Within days," Mr. Clinton said, he will formally ask the Senate for its advice and consent on admitting the three countries to the alliance. The Senate is expected to vote this spring; approval requires a two-thirds vote.
"By taking in new members and working closely with new partners, including Russia and Ukraine, NATO can help to assure that Europe is a stronghold for peace in the 21st century," Mr. Clinton said.
He also appealed for bipartisan support for American troops and their mission in Bosnia, which has now been extended past June. "The progress there is unmistakable -- but t is not yet irreversible," Mr. Clinton said.
After extending the presence of American troops in Bosnia twice now, Mr. Clinton has refused to set a new deadline, saying their mission will be completed when achievable goals are met.
And he asked the Senate to approve the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which the United States signed in September 1996. While nearly 150 countries have signed the treaty against nuclear weapons tests, only 8 have ratified it, and the earliest it could come into force would be this September.
With the Iraq crisis continuing, Mr. Clinton also made an appeal for Congress to "make good on our debt to the United Nations." Increasingly, he said, "we are working with other nations to achieve common goals. If we want America to lead, we got to set a good example."
The world is also interconnected in its economic life, he said, "whether we like it or not," as the current crisis in Asia has shown. For that reason, he said, he is asking Congress to renew the American commitment to the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: Top Woman in Iran's Government Once Spoke for Hostage-Takers

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Massoumeh Ebtekar is the highest-ranking woman in Iran's Government, a symbol of President Mohammed Khatami's promise to promote women into high-profile positions.
A 37-year-old mother of two with a doctorate in immunology, Ms. Ebtekar was appointed last August as vice president for the environment, a job that gives a woman Cabinet rank for the first time in Iran's Islamic Republic. 
 But Ms. Ebtekar is a woman with a history, a history she would rather not dwell on these days.
More than 18 years ago, as an 18-year-old freshman at the Polytechnic University in Teheran, Ms. Ebtekar was the official interpreter and spokeswoman of the militants who occupied the American Embassy in Teheran. Speaking the near-perfect English she learned in the United States as a child, hiding her hair under a black hood, and using the nom de guerre "Mary," she became an object of anger and curiosity with her appearances on American television.
Night after night she listed the "crimes" of America against Iran and denounced the hostages as "spies" who should be put on trial if the United States did not turn over the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, to Iran's revolutionary leadership.
Asked by an ABC News correspondent whether she could see herself picking up a gun and killing the hostages, she replied: "Yes. When I've seen an American gun being lifted up and killing my brothers and sisters in the streets, of course."
These days her role in the embassy seizure is largely forgotten, or at least ignored. It is nowhere on her official resume; it was not included in the extensive profile and interview of her that appeared in Zanan, a prominent women's magazine, after her appointment.
Ms. Ebtekar meets foreign journalists and dignitaries to explain how Iran is struggling to improve Teheran's dismal air quality and to prevent further pollution of the Caspian Sea from oil development. Later this week she will accompany Iran's Foreign Minister and the Governor of the Central Bank to the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
But when confronted by an American journalist who said she recognized her from her role in the embassy occupation, Ms. Ebtekar acknowledged that she was the face and voice of the keepers of the hostages.
Her words came slowly, when asked directly whether she was "Mary."
"I was," she said. "But I don't bring those things up."
Asked about the wisdom or folly of that chapter in Iranian history, she had no apology and made no excuses.
"I wouldn't think that it would be logical for any nation to look back and to see any part of their revolution or their movement as negative because at that time, when it is considered in its own context, that was the best direction that could have been taken," she said in English in an interview in her office. "I feel that in that context, that reality, it was a basic necessity in society, in that period of the revolution to preserve the values."
Dressed in a long pin-striped coat, a dark-blue headdress and high-heeled boots, Ms. Ebtekar seemed nonplussed that she had been recognized.
She said it was a band of students, not the authorities, who planned and carried out the embassy takeover. She recalled that she, like the other hostage-takers, lived in the embassy compound at different stages to guard their captives.
Asked how she was assigned such an important role as official spokeswoman at such a young age, she smiled. "Everybody just naturally found their roles," she said.
After the hostages were freed on the day of Ronald Reagan's Inauguration as President in January 1981, some hostage-takers were rewarded with influential jobs -- as ambassadors and deputy ministers, for example. Others were elected to Parliament.
In 1981 Ms. Ebtekar was made editor in chief of the English-language newspaper Kayhan International. The man who gave her the job was Mr. Khatami, who was then head of the Kayhan publishing house.
As President, Mr. Khatami has stressed the importance of creating a civil society in which the rule of law prevails.
In his interview with CNN earlier this month, Mr. Khatami even expressed regret that the feelings of the American people had been "hurt" by the hostage crisis, the closest any senior Iranian official has come to apologizing.
But his appointment of Ms. Ebtekar to such a lofty post raises questions about whether he considers her past role relevant or if he simply does not understand how deeply it affected both the American Government and the American people.
"I continue to regard the seizure of the embassy as among the most egregious violations of the traditions and norms of diplomacy and a gross violation of human rights," Bruce Laingen, the charge d'affaires and most senior diplomat at the American Embassy when it was seized, said in a telephone interview. "I'm offended and regret that one of those involved in that violation is now honored in this way."
Iranian officials declined to speculate about the reasons for Ms. Ebtekar's appointment, except to say that she is eminently qualified for the job.
During the interview, Ms. Ebtekar explained how she came to speak English so well. She lived in Teheran until she was 3, then moved with her parents to a middle-class suburb of Philadelphia. She lived there for six years, attending Highland Park elementary school while her father was a doctoral student in engineering at the University of Pennsylvania.
After returning to Iran, she continued studying English at the international school in Teheran. As a freshman majoring in engineering at the Polytechnic University, she took part in demonstrations that helped topple the Shah.
Later she became a university professor and activist in women's affairs. Her father, she said, was the revolution's first Minister of the Environment, and she is proud to sit in the same office he once did.
She also talked about the burden of the early days of the revolution, when she was so young.
"The men and women who came up with the revolution have undergone such difficult stages, difficult stages -- both social and political turmoil," she said. "Just undertaking and shouldering the responsiblity of implementing and bringing forth a new set of values."
At the end of the interview, Ms. Ebtekar told her American guest to turn off the tape recorder. Then she asked that not very much be written about her role as Mary.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Subtext Vs. the Text

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Like Richard M. Nixon in the same ceremonial setting almost 24 years ago, Bill Clinton struggled tonight to convince Congress and the country that he has not already become a past-tense President.
It seemed almost as if two films were running at once on this intensely charged evening in the Capitol, with one depicting a ritual of state, complete with traditional gestures of politesse, and the other telling a depressing, altogether more sordid story. Which was true? Which mattered the most? 
 "It's not so much a question of whether Clinton can survive," one of the President's aides said glumly this afternoon, "but whether he can lead effectively for two or three more years when he'll be the butt of Jay Leno's jokes every night."
In a State of the Union Message originally designed to re-energize his Presidency, with a potentially highly popular proposal to use any budget surpluses to shore up the Social Security system, Mr. Clinton tonight sought to muffle the drumbeat of accusations about his involvement with a White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.
Unlike Mr. Nixon, who vowed in his final State of the Union address in 1974 to survive Watergate, Mr. Clinton never mentioned the crisis that gripped his Presidency.
Instead, he began with a glowing report on American life today, in accord with the Constitutional mandate requiring Presidents to "from time to time give the Congress information of the state of the Union." Then, as if unfazed by the frenzied melodrama of recent days, he slowly unrolled the traditional national shopping list -- education, trade, welfare, health, defense, campaign reform, urban development, the environment.
"Save Social Security first," he said in a key passage of a speech as formulaic in structure as last year's or next year's. "I propose that we reserve 100 percent of the surplus -- that's every penny of any surplus -- until we have taken all the measures necessary to strengthen the Social Security system."
Not that he and his aides and the members of Congress arrayed beneath him were not thinking about Ms. Lewinsky. A few Senators and Representatives, but only a few, confessed beforehand that they would be pondering their Constitutional roles as accusers and jurors (should it come to impeachment). Many more, along with White House staff members, were wondering about Mr. Clinton's capacity to continue to govern.
A senior Democratic Senator, speaking on condition of anonymity, put it this way: "I don't think he's through as President, but unless he's lucky, I think he may be through as a commanding political figure."
The President's strategy was clear enough: to persuade the nation that in these "good times for America," as he called them, the vigor of the economy, low inflation, reduced crime and new proposals for Social Security and child care and other measures to help those whom the boom has bypassed were far more important than his own sexual peccadilloes, real or imagined.
By dwelling only on substance, he sought to persuade voters to compartmentalize their minds the way he and his wife say they do, setting aside charges and lawsuits and scandals and concentrating on the serious business of government. No connection between the two, he implied. One public, the other private.
But how much attention did ordinary people pay to what he was saying? Were they wondering how he could pull any of this off, given the Lewinsky situation? Were they searching his eyes for clues as to whether they should believe his earlier denials of a sexual relationship with her, and watching for body language that might bespeak his state of mind, even if his words did not?
Or were they carefully digesting his list of policy prescriptions?
Underlying the whole spectacle -- indeed, the whole Lewinsky episode -- was the proposition that Thomas Jefferson expressed so elegantly in his inaugural address: "Sometimes it is said that man cannot be trusted with the government of himself. Can he then be trusted with the government of others?"
In trying to put across his program tonight, and then put it into effect, Mr. Clinton faced a multi-layered problem that would have daunted most men but seemingly not him.
First, all State of the Union speeches are wish lists, unlike speeches that open European parliaments, which are specific pledges to pass specific laws. No American President can make such promises, because while he proposes, Congress disposes.
Second, in this Congress both Houses are controlled by the Republicans, who have no real incentive to go along with the President.
Third, Mr. Clinton has only limited influence with the members of his own party on Capitol Hill.
And fourth, a series of scandals -- Whitewater, Travelgate, Filegate, fund-raising violations -- plus the Gennifer Flowers and Paula Jones cases, have eroded the President's credibility, to some degree with the public and to a greater degree among officeholders. Political professionals here and in Arkansas have for years heard tales of a licentious personal life, so they are extremely skeptical about his denials in the latest "bimbo eruption," to use the expression coined by his onetime aide, Betsey Wright.
Even before the Lewinsky case became public, the electorate took a somewhat jaundiced view of the President, which must haunt him as he seeks to cement a prominent place in history. In a Time magazine poll in early June, voters were asked what they thought Mr. Clinton would be remembered for 25 years from now. More than twice as many said "controversy over his personal life and financial dealings" as said "his accomplishments as President."
One of Mr. Clinton's goals has been to restore people's faith in government. That theme was sounded toward the end of his speech tonight. "Our government, the instrument of our national community, must earn the confidence of the American people," he said.
Missing from his text, perhaps not wholly surprisingly, was any acknowledgment that disillusionment with leadership played a role in disillusionment with government.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: CONGRESS;
Republicans Seek to Seize High Ground as Democrats Begin to Rally Around President

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Facing a weakened adversary, Republicans today sidestepped the titillating questions surrounding President Clinton and sought to present themselves as the stable, substantive political alternative.
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, captured the tone in the party's official televised response to the President's State of the Union address, devoting his speech to Republican proposals for tax cuts and tax simplification, better schools, and smaller government. 
 His hands folded, staring intently into the camera, he framed the difference between the two political parties with two simple questions: "Big government or families? More taxes or more freedom?" And just as Mr. Clinton has in recent years he spoke repeatedly of children and families.
He may have been taking a veiled swipe at Mr. Clinton when he said the Republican Congress had only just begun "the difficult job of stopping big government, making it more responsive and -- perhaps hardest of all -- rebuilding the trust you used to have in your elected officials."
The Mississippi Republican's only oblique allusion to Mr. Clinton's problems was a warning to Iraq. "Let me make one thing clear to Saddam Hussein, or anyone else who needs to be told," Mr. Lott said. "Despite any current controversy this Congress will vigorously support the President in full defense of America's interests throughout the world."
Democrats, aware of the high stakes for their party and reassured by polls that show Mr. Clinton retaining public backing, began rallying around Mr. Clinton in force, echoing Hillary Rodham Clinton's combative defense of her husband.
They cheered him and grabbed for his hand as he came down the aisle of the House chamber and rose to their feet for him time and again.
Just hours earlier, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader who has so often been at odds with Mr. Clinton, gave a rousing speech of support for him before a closed-door caucus of House Democrats.
Democrat after Democrat emerged from the session slamming the press, the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, and blaming for President's troubles the same right-wing conspiracy machine that Mrs. Clinton had attacked earlier in the day.
"There are strings that lead, wires that lead, to the right wing camps from the very beginning," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House minority whip. Representative James P. McGovern, a Democrat from Massachusetts, said, "Starr is dropping new allegations and innuendos every day. This is not "Melrose Place." This is the United States Government. We need to get on with the people's business."
But intent on holding the moral high ground, Republicans resolutely promoted their own view of policy issues. "If we're truly going to help American families," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the chairman of the Republican conference, "and we're going to renew the moral spirit in our country, we've got to find a way to get this tax load down on American families."
Under the banner of "family, faith and freedom," Mr. Lott spoke of the past successes of the Republican Congress, then outlined a program that played to historic Republican advantages on tax cutting and tax simplification, and on fighting crime and drugs.
"Republicans want you, the people who work hard for the money, to keep more of what you earn," he said. "The President seems to think that big Government can solve all of your children's problems if you if you will just give Government more of your money and more control over your lives. Nonsense." He called for oversight hearings to find out why Americans "aren't getting their money's worth from Government."
He also highlighted proposals on education -- including teacher merit pay and school tuition vouchers -- to try to erode the Democratic edge on that issue. "When one quarter, one out of four, of our high school students can barely read, isn't it obvious the current system isn't working?" Mr. Lott asked.
On a social issue of importance to party conservatives, Mr. Lott challenged Senate Democrats to help override Mr. Clinton's veto of legislation that would have banned a particular abortion procedure in which a fetus is partly delivered and then its skull is collapsed. Mr. Lott called this "the dreadful practice of partial-birth abortion."
With the nation looking toward the first budget surpluses in three decades, Republicans began aggressively standing against new spending programs. But they did not immediately embrace Mr. Clinton's call for 100 percent of the surplus to be dedicated to shoring up the Social Security system for the retirment of the baby boom generation.
"We should commit here and now not to spend any budget surplus on unnecessary Government programs," Mr. Lott said. "If there is a surplus we should use it to pay down the national debt and return the rest to you the taxpayer. After all it's your money.".
Representative Robert Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who chairs the Appropriations Committee, said, "If you took his speech at face value, you'd have a very difficult time to find any surplus because he spent it all on everything else."
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, called many of Mr. Clinton's proposals a "nonstarter for a Republican Congress." He said Republican leaders were looking to go beyond Mr. Clinton's promise to present a balanced budget for the 1999 fiscal year and to seek balance in the current fiscal year, which ends in September. That would require a $5 billion reduction in spending.
In a sign of how determined the Republicans are to play hardball while the White House is reeling, even before Mr. Clinton spoke, Mr. DeLay declared one Clinton initiative after another dead or in peril.
He said the President had actually lost some of his Republican support for expanded trade authority. He proclaimed that there was "no way in the world right now" Congress would approve more financing for the International Monetary Fund "particularly when the "President of the United States is not out there taking the lead, trying to convince the American people it's in the interests of the United States to bail out corporations and banks for bad economic decisions."
Mr. DeLay also cast doubt on the fate of the tobacco settlement, saying Republicans had doubts about the precedent that would be set if tobacco companies have immunity from prosecution.
Buoyed Democrats, rallied not just around Mr.Clinton but around a program they saw as a winning election-year platform. "The speech reminded us why the President stays popular through everything that's hit him," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat.
Only occasionally during the day did lawmakers veer from their respective party scripts. Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, ignoring party instructions not to delve into the details of the allegations against the President, could not resist going after the credibility of Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern who has reportedly said that she had an affair with Mr. Clinton. "I haven't heard that she played with a full deck in her other experiences," Mr. Rangel said.

Godspeed, John Glenn." (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: REACTION;
Tics and Gestures Steal the Show

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Watching with a contagious interest in nuance and deportment as much as in words, in what was not said as much as what was, Americans reacted to President Clinton's State of the Union Message with varying enthusiasm for his agenda and equally divided opinions on the state of his composure.
Drawn to television by a week of frenzied pursuit of Presidential amatory entanglements, people seemed to find it difficult to sort out their thoughts on what they saw and heard, as they weighed the personal with the political. Never were they more attentive to physical attributes, or lack thereof. 
 "Look at those bags under his eyes," said Lilian Redondo, 64, a retired phone company worker who was watching at a bar in Los Angeles. "You know he hasn't slept."
When he had finished his speech, Ms. Redondo remarked: "It didn't matter what he said. But he gave it his best shot."
Kate Lockwood, a sophomore at Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vt., said the scandal enveloping the President made her skeptical of his every smile and gesture.
"The facts that he gave in the whole speech, they are hard to deny," Ms. Lockwood said. "I just had a hard time believing. The whole time, I kept thinking, How do I know what you're saying? Maybe you're lying to me."
A small, sometimes boisterous crowd assembled around a television at Louie's, a bar and restaurant in Dallas. John E. Collins, 58, a lawyer, furnished a running commentary in which he underscored the President's repeated use of the phrase, "a more perfect union." Yet Mr. Collins gave the President an A-plus for his performance.
Richard Scherba, a Republican lawyer at Louie's, added, "If this was his swan song, he did it with great grace."
But Mr. Scherba judged the substance of the address unfavorably. "We've now entered the realm of the virtual reality surplus," he said. "They say it's real. It looks real. But it doesn't exist off the screen."
Nonetheless, Mr. Scherba's belief was that people were less curious than customary about Mr. Clinton's words. "They were observing the state of the President," he said.
Indeed, for most viewers, the Presidential address had the feel of a fictive adventure, a declaration of political intent caught in a salacious subtext. There was often an anticipatory undercurrent as the words were spoken: Might he say something about it? Would there be news of the bedroom as well as the budget?
It was a speech in which viewers dissected facial tics, worry lines, eye movement, the demeanor of the First Lady -- keys, they hoped, that would unlock inner secrets.
"He seems a little strained," said Katie Towler, 41, a freelance writer who watched the address with her husband, James A. Sparrell, 41, a psychologist, at the home of friends in Portsmouth, N.H. "He doesn't have his usual, his usual verve."
"Yeah," her husband said. "I don't think he looks or sounds the same. I have never seen him look like that. He looks exhausted."
"He looks terrible," his wife said.
Others saw the same picture and judged the President's demeanor altogether differently.
"He seemed quite composed in spite of all the misery he's in," said Lyle Mercer, a Seattle retiree. "He put on quite a good show."
Mr. Sparrell, in Portsmouth, said the focus on scandal took attention from other issues.
"It's sad that the substantive stuff, unemployment, the deficit, are down and no one is paying attention," he said.
Robert Gainor, 34, a lawyer at the Portsmouth gathering, also wanted to look beyond the events of the last week. "I give him credit," Mr. Gainor said. "I think he's done stuff."
As the President turned in his speech to his proposal to hire more teachers and reduce class size, Mr. Gainor signaled his approval: "Yeah, well, that's good. He's going to points that people understand."
Jack McEnany, 41, a writing teacher, could not refrain from alluding to the accusations that Mr. Clinton had had an affair with a White House intern in her 20's: "He's been doing some mentoring himself, hasn't he?"
Many people came away from the address imbued with hope.
"He transcended the crisis," said William O. Goodman, a plaintiff's lawyer in Austin, Tex. "He didn't abandon any of his principles. It's like his problems didn't even exist. It's a class act. Remarkable."
Others gave the address itself high marks. "The speech was fantastic," said Ramon Casteneda, 54, a bartender in Los Angeles. "He addressed the points that are especially important to children so that they can go to college. I'm a working man. I can't afford things like college for my two kids because it is so expensive."
Six people who watched the address together in Miami were disappointed that Mr. Clinton did not include more serious proposals on the environment, and one wanted to hear about food stamps being restored to the elderly and disabled. But on the whole, they approved of the speech.
"He satisfied everything that I wanted him to do," said Kathleen Egan, 42, a hospital administrator. "He got on with the business at hand, the business of running the country."
Diane Greenwald, a Manhattan psychiatrist, said she liked what the President said about rescuing Social Security and about health plans, but otherwise thought the topics were too global. "He gave everybody everything they needed," she said.
Ms. Greenwald's daughter, Laurabeth, who is in eighth grade, said she thought the President "made everything too perfect."
"It got kind of annoying," she said.
She grimaced when the President mentioned mandatory summer school, and she asked, "Isn't he going to extremes?"
Any number of viewers confessed, not without some pangs of chagrin, that the scandal had intensified their interest in the speech.
"Ordinarily, I may not have been very interested in the State of the Union, though we watch it every year, but I will have my antenna up and listen more thoroughly tonight," Sue Dickerson, 75, a retired social worker, acknowledged before tuning in at her Memphis home. "I guess it's kind of sadistic, but here's a man up there squirming for his life and it will be interesting to watch. Isn't that terrible?"
Some people said that they were disappointed that the President did not address the accusations against him, while others were relieved at the omission.
"He has to mention it, he should mention it," said Bill Prett, 46, an inventor of refrigeration equipment who watched the address at the Texas Chili Parlor in Austin. "People expect it and they'll wonder what's up if he doesn't."
Doatsy Shrake, 54, a real estate agent who also watched while indulging in chili, agreed, saying, . "He needs to acknowledge it somehow, even if it's only to refer to domestic affairs."
But Jesse Petty, 26, the manager of the chili parlor, had a different view. "As long as he's not sleeping with me, I'm not interested," she said. "It's none of my business."
Loren Callahan, 26, a photographer in Seattle, said there was a time and place for answering the accusations, and last night was not it.
"No, not in the State of the Union," Ms. Callahan said. "That's the state of Bill."
Eight students who watched the speech with one of their professors in a dorm room at DePaul University in Chicago, punctuating their viewing with snickers and sly jokes, agreed that the President appeared strong and did what he needed to do.
There was applause when Mr. Clinton issued his stern warning to the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Applause resounded again when he called for the United States to pay its tardy dues to the United Nations.
Though the students had their disagreements on various policy points in the speech, they echoed the sentiments of Angela Lam, 21, a senior and political science major, who said: "I think we saw vintage Clinton. No matter what's going on behind the scenes, he's going to show strength. He wasn't going to let on that there was any crisis in his Administration."
Thomas Stein, 21, also a senior and political science major, said he thought the President managed to put people at ease.
"He appears to be strong at a time of weakness and presents to the nation that his Administration is moving forward," Mr. Stein said. "I think the nation forgot about his problems for this hour."
Sharon Bicks, 36, a caterer in Memphis, watched the address while making 11 dozen ham biscuits. "The speech enhanced my opinion of Clinton," she said. "I had been distracted by these allegations, but now I'm refocused on what this President has meant for this country and the world, and it is all absolutely positive."
Of course, not everyone could weigh the words and the issues without strong sour emotions.
"I had a hard time focusing on what he was saying," said Karen Shea, 52, a Memphis investment broker and a registered Republican who said she voted for Mr. Clinton in 1992 and 1996. "All I could think was, You're a liar and a hypocrite."
"A lot of good things have happened during his Presidency," Ms. Shea said. "I voted for him because he does care about the issues I care about. And I like a lot of what he said tonight. But I still think he needs to go. I couldn't help but laugh when he talked about responsibility."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON, WITH CRISIS SWIRLING, PUTS FOCUS ON SOCIAL SECURITY IN UPBEAT STATE OF UNION TALK

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton, facing the gravest personal and political peril in a crisis-prone career, emerged from the darkness shrouding his Presidency for more than an hour tonight to proclaim the state of the Union sound and to propose a plan to rescue Social Security.
Swathed in bright television lights and enveloped in the grandeur of the House chamber, the President was met by a thunderous ovation from both sides of the aisle as he arrived at 9:09 P.M. to deliver his annual State of the Union address. On a rainy night in a scandal-fevered capital, the political world suspended its speculation on Mr. Clinton's personal and legal future and focused, if distractedly, on his political program. 
 Mr. Clinton decided several days ago to make no reference in his speech to the accusations against him and he did not. He hewed more closely than usual to his prepared text, which was released late in the afternoon -- hours earlier than for any previous State of the Union speech. Transcript, page A19.
The President delivered what amounted to a political manifesto for the midterm election, proposing billions of dollars in new spending on social programs that have proved popular with the public, paid for through closing unspecified tax loopholes and billions of dollars in tobacco taxes that may never be enacted.
As the soaring economy generates surplus revenue beyond what is needed to balance the budget and pay for the President's spending priorities, Mr. Clinton hopes to use the excess money to begin to address the largest fiscal problem confronting the nation -- the future of Social Security.
In the centerpiece of his speech, Mr. Clinton said that the surpluses bequeathed by six years of robust economic growth should be set aside until a solution is found to the looming insolvency of Social Security, the politically sacred core of the Government's contract with the American people. His message to both Democrats and Republicans salivating to spend the bounty on new programs or tax cuts was the same: Wait.
"What should we do with this projected surplus?" Mr. Clinton asked rhetorically. "I have a simple four-word answer: Save Social Security first." The chamber erupted in applause.
"Tonight I propose that we reserve 100 percent of the surplus -- that's every penny of any surplus -- until we have taken all the necessary measures to strengthen the Social Security system for the 21st century," Mr. Clinton said.
Two years after he declared the end of the era of big government, Mr. Clinton painted a sweeping landscape of Federal activism, from subsidies for care of babies to expansion of the health-care program for the elderly.
He presented a Democratic plan to distribute the spoils of a strong economy to schoolteachers, working parents, laid-off workers and Medicare recipients, a distinct contrast to Republican desires to cut taxes, bolster military spending and devote billions of dollars to traditional public works projects.
"We have moved past the sterile debate between those who say Government is the enemy and those who say Government is the answer," Mr. Clinton said in a succinct statement of his animating philosophy. "My fellow Americans, we have found a third way. We have the smallest Government in 35 years, but a more progressive one. We have a smaller Government, but a stronger nation."
But the unanswered question that hung over the Capitol was whether Mr. Clinton would remain in office or have the political clout to carry out his ambitious plan to use Government as a lever to carry the nation into the next century.
And even if he manages to survive the current crisis over his reported sexual misconduct with a former White House intern, it remains uncertain whether he will command the political and moral authority to govern.
The only sign of the strain Mr. Clinton is under were the deep bags beneath his eyes.
Once the decision was made to avoid mentioning the scandal, aides said that they combed the wording for any word or phrase that could be interpreted as an oblique reference to the accusations.
Few other politicians of his generation -- or any other -- could have pulled off a performance like that of Mr. Clinton tonight. For 74 minutes, the President bestrode the national stage enveloped in the trappings of great office -- the Speaker's throne and the vibrant colors of the oversized American flag behind him, before him the assemblage of the elite of the three branches of American Government and the diplomatic corps.
The hum of the evening was not of greatness, but of the proximity of tragedy to triumph, a reminder that such offices are occupied by mere men who can be stripped of their majesty overnight by their own human frailty.
In yet another sign that history looks upon humanity with a gimlet eye, Mr. Clinton delivered his State of the Union address on the same day that his personal secretary, Betty Currie, was called before a Federal grand jury investigating charges of perjury and obstruction of justice involving the President.
Also today, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has taken charge of her husband's defense against the accusations of adultery and perjury, said on national television that she and her husband were the targets of a "vast right-wing conspiracy."
Mrs. Clinton, who gazed down on her husband from the House balcony with assent and apparent admiration as he spoke, has been Mr. Clinton's most stalwart defender in the most personally punishing week the President has endured.
In Oslo, three conservative members of the Norwegian Parliament nominated Mr. Clinton for the Nobel Peace Prize, citing his foreign policy accomplishments.
The speech was well-received, interrupted at least 90 times by applause, frequently only by Democrats. That was the highest number of applause interruptions in Mr. Clinton's State of the Union address in the past four. In 1995, there were 96.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, delivered the Republican response to Mr. Clinton's address. He argued that the President offered a vision of more Government, while the Republicans promised a smaller Government and lower taxes.
And he said that the Republican-led Congress intended to hold Government accountable: "From the classrooms to the courts. From the clerks to the President's Cabinet. From the post office to the Presidency."
Mr. Clinton sailed forward into the stiff wind of adversity, taking political comfort from what he called the healthiest domestic economy in a generation and the first balanced budget in 30 years.
"Turning a sea of red ink into black is no miracle," Mr. Clinton said. "It is the product of hard work by the American people and of two visionary actions in Congress -- the courageous vote in 1993 that led to a cut in the deficit of 90 percent and the truly historic bipartisan balanced budget agreement passed by this Congress.
"Here's the really good news: if we maintain our resolve, we will produce balanced budgets as far as the eye can see."
He promised more spending for food safety and biomedical research, renewed his call for a war on smoking by teen-agers, advocated an increase in the minimum wage and proposed new programs to help workers displaced by foreign competition.
On foreign policy, he urged Congress to support his call for shoring up the International Monetary Fund so that it could deal with the economic crisis sweeping Asia. He said that the fate of the economies of Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea have a direct impact on American jobs and prosperity.
"Preparing for a far-off storm that may reach our shores is far wiser than ignoring the thunder until the clouds are just overhead," he said.
To Iraq, he issued a threat of military action if Baghdad did not quickly come into compliance with the United Nations weapons inspection program.
"I know I speak for everyone in this chamber, Republicans and Democrats, when I say to Saddam Hussein: You cannot defy the will of the world. And when I say to him: you have used weapons of mass destruction before and we are determined to deny you the capacity to use them again."
He threatened military action against Iraq and chided his own party for denying him authority to negotiate free-trade deals.
Many of the specific proposals in the speech had been foreshadowed over the past several weeks. The President's desire tonight was to describe the philosophical threads that weave the programs into a coherent vision of governance.
"We are moving steadily toward an even stronger America in the 21st century," Mr. Clinton said. "An economy that offers opportunity. A society rooted in responsibility. And a nation that lives as a community."
Mr. Clinton, who only a day earlier angrily pronounced the humiliating words, "I never had sexual relations with that woman," tonight spoke of using his office to strengthen the American family.
He repeated his proposal for a $1.50-a-package tax on cigarettes to discourage smoking by young people. He proposed scholarships and background checks for child care workers. He asked Congress to increase the tax deduction for day care for middle-income families.
He called for the hiring of 100,000 new teachers, to reduce the size of classes in grades 1 to 3 to 18 students nationwide, but did not specify the means to pay for the costly plan. He renewed his proposal for expanding Medicare to cover Americans as young as 55 who had lost their health insurance because of corporate layoffs, which officials said would be financed by reductions in "fraud and abuse" in the Medicare program.
