HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: IN THE POLLS;
Confidence Grows in Clinton's Ability to Remain Effective

BYLINE: By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
The State of the Union address appears to have bolstered the American public's view that President Clinton can continue to govern effectively and accomplish policy goals, but the public remains divided on the issues surrounding accusations of an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, according to several polls conducted immediately after the President's speech.
Support for the job Mr. Clinton is doing increased in a poll conducted by CBS News. But Presidential job ratings tend to receive a bounce in polls taken immediately after a State of the Union address. 
 The polls also found Mr. Clinton's morals and honesty to be viewed more positively. For example, the Gallup Organization conducted polls before and after the speech with the same group of people. Before Mr. Clinton's address, only 35 percent said he set a good moral example for the nation, and 61 percent said he did not. After the speech, opinion was more evenly divided: 49 percent said the President set a good moral example and 47 percent said he set a poor one.
These findings and other survey results need to be viewed in the context of limits of these types of polls, which are typically quick and taken minutes after a specific event. For example, only the opinions of people who are home during a short period of time are measured.
CBS News asked whether assertions of infidelity and obstruction of justice would interfere with Mr. Clinton's ability to do his job effectively. On Monday night, 51 percent said those accusations would interfere with his ability to govern effectively; 46 percent said they would not interfere. But after the speech that impression changed as well: 41 percent said he would be impeded, while 58 percent said he would not.
But there appears to be no real change in the public's view of whether there is any truth in the accusations that Mr. Clinton had an affair with the 21-year-old intern. In NBC polls both before and after the speech, nearly 40 percent said they thought Mr. Clinton did have an affair with Ms. Lewinsky. About 30 percent continued to say that the accusations were untrue. The rest offered no opinion.
NBC and ABC each polled random samples of adults by telephone immediately after the speech, finding that about 6 in 10 had watched the speech. The NBC poll includes the views of 405 adults and the ABC poll is based on 528 adults. Gallup called back 488 adults who had previously been polled, and re-interviewed the 400 who had watched the speech. CBS News recruited a sample of the public to watch the speech, and 843 participants called an 800 number to respond to questions after the speech.
The margin of sampling error for all of the nationwide polls was plus or minus 4 or 5 percentage points. In addition, polls conducted entirely in one night introduce additional error.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Workers Revitalize a Town

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: DODGE CITY, Kan.

 BODY:
Like a swaggering cowboy coming in off the trail of old, Dodge City is flush these days. Its economy, if not booming, is at least "hitting on all cylinders," in the words of one business leader, and the muscle is being supplied largely by men and women from Mexico and Central America.
For more than a decade, the immigrants have been pouring onto the High Plains to work in the meatpacking plants here, drawn by the lure of stable jobs at union wages with full benefits and the chance to buy a home and join the middle class. Some come wearing cowboy hats and driving pickup trucks with Mexican license plates. Others are veterans of the insecure life of migrant farm work farther west. 
 Still others are fleeing what they see as the increasingly unwelcoming atmosphere of Southern California, or they have left lower-wage jobs in Texas. They are taking jobs that civic and business leaders say local young people shun as they leave for opportunities in larger cities.
"The story here and across this part of the country is that we've quit producing an adequate number of workers to do the jobs traditionally done in various communities," said John C. Campbell, president of the Dodge City Area Chamber of Commerce.
"Dodge City is engaged in the important business of feeding the population," Mr. Campbell said, "but without enough workers. In this country, we've made it socially unacceptable for our own young people to do anything except the white-collar-and-tie kind of job. So Hispanic workers are doing those jobs -- in the slaughter houses -- for average wages of $22,000 a year, which makes them middle income in Dodge City."
Hispanic workers constitute about 75 percent of the work force at Dodge City's two largest meatpackers, those of the Excel Corporation, part of Cargill Foods, with about 2,500 workers, and the National Beef Company, part of Farmland Industries Inc., with 1,300 to 1,400 workers. Similar estimates are made for the work forces of meatpacking plants at Garden City, Kan., 50 miles to the northwest, and Liberal, Kan., 75 miles to the southwest.
The trend is being repeated in many other low-population counties across the Midwest, the South and the Plains States, especially in communities with meat- or chicken-processing plants and low unemployment.
The Center for Immigration Studies, in Washington, said in a report last year, "Counties where immigration's impact is rated as 'intense' or 'hot' are found not only in California, Texas, Florida and New York, but also in Iowa, Georgia, Kansas and Idaho."
In addition, the spreading impact of immigration is thought to be understated in the report because it was based on data from the 1990 Census. In Dodge City's case, most of the immigrant influx has occurred since 1990.
The changing makeup of Dodge City resonates throughout the community, nowhere more so than in the public schools, which are struggling to deal with explosive growth and change in the student body. In Unified School District 443, which serves Dodge City, Hispanic students make up 42.7 percent of the 5,115 total. In the lower grades, they account for 52 percent to 54 percent of the pupils.
The population of Dodge City is estimated to be up 18 percent to 20 percent from the 1990 census figure of 21,000, and civic leaders say all of the increase, and more, can be attributed to the Hispanic arrivals. Without them, they say, the population would be declining.
More than half the home purchases last year were by Hispanic buyers. Some churches have become bilingual, with Hispanic members making up about half the congregations. Banks and stores are looking for bilingual employees.
The Dodge City Daily Globe publishes a tabloid weekly in Spanish. The School Superintendent, Sharol Little, is studying Spanish. So are the officers and staff members of the Ford County Sheriff's Office, a successor to law-enforcement operation once run by the fictional Marshal Matt Dillon and the real-life Bat Masterson and Wyatt Earp. About half the people in the county jail, which holds 72, are usually Hispanic detainees, said the Under Sheriff, Bryan Burgess.
Dodge City was founded in 1872, first serving as a center for the buying of buffalo hides and later as a trailhead for cattle driven up from Texas and then sent east on the Santa Fe Railroad, which still slices through the center of town.
Although a handful of Hispanic families have been here since their ancestors came as railroad workers, most of the longtime inhabitants of Dodge City are descendants of northern Europeans, some of whom made their way west along the Santa Fe Trail long ago.
 "We have two cultures that are diverse, but they're merging," said Jeffrey Hiers, an insurance man and chairman of the Chamber of Commerce. "If we said it was easy, we'd be lying, but we've not seen any big racial incidents, not like what I saw growing up in Atlanta in the 60's."
Israel Padilla, a native of the Mexican state of Chihuahua who married a Kansan, said he got along with both cultures in Dodge City and dismissed the problems as mostly small things. Mr. Padilla said, for example, there were complaints of rowdiness involving Hispanic residents.
"Spanish-speaking people like to express themselves, outside as well as inside," he said, "so noise is a problem for some people. But I always think that if you know the language you can get along with anyone."
Mr. Padilla, 32, is the youngest of nine children in a family split between Kansas and Chihuahua. He arrived as a high school junior, cared for by an older sister who found work in the meat plants. Struggling to learn English, Mr. Padilla finished high school, then went to St. Mary of the Plains College in Dodge City on a soccer scholarship and earned a degree in physical education. Along the way, he, too, went to work for Excel, where he remains today while looking for a job that will make use of his college degree.
As Mr. Padilla talked, another sign of the cultural divide showed when two of his brothers and two teen-age nephews walked in the front door of his home -- unannounced.
"They never call first," said Mr. Padilla's wife, Rebecca, who grew up in Wichita and met her husband in college.
One of the brothers, 36-year-old Jesus, sat down and talked about his work at the National Beef plant, pulling out a pay stub showing that, in a week with extra holiday pay, he earned $583 and cleared $443. A good job is all that keeps him in Dodge City, he said.
"I never wanted to come to the United States," he said. "I began to work in California years ago, then I returned to Chihuahua. But I couldn't find a good job, and my mother kept telling me to leave, that she didn't want me lying around the house being lazy."
By contrast, Horacio Padilla, 39, newly arrived from Texas, seemed thrilled that he had already been hired by National Beef, despite a shriveled left arm.
A question that seems to arise very infrequently is whether all of the immigrants are in this country legally. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has occasionally raided meatpacking plants in western Kansas and elsewhere on the High Plains, but civic leaders say the immigration service is spread so thin that its agents seldom get west of Wichita.
"We have no interest in hiring illegals," said Jim Maher, the human resource manager of Excel. "They do nothing but cause trouble because if they're caught they leave, and then we're short workers. We require all the documents the Government will allow us to request without running into conflicts with civil rights laws."
Mr. Maher said that "word of mouth" was his main recruitment tool, with workers here telling relatives in Mexico about the benefits and the wage scale, which starts at $8.64 an hour and goes to $12. Despite that, he said, the turnover at the plant is about 50 percent a year, with many people working a few months, then returning to Mexico, often to return here a year or so later.
The turnover in the beef plants is one reason school administrators and teachers face stiff challenges in educating some of the immigrants' children, as they are regularly withdrawn from school to return to Mexico. While maintaining instruction in English, the school system has hired a few bilingual teachers and more than 30 bilingual teachers' aides to provide individual help to new students with limited English.
School officials say about 20 percent of the Hispanic students arrive with virtually no knowledge of English. This year, a newcomers' class was initiated for those in grades three through six. It includes a six-week course in basic English, and then, with an assigned "buddy" to accompany them, the new students start regular class.
"When they come, they are intimidated by the United States," said Veronica Williams, the bilingual teacher of the newcomers' class. "We try to teach them self-esteem and build on the skills they have."
After more than 30 years without new schools, the school district opened three new elementary schools in 1995 and plans a vote this spring on a proposed $45.5 million bond issue to build a new high school and convert the old one into middle school classrooms. But administrators expect to be using portable classrooms before it is ready.
Even though most of the new Hispanic residents are not eligible to vote, school leaders expect the bond issue to pass easily, reflecting the expansive and optimistic mood that seems to pervade Dodge City. Last June, voters overwhelmingly approved an additional 1 cent sales tax to finance public works, including a special-events center.
All this adds up to an estimated $150 million in nonresidential construction, expected to begin within a year.
"And meatpacking is paying the bill," said Mr. Campbell of the Chamber of Commerce. "Does it smell? Yes. So do paper mills. And our air is cleaner than in Los Angeles."

HEADLINE: On the Record, Arab Leaders Oppose U.S. Attacks on Iraq

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 28

 BODY:
As the United States intensifies its threat to use military force against Iraq, Arab leaders are once again voicing strong public opposition to that course. But some officials are reportedly hinting in private that they would not be altogether dismayed if the United States did carry out military attacks.
In public, officials led by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt are warning as they have for months that military strikes would compound the misery of the Iraqi people, who have suffered enough through more than seven years of economic sanctions. 
 Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, whose country was a crucial ally of the United States during the Persian Gulf war in 1991, declared this week: "A military settlement cannot be considered a solution. It would be another problem."
And Esmat Abdel-Meguid, the Secretary General of the 21-member Arab League, said on Monday: "The principle of using force is downright rejected. Such a military strike would only add to the suffering of the Iraqi people."
But such statements have sounded less vociferous than those made as recently as November, when the latest crisis between the United Nations and Iraq began. And among strong American allies like Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, diplomats and officials there say, there appears to be growing resignation that the crisis must be resolved, even if that means the use of military force.
Diplomats in the Persian Gulf region say some officials there have told them in confidence that they would support military strikes at the weapons installations that give Iraq the ability to threaten its neighbors.
The apparent contradiction between those public and private views tells much about Arab sentiment about Iraq seven years after the gulf war. Concern about the plight of the Iraqi people has grown so deep across the Arab world that virtually no Arab leader is ready to publicly counsel military action.
At the same time, there remains no love lost for the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, who is reviled by his fellow Arab leaders. When promised anonymity, some Arab officials in the Persian Gulf have counseled the United States against the pinprick strategy adopted by American military planners in the past, which they say has only enhanced the Iraqi leader's popularity with his people.
Instead, they have argued, the United States should wage a sustained bombing campaign to destroy Iraq's capacity to produce weapons of mass destruction and undermine President Hussein's power.
Such thinking may be reflected in the private meetings that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is likely to hold with Arab leaders if she proceeds, as is now expected, from meetings in Europe beginning on Thursday on to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries.
"I cannot imagine any Arab state joining in or publicly endorsing any renewed attacks, and I would expect the criticism from many quarters to be vehement," said one gulf official. "At the same time, Saddam remains a headache for us all, and I think some of us would applaud privately if the United States can find a way to make him feel some pain.'
Still, the Arab news media and diplomats have voiced considerable skepticism in recent days about what may be behind the new show of American muscle-flexing.
A front-page editorial in the Egyptian Government daily Al Jumuriya addressed to Mr. Clinton warned on Tuesday: "Killing more Iraqis who are besieged and exhausted will not take you out of your problem. Your salvation remains in your ability to resist blackmail."
Some prominent Egyptians have argued that United States officials and Western diplomats are deliberately exaggerating the possibility that any military strike might receive private support.
Raouf el-Reedy, a former Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, said in an interview today: "This is a common line in American foreign policy. They always talk about private talk from some Arab countries. They need to show that they still have allies in the region."
And even as the Clinton Administration is trying to refocus attention on its months-long standoff with Iraq, Arab leaders say they are determined to maintain a focus on what they regard as an increasingly dangerous stalemate in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.
After a meeting this week with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, Egypt signaled that it might soon throw its support behind a Palestinian proposal for an Arab summit conference.
Mr. Moussa of Egypt said after the session that it was "a bit early" to set a time and place. But he described the convening of such a session as "a probability," which appeared to reflect the depth of Arab dismay over what has been perceived as the lack of progress last week in President Clinton's meetings with Mr. Arafat and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
Since leaving Washington last week, Mr. Arafat has paid visits to Mauritania, Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia in a bid to rally support for an Arab summit meeting.
If such a meeting is held, it could serve as a forum for Arab countries to express opposition to the prospect of new American attacks on Iraq.
But the force of such statements could be dulled if Ms. Albright and other American officials who are expected to tour the region in the days ahead receive assurances in private that such attacks, while not preferable, would not lead to a rupture in relations between the United States and the Arab world.

HEADLINE: Israel Sketches Out an Overall Drop in U.S. Aid Over 10 Years

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Israel's Finance Minister met with Administration and Congressional officials today to outline a proposal by the Israeli Government to phase out $1.2 billion in annual economic aid from the United States in exchange for a $600 million increase in Washington's yearly military aid package.
The proposal by Finance Minister Yaakov Neeman met with a cautious reception at the State Department and on Capitol Hill, with some officials questioning why the United States should increase its military assistance to Israel at a time when the Israeli Government is supposed to be committed to peace negotiations with its neighbors. 
 Mr. Neeman's mission to Washington this week grew out of a pledge made by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during an address to Congress two years ago to reduce Israel's dependence on American aid. Israel has repeatedly been reminded of that pledge as Congress has slashed billions of dollars from the foreign aid budget.
In a statement, Mr. Neeman said that the Israeli proposal to reduce the size of the overall American aid package, while increasing military aid, was "a bold step on the road to economic independence" that also recognized "Israel's ever-growing security needs."
Under the proposal, the current $1.2 billion annual economic aid package would be ended entirely over the next 10 to 12 years, while American military aid to Israel would be increased to $2.4 billion a year, from the current level of $1.8 billion.
Gadi Baltiansky, a spokesman for the Israel Embassy, said the increase in military aid was necessary because "we are not in a peace process with Iran or Iraq -- they are threatening to launch missiles at us and calling for our destruction."
While Congressional officials said they would welcome an effort by Israel to reduce its economic dependence on the United States, they were still concerned about the long time frame suggested by the Israelis for the phasing out of the economic aid, and by an Israeli request to spend more of the military aid in Israel.
Under the current aid package, Israel is limited to spending no more than 25 percent of the American military aid in Israel; most of the rest of the money is spent on weapons and other products from American contractors. In their meetings this week, Israeli officials asked that they be allowed to spend more of the military aid -- possibly most of it -- at home.
"I think members are impressed, definitely, that the Government of Israel has come forward with a proposal for a meaningful reduction in assistance," said a Congressional official who was involved with the talks and insisted that he not be identified. "But 10 to 12 years is a long time. I think we would definitely want the time frame to be shorter." And he said the Israeli request to spend more of the military aid in Israel "is problematic -- a lot of members of Congress would have a hard time justifying that."
Another Congressional official said that any increase in the military aid budget for Israel should be reviewed closely. "I guess the question is, why should we be talking about spending more money on weapons at a time when we all hope the Middle East is moving towards peace," he said, insisting on anonymity.
The State Department had no comment on its aid talks and said the United States had not yet taken a position on the proposal. "We're in listening mode," said a department official.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Frozen North Doesn't Jump For Hot News

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
WITH the news on the television at Kegler's Lounge and Restaurant, the lunchtime regulars were slightly distracted from their post-Super Bowl quarterbacking. Todd LaVere, behind the bar, heard President Clinton's name and gave a little smile.
"If the President can run the country and have relations on the side," he asked, "then what's it to anybody?" 
 "Yeah," said Jerry Corbett, rocking back on his bar stool. "If the President has as many women as they say and the country's in this good a shape, I say that makes him a pretty darn good President."
"What somebody does on the side -- their morals -- that's their business," Mr. LaVere said.
"I think so too," Jerry Corbett said.
Sitting next to him, Francis Hoffman, nursing a Molson, looked a little bored. A Jefferson County transportation worker who has spent the last three weeks clearing toppled trees from roads and driveways, he was still more interested in talking about the North Country ice storm than the Washington firestorm.
"People around here really aren't talking about the President," he said. "They're impressed by the ice storm. They've been talking about it for weeks. They'll be talking about it for years. Clinton? Nah."
He, like most everyone else here, has more immediate concerns. The Great Ice Storm of 1998 may have been knocked off the front pages of the local papers by the allegations that the President had sex with a former White House intern. But Watertown (pop.: 29,900) could be Paris in terms of its take on the scandal. Not that people don't care about what is happening in the capital; they do. But the sex scandal doesn't seem to have earth-shattering implications in this Republican stronghold, no matter what the talking heads on the news say.
The President of the United States might be relieved to know that not everyone is riveted to his political crisis. In a place that is dealing with its own catastrophe, his rates a distant second. Time and again, people interviewed here on the streets and in the mall said there was too much to do at home to worry about sorting out the ever-changing salacious details in the news.
"I don't really see why this story is as big as the media is making it out to be," Mr. Corbett said. "It's not Watergate." Mr. Corbett, a state transportation worker, has been working overtime clearing trees and assisting emergency situations. His own house on the outskirts of the city was without power for two weeks, but he considers himself lucky. "There are still some people in Alex Bay without power," he said.
THE ice storm, which knocked down power lines in six vast upstate counties, caused the Black River, which runs through Watertown, to overflow at more than 16 feet above flood level, a record. It continues to disrupt routines three weeks later. Businesses have yet to reach full speed, schools must rejigger exam and vacation schedules, and buildings are still flooded.
Few people would say they were left unscarred by the disaster, even those who lost power for only a few days. "I have a tree sitting on my roof," Mr. LaVere said nonchalantly, as if it belonged there. "The biggest problem for me is the loss of business. We were open, but people were busy coping with the storm."
About 150 city trees, mostly maples, are marked for euthanasia. That doesn't include the trees in backyards and front yards that must be cut. All day, every day, dump trucks and front-end loaders inch their way through town, picking up debris. And all day, every day, people are in and out of the old Woolworth building, which has become a one-stop emergency disaster center housing the Red Cross and other relief organizations.
Not to mention there are uncalculated millions in lost wages and business and in damage to assess in a city that was struggling economically before the storm.
Clinton? Nah. "Right now, people are still in recovery mode," said Mary Corriveau, the assistant city manager, when asked about the White House scandal. "There's always the talk when you're sitting around at lunch. But the major focus is on getting things back in order."
And ice storm or not, some people think the White House crisis does not merit their close attention. "I'm tired of trying to sort out the gossip," said Cara Weiss. She was buying The Watertown Times at Stewart's convenience store -- to catch up on storm-related developments.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Solid Earnings Drive Dow Up In Busy Session

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market erased the vestiges of an early-year decline yesterday, surging for the second consecutive day after a broad array of big-name companies reported solid quarterly earnings.
The profit reports overshadowed resilient anxiety over Asia's economic crisis that has hurt stocks for much of January and sent investors shopping for a wide variety of stocks on what turned out to be one of the heaviest trading sessions ever. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average soared 100.39 points, or 1.28 percent, to close at 7,915.47.
It was the highest close since Jan. 5 and marked the first time since August that the Dow had gained 100 or more points on consecutive days.
Broader indexes also rallied, with health care, technology and transportation stocks in heavy demand. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 8.44 points, or nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 977.46, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained about 2 percent.
"This was a very, very impressive showing," said Hildegard Zagorski, a market strategist at Prudential Securities. "Corporate profits were good, the economy remains strong and events in Asia have calmed down a little bit."
Strong profit results from Coca-Cola, Philip Morris and United Airlines helped set the tone early yesterday. Technology stocks surged after the Oracle Corporation, which had been struggling, said it expects to post solid earnings in its fiscal third quarter.
Few sectors were left out of yesterday's rally. The Dow Jones transportation index gained 2.7 percent and big technology stocks, as listed in the Morgan Stanley high tech index, gained 3.6 percent.
"Health care and technology stocks were screaming today," said Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "And transportation stocks also took off. That's partly because jet fuel is getting cheaper."
Although the stock market had been weathering a difficult January -- one plagued by a political fiasco at home and fears of a spreading economic crisis in Asia -- stock prices have held up relatively well. Wall Street strategists say that is an indication investors continue to send money into the market.
Profit expectations have been trimmed back for 1998, largely because of a slowdown in Asia, but investors may be recognizing that the American economy remains healthy and inflation seems to be a diminishing threat.
Those points were emphasized Tuesday night in President Clinton's State of the Union address, and some analysts believe the speech helped lift investor confidence. The possibility that the crisis at the White House may be subsiding may also be lifting investor spirits, they said.
"President Clinton underscored all the positives last night," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall 21st Advisers in New York. "So I think the market decided that bedrock basics are still very positive."
Among those basics are a strong domestic economy, what Abby Joseph Cohen -- the widely followed market strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company -- calls the "supertanker" economy because of its relentless course of growth, job creation and improved corporate profits.
Although fears remain about the impact of the crisis in Asia, many analysts continue to look to health care and technology stocks -- sectors that have proved to be the backbone of the stock market for more than a year.
Yesterday was no exception. Technology stocks had been underperforming the broader market since mid-October. But the last few days they have been gaining, led by the largest companies.
Intel and Microsoft -- the twin towers of the technology industry -- soared again yesterday. This year, shares of each of those companies are already up more than 15 percent. With yesterday's gain, Microsoft is now valued at $180 billion, more than the Big Three in the auto industry -- Ford, General Motors and Chrysler -- combined.
Even though corporate profit growth will slow in 1998, several Wall Street strategists said the market might have already factored in a slowdown. Since June, for instance, the Dow has been in what some Wall Street analysts call a "trading range," bouncing up and down between 7,500 and 8,200.
The Dow closed 1997 at 7,908.25. Coming into this week, it looked like the blue-chip average would post a loss in January for the first time since 1990, when the index fell nearly 6 percent.
But yesterday, the Dow crept above its 1997 close, and although there's almost no chance it will match the 5 percent gains recorded in the first month of the last two years, a positive return at the beginning of the year could help lift investor confidence.
"If we end up with a positive January, that could improve their psychology," Mr. Stovall said.
That was the attitude yesterday. At least for a day, it seemed, Wall Street strategists believed that investors wanted to view the stock market glass as half full.
Financial reports that usually spell trouble for the market were largely ignored. The price of oil and gold are rising and there is Government evidence that wage pressures are rising sharply in the United States -- all dour signs for corporate America -- and yet the stock market gained.
Heavy inflows into mutual funds may be partly responsible for the gains, analysts said, noting that trading volume has been soaring this month.
Yesterday, more than 706 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the fifth-highest volume session of all time. And more than 25 million shares of Oracle traded hands on the Nasdaq market.
"There's substantial money flowing into equities," Mr. Stovall said. "We're seeing a little resumption of the bull market that had pulled back."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: CAPITOL HILL;
G.O.P. Opens Attack on the President's New Spending Plans

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Republican Congressional leaders today began a battle against President Clinton's new agenda, saying his spending proposals would revive the era of big government that he so dramatically declared dead just two years ago.
Presenting a joint front the day after Mr. Clinton's State of the Union address, the chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees said they estimated that his expansive proposals would amount to as much as $50 billion in new spending and break the balanced-budget agreement struck just last year. 
 "That means we would have a bigger Federal Government," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. "I thought we had convinced the President and the President had made up his mind that he was committed to a smaller Federal Government."
The Republican complaints signaled the resumption of an intense ideological struggle over the size of government, a battle that had abated briefly once the President and Congress reached across party lines to arrive at the landmark agreement to balance the budget.
The Democrats do not want to be labeled as big spenders once more. But they believe that the particular health care, education and environmental initiatives that the President outlined in his speech, and will offer in more detail in his budget, will prove more popular in an election year than will Republican proposals for tax cuts.
"The Republicans have said, 'Let government stay out of the lives of people,' " said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee. " 'If they're sick, if they're old, if they're uneducated, if they have no place to live, let the private sector handle it. Just give them a tax cut.' "
White House officials said the President's budget proposal, to be issued next week, would not jeopardize the balanced-budget agreement, because offsetting savings would pay for any new programs.
"We certainly acknowledge that we have new initiatives in child care, health care, education and the environment," said Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's chief economic adviser. "But we are paying for them with specific offsets that keep discipline and should keep us on a path to an early balanced budget."
The chief way the President plans to pay for his new proposals, while at the same time preserving a budget surplus that he would dedicate to shoring up Social Security, is to use billions of dollars from proposed tobacco settlement legislation.
But it is far from certain that Mr. Clinton will ever get that legislation out of Congress, particularly if he is considered too weakened by scandal to fight for it. Several Republican leaders have already expressed doubts about the proposal.
Further complicating the issue, Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested in an interview that any money from the tobacco industry could be used to support Mr. Clinton's call to bolster Social Security and also leave room for Republican tax cuts.
"What if we skip all of his new spending programs?" Mr. Gingrich said.
Republicans spent most of January letting Mr. Clinton get his agenda out and dominate the news. But the sex scandal gives them hope that if they move fast, they can take the initiative away from him. Mr. Kasich and Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said they hoped to produce a joint budget plan for the 1999 fiscal year by March, which would be unusually early.
But the Republicans have their share of internal disputes to resolve, as the prospect of surpluses whets appetites. Republicans are pushing several competing tax-cut plans, and the party also has its share of spenders.
One faction of Republicans wants to see an increase in spending on highway programs. Aware of the potential to break the budget agreement, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said today that such a bill, which had been expected to be one of the first matters before the Senate in the new session, would most likely be delayed until spring.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE;
Many Turn Deaf Ear to Scandal

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 28

 BODY:
Jack McHale, 80, does not believe it. Arvin Gee, 24, does not want to hear about it. And Tanya Lieb, 42, does not care.
"I'm sick of hearing about this scandal," said Ms. Lieb, a beautician in the town of Monticello, Ill., who joined a crowd of about 13,000 people in a thunderous welcome for President Clinton here today. "What he does in his personal life, that's his business." 
 Some people said they might reconsider a defense of the President if he engaged in a cover-up. But from what they have heard so far, most people who showed up today for the warm-as-toast reception for Mr. Clinton at the University of Illinois here said they wanted to put the scandal to rest.
Indeed, the largest group of protesters today denounced the news media for focusing on accusations that Mr. Clinton had sexual relations with a young White House intern. One protester held a sign that said, "Kill the Overkill." Another placard demanded, "News, Not Views!
To be sure, there were some people who said adultery alone would prove a man unfit to lead the country.
"He has not provided moral leadership," said Brian Rummery, 31, an associate pastor at Windsor Road Christian Church. "And nothing he says will make me feel differently."
But most people here said private sin had little to do with public statesmanship. "I might not think of him as a good husband," said Scott Inman, a 36-year-old warehouse worker, "but I approve of him as a President."
While college students numbered heavily in the crowd, there were plenty of teachers, farmers, tradesmen and mothers with young children in tow.
Time and again, people invoked the widespread reports of former President John F. Kennedy's infidelities as evidence that sexual conduct had little to do with leadership capabilities.
"This moral stuff, that's all pretty personal," said Melvin Sims, 49, who was directing traffic at today's gathering and who said he had voted twice against Mr. Clinton. "Let's just worry about how he does his job."
And some might judge Mr. Clinton more harshly, they acknowledged, if the economy was in trouble. "As long as he's running the country and I'm working and making money," said Arthur Johnson, a 49-year-old carpenter, "he can do whatever he pleases in his spare time."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
German Bank Acts to Shield Itself on Asia

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The Asian financial crisis reached into the heart of Europe's banking system today, when the biggest bank in Germany announced that it would set aside $777 million to cover potentially soured loans in the region.
The announcement by Deutsche Bank A.G. marked the largest amount yet set aside by a Western bank as a cushion against possible defaults. The cushion was nearly twice the size of the bank's loss provisions for all loans in 1996. 
 "It is inevitable that other banks will follow," said Piers Brown of UBS Securities in London. "The issue going forward is whether this is all they need to do."
German and French banks have been among the most aggressive lenders to South Korea and Southeast Asia, their commitments exceeded only by the Japanese. Many German banks significantly expanded their lending just before Asian financial systems began to unravel last summer.
Until now, Deutsche Bank and other big European banks have insisted that their potential Asian losses would be modest, at most. But investors became increasingly convinced that large losses lay ahead and began selling a range of French and German banking shares.
Deutsche Bank said the size of the loan-loss provision was still considered minimal and did not mean that it would sustain significant damage from Asia.
"If you're a small bank, one billion D-marks is a very big number," a spokesman, Detlev Rahmsdorf, said, "but we are a very big bank." He referred in very broad terms to a billion German marks, now about $555 million.
But the increased cushion for possible losses surprised banking analysts in its magnitude. It is meant to protect the bank from any losses on about $5 billion in loans to four of the most-troubled Asian economies -- those of South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia.
Deutsche Bank also set aside $1.4 billion to cover the costs of a further reorganization of its investment banking and commercial banking operations, which analysts said could result in thousands of job losses. Taken together, the two moves reduced 1997 operating profit by one-third.
The bank has spent billions in the last decade to try to establish itself as a leader in worldwide investment banking. It recently shuffled the leadership of the investment banking effort, and has spent huge amounts of money in New York and London, the principal centers. But it has yet to even come close to reaching its goals.
Deutsche Bank's move to protect itself from bad Asian loans partly reflected the inability of many Asian borrowers to repay debts coming due because of the weakened values of their currencies.
The big French bank Societe Generale announced last week that it would set aside $164 million to cover any Asian loan losses.
Paradoxically, the news provided the biggest boost in weeks for Deutsche Bank's stock, which jumped 8.55 marks here today, or 7.8 percent, to 118.65 marks, on heavy volume. Analysts said investors had primarily been encouraged by news of the restructuring charge, which they interpreted as a harbinger of plans to slash the bank's work force and reduce future costs.
"Markets always like news of a restructuring," said Manfred Piontke, an analyst with Bank Julius Baer here. "The bad news is out, and things can only get better."
But many other big French and German banks are expected to be affected by Asia's financial crises. Analysts estimate that Dresdner Bank and Commerzbank. Germany's second and third largest, each have more than $3 billion in loans to troubled Southeast Asian countries. And because Commerzbank is substantially smaller than the two German giants, its exposure to problem loans is more dangerous.
Mr. Brown of UBS estimated that Commerzbank loans to the most troubled Asian nations added up to 37 percent of its equity, compared with roughly 26 percent for Dresdner Bank and 27 percent for Deutsche Bank.
Indeed, rumors were rampant today that Commerzbank would announce new provisions for bad loans in the next few days. A spokesman for the bank refused to comment.
The most exposed French banks, besides Societe Generale, are Credit Lyonnais, Credit Agricole Indosuez, Banque Nationale de Paris and Banque Paribas.
Several analysts noted that Deutsche Bank's new provisions for bad loans were bigger than they had expected.
"They are larger than what we had been looking for," said Matthew Czepliewicz, who follows European banks for Salomon Smith Barney. Mr. Czepliewicz had figured that bad loans would account for less than 10 percent of the total loan portfolio, while Deutsche Bank increased its provisions by 15 percent.
Also surprised was Peter Thorne, banking analyst with Banque Paribas, who has in recent months been one of the sharpest critics of European banks' exposure to Asian loans.
"I didn't expect them to take such large provisions," Mr. Thorne said, while adding: "They are facing up to reality. They are maintaining the high ground of accounting."
Beyond problem loans, many banks may also have substantial Asia-related losses in their trading operations, including in foreign-exchange dealings and in the use of securities known as derivatives to hedge risks against currency and stock-price fluctuations.
Deutsche Bank, which has aggressively expanded its business in derivatives, has been rumored to have lost more than $100 million during the wild market swings in Asian stocks and currencies. A question among analysts was whether the loan-loss provisions announced today included a cushion for possible losses from derivatives.
Another important question lies in bank exposure in Asia beyond the countries at the center of the crisis. Lending to Hong Kong, in particular, is far higher than that to South Korea or Indonesia but is generally not considered as part of the problem. Yet Hong Kong has been under intense pressure of its own. Property prices, which underlie much of the banking system there, have plummeted, though the Hong Kong dollar has remained within a United States dollar-linked trading range.
"Hong Kong is the big wild card," Mr. Czepliewicz of Salomon Smith Barney acknowledged.
Deutsche Bank's latest restructuring seemed to reflect an effort to stick with its original goal of trying to build a world-class investment bank, even while reining in costs.
As part of the reorganization, two of its board members, Josef Ackermann and Ronaldo Schmitz, will assume responsibility for overseeing the company's corporate and investment banking. Deutsche Bank has appointed Michael Dobson, who has been chief executive of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, to head its asset management business.

HEADLINE: Pataki's Dairy Farm Plan Risks Consumers' Anger

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The beleaguered dairy farmers of upstate New York have long demanded an increase in milk prices, warning lawmakers here that after years of rising costs and stagnant incomes, farms are going out of business at a startling rate.
But the requests have run into strong opposition from residents and lawmakers from New York City and its suburbs, who as big consumers of upstate milk would shoulder the potential burden of a price increase that critics say could run as much as 21 cents a gallon. 
 Now, with upstate farmers reeling from the effects of this month's devastating ice storm, Gov. George E. Pataki has thrust himself into the debate, saying he wants to find a way to bail out an industry that has been among his staunchest supporters. But the issue puts the Governor in a difficult political bind, since the relief the farmers are seeking would be likely to anger downstate consumers.
Milk prices are generally set by the Federal Government, under a Depression-era system intended to insure even distribution and fair pricing of the perishable product. But New York's farmers are pressing the Governor to back legislation allowing them to join a regional dairy group that is permitted under Federal rules to set higher milk prices for farmers.
Mr. Pataki's advisers are also considering less-sweeping alternatives, like specific tax cuts that would give the state's 9,000 dairy farmers some financial relief. But the farmers, who complain that milk prices are as low as a decade ago, are unlikely to be satisfied with anything short of the price increase. And the Governor will be under considerable pressure to deliver, since they represent the economic backbone of a region whose support was crucial to his victory in 1994.
But at the same time, he must weigh the concerns of people in the New York City metropolitan area who say that a price increase amounts to an unfair tax on consumers that is merely intended to transfer income from downstate to upstate. They also say that such an increase would be especially hard on poor people because they typically spend twice as much of their income on food as wealthier families.
"The Governor is in a tight spot," said Russ Haven, the legislative counsel for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a good-government organization. "Dairy farmers have united to push for a price increase. On the other hand, downstate consumers will be very unhappy if government action pushes milk prices up."
New York is the third-largest producer of dairy products in the nation, after California and Wisconsin. But the state's dairy farmers, 80 percent of whom run family farms, have been on the brink of financial ruin in recent years as their profit margins have declined sharply. Last year alone, more than 200 farms went out of business after the price of wholesale milk dropped 20 percent.
The debate in New York has largely centered on the question of whether Mr. Pataki should push legislation allowing New York to join a coalition of the six New England states, known as the New England Dairy Compact, that can set wholesale milk prices higher than the Federal pricing system permits. The Federal Government has allowed states to form such compacts as it refines its current milk pricing system amid complaints from dairy farmers nationwide.
Mr. Pataki has not taken a position on the compact, but it is being considered by a 15-member task force he created in the fall to examine the dairy issue. The task force is expected to make final recommendations as early as next week.
A bill to allow the state's farmers to join the compact is already moving through the Republican-led State Senate. The position of the Democrats who control the Assembly is less clear, but upstate Democrats, whose hold on their seats may be precarious to begin with, are likely to plead with the Speaker, Sheldon Silver, not to stand in the way of the measure.
The major lobbying group for farmers, the New York State Farm Bureau, recently took the unusual step of calling on the state to enter the dairy compact. Until then, the farmers themselves had been divided on the issue, with some saying they would fight any new form of regulation.
The fundamental problem farmers face is that the price milk processors pay them has dropped to about the same level as a decade ago: $13.95 for every 100 pounds of milk. That translates into $1.06 per gallon, compared with the roughly $2.55 that retailers charge at stores. The prices have dropped partly because of an oversupply both locally and nationally and partly because of new Federal policies intended to remove Government price supports.
If New York joined the dairy compact, dairy farmers could charge an additional $1.30 for every 100 pounds of milk, according to industry experts. That would translate into an additional 10 cents per gallon.
The dairy farmers contend that such an increase would not necessarily raise milk prices for consumers but would rather cut into the profits of companies that process milk, as well as retailers.
These middlemen generally have larger profit margins than the farmers themselves.
"If we enter into the New England Dairy Compact, farmers will get more money for the milk they produce," said Randall Sawyer, a spokesman for the New York Farm Bureau. "The people who will determine whether consumers get hurt are the milk processors and the retailers."
But critics, including consumer groups and advocates for the poor, say the compact amounts to a legal cartel that has hurt consumers in other states. In Connecticut, for example, the price of milk on store shelves went up 20 cents a gallon because the higher prices were passed on to consumers, the critics say.
The critics estimate that New York consumers could see milk prices rise by up to 21 cents a gallon if the state entered into such an agreement. And they say that consumers in the New York City metropolitan area would end up paying about $50 million of an estimated $91 million in increased milk prices each year.
"We are sympathetic to the plight of farmers," said Art Jaeger, the executive director for Public Voices for Food and Health Policy. "But we don't think the solution is raising prices for consumers."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Albright Says U.S. Is Ready To Act Alone Against Iraq
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said the United States was ready to act alone if necessary to punish Iraq for its efforts to develop chemical and biological weapons. Though Ms. Albright reiterated the warning that President Clinton delivered on Tuesday, White House and Pentagon officials sought to stamp out expectations that a strike against Iraq was imminent or inevitable. A6 

Iraq said it might ask the International Court of Justice to intervene in the standoff. The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, said the Clinton Administration was trying to cover up its "miserable crisis" by making Iraq a scapegoat. A6
 
In public, Arab leaders are voicing strong opposition to the use of force against Iraq. But diplomats in the Persian Gulf region say some officials there have told them in confidence that they would support military strikes at the weapons installations that give Iraq the ability to threaten its neighbors. The apparent contradiction between those public and private views tells much about Arab sentiment about Iraq seven years after the gulf war. A6
 
Worries Over Riots in Indonesia
Indonesia's Government has begun to fear that thousands of newly unemployed people could rise up in violent protests and shake its hold on power. Small food riots have already begun in parts of Java, and the Government is bracing for the possibility of more riots when it ends price subsidies for beans, sugar and flour on Sunday. The moves are part of an austerity plan to end the country's economic crisis. A3
 
Safer World for the U.S.
Top American intelligence officials testified that while the world bristles with weapons, the United States is relatively secure from the threat of war. In testimony before a Senate committee, the experts warned, however, that potential threats still come from the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. A3
 
Environmental Law for Brazil
The Brazilian Congress gave the country's environmental agency legal authority to enforce environmental protection laws, days after Government figures showed that destruction of the Amazon rain forest had reached its worst-ever level in the mid-1990s. A8
 
De Klerk Acknowledges Affair
Answering speculation, former South African President F. W. De Klerk publicly acknowledged a longstanding affair with a married woman, but denied that it had forced him to leave politics last year. Mr. DeKlerk, 61, is also married. He said that the matter "is a typical human drama which happens in many families" and that "there are no dramatic scandals involved." He did not name the woman, saying he hoped she would not be hounded. (Agence France-Presse)

Multiple Sclerosis Study
Researchers reported that multiple sclerosis appears to go beyond the stripping of insulation that sheathes nerve cells, and severs the nerves themselves. The finding may explain why people with multiple sclerosis eventually become unable to walk, for example, or may lose vision in an eye. It also suggests strategies for treatments with experimental drugs that can prevent nerve cell death, at least in laboratory experiments. A1

Researchers have found seven ants in amber that are among the oldest ever found, making it clear that what may be the world's most populous terrestrial creatures were underfoot and already diversifying when dinosaurs trod the earth. A12

BUSINESS DAY D1-26
 
Agreement in South Korea
South Korean banks and their international creditors reached an agreement to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans, ending three weeks of often tortuous negotiations. The South Korean Government agreed to guarantee repayment of the loans, all of which were coming due in a year or less. The loans have been the focus of intense concern in Washington and elsewhere because the South Koreans' inability to repay them has threatened to topple the country's fragile economy. The South Korean predicament has also become a barometer of the broader Asian economic crisis. A1
 
Asian Fallout in Germany
The Asian financial crisis reached into the heart of Europe's banking system. Deutsche Bank, the biggest in Germany, announced that it would set aside $777 million to cover potentially soured loans in the region. D1

Settlement talks between Merrill Lynch and several female financial consultants who had filed a sexual discrimination suit broke down hours after people involved in the negotiations said that a settlement appeared imminent. D3

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Leaves Washington Controversy Behind to Talk Policy in the Midwest

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 28

 BODY:
Setting aside certain slight if metaphorically inconvenient mishaps -- notably when Air Force One got stuck in the Illinois mud -- President Clinton had a politically comforting day today after a very bad week.
With his last national election behind him but perhaps his toughest political fight ahead, Mr. Clinton returned to the campaign style that he loves, trying as he has in past crises to substitute public excitement about his policies for any suspicions about his personal conduct. 
 Introduced by a revved-up Vice President Al Gore and showered with cheers by the biggest crowds he has seen since his second Inaugural Address, President Clinton spoke here and in Champaign-Urbana, Ill., about fixing the Social Security system, fighting global warming, and improving education.
He did not take questions. And he did not mention accusations boiling over back in Washington -- and on the minds of many in his audiences -- that he had had an affair with an intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, and then urged her to lie about it under oath.
"It feels good to be back in God's country tonight," Mr. Clinton shouted at the rally here, on his first trip out of Washington since the disclosure of the accusations against him a week ago. Thousands of people packed the plaza outside the La Crosse Center and spilled back down the streets leading to it.
As he listed the economic accomplishments of his Administration, Mr. Clinton predicted for the first time tonight that the budget would be balanced this year. "I think it'll be balanced before the year's out," he said. His aides had previously indicated that they expected the deficit to all but disappear this year, for the first time in three decades.
Mr. Gore delivered growling stemwinders in urging the audiences to stand by the President, although he never mentioned the charges against Mr. Clinton. By contrast, the President rambled a bit, as he often does before smaller crowds. He extolled the virtues of the Internet, and, as he discussed Social Security in Illinois, he grew wistful about his youth. "I thought I would live forever, always young," he said.
"Keep your eyes on the future," he urged the crowd of more than 10,000, which filled the University of Illinois Assembly Hall up to its ceiling. Then, because his whole audience could not fit into the Assembly Hall, Mr. Clinton addressed two overflow crowds of thousands more in other auditoriums.
Today's trip had been carefully planned by Mr. Clinton's aides -- who picked friendly towns with strong economies -- to produce enthusiastic crowds for a reprise of policies Mr. Clinton outlined in his State of the Union Message Tuesday night. But the timing and venues, Mr. Clinton's aides said, turned out to be perfect to showcase the President going about the people's business, the image his aides want to project in this crisis.
When Mr. Clinton left the University of Illinois to travel here, the White House's plans went slightly awry. As Mr. Clinton's 707 attempted a right turn onto the main runway, one wheel rolled off the tarmac onto grass, and the plane stopped dead.
The President was delayed for more than an hour while a substitute airplane rushed to Champaign-Urbana. His aides sadly shook their heads over an embarrassing image that they believed would dominate television newscasts. They were right.
Mr. Clinton also confronted less figurative reminders of his difficulties. Directly across the Mississippi River from the rally here, carved into the snow piled on the western bank, was a one-word message: "Impeach," in gigantic letters. The same message, in similar dimensions, appeared in a field near here under the President's flight path.
White House advance teams in both locations had been drumming up crowds for days. At the University of Illinois only two previous Presidents had ever spoken -- Gerald R. Ford in 1976 and William Howard Taft in 1911. The line to see Mr. Clinton started forming at 2 o'clock this morning, in frosty air redolent of nearby hog farms.
Opinions about Mr. Clinton and the scandal were as varied as the rumors dogging the President. But among Democrats at least, the general sentiment was captured by one of the rock songs played by the school band as Mr. Clinton arrived at the stadium in Illinois: "Carry On, My Wayward Son," by the band Kansas.
"That's his own business, between him and his wife," said Betty Williams, 61, of Urbana.
Michelle Palmer, 24, said that she did not vote for Mr. Clinton in 1996. But she said that people made too much of his private life. "If it didn't directly have anything to do with the way this country's ran, I don't think it's any of my business," she said.
Her father, John S. Palmer, who called himself a die-hard Republican, disagreed. "Sure it's our business,"' he said. "He's the President of the United States." Mr. Palmer, a disabled veteran, said that he was concerned about accusations that Mr. Clinton had lied and obstructed justice. But, he said, if he could just resolve his personal troubles, Mr. Clinton would "be a damn good President."

HEADLINE: Mayor, Ordering City Hall Review, Delays Plan to Build Mall Over Brooklyn Terminal

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Saying that City Hall needed to be more involved in the planning process, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday delayed by at least a month a plan to build a shopping mall over the Atlantic Terminal in downtown Brooklyn.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority had been set to vote on the plan at a meeting yesterday, but the item was abruptly pulled from the agenda at Mr. Giuliani's request. 
 Curt Ritter, a spokesman for the Mayor, said Mr. Giuliani decided yesterday morning that "City Hall wanted the opportunity to review the plan more carefully."
On Tuesday night, the M.T.A. received a letter from the city's Economic Development Corporation that authorized the developer of the mall, Forest City Ratner, to proceed with the project. John S. Dyson, who is the chairman of the Mayor's Council of Economic Advisers and one of Mr. Giuliani's representatives on the board of the transportation authority, said that after seeing an article about the mall in The New York Times yesterday morning, the Mayor had some questions about it that Mr. Dyson and other administration officials could not answer.
"The E.D.C. thought they had enough information on this," Mr. Dyson said, "but at the Mayor's meeting this morning, we wanted to look at it one more time. It's kind of a communications snafu a little bit."
Mr. Dyson said the Economic Development Corporation, which must approve any development at the terminal because it falls within a city-designated redevelopment zone, withdrew its letter yesterday morning after being contacted by the Mayor's office. But an official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that the Mayor pulled the item from the M.T.A. agenda because he was angry that the plan appeared to be going ahead without his knowledge.
"It's unfortunate," the official said. "This project is a very meaningful project. Perhaps there will be a briefing with the Mayor's office as to the contents of the project so that it could move forward smoothly."
The project calls for a 450,000-square-foot mall to be built above the terminal, which is home to a Long Island Rail Road station and 10 subway lines.
Mr. Dyson said the Mayor had questions about some changes in the plan, but he would not specify what they were. However, another official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the plan had been virtually unchanged for six months.
A spokesman for Forest City Ratner did not return a phone call yesterday.
The item is expected to be back on the transportation board's agenda next month, Mr. Dyson said.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: SOCIAL SECURITY;
Yes, a Surplus Would Help, But Tough Choices Remain

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Applying projected budget surpluses to the financial problems of Social Security could help make fixing the retirement system easier than Washington had feared, but would not eliminate the need for politically excruciating choices, White House officials and members of both parties said today.
Congress and the Clinton Administration would still have to wrestle with raising taxes, cutting benefits, increasing the retirement age or making other unpopular decisions to shore up Social Security. 
 Moreover, they still must resolve an emotional ideological debate over whether the Government should continue to take money from the working-age generation and transfer it to retirees, which is what happens now, or whether Social Security should be transformed so that individuals would have more freedom and responsibility to save for their own retirements.
The day after President Clinton urged Congress to deal with Social Security before spending any Federal budget surpluses, members of both parties acknowledged being concerned that overplaying the potential benefits from the surplus could erode the political will necessary to deal with Social Security's financial woes.
And some analysts said that the entire notion of using the surplus for Social Security was meaningless in the complex world of Government accounting, amounting to no more than moving money from one pocket to another. "Applying the budget surplus to Social Security is not a substitute for structural reforms," said Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a Democrat from Texas who has been pressing for action to shore up the retirement system.
Although Administration officials had considered calling for every dollar of the surplus to be allocated directly to Social Security, Mr. Clinton in the end took a more measured step, saying that Congress should not parcel out the surplus to tax cuts and new spending programs until it had determined how much of the fiscal windfall it needed for the Government to pay the baby boom generation's retirement benefits.
The Administration now believes that the surplus will rise sharply in a few years and total $200 billion over the next five years.
If Congress and the White House decided to use the entire surplus on Social Security, they could eliminate a big chunk of the problem before having to take unpopular steps like cutting benefits, raising taxes or increasing the retirement age, according to early estimates. Alternatively, they could use the money to provide much of the financing needed for a transition to a system in which more of the responsibility for retirement savings was shifted to individuals.
Henry J. Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who is an authority on Social Security, said his rough calculations suggested that the projected surpluses could close about 25 percent of the gap between Social Security's long-term obligations and the money the retirement system would have available if no changes were made.
But that would still leave the nation to decide how to make up the rest of the shortfall.
Government economists said that as a rough rule of thumb, every $100 billion of budget surplus that could be applied to Social Security would help extend the system's solvency by one year beyond 2029, when the program will no longer be able to pay all of the benefits promised to retirees.
"We're saying there should not be legislation that drains the surplus through spending or tax cuts until we know how much of the surplus will be required, along with other measures, to solve the long-term Social Security challenge," said Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy adviser and the primary architect of the Administration's approach.
"We're not saying this is the full solution," Mr. Sperling said.
The Administration also had other goals in mind. Linking the surplus directly to Social Security makes it easier for Mr. Clinton to argue against the sweeping tax cuts that many Republicans are seeking. And by wrapping himself in the mantle of fiscal responsibility, Republicans said, Mr. Clinton is seeking to divert attention from the budget implications of the array of domestic policy initiatives he laid out in his State of the Union Message.
Indeed, neither party showed any signs of curbing its appetite for using the surplus to other ends.
"There is room both to save Social Security and to protect Americans from high taxes," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and one of the most ardent Republican proponents of tax cuts.
Social Security currently takes in about $100 billion a year more from payroll taxes and interest income than it pays out in benefits. The excess money is nominally placed in a trust fund, although the fund is largely an accounting fiction. In reality, the Government uses the Social Security surplus to help finance its annual operating budget, and gives the retirement system an i.o.u. in the form of special Treasury bonds.
The result, many economists say, is no practical difference between using any budget surpluses to reduce the overall national debt and using it for Social Security. White House officials disagree, saying it is possible to bolster Social Security's balance sheet in a meaningful way by applying the surplus to it.
Advocates of substantially overhauling Social Security say the best use for any budget surpluses would be to pay the transition costs to the new system. Under the current system, employees and employers split a 12.4 percent payroll tax. One widely discussed proposal calls for two percentage points of the payroll tax to go into individual accounts for the future retirements of the workers paying the taxes rather than to the Government to pay for the benefits of current retirees.
But such a shift would leave the Government with about $70 billion a year less than it takes in now to pay benefits for current retirees. The budget surpluses, advocates of such a change say, could fill that gap, allowing the Government to pay current benefits and require today's generation of workers to save for their retirements.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Banks in Accord to Extend $24 Billion in Korea Loans

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
South Korean banks and their international creditors reached an agreement late last night to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans, granting the country an important reprieve in the financial crisis that has afflicted much of Asia since last summer.
The agreement, which ended three weeks of often tortuous negotiations, marks the first time in the crisis that banks have given any of the stricken Asian nations such a measure of relief. 
 It also reflected the pressure confronting both the South Korean banks and their creditors to find a speedy solution to avoid defaults on the most pressing debts. Otherwise those debts may have spiraled into much larger problems that could have affected industrial countries like Japan. Moreover, the creditors, which have been accused of reckless lending to Asia during its boom years, had little choice but to extend repayment unless they were willing to absorb big losses.
The agreement represents a turning point that gives South Korean banks more breathing room and could lay the basis for foreign investment to flow back into what had been the world's 11th-largest economy until a few months ago. It also could provide a precedent for Indonesian debtors, which also are struggling under the weight of short-term foreign bank loans and are seeking relief from international banks.
Investors and lenders have been unwilling to take a long-term view of South Korea's prospects until the country's short-term debt problems were resolved.
"The key thing is putting a financial backstop in place, and that is what this agreement achieves," said Gene Frieda, an emerging-markets specialist with I.D.E.A., a research firm based in New York.
But it is premature to call the agreement a definitive event that could expedite an end to the crisis. The South Koreans, who already have a $57 billion rescue package from the International Monetary Fund, must still raise billions of dollars for additional debt repayments and for rebuilding their economy.
The South Korean Government agreed to guarantee repayment of the loans, all of which were coming due in a year or less. Under the deal, the maturities have been extended from one to three years.
Although people involved in the negotiations were optimistic last week that a deal might be concluded earlier this week, that optimism had faded last weekend as the South Koreans and an unwieldy collection of international banks haggled over how high an interest rate the new debt would carry.
The South Koreans, as was in their interest, had been pressing for lower rates, while the bankers had been pressing for higher rates. The final agreement appears to strike a middle ground.
"This achievement marks a critical step in the efforts of Korea to surmount its current liquidity crisis and to restore stability to the Korean banking center," Chung Duck Koo, South Korea's Deputy Minister of Finance, said in a statement. William Rhodes, a Citicorp executive and veteran debt renegotiator who was the spokesman for American banks in these talks, said: "I think it was a very positive negotiation. We were striving to get a realistic negotiation and that's what we achieved."
The one-year loans will pay interest of 2.25 percentage points above the six-month London interbank offered rate, known as Libor, a benchmark international lending rate, which is at 5.625 percent. Korea's two-year loans will pay 2.5 percentage points above Libor. The three-year loans will pay 2.75 percentage points above Libor.
Another point of contention in the negotiations was what portion of the debt would be guaranteed by the South Korean Government. But that issue was less contentious than how steep an interest rate the new debt would carry, according to people close to the negotiations.
It was resolved relatively quickly with the Government agreeing to guarantee the entire $24 billion.
"We started far apart, that's certainly true," said one person involved in the negotiations. "People had different expectations."
But people involved in the negotiations said that the talks had been congenial and that both sides hoped the agreement would improve South Korea's borrowing prospects.
The country will now need to raise a substantial, though as yet undetermined, amount of money, most likely through a multibillion-dollar bond issue.
"The South Koreans need a lot for the year, but the question is, how much do they need right away?" said a person involved in the negotiations.
When banks recently agreed to extend payment on, or roll over, about $28 billion in short-term loans coming due by March 31, it was thought that South Korean banks had $5 billion more in short-term loans coming due by the end of the year, for a total of $33 billion. But the total short-term bank debt due by the end of 1998 was recently revised to less than $30 billion.
Only short-term loans owed by South Korean banks are subject to the terms of last night's agreement. Other corporate debt is not being renegotiated. In December, the South Korean Government said it had $153 billion in external debt, with about $92 billion of that in short-term debt due to repaid by the end of 1998. Those figures are no longer considered accurate.
Under the agreement, the creditor banks will exchange old South Korean debt for the new debt before the end of February. The exchange will be completed by March 31, when temporary extensions on some of the old debt had been due to expire. The South Korean Government has said that it will need at least $15 billion of the short-term debt to be converted for an exchange to be successful.
Now that the South Koreans have tentatively addressed their short-term debt problem, they face the even trickier task of deciding how to raise new money to further bolster the country's economy.
Although some bankers had suggested the Government might try to raise as much as $30 billion in a bond offering, most analysts think that number is far too high, given the fact that the South Korean Government has never done a major bond issue.

Japanese Stocks Rise
 TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 29 (Bloomberg News) -- Japanese stocks rallied today after being down most of the session.
The benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index climbed 40.76 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 17,014.59. Stocks fell nearly 30 points in early trading, led down by Sakura Bank Ltd. and Fuji Bank Ltd., on concern that a Government plan to aid banks will be delayed by a Finance Ministry scandal.
Markets in other Asian countries, including South Korea, Indonesia and Singapore, were closed for holidays.

HEADLINE: PLUS: BASEBALL -- BOSTON;
Valentin to Get $25 Million Contract

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The yearlong disenchantment of John Valentin turned to economic satisfaction yesterday. His agent, Richard Moss, and the Boston Red Sox concluded negotiations on a new contract, agreeing to a four-year deal for $25 million.
Valentin, who had put in $7 million for salary arbitration to the team's $5.5 million, was unhappy a year ago because the Red Sox moved him to second base so that Nomar Garciaparra, a highly touted rookie, could play shortstop. After he staged a brief spring training walkout in protest, Valentin wound up playing 79 games at second and 64 games at third. Garciaparra wound up as the American League rookie of the year. 
 Valentin, who batted .306 while earning $3.8 million, had expected to be traded, but the Red Sox did not want to lose the offensive punch he provides as an infielder. He achieved career highs last season with 176 hits, 47 doubles, 5 triples and 287 total bases.
In another salary arbitration case, Jeromy Burnitz of the National League Milwaukee Brewers went from a $225,000 salary last season to a four-year contract worth $14.5 million. The outfielder, who had sought $2.6 million to the club's $1,505,000, led the Brewers with 27 home runs and 85 runs batted in. MURRAY CHASS
