HEADLINE: James Bond, Then to Now: Agent of Cultural Change

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH

 BODY:
James Bond is back. In fact, he will not go away. The James Bond films are the most successful movie franchise in history, with most of the movies among the top earners of the year. "Tomorrow Never Dies," the current Bond film, opened on Dec. 19 and was still in the Top 10 at the box office last weekend, having earned $115.5 million, second only to "Titanic" among the current hits.
Over the last 36 years, there have been 18 Bond films -- 20 if you count the Bond parody, "Casino Royale," and "Never Say Never Again," the 1983 remake of "Thunderball," which marked Sean Connery's return after 12 years. 
 For the unenthusiastic, all Bond movies, which were initially based on a character created by Ian Fleming, seem to be pretty much the same: James Bond, the handsome, rakish British secret agent, after flirting with his boss's secretary, Moneypenny, and ably assisted by the devices of "Q," the equipment officer, escapes death several times. Bond seduces, or is seduced by, an untrustworthy woman, and finally, Theseus-like, penetrates the innermost lair of the villain and destroys him. In the end, Bond gets the girl, usually drifting off with her in a boat, or at least necking with her near a body of water.
But to Bond aficionados, and scholars in the field of cultural studies, James Bond just isn't what he used to be. Fathers, brought up on the early Bond movies like "Dr. No" and taking their sons to see "Tomorrow Never Dies," have complained that the new Bond film devotes no time to character development. For them, "Dr. No," with its relatively leisurely pace, in which Bond flirts a little, drinks a little, then kills off a villain or two, is the ideal Bond.
But just as the audience judges the Bond films, the films judge the audience, providing a kind of map of cultural change over the years.
Literally scores of scholarly works have been written on the James Bond films. "The primary ideological and cultural coordinates within which the figure of Bond has functioned have been, first, representations of the relations between West and East," Tony Bennett and Janet Woollacott write in their 1987 book, "Bond and Beyond," and second, "representations of the relations between the sexes." The authors, drawing on the work of the French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan, write that the figure of Bond has provided a focus "within the ideological construction of gender relations and identities."
"He's gone from being an anti-Communist, to fighting rogue generals, to being against a combination of Bill Gates, Rupert Murdoch and William Randolph Hearst," said Daniel Leab, a professor of history at Seton Hall University. Mr. Leab was referring to Elliot Carver, the villain in "Tomorrow Never Dies," a media baron who manipulates the news. Mr. Leab pointed out that the screenplay for "Tomorrow Never Dies," written by Bruce Feirstein, even has Elliot Carver uttering words attributed to Hearst: "You give me the pictures. I'll give you the war."
In the old days, Bond used to be at war with the Chinese Communists. "Now Bond works with her," Mr. Leab said, referring to Michelle Yeoh, a veteran of Hong Kong kung fu movies cast in the film as a Chinese Communist agent who cooperates with Bond.
Along with the political economy, the character of Bond himself has evolved through the years. "Sean Connery was the classic working-class Scot," said Toby Miller, a professor of cinema studies at New York University, who is writing a scholarly study of spy films, including the Bond movies. "He's a person who, because of his accent, every time he says anything cultivated about brandy, is sticking it to the Brits. There is a dissonance between his accent and his observations, and in the Britain of the 1960's, that was an important part of his appeal."
Roger Moore, who played Bond for 12 years starting in 1973, was more like the Bond envisioned by the Fleming novels, cool and smooth and a little stiff. Timothy Dalton was a blip on the horizon, and George Lazenby got to play Bond only once.
Pierce Brosnan is very much a Bond for the 90's. The Irish-born Mr. Brosnan has an indeterminate accent, not quite high English, not quite Connery, a reflection perhaps of the breakdown of English class lines. Some women find Mr. Brosnan a rather unsexual Bond, more interested in killing off his enemies than in attending to his girlfriends.
"The women are the key to the evolution of the Bond films," Mr. Miller said. "In 'Tomorrow Never Dies,' the time that would have been spent in the past establishing the relationship between Bond and the Bond girl goes to letting her have her own fight scenes. There are three to four minutes of Michelle Yeoh fighting. Normally, that would have been three to four minutes of her staring into his eyes.
"Also, another significant change: she has a fight scene and Bond is not there the whole time to see it. She doesn't need Bond's approval and protection."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Picture Album in an Archive Never at a Loss for Words

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
Did you want to look at an aardvark or an armored truck? A balloon or a battleship? A rare garden bug or a garden-variety politician? From her vast stock, Romana Javitz (1903-1980) could find you a picture of anything. As chief custodian and cultivator of the New York Public Library's Picture Collection from 1929 to 1968, Ms. Javitz helped it grow from a modest resource to a major repository of five million items that reflect the ever-changing shifts in popular taste.
Although the library is much better known as a source of linear learning, it is also one of the great centers for pictorial research, used by artists, designers, publishers, illustrators, television prop staffs, advertising people, Web site developers, students, historians and others wanting ideas and documentation. Its Picture Collection circulates material from books, magazines, catalogues, pamphlets and advertisements, as well as from prints, movie stills, postcards and photographs, filed under nearly 12,000 subject headings. 
 Now, 18 years after Ms. Javitz's death, the library is commemorating her role in making all this happen. "Subject Matters: Photography, Romana Javitz and the New York Public Library" is a small but, despite its uncatchy title, lively show. It presents an overview of the Picture Collection and its development, along with some of the more than 2,000 photographs she acquired from such luminaries as Lewis W. Hine, Dorothea Lange, Walker Evans and Berenice Abbott, among others.
The Picture Collection started informally in 1914 as a response to growing demand for pictorial material viewed in terms of subject rather than esthetics. By 1926 the expanding file had been given its own space, and in 1929 Ms. Javitz, who initially worked part-time at the library while studying painting, took over.
"She saw the Picture Collection as an encyclopedia of visual knowledge, and built a useful system for the dissemination of that knowledge," writes Anthony T. Troncale, associate head of the Digital Imaging Unit in the library's Preservation Division, who organized the show with Julia Van Haaften, curator of the Photography Collection in the Division of Art, Prints and Photographs.
One of Ms. Javitz's salient contributions was devising an up-to-date indexing system that made pictures readily accessible by subject matter. Seeking "Relationships," for instance, you might look under Conversation, Courtship, Love, Kissing, Marriage or Erotica. And she also encouraged borrowers to draw, rather than write, their requests. Whisky stills, Queen Victoria and nudes are some of the quirkily illustrated call slips on view in the show. A signed scenario for a projected film about a photographer by Joseph Cornell, a Picture Collection user who became a Javitz friend, is there, and a 1995 cartoon strip about the collection by Art Spiegelman that includes a three-panel view of Ms. Javitz plying her trade with a pair of scissors.
Another significant contribution to the field of visual research came about through her concern over the neglect of American folk arts and crafts. In 1935, she, along with artist-users of the collection, hatched a proposal (its typescript is on view in the show) under which the New Deal's Works Progress Administration would hire unemployed artists and illustrators to document American decorative arts. Thousands of watercolors recording everything from toys to quilts to clothes to iron railings were produced. Now ensconced at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, as the Index of American Design, the collection forms a significant record of indigenous American crafts.
Much of the show's space is given to works from the group of photographs that Ms. Javitz acquired over the years, sometimes as gifts from photographers, which is now separated out as the Romana Javitz Collection. She chose them more for their subject matter than as works of art. "As a librarian," she said in an interview, "I find that I want very much to read the facts in the photograph."
Hine, befriended by Ms. Javitz late in his life, is represented by five documentary prints, among them a touching 1910 scene of a little boy working at midnight in a glass factory. Photographs by Lange include a 1934 view of an assembly of unemployed men in San Francisco, surprisingly well-dressed and wearing snappy fedoras. A 1938 shot by Abbott shows the French liner Normandie in the North River, cheered by a crowd on shore.
Among Ms. Javitz's most important acquisitions, in 1936 and 1937, were duplicates from the photographic division of the Federal Resettlement Administration (later known as the Farm Security Administration). A New Deal agency, set up to help farmers displaced by drought and economic ruin, it had a division that hired talented photographers to document the farmers' plight. One was the artist Ben Shahn, a friend of Ms. Javitz, who suggested to Roy D. Stryker, chief of the agency's photo division, that it provide the Picture Collection with duplicates. And thereby hangs a tale.
From the initial shipments, in 1936 and 1937, came such works as Shahn's 1935 photo of a North Carolina fiddler at home on a Sunday afternoon, Evans's 1936 study of black men in front of a Vicksburg, Miss., barber shop and Arthur Rothstein's stark 1935 night shot of a stretch of highway in the Texas Panhandle. But by the early 1940's, with economic conditions looking up, the agency was pushed by certain Congressmen to project a more positive image of America.
During World War II, a number of the agency's 180,000 images came to the Picture Collection clandestinely, in anonymous packages, while Congress threatened to impound its files as un-American. Later it turned out that Stryker, alarmed over that possibility, wanted to make sure that a duplicate file would be available in New York. But he didn't dare to send them officially until the threat was removed. That happened in 1944, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed a directive giving the Farm Security archive to the Library of Congress.
After World War II Ms. Javitz kept on acquiring, by gift or purchase, the documentary work of American photographers, making the Picture Collection one of the few institutions willing to take on young contemporaries. For some reason, she eschewed what is now known as the New York School of Photographers, including Diane Arbus and Robert Frank. With some notable exceptions, like Helen Levitt, her choices are mostly unknown today. The best of the works on view are urban vignettes, like Ann Treer's 1963 look at tough neighborhood kids on West 20th Street, David Turner's 1962 shot of a well-hatted pair of loquacious subway riders and a 1963 homage to a broken doll in the street by Beuford Smith, one of several black photographers whose work entered the collection in the 1960's.
It is a challenge in a small exhibition to represent the work of a system as vast and varied as the Picture Collection, now slowly being digitized, as a computer in the show gives evidence. And perhaps the library has not given the Picture Collection part of the show enough space and explanation. But as a tribute to Ms. Javitz and her innovative role in the art world, the exhibition is a real occasion.
"Subject Matters: Photography, Romana Javitz and the New York Public Library" is at the library's Center for the Humanities, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, through March 28.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Romana Javitz, as portrayed by Art Spiegelman in a cartoon that was first published in The New Yorker. (Art Spiegelman, 1995)

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
In Search Of Bridges To a Time Long Lost

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Our search for remote, exotic specimens of the covered bridge ends with a toast of the local lager: Here's to frosty mornings, icy streams and raindrops on hex signs. 
 The largely uncelebrated bridges of Berks County in Pennsylvania are worth a salute, although they number only five. The reward of the hunt for these 19th-century wooden trusses is not just an architectural tour, but also a sentimental journey along two-lane roads that swoop by blond fields of winter and hand-painted signs advertising fresh eggs and the Republican candidate for constable.
There is no Clint Eastwood movie or steamy best seller to enshrine this southeastern Pennsylvania county and draw the tourists. There is just the quiet romance of burgundy barns and clattering wooden bridges decorated with hex sunwheels and tulips, stars and hearts. And there is scrapple.
"You want to talk Madison County," scoffed Roger A. McCain, referring to the book by Robert James Waller, "The Bridges of Madison County," and the movie made from it. "Madison County is the best place to see covered bridges in south central Iowa. Not in the world. Not in North America. Not even in the Midwest. But in Iowa."
Perhaps it is no surprise that Mr. McCain, an economics professor at Drexel University and master of a Web site devoted to covered bridges, prefers his home territory of Pennsylvania for the gentle pursuit of "bridging." In Berks County, he admires remote wooden spans like the red Dreibelbis Station Bridge, with its unusual step-shaped portal, or the 165-year-old Griesemer's Mill Bridge, topped by a handpainted hex sign (a form of Pennsylvania Dutch folk art).
"Biased as we may be," Mr. McCain acknowledged, "we still regard Pennsylvania as the Covered Bridge State."
Winter is one of the best times to roam Berks County, when the dark branches of trees are stripped bare, and snow is drifting against the creek beds. For the engineer at heart, this is when the pure, clean outlines of the covered bridges are clearly visible for careful study. For the romantic, the fragrance of hot apple cider and wood smoke hovers in the brisk air.
There is an amber-in-time quality to the villages and hamlets of Berks County, which have avoided the worst of the commercialism of neighboring Lancaster County and its relentless Amish tourist industry.
Berks, a diamond-shaped county of 864 square miles, is about 125 miles southwest of New York and 56 miles northwest of Philadelphia. Its first European settlement was founded by Swedes at the mouth of the Manatawny Creek in 1701. The early pioneers were followed upstream by successive waves of immigrants, Huguenots from France in 1704 and Germans in 1712. Later, a steady migration of Germans came from upstate New York to the county's Tulpehocken Valley.
The influence of these immigrants has endured, from the Griesemer Bridge, named for an early Huguenot, to staple recipes of Pennsylvania Dutch cooking like "drechter kuche," funnel cake.
Old Route 22 presents such an extensive outdoor collection of vivid Pennsylvania Dutch barn signs in red and blue, yellow and white that it has been dubbed the hex highway. That highway links two of the farm roads leading to the Kutz's Mill Bridge and the Dreibelbis, which is just a short drive from the warm refuge of the Deitsch Eck (Dutch Corner), a restaurant offering Pennsylvania Dutch meals.
Inside the Deitsch on a winter weekend, a waitress served apple cider and pumpkin custard pie to a Sunday post-church crowd, settled at red-checked tables below a white ceiling of pressed tin. The dark oak bar was decorated with green-striped squashes; tulip hex signs lined the shelves.
Draped from a wall was a thin linen towel emblazoned with the names and pictures of the Berks bridges: Pleasantville and Wertz Mill (Red Bridge) as well as Dreibelbis, Kutz and Griesemer.
Here, my husband and I committed a minor social gaffe, asking for mustard to eat with a dark brown brick of scrapple, a deep-fried mix of beef, pork liver and corn meal that is a quintessential Pennsylvania breakfast staple.
As we later learned, some aficionados like their scrapple generously swathed in butter and pepper bits so that the dish resembles a gravel trail. Others prefer maple syrup.
"You eat this with something sweet like apple butter or syrup," the waitress gently corrected us before excusing herself to leave for church.
As we lingered through Sunday evening after a long weekend in Berks County, we discovered that the pace of life slows virtually to a halt after sundown on Sundays.
It's so quiet in Boyertown, for example, that our hosts at the isolated Enchanted Cottage -- a cozy bed and breakfast set in the woods near the Landis Store Hotel -- suggested that we consider dining at the Hill Country Church, where you can get a turkey plate for $7.
In fact, the Landis Store Hotel closes on Sundays, but on other evenings it attracts diners up a winding, dark, two-lane road for generous mugs of the local Stoudt Golden Lager and dishes of terrine of duck. Teddy bears handmade by a local farmer's wife line the windowseats of the two-century-old tavern.
During the day, the pace quickens in Berks County, but according to its own gentle rhythms. There's the monthly trap shoot in Perrytown or the weekend quilt auctions advertised on Fridays in The Mercury in Pottstown and The Reading Eagle.
Daniel Boone's 18th-century stone homestead, in Birdsboro, is open for tours of its log house and blacksmith shop. And there is a quiet industry serving people in search of ancestors' tombstones that may be among those scattered in more than 100 family burial grounds throughout the county, said John Moxon, owner of Reiff Farm bed and breakfast in Oley.
Guests at his stone farmhouse can stroll up a hill to the Reiff family cemetery of seven graves, which includes plots of Revolutionary War soldiers, Capt. Daniel Reiff and Conrad Reiff.
Mr. Moxon's family bought the farm from the Reiffs, and he grew up in the farmhouse where he now flips blueberry pancakes and serves them on a table set with English china and family silver.
A former money manager in New York and in Bucks County, Mr. Moxon opened the bed and breakfast two years ago, drawn home by cherished childhood memories of "wandering the woods and the stream, and watching the moon rise over the pond."
A sense of history so pervades Berks County that the area, which is better known for its outlet shopping in Reading, is an antiques browser's paradise with a wide variety of flea markets offering prices to shame New England antiques stores.
In Leesport, flea markets alternate weekends with exhibitions dedicated to guns, Lehigh rabbit breeders, scale railroads and reptiles (sponsored by the Reptaquatics). The market is a particularly good place to sample warm braids of pretzels or that rarest of rare dishes: prune pie.
Some of the merchandise is contemporary and of garage quality; sweatshirts and towels are sold along with small family heirlooms. But it remains a place of little bargains like our purchase of a $3 set of handblown, pastel-colored liquor glasses that an elderly woman was clearing out along with plastic Christmas decorations.
Other stops on the washboard circuit are Stoudtberg Antiques Mall, in Adamstown, where, if you time a visit correctly, you can dance a polkato a live band; or Renninger's Antique and Farmer's Market in Kutztown, which has a Saturday antiques market and three huge outdoor flea markets held in April, June and September.
Antiques bargains can also be found in small towns like Shartlesville, which is worth a stop to visit two old-fashioned hotels, Haag's Hotel and Shartlesville Hotel. They serve generous multi-course meals of Pennsylvania Dutch salads and applesauce and slabs of hams and roast chicken that leave you breathless from the sheer quantity.
Somehow the taverns of 19th-century Berks County have managed to flourish as working hotels, run by owners who are city refugees with a talent for restoration.
The Oley Valley Inn, a hotel on Main Street with a wide white porch and green shutters, features remodeled rooms with antique armoires and marble furnishings and offers banana pancake breakfasts. Southeast of Oley, which is itself listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is the Yellow House Hotel, a stagecoach stop dating back to 1801.
The Yellow Hotel's present owners, Jack Rahn and Carl Brown, both from Philadelphia, bought the business more than 19 years ago. Some of the employees have worked there for more than 30 years, watching the hotel evolve from little more than a bar and pool hall into a working hotel.
Just a short drive north of the hotel are the bridges of Pleasantville and Griesemer. Cars can still rumble through the Griesemer and three of Berks County's other covered bridges, but the entrances of the Pleasantville Bridge are piled with small mountains of smooth, gray rocks to bar the traffic of the 20th century.
Built in the 1800's, when inland farmers and water-powered mills needed practical transportation across streams, the bridges were covered because the wood was vulnerable to rot and roofing provided protection.
Today, the cool, dark shade of a covered bridge is an impractical refuge from the world, a place where the characters of "The Bridges of Madison County" found love, or, in some extreme cases, obsession.
Recently Mr. McCain, whose hobby is bridging, encountered a man in a drugstore who noticed some postcards of covered bridges and then boasted that he had photos of the same structures. He started pulling pictures out of his wallet, recalled Mr. McCain, and offered to show him more shots that he had outside in his car. Mr. McCain politely demurred.
"It's nostalgia," Mr. McCain said. "The bridges give you a feeling of being in touch with the 19th century that you can't find in any other way."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Greenspan's Reassuring Comments Cause Treasury Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rallied yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that Asia's economic crisis would give the American economy "some breathing room from inflation pressures."
Mr. Greenspan, who made his comments to the Senate Budget Committee, helped clear up several of the questions that were overhanging the bond market and sparked the recent selloff. 
 He reassured investors that he expects the economic turmoil in Asia to result in slower growth here.
"We have as yet experienced only the peripheral winds of the Asian crisis," Mr. Greenspan said. "But before spring is over, the abrupt current-account adjustments that financial difficulties are forcing upon several of our Asian trading partners will be showing through here in reduction in demand for our exports and intensified competition from imports."
"All of this suggests," he continued, "that the growth of economic activity in this country will moderate from the recent brisk pace."
This reassurance from the central bank was important because there are no significant signs yet that the economy is slowing from its rapid pace of last year.
The Fed chairman indicated that the inflation outlook, already the best in more than a decade, could improve. "The likelihood that we shall be seeing some lower prices on imported goods as a result of the difficulties in Asia may afford some breathing room from inflation pressures," he said.
But he also warned that tight labor markets could add to wage pressures, a fact shown in the jump in the Employment Cost Index for the fourth quarter that was reported earlier this week. And he once again mentioned deflation -- the fact that prices could fall -- although he did not indicate that deflation was an immediate concern.
"As a consequence, we must be vigilant to the re-emergence of destabilizing influences -- both higher inflation, and shortfalls in demand and decreases in some prices that would press the disinflation process too far, too fast," he said.
Together, his comments seemed to bolster the view that the Fed is on hold for the time being, with no chance of a rate increase and, unless the Asian drag is more than expected, no rate cut either.
The 30-year bond gained 1 1/2 points, to 1043/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.83 percent, from 5.94 percent on Wednesday.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's policy-making arm, meets next Tuesday and Wednesday to determine the Fed's outlook for short-term interest rates. Later, the chairman will make a formal presentation of central bank policy to Congress.
"His comments were very balanced and the market liked it," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "While carefully presenting the risks on both sides of the economic outlook, Mr. Greenspan was nevertheless very reassuring to the bond market."
Elsewhere, the Treasury said its auction of $12 billion in 52-week bills produced an average rate of 4.965 percent, down from 5.065 percent last month and the lowest since 4.64 percent on Feb. 1, 1996. The bond-equivalent yield on the bills was 5.2 percent.
"Low yields are back, retail is showing signs of buying and corporate issues are crawling out of the woodwork," said John M. Atkins, senior analyst with Technical Data of Boston.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new 52-week bill:

HEADLINE: Rowland Asks For Purchase Of Open Land

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed spending $160 million to preserve more than 20,000 acres of open space in Connecticut over the next five years, a plan that in its first year alone would increase by nearly tenfold the money the state has spent on open space during his administration.
Mr. Rowland, who is seeking re-election this year, also set a goal of preserving about 670,000 acres of open space within 25 years. There are currently about 450,000 acres of open space, about half of it owned by the state and the rest owned by municipalities, land trusts and water companies. 
 The Governor's proposal, which comes less than two weeks after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey promised in her inaugural address to preserve 300,000 acres of open space, is a departure for Mr. Rowland, who has been under fire from Democrats and some environmental groups for his environmental record.
In the last 2 1/2 years, the state has spent $2.1 million on open space. Mr. Rowland is proposing to spend $32 million next year. A spokesman for United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, who is seeking the Democratic nomination to run against Mr. Rowland, called his proposal "campaign rhetoric."
At a press conference today to announce his proposal, Mr. Rowland acknowledged that he had a different priority when he took office: improving the state's economy. With Connecticut out of the recession, he said, "We can now turn to preserving our open space and improving our quality of life.
"What we're really trying to do with this plan is to protect open space from ourselves," Mr. Rowland said.
Environmental activists seemed almost giddy at today's press conference, and praised Mr. Rowland for backing the recommendations of an open-space task force, which released its final report today.
"It's going to make a huge difference," David Sutherland, co-chairman of the Land Conservation Coalition of Connecticut, an alliance of environmental groups, said of Mr. Rowland's proposal. "There are towns that are going to look different in 20 years than they would have."
Democrats said Mr. Rowland's open-space proposal was at least partly motivated by politics. "I think he knows he's weak on the environment," said Kevin B. Sullivan, the president pro tempore of the State Senate. "But whether he's a Johnny-come-lately or not, he's here. The good news is I think we'll do something."
Democrats also criticized Mr. Rowland's plan as moving too slowly. Last year, the Legislature approved a goal of preserving about 10 percent of the state as open space. Mr. Rowland's proposal called for reaching that goal in 25 years. Democrats said they would push for reaching it in 10 years.
As part of his announcement, Mr. Rowland also said the state would try to intervene in a controversial and high-profile development plan in Easton in which a private company is offering $14.1 million to buy 737 acres of land owned by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company to build 100 million-dollar homes and an 18-hole golf course.
Mr. Rowland said the state, with the towns of Easton and Weston, would try to exercise its right of first refusal to buy the water company's property. The actor Paul Newman, who lives in Westport, has pledged $500,000 over five years to help preserve the land.

HEADLINE: Regulators Oppose End to Session if Dow Plunges

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The nation's top financial regulators told Congress today that they oppose a proposal by securities markets to suspend trading for the day after stocks fall sharply, saying that the new rules would be too restrictive.
"Closed markets create panic, create fear, create uneasiness, create uncertainty," Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said before a Senate Banking subcommittee on securities. "That's when investors get scared." 
 The staff members of the New York Stock Exchange and 10 other securities markets agreed this week on a plan that would close markets for the rest of the day if the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 20 percent.
The proposal, drafted by staff members of the exchange and scheduled to be considered by its board on Feb. 5, would also close markets for the day if the Dow fell by 10 percent after 2:30 P.M., Eastern standard time. It would close the market for an hour if the Dow index fell by 10 percent before 1 P.M. and for 30 minutes if the 10 percent decline occurred between 1 and 2:30 P.M.
Under current rules, the Dow must fall only 350 points -- or less than 5 percent at current levels -- before trading is halted for 30 minutes. If the Dow falls 550 points, or about 7 percent at current levels, trading is halted for an hour.
While the regulators support raising the limits on the amount that stocks can fall before trading is interrupted, they oppose the plan to close markets for the rest of the day.
Mr. Levitt, whose agency must approve any proposal, threatened to have the S.E.C. and Commodity Futures Trading Commission unilaterally change the rules if the exchange does not act "to protect investors adequately."
The exchange's "circuit breaker" changes are designed to give investors a breather to avoid panic selling. "Circuit breakers help insure our market is fair for all and does not become a free-for-all for a handful of large traders during periods of market volatility," the exchange's chief economist, James L. Cochrane, testified today.

HEADLINE: Zambia Gazes at the Power Elite's Dirty Laundry

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 23

 BODY:
When former President Kenneth D. Kaunda arrives at court each morning, up to 100 soldiers surround him and not only shove photographers back with rifle butts, but also jump like basketball forwards trying to block his face.
Inside, when a political ally of his asks for a glass of water, a lawyer for Mr. Kaunda makes the court clerk taste it first. 
 Suspicion runs deep in Zambian politics these days.
In the last two years, Zambia has had a bomb blast outside the President's house, a roundup of opposition leaders, a flawed election, the shooting of two opposition candidates, a lawsuit asserting that the President is secretly a foreigner, threats of invasion, riots in the capital, a coup attempt, a roundup of 90 coup suspects, torture allegations and, on Christmas Day, the arrest of Mr. Kaunda.
And yet, life goes rather normally. The country, some say, would probably be much the same if none of this had happened. This nation of nine million people on the divide between relatively stable southern Africa and chaotic central Africa is stumbling along: Once relatively wealthy, now poor; once staunchly socialist, now aggressively free-market; never wholly democratic nor wholly despotic, Zambia is still giving the donor nations that support it a combination of hope and the heebie-jeebies.
A state of emergency is in effect. But there is no curfew, airports are open and rush-hour traffic jams the business district. As a police sergeant in the northern city of Kitwe said, "The state of emergency is only for the political elite in Lusaka."
Under the emergency's broad detention laws, Mr. Kaunda is under house arrest while the police try to build a case that he was behind the three-hour coup attempt on Oct. 28.
His lawyers are fighting to have him released, since the prosecutors have presented no evidence, other than an unsubstantiated statement that he agreed to give the coup leaders money and jobs. But Zambia's courts are so slow that a habeas corpus hearing, normally urgent, has dragged on for a month. The Government says Mr. Kaunda exploits the hearings to make speeches, and the court has barred all press contact with him.
Many Zambians and outside experts believe that the coup attempt had nothing to do with Mr. Kaunda, but was a foray by a few captains and majors who had been drinking and were bitter about their low pay and their generals' handsome lifestyles.
One of the two accused coup leaders, Capt. Jackson Chiti, testified on Jan. 15 that the police had tortured him, demanding that he implicate Mr. Kaunda. But he denied that the former President was involved and tearfully apologized to him in court.
But there are other theories too: one put about by some American officials and South African military experts is that Zambia overreacted to a feeble coup attempt because it is terrified that Angola is plotting against it.
Supply flights to the Unita rebels in eastern Angola have originated in western Zambia, prompting threats of invasion by the Angolan Government. Since Angolan troops helped overthrow Presidents Mobutu Sese Seko in the former Zaire and Pascal Lissouba in the Congo Republic last year because Unita had bases in those countries, Zambia is nervous.
But Eric Silwamba, the President's chief of staff and a special envoy to Angola, said Zambia closed the airstrips and expelled the South African company running the supply flights, Meteor-Ex. Its relations with Angola are cordial again, he said.
Nonetheless, a South African military expert said western Zambia's airspace is still largely unwatched by radar and the Zambian Army is spread thin in border areas west of the Zambezi River.
Mr. Silwamba denied that the demoted Defense Minister and other party insiders had enriched themselves by helping Unita, which still controls diamond areas.
The most common outlook on the repeated crises of the last two years is that they all spring from a deep hatred between two very touchy men: Mr. Kaunda, a schoolteacher who led Zambia to independence from Britain in 1964 and ruled it for 27 years, and President Frederick J. T. Chiluba, a trade unionist who formed the coalition that ousted Mr. Kaunda in a democratic election in 1991 and then fractured in squabbles.
Mr. Chiluba "tried to destroy Dr. Kaunda's reputation, calling him a dictator who ruined the country," said the Rev. Nevers Mumba, a clergyman building his own political party. "That touched Dr. Kaunda's ego and pride. That's what made him come back into politics."
The two could hardly be more different. Mr. Kaunda is tall and solid, wears Nehru suits and affects a large white handkerchief into which he alternately storms and weeps; as a liberation leader he combed his hair like Don King's, but now, at 73, he has a gray beard and lives on raw vegetables.
Mr. Chiluba, 54, is tiny and efficient, a fundamentalist Christian who wears natty suits and does without a scurrying entourage. In his rapid-delivery speeches, he quickly lapses into tart scorn, doing imitations while telling folksy stories deriding Mr. Kaunda, African and Western leaders and other critics.
"I think he's driven by a fear of appearing weak," said Jim Polhemus, an American consultant studying democracy here. "The people around him are telling him not to let Mandela or Mugabe or the donor nations push him around."
Asked about the series of crises,Mr. Kaunda's party says Mr. Chiluba changed the Constitution to bar him from running again in 1996, planted small bombs as an excuse to claim the existence of a "Black Mamba gang" and jail his party leadership until the 1996 race was over, rigged the election, secretly ordered the police to fire into Mr. Kaunda's car during a 1997 party meeting, grazing him and seriously wounding an ally, framed him on the coup charges and hopes for another chance to kill him.
Mr. Chiluba's aides say Mr. Kaunda ignored the people's will by running again, produced false witnesses saying Mr. Chiluba is Zairian, faked his own shooting, provoked the 1997 riot in which the downtown market was burned and arranged the coup attempt.
Almost every one of these charges has led to court; almost all have petered out inconclusively. The Black Mamba bombing charges were dropped for lack of evidence. The Supreme Court ruled that Mr. Chiluba did not have to take a DNA test to prove his identity. It still has not ruled on the 1996 election. The wounding of Mr. Kaunda has yet to be officially investigated.
Acknowledging that it looked as if the Government trumped up the Black Mamba case, Mr. Silwamba says the police botched it by being hasty. They do not want to repeat that mistake over the coup, he said. He denied that the Government was persecuting Mr. Kaunda.
Many Zambians view these fights as confined to the political elite.
"The average Zambian is marginalized completely, and the playing ground is being left to the politicians," said Ngande Mwanajiti, who ran the Clean Campaign Committee in 1996. As a defender of civil liberties, though, he feels threatened. "The police can come and take me away at any time."
Most Zambians, however, are just trying to get by. The standard of living today is about half what it was in 1964, when copper prices were high. Mr. Kaunda's socialism unraveled the economy, and Mr. Chiluba's bold privatization efforts have forced thousands of layoffs.
The foreign investment he hopes to attract is slow in arriving, and the budget is propped up with foreign aid. Mr. Silwamba calls that "the pity of being a poor country -- they give the money, so they want you to play the tune."
Mr. Chiluba's Government resents the fuss foreigners are suddenly making over Mr. Kaunda. They recall that Mr. Kaunda muzzled the press, jailed hundreds of political opponents and made children leave school to line the roads and wave whenever his motorcade went by. Many Zambians remember waiting all night for cooking oil or sugar, which inevitably ran out, leaving soldiers to whip angry shoppers away.
"Now," a museum guard said, "it is the opposite. There is food on the shelves -- but no money to buy it."

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Benefit to U.S. In Asia Crisis

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that Asia's financial crisis would soon be felt in the United States, but said the resulting slowdown in economic growth would reduce any remaining risk of inflation derailing the nation's seven-year expansion.
Testifying before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan called the economy exceptionally healthy, with inflation so far remaining dormant despite strong growth, low unemployment and solid income gains. 
 Mr. Greenspan said he was not ready to conclude that inflation was no longer a threat, especially given that wages are being pushed up as employers struggle to find the workers they need. But he acknowledged that the economy could also be endangered by a rapid weakening in demand and falling prices. And he left analysts and investors with the impression that the central bank was likely to hold interest rates steady at its meeting next week and for months to come.
"We have as yet experienced only the peripheral winds of the Asian crisis," Mr. Greenspan said.
"But before spring is over," he said, the effects of tumbling currency values in Asia "will be showing through here in reductions in demand for our exports and intensified competition from imports. All of this suggests that the growth of economic activity in this country will moderate from the recent brisk pace."
Such a slowdown, Mr. Greenspan said, "would appear helpful at this juncture."
Appearing on Capitol Hill as Congress begins drafting next year's budget, Mr. Greenspan also generally supported President Clinton's call to dedicate any budget surpluses first to shoring up the ailing Social Security system. While saying that broad-based tax reductions are good for the economy, he said there was "no urgency at this point to move" on tax cuts and suggested that Republicans should wait to do so until the Government had made some progress in paying down the national debt, including its i.o.u.'s to the Social Security system.
The prospect of surpluses provides "a very useful platform to finally get to a point where the Social Security problem is something which is truly resolvable without exceptionally difficult political problems," he said.
Mr. Greenspan warned Congress not to assume that all the projections of huge surpluses in coming years would necessarily come true, and he made a veiled criticism of Mr. Clinton's array of new spending proposals.
"We must not allow the recent good news on the budget to lull us into letting down our guard," Mr. Greenspan said. "Programs can be easy to initiate or expand, but extraordinarily difficult to trim or shut down once a constituency develops that has a stake in maintaining the status quo."
The chairman also said he supported the Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund. Bolstering the fund, he said, will allow it to confront any future international financial crisis in a way that "minimizes their disruption and minimizes the impact on the United States."
Mr. Greenspan's statements about the spillover from the problems in South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand and their neighbors came as a senior Clinton Administration official signaled the White House's growing frustration with Japan for not doing more to stimulate its own weak economy and help the rest of Asia recover.
After months of goading Japanese diplomats in private, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, went public today, saying in a speech here that Japan had to do more to deregulate industry, open up its economy to trade and spur domestic demand.
"Japan, as the world's second-largest economy, must play a more active role in helping to bring Asia out of its current economic crisis," Ms. Barshefsky said. "Its efforts to date have been woefully inadequate."
Like Mr. Greenspan, Administration officials and private economists expect the United States trade deficit to surge in coming months. Because the dollar has risen sharply in value relative to Asian currencies, they are projecting that American companies, whose products are now more expensive in foreign markets, will see their exports to the region fall off. At the same time imports of goods from Asian competitors, which are falling in price in dollar terms, will rise sharply.
The cheap foreign goods will help hold down inflation, Mr. Greenspan said.
"But they will not permanently suppress the risks inherent in tightened labor markets," he added.
So far, improvements in productivity have made up for the increased wages employers are being forced to pay to attract workers at a time when the unemployment rate, at 4.7 percent, is near a quarter-century low. But Mr. Greenspan continued to caution that it was unclear how long that pattern could hold.
"As a consequence, we must be vigilant to the re-emergence of destabilizing influences -- both higher inflation, and shortfalls in demand and decreases in some prices that would press the disinflation process too far, too fast," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: A New Era Of Wheeling And Dealing;
Rising Competition Squeezes Car Sellers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 29

 BODY:
When James Bordoshuk shopped for a Ford Explorer seven years ago, he lugged his young children to one showroom after another over several weekends and haggled for hours. He finally bought the sport utility vehicle from a dealership three miles away from his home -- one of 42 Ford dealers in metropolitan Chicago.
Last August, when Mr. Bordoshuk decided he wanted another Explorer, he took a different approach. He went on the Internet to check wholesale prices. Then he turned to an Internet buying service and ordered the vehicle from a dealer 18 miles away, bypassing a dealership only a mile from his home. In fact, he made his only trip to a showroom when he drove the Explorer home. 
 "I wouldn't do it any other way," Mr. Bordoshuk said.
After nearly a century of making comfortable livings selling cars in their immediate areas, car dealers now face one of the most difficult environments in years. Despite buoyant sales of cars and trucks, 850 dealerships have closed since 1992. Pretax profit margins are now wafer thin, and many experts predict that hundreds of dealerships will close within the next five years.
Thanks to the Internet, almost anyone selling the same product is a potential competitor whether the showroom is in the next town or the next state. The used-car lot and the service department, long big moneymakers, are facing fresh competition from superstore used-car chains and specialized repair stores. And in an unexpected turn, the improvement in car quality and longer-lived components are producing a dark side for dealers: lucrative warranty repairs have declined and tuneups are few and far between.
Dealers are also being squeezed by big players entering the business. Publicly traded companies with wads of Wall Street capital are buying dozens of dealerships, hoping to operate chains with money-saving efficiencies. Even the manufacturers have gotten into the act. They are buying out some dealerships and shutting them down.
Strong auto sales for the last four years have helped even the weakest dealers. But given the high rate of attrition among dealerships during recent recessions, the next sales slump could drive far more dealers out of business. When auto dealers from across the country gather in New Orleans this weekend for their annual convention, competition will be Topic A; not whether it will continue to increase, but how quickly.
A few experts, like Mark Rikess, a Los Angeles-based consultant to 400 dealerships, predict that up to half the nation's dealerships will disappear within five years, even without a recession. "Margins are continuing to tumble across the board, and will tumble severely in the next two to three years," Mr. Rikess said. "It's just going to be too difficult to make a return on investment."
Many dealers say that such predictions are too gloomy. Dealers are learning to use the Internet themselves, while constantly re-evaluating ways to stay competitive, said John P. Peterson, a Pontiac and GMC dealer in Bloomington, Minn.
Car dealers have overcome difficulties before, such as rising gas prices in the 1970's and high interest rates in the 1980's, he said, adding, "Not many of us run and hide and not many of us get out of the business."
But many dealers are clearly concerned, particularly about the Internet. A survey released earlier this month by J. D. Power & Associates, a consulting firm, found that only 10 percent of dealers viewed the Internet as a help, while 48 percent saw it as a threat.
Traditionally, dealers tried to stay out of each other's way to avoid needless competition. Auto makers have long assigned territories to dealers, although several of them can share an area in large cities. Though nothing prevents car buyers from traveling across these imaginary lines to check prices, time-consuming haggling has discouraged most buyers from doing so.
But the Internet now allows some dealers to market their low-cost cars to anyone with a computer and a modem. There has also been a rapid proliferation of car buying services on the Internet that take orders from buyers and forward them to dealers willing to sell at close to invoice prices.
These buying services charge up to $3,500 a month to dealers in exchange for referring buyers. The services have generally concluded that there are far more dealerships in the United States than are really necessary, because Americans are willing to drive greater distances to buy cars. Auto-by-Tel, which arranged for Mr. Bordoshuk to buy his Ford Explorer, has stopped recruiting new dealers now that it has a network of 2,700 dealers around the country. But that is still only an eighth of the dealers in the United States.
All told, roughly 1 in 5 auto purchases is made by buyers who consult the Internet or a traditional car buying service that for a fee helps buyers locate the car and price they want. Only a few years ago, just about 1 in 10 buyers consulted an intermediary. About a third of those who consult the Internet or a buying service actually buy cars through them, while many of the other buyers use the prices they obtain to wrangle better bargains from nearby dealers.
Either way, the result is that showroom profits are being squeezed and on-line services are growing. Executives at on-line buying services acknowledge that they are making life more difficult for many dealers. "We allow a dealer to reach other dealers' customers, and get their customers," said Frank Zamani, the chief executive of Autoweb.com. The typical buyer who uses the Internet winds up driving twice as far to purchase a vehicle as a traditional buyer, Mr. Zamani added.
Auto makers are encouraging the consolidation of dealerships, concluding that many dealers are needlessly competing with others selling the same brands. But auto executives are trying to avoid panicking dealers by suggesting that there will be widespread closings.
"I don't see it as being a fast process," said John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation. "I see it as a slow process."
An extreme example of long-distance auto marketing has been unfolding in Kellogg, Idaho, a rural town of 2,600 people where a Dodge dealership, Dave Smith Motors, has been selling nearly 4,000 cars and light trucks a year. Using low prices and traditional marketing methods -- giving solid gold coins to people who refer buyers -- as well as the Internet, the dealership has drawn customers from as far as Seattle, some 300 miles to the west. It even provides a shuttle service from the airport in Spokane, Wash., for buyers who fly in and drive their purchases home.
Rival dealers in the region are furious, and they have complained bitterly to the Chrysler Corporation that Dave Smith Motors should not be allowed to buy so many vehicles from the manufacturer, particularly popular full-size Dodge Ram pickups.
But Chrysler has continued to ship ever more vehicles to the dealership in northern Idaho, while trying to reassure smaller dealers that they, too, can increase sales if they improve customer service and attract more buyers by word of mouth.
General Motors and the Ford Motor Company have been more cautious than Chrysler in shipping lots of high-profit vehicles to successful dealers, but they are consolidating dealerships. Ford agreed this winter to set up a joint venture with its dealers in Tulsa, Okla., for example.
The company's plan is to buy all eight Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealerships in Tulsa and close at least half of them. It will also open several shops that service cars but do not sell them. G.M. is acquiring a dozen of its dealerships in the San Fernando Valley, north of downtown Los Angeles, with the goal of closing many of them and consolidating the rest under a single owner.
But factory takeovers of showrooms are few compared with acquisitions by publicly traded companies. Until late 1996, auto makers resisted the idea of publicly held companies controlling dealers, fearing that the manufacturers would lose control of their distribution systems. But they now say that corporate management and deep pockets could prove useful in transforming the business.
Republic Industries, run by H. Wayne Huizenga, who has already made a fortune consolidating the nation's waste disposal business and the video rental business, has been the busiest acquirer of dealerships. Mr. Huizenga has amassed 52 dealer groups with a total of 268 franchises, mostly clustered in big cities in the South.
With competition eroding showroom profits, some experts suggest that the next area of trouble could come in service and parts departments. Most service business comes from new-car customers. But as quality has improved, repairs are more likely to come to light later, when the vehicles are in the hands of second owners, who tend to use independent garages. Auto service and parts chains, owned by companies like the Penske Corporation, have also taken away from dealerships much of the high-profit oil and lube business. Now they are moving into more complicated repairs.
With all these changes happening simultaneously, profit margins are under pressure in every area of a dealership, said George E. Hoffer, an economics professor at Virginia Commonwealth University who specializes in the business. "Consolidation in auto industry retailing," he said, "is inevitable."

HEADLINE: After Derailing Trade Bill, Labor Sets Ambitious Goals

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Looking for new legislative successes after blocking President Clinton's fast-track trade bill last year, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. outlined an ambitious legislative agenda today that would raise the minimum wage and require employers to pay at least 75 percent of workers' health insurance premiums.
At an executive council meeting here, the group's leaders also voiced support for bills that would require employers with more than 50 workers to offer pensions and would bar companies from paying part-time workers less an hour than they pay full-time workers who do equivalent work. 
 At a news conference, John Sweeney, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, also said the federation would oppose new Federal outlays to the International Monetary Fund unless the fund did more to protect workers' interests when it imposed austerity programs on third-world countries.
Peggy Taylor, the federation's legislative director, said the 13-million-member group hoped that some proposals, especially a minimum wage increase, would be enacted this year. But she acknowledged that others, like a proposal to require employers to pay three-fourths of health insurance premiums, were long-term goals that the federation hoped would eventually be passed after years of building support.
"Some of what we're doing here is to set out how things ought to be," Ms. Taylor said.
Federation officials voiced confidence that at least some of their legislative proposals could win approval in a Republican-controlled Congress even if the sex scandal swirling around President Clinton undercut his ability to push through legislation.
"I think it's too early to say this legislative agenda will be in trouble because of what's happening with the President," said one senior federation official. "The Republicans respond to what the public wants, and the public has responded very well to these proposals."
Union officials said they adopted the proposals after surveying union members and the public. This polling found that Americans were optimistic about the economy, but still feared losing basics like health insurance.
While acknowledging that wages have started to rise faster than inflation, Mr. Sweeney said, "Working families remain deeply concerned over their long-range future because of the growing cost of education as well as growing gaps in some of the basics no American family should be without: health care and pension coverage."
Federation officials noted that even though unemployment was dropping, the number of Americans without health insurance had climbed to more than 40 million. According to a new study commissioned by the labor federation, the uninsured population has risen principally because employers have increasingly embraced plans that raise the premiums and deductibles that workers must pay. As a result many financially pressed workers have decided to forgo insurance.
Union leaders aim to make health insurance more affordable with their proposal to require that businesses with more than 50 workers pay 75 percent of premiums. The federation sees this as an attractive proposal that Democrats can rally behind to help them in this November's Congressional elections. Currently, 32 percent of American workers who have health insurance end up paying more than 25 percent of their health care costs
But business groups attacked labor's proposal. Asserting that it would create a new mandate that would cost employers hundreds of millions of dollars, Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said, "What they don't understand is that this piling-on of mandates from labor unions and the Clinton Administration is posing a threat to businesses' continuing to provide health coverage at all."
Business leaders are also alarmed about the federation's proposal to require corporations to provide pensions -- another mandate that employers insist would result in astronomical costs.
Even with a Republican majority in Congress, labor leaders predict that they can get a higher minimum wage enacted by wooing enough Republicans to join Democrats to muster a majority. The federation helped push through a higher minimum wage two years ago by doing just that, and the minimum rose to $5.15 an hour from $4.25 as of last September.
When President Clinton called for a higher minimum in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, Democrats applauded, but Congressional Republicans were conspicuously silent.
"Two years ago there were very few people who thought we could get an increase in the minimum wage Mr. Sweeney said, "I would hope the minimum wage would be brought up over a period of time to a level where these workers could keep up with the standard of living."
He called for increasing the minimum and then letting it rise automatically each year with inflation, a formula that would eliminate the perennial political battles on the minimum wage. Some federation officials are backing a bill, proposed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that would raise the minimum by 50 cents a year for three years.
Randy Johnson, the chamber's director of Congressional affairs, opposed a higher minimum, saying: "It's too soon. We still don't know what the effect of the last one was."
Federation officials said they would back President Clinton's plans to increase spending on child care and education and would work closely with him to strengthen Social Security's finances.
Ms. Taylor said it appeared that the White House would not seek to push through a fast-track trade bill again this year. Last year, unions were pivotal in derailing the bill, which would have made it easier to negotiate free-trade agreements with more countries.
Ms. Taylor said, "The feeling is the Administration doesn't have enough political capital to push through fast-track and additional I.M.F. funding in a campaign year."
The federation's executive council approved a resolution today stating that the United States should condition its proposed $18 billion in new contributions to the monetary fund "on fundamental changes in the I.M.F.'s program."
The federation said the fund should provide money to nations only if they allow basic human rights and labor rights.
"We have an interest in having Asian currencies stabilized," Ms. Taylor said. "We don't want a worldwide depression. We have hundreds of thousands of jobs at stake. But that doesn't mean we should give the I.M.F. the money no matter what."

HEADLINE: Exile Group Seeks More Aid for Cuba, With Strings Attached

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 29

 BODY:
In a move to undermine a bill that would allow the sale of food and medicine to Cuba, a leading Cuban exile organization said today that it would try to increase the amount of humanitarian aid to the island by having international relief agencies distribute such assistance.
The group, the Cuban-American National Foundation, the most politically prominent exile group and a staunch advocate of tight trade restrictions against Cuba, said that it was seeking Federal legislation or a Presidential order to permit more humanitarian aid, including United States Government assistance, as long as it is distributed directly to needy Cubans. The group said that with groups like the Red Cross distributing the aid, the Cuban Government could not benefit by levying taxes or assessing unwarranted costs. 
 The officials said that they had developed only the "nonnegotiable principles" of their plan and that other details had not been worked out. They said that no relief agency had agreed to participate yet.
But Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, has endorsed the proposal, which includes exploring use of the Federal "Food for Peace" program.
The foundation's announcement does not signal a softening in the group's position as much as a tactical maneuver to derail a bill that they believe would weaken the embargo. It is also a response to growing criticism of the embargo here and abroad, the officials said.
Today's announcement came less than a week after Pope John Paul II, in his recent visit to Cuba, repeated his opposition to the trade sanctions.
But the plan has created a rift over tactics among conservative exiles who are unwavering supporters of the embargo and usually present a united front on Cuba policy. Two Cuban-American House members from Florida, Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, both Republicans, broke ranks with the group, saying its idea needlessly opens a new debate over the embargo and invites legislation that could end up being very different from what was intended.
In a statement, the two said that the embargo already allowed private donations of food, medicine and clothes to Cuba, and that if a problem existed it was that "Fidel Castro has never allowed food and medicine to flow freely to the Cuban people."
But embargo supporters have been put on the defensive by the embargo's failure to spur democratic change in Cuba after nearly 40 years and by increasing criticism that they are adding to the misery of the Cuban people. This month, as the Pope drew attention to Cuba's humanitarian needs, a large coalition of American business groups and religious and human rights organizations announced their support for a bill that would allow Cuba to buy food, medicine and other medical supplies from American companies.
Officials with the foundation conceded that their proposal was more a political move than a realistic one because they doubted the Cuban Government would accept their conditions. But they said it was meant to put the onus on President Fidel Castro of Cuba, who, they said, had used the hardships inflicted by the embargo to gain international sympathy and as a source of blame for problems on the island.
"This is a way to unmask the Cuban regime," said Jorge Mas Santos, son of the late chairman of the foundation, Jorge Mas Canosa.
Today, one of the sponsors of the bill that would allow sales of humanitarian items to Cuba, Representative Esteban E. Torres, Democrat of California, said free trade between the United States and Cuba was the best way of meeting humanitarian needs on the island.
"My response to these well-intended relief initiatives is to restate our central goal: Let's provide trade, not aid," Mr. Torres said in a statement. "That is the principle that motivates U.S. global policy, and it certainly has relevance to current economic problems and needs in Cuba."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Park Avenue Hotel Being Converted Into Condos

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Aiming for the top of the Manhattan residential market, the owner of the Mayfair Hotel at the corner of Park Avenue and 65th Street is spending $55 million to convert the 1925 building into 70 luxury condominiums.
The sponsor of the conversion, to be completed in September, is Park 65th Associates L.P., an affiliate of Colony Capital, a real estate investment group in Los Angeles. The company bought the 15-story hotel at 610 Park Avenue for $15 million at a foreclosure sale in July 1996 and closed it last March. 
 Initially, Colony had intended to maintain the Mayfair as a hotel. But the principal in charge of East Coast assets, Lawrence A. Kestin, said that Colony switched because "we felt the conversion was economically more viable, since there was a pent-up demand for large luxury prewar condominiums."
The Trump Organization is helping to develop and construct the apartments, which replace 210 hotel rooms. A Manhattan brokerage, the Sunshine Group, is the exclusive sales agent.
The building entrance has been relocated to Park Avenue from 65th Street.
The conversion highlights several characteristics of residential development in Manhattan. One is that it is a condominium, underscoring what brokers and developers say is buyers' increasing preference for their flexibility over the restrictions of cooperatives.
The Mayfair joins several recently built or converted condos. They include the 76-unit Siena on 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues and the Trump International Hotel and Tower, with 168 units, at 59th Street and Central Park West.
Additional condos are planned. Last year 8 plans, representing 423 apartments in new or converted buildings, were accepted for filing, according to the State Attorney General's office, which reviews condo plans before sales proceed. About 15 additional projects, totaling 2,045 apartments, are in development, according to Marketing Directors Inc., a marketing and brokerage concern. Among them is a 35-story building with one apartment per floor at 60th Street and Park Avenue. Construction is to begin in midsummer.
The conversion at 610 Park Avenue also reflects buyers' appetite for large prewar-style units. Because of limited construction, the demand outstrips the supply, brokers said.
Such buildings typically have spacious apartments with entrance foyers, 10-foot-high ceilings, elaborate moldings and fireplaces. Larger apartments also have maids' rooms, separate dining rooms and full kitchens.
The Real Estate Board of New York recorded the median per-square-foot sales price at $321 for the 226 prewar condominiums sold from July through September, up from $273 for the 191 units sold in that period in 1996. The board attributes the rise largely to increased sales of luxury units, primarily on the East Side.
Since sales started in the summer at 610 Park Avenue, contracts have been signed on all but three apartments in the brick-and-limestone neo-Gothic building. The apartments have 986 to 4,400 square feet and are priced from $700,000 to $7.4 million.
In the sales campaign, the average per-square-foot selling price rose, to $1,100 from $950, said Louise Sunshine, head of the sales agent. Buyers have primarily been Manhattan residents or people with a pied-a-terre in the city, Ms. Sunshine added.
Marketing Directors said Trump International was the only other project where the average per-square-foot price broke the $1,000-a-foot level for new apartments.
Each apartment, designed by Costas Kondylis & Associates, will have nine-foot coffered ceilings, entrance foyers, wood herringbone floors and seven-inch base moldings. A typical 2,000-square-foot two-bedroom unit will have a 20-by-20-foot living room. Some apartments will also have libraries and fireplaces.
The building reflects a trend toward increased services. Owners will be offered the services of Daniel Boulud, chef of Restaurant Daniel, which in December will open a 12,000-square-foot establishment in the lobby. The services include, for a fee, preparing and serving meals in the condos and advice on managing wine collections.
Maid service and valet parking will be available. Among the planned amenities is a fitness center, which is included in the monthly maintenance fees. The fees range from $1,250 to $7,500, including real estate taxes.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
S.& P. 500 at Record Close On Low-Inflation Outlook

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Expectations of lower inflation lifted stocks yesterday for a third consecutive session, propelling the Standard & Poor's 500 index to a new closing high.
The market's exuberance was fueled by comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who told the Senate Budget Committee that slower United States economic growth as a result of the financial crisis in Asia would have a positive effect, helping to ward off inflation. His words were also taken as a sign that interest rates would not be increased anytime soon. 
 His comments lifted the bond market and reversed an early selloff caused by concern about earnings.
The rally in stocks was helped by gains among technology and telecommunications shares and by cyclical stocks, which tend to benefit from low interest rates. Makers of consumer staples benefited, too.
In addition, oil, gas and other energy stocks were broadly higher as expectations of a United States military attack on Iraq raised oil prices and dampened expectations of excessive supply.
Mr. Greenspan's comments followed strong earnings reports earlier this week from a number of companies, including Disney, Coca-Cola and United Airlines.
"This is a feel-better rally," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney.
"Investors had time to sort through the month of January, earnings are better and the Far East isn't getting any worse. And Greenspan sounded reassuring that growth was still solid without any problems with inflation."
The S.& P. 500 closed at 985.49, up 8.03 points, just eclipsing its previous closing high of 983.79 on Dec. 5. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 57.55 points, to 7,973.02. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite jumped 8.67 points, to 1,619.49.
While investors took heart from the recent flow of positive earnings reports, in reality, corporate earnings are in line with expectations, said Chuck Hill, director of research at the First Call Corporation.
So far 308 companies in the S.& P. 500, or about 62 percent, have reported their most recent quarter's results. Of those, 50 percent have come in above analysts' expectations, 23 percent have been in line with forecasts and 27 percent have been below estimates. Those figures are in line with quarterly averages going back to 1994 and suggest that on average fourth-quarter earnings will be about 2.2 percent above expectations over all, which is in line with previous years, he said.
In fact, Mr. Hill said that companies' reports were being compared with expectations that analysts had earlier reduced. He added that analysts were cutting their forecasts for the first quarter.
And while the S.& P. reached a new high yesterday, the Dow has failed to maintain a break through 8,000, a ceiling it has been struggling with since its record high of 8,259.31 on Aug. 6. The last time the Dow closed above 8,000 was Dec. 9.
"I don't like to see the averages get out of gear," said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. "I'd like to see if the Dow can catch up. It's a little bit of a divergence, but I don't think it's a major problem now."
The S.& P. was able to reach a new high because it has a high concentration of companies that make consumer staples, pharmaceuticals and beverages. These are attractive when investors fear slower earnings growth and greater market volatility over all, as was the case as the year began, Mr. McCabe said.
The stock of the Keebler Foods Company, the cookie and cracker company, gained 2 13/16, to 26 13/16, on its first day of trading. The company sold 11.6 million shares at $24 in its initial public offering.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Ready to Work, After Battling Mental Illness

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
Darius Hayward is between jobs. Almost a month has passed since his holiday-season stint as a Toys "R" Us stock clerk, and he does not relish the feeling of joblessness. On the other hand, he finds a certain pleasure in telling people he is temporarily unemployed, because until November, Mr. Hayward, 36, had never held a job.
For nearly a decade, he was in and out of the psychiatric ward of Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, fighting off the taunting voices he heard in his head. Until last year, it was a major effort for him simply to get out of bed. 
 "It gets boring being in the hospital day after day," said Mr. Hayward, whose paranoid schizophrenia was diagnosed when he was 22. "In fact, it wasn't any fun at all."
He caromed from one anti-psychotic regimen to the next, and until he started taking monthly doses of Haldol last year, nothing seemed to silence the voices. "Either the drugs would make me sick or just make me want to sleep," he said.
Before the onset of his illness, Mr. Hayward says his life was unremarkable. He lived with his mother and grandmother in Brownsville, Brooklyn, spent his free time playing basketball and, after graduating from high school, attended Wiley College in Texas. "I was the happiest kid on earth," recalled Mr. Hayward, a genteel, soft-spoken man with a neatly trimmed goatee.
But during his sophomore year, he began to hear the whispered taunts. One night he was arrested for disorderly conduct at an off-campus fast-food restaurant and jailed for four days, although he does not recall what he had done. Expelled from Wiley, he transferred to a college in Alabama, where he stayed only a few semesters. He returned to Brooklyn to live with his mother, and the voices became increasingly cruel, ridiculing his every move. "It was like I had the devil sitting on my shoulder," he said. When his delusions became unbearable, his mother had him hospitalized.
As his condition stabilized with medication, he moved back home. Pleased with his recovery, a psychiatrist referred him last spring to a job-training program run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The bureau has helped hundreds of formerly institutionalized adults find jobs as porters, messengers and sales clerks. "The employees we've hired are consistent, efficient and take pride in their work," said Lee Waxman, the owner of Vita Plus, a natural-food store in downtown Brooklyn, of his referrals from the program.
During his six months in the bureau's retail training program, Mr. Hayward learned the fundamentals of good customer service: keep smiling, try to make helpful suggestions, never chew gum and arrive on time.
Punctuality was never a problem for Mr. Hayward; most days he arrived 20 minutes early for his shift at the Toys "R" Us on Fulton Street, where he restocked shelves, fed the trash compactor and climbed a ladder to help customers reach merchandise. "It was a lot of fun," said Mr. Hayward, who saved $250 during the holiday season.
Gail Elias, the coordinator of the retail training program, says Mr. Hayward has been a role model for other participants, many of whom arrive timid and fearful but graduate with self-confidence. "Darius really wants to succeed," she said. "I don't think he'll have any problem finding another job." On Monday, he has an interview at Kmart that Ms. Elias helped arrange.
While he seeks a job, Mr. Hayward spends his days at his immaculate apartment in Brownsville. Family photos are carefully arranged along his living-room wall and a shelf displays a half-dozen basketball and baseball trophies. He rarely plays sports anymore, he said, "because I can't make those fancy moves like I used to."
Mr. Hayward has been living on his own for the last three years on disability benefits, since his mother, grandmother and brother died. He has overcome a stutter, and he smiles more than ever. "I used to avoid people, but now I like talking to everyone," he said.
Now confident in his ability to hold a job, he says he is ready to take the next big step. "I've proven that I can take care of myself," he said. "Now I want to prove that I can support a family."
