HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
On Asian Crisis Balance Sheet, Credits and Debits for the U.S.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
For drivers who pull into gasoline stations these days, the Asian crisis is a blessing. Falling demand for oil in Asia has helped to cut the average price of a gallon of regular gasoline in the United States to $1.08, from $1.20 last month. Not since 1989 has gasoline been so cheap. Home owners are similarly blessed. Thanks largely to the crisis, interest rates have fallen and the number of mortgage refinancings is higher than ever.
But for Caterpillar Inc., the crisis is not much fun at all -- demand for its heavy construction equipment, until recently so strong in Asia, has "declined sharply" as building projects have been canceled. For Eastman Chemical, the crisis blows fair and foul. Chemicals and plastics, the products it makes, have fallen in price as demand in Asia has fallen. But the price of a $20 million plastics plant that Eastman is building in Malaysia is shrinking, thanks to the falling currency there. The Limited is a winner for similar reasons. Making stylish blouses, sports clothes and underwear in Asia is suddenly less costly, which means a windfall profit for the big retailer, or the leeway to lower ticket prices in America, or a bit of both. 
In many ways, both positive and negative, the Asian crisis is affecting American businesses and consumers.
Most forecasters hold that by summer the entire economy could very well be growing more slowly, battered down by Asia. Indeed, many say that the more widespread the problems in Asia become, the more they would affect American businesses that rely on business abroad, and the more they could threaten the health of American stock markets.
But whatever the future holds, in the present, the Asian turmoil has produced a surprise -- throwing off enough pluses in America to dilute the minuses.
"The Asian crisis is real," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, an investment consultant. "But even as it takes away with one hand, it gives with the other."
What it is giving, more than anything else, is lower interest rates, making home and car loans cheaper. Weakening global demand coupled with overproduction of many goods -- felt most powerfully in Asia, where the crisis has crippled currencies, disrupted businesses and dried up lending over the last six months -- helps to explain the decline in rates here. So does an influx of investment in American government securities from investors looking for a safer bet than Asia. Home construction is strong, and so are vehicle sales. These two huge industries are giving the American economy a powerful if perhaps temporary boost. "Most data still depict a solid path for economic growth," Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, recently told clients.
Some members of Congress said the prospect of consumers benefiting in some way from the Asian crisis without any immediate economic problems had made it somewhat harder to justify American involvement in the international bailouts of South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia. Among other things, they said, it is difficult to convey a sense of urgency about the Clinton Administration's request for $18 billion to bolster the ability of the International Monetary Fund to deal with any future crises.
But those who support the bailouts said that in their conversations with American business leaders, most executives were deeply concerned about the implications of the Asia crisis for their profits, their competitiveness and their ability to continue creating new jobs.
"The concern about lost jobs more than offsets the benefits of cheaper goods," said David Runkel, the spokesman for Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking Committee.
Mr. Steinberg's latest weekly advisory lists the damage that he sees ahead -- particularly a "horrendous deterioration" in the trade balance as cheaper Asian goods arrive in the United States while American exports, made more expensive by the strong dollar, dry up.
Basing their predictions on the expected trade damage, many forecasters estimate that the Asian crisis will in time shave half a percentage point from the nation's annual economic growth, which was more than 3.5 percent last year.
Nonetheless, the pluses from the Asian crisis pop up frequently, and in unexpected ways. South Korea, for example, rarely purchased soybean meal from America. But over the last four weeks, it has suddenly bought 200,000 tons of this staple. Seeking to shield American farmers from the Asian damage, the Agriculture Department in late December guaranteed the repayment of $1 billion in Korean loans for the purchase of American food.
"No one had penciled in Korea as a buyer of American soybeans," said Robert Kohlmeyer, a grain specialist, "and now their soybean purchases explain why food exports to Asia are still strong."
Crude oil prices have fallen by nearly 30 percent since last summer. The unusually warm American winter has helped by reducing the demand for heating oil. A sharp rise in worldwide oil production is another big factor. But Asia looms largest.
"Until a few months ago," said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, "explosive growth in the demand for oil came out of Asia. Now that is gone, and suddenly there is too much oil. You are likely to see in 1998 not only the lowest price in years for gasoline, but also for jet fuel, diesel and heating oil. That is a bonanza for consumers."
The Limited appears to be enjoying a similar bonanza, one that will soon show up as a combination of lower retail prices in America and higher profits, the company said. Weaker Asian currencies make whatever is produced in the region less expensive in dollars. And rising unemployment in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and the Philippines holds down the wages of those who make The Limited's clothing there.
"Even outside Asia, where currencies have not devalued, our suppliers are sensing the competitive pressures from Asia and they are holding back on what they charge us," said Martin Trust, president of the Limited's manufacturing arm. That is the case, he said, in Mexico, a big supplier for the retail chain.
Often the pluses are coupled with the minuses. The world, for example, is awash in petrochemicals and plastics, partly because of rising production in Asia as demand there falls. The prices of these products, naturally, are falling and that squeezes Eastman Chemical of Kingsport, Tenn. On the plus side, however, the company is not only saving money in constructing its new plastics plant in Malaysia but also in building a petrochemical operation in Singapore.
Vehicle sales remain strong -- roughly 15 million cars and trucks a year, the same high level for nearly four years. But while American car makers gain ground in the marketing of expensive sport utility vehicles, two Korean companies, Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors, are making modest gains in the American subcompact market, having nearly doubled their combined sales in December, to 22,600 vehicles, from November's 12,300. Some Hyundai models sell today for $8,500, down $1,000 from last year.
Similarly, the nation's agricultural exports are holding up, thanks in part to the $40 million in soybean meal sold to Korea this month. But grain prices have fallen, hurting farmers. Despite the Korean sales, soybeans, for example, are off more than 25 cents a bushel since Dec. 1, closing last week at $6.70. "You would be a fool if you tried to sort out all the reasons for the price declines," said Mr. Kohlmeyer, the grain specialist, "but there is no doubt that in people's minds, Asia looms largest."
The damage to fourth-quarter earnings showed up particularly at three giant money center banks -- J. P. Morgan & Company, Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation. All are struggling to hold down losses from Asian loans and from trading in the region's currencies. But even as they struggle, the banks are finding opportunity in the crisis. Chase, for example, is the newly hired chief financial adviser to three troubled companies in Indonesia and Thailand.
"You adjust your fees so that you collect a little up front, and substantially more down the road when these companies are healthy again," said Robert Fallon, chief of Chase's Asia-Pacific division.
For Ronald Bullock, president of the Bison Gear and Engineering Company, near Chicago, sorting out the pluses and minuses is like trying to solve Rubik's cube. His company makes electric motors. The copper and manganese he buys for these motors have fallen in price on world markets, reducing his cost. Falling demand in Asia helps to explain the falling price. But Mr. Bullock's customers in America are not as quick to buy his motors, whatever their price. They are manufacturers of motor-driven ice-making machines and soft-drink dispensers, often sold in Asia. And their orders are falling.
On top of this, electric motors made in Korea and Malaysia are coming into the American market in larger numbers, competing with Bison's product. The prices of these imports have fallen, but not by much, Mr. Bullock said. The Asians, too, must buy copper and manganese, which are priced in dollars. That is not easy when Asian currencies are falling in value.
"The inroads these competitors can make into our markets may be limited," Mr. Bullock said hopefully, "because of the dollar costs of their materials."
There is outright damage from the Asian crisis, of course, even on college campuses. Two hundred students at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., 5 percent of the total enrollment, are from Asian countries caught in the turmoil. "They have been asking for tuition relief and more on-campus employment, which we are providing," said Lorna Hunter, dean of admissions and financial aid. "I don't see a panic, but they are watchful."
While reporting record fourth-quarter earnings, Caterpillar nevertheless noted that Asian demand for its heavy construction equipment had fallen significantly. In otherwise upbeat earnings reports, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation also warned of trouble ahead. And the Raytheon Company announced last week that its engineering and construction division would eliminate 1,000 jobs, partly because of less Asian business.
That may be just the vanguard of Asian-related downsizing. If the crisis continues, half a million jobs in the United States could be eliminated, the Economic Policy Institute concluded in a new study. Clearly the public is beginning to associate Asia with unemployment.
"In our latest poll, 10 percent of the people we interviewed spontaneously mentioned the Asia problem," said Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "They see it as a danger to jobs and also as a source of downward pressure on prices. The job insecurity tends to inhibit shopping, and so do the falling prices. Some people are waiting for prices to get even lower."
Beyond the damage that can be measured now or in the near future, there is what some experts describe as the toll from lost opportunity -- the business that will never be done.
Wal-Mart Stores, for example, has curbed plans to expand into Asia, said Kenneth Harris, a partner at Cannondale Associates, a marketing and sales consulting firm near Chicago.
"They had not publicly spoken of going into Asia," Mr. Harris said, "so there is nothing to pull back on. They also have plenty of room to expand elsewhere. But something is lost."

The Asian financial crisis has raised fears about the damage it could do to the American economy, but it also has had unexpected benefits.
 
FALLING PRICES Falling demand in Asia for oil and other commodities has reduced prices here.
 
FALLING INTEREST RATES With inflation lower and fewer places to lend abroad, American banks are lowering rates on mortgages and car loans to stimulate borrowing.
 
. . . and Worse
 
RISING TRADE DEFICIT As Asian countries reduce their imports and flood this market with cheaper exports, the trade gap is expected to grow.
 
FALLING PROFITS Some companies doing business in Asia have already felt the impact, and profits could be hit further.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 498 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Budget Choices

 BODY:
With sizable budget surpluses flowing from New York City's economic boom, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani could easily have proposed major new spending programs and tax cuts for next year. Instead, he has prudently chosen to stick with fiscal discipline. The financial plan outlined by Mr. Giuliani yesterday calls for selective new expenditures for education and anti-drug programs, as well as elimination of the sales tax on clothing and other modest tax reductions. But these would be paid for with spending cuts elsewhere. His projected $35 billion budget thus lays the groundwork for economic stability in the city.
Mr. Giuliani's most flamboyant gesture was aimed at the city's community college system, which he asserts spends too much on remedial programs for students who cannot read, write or do arithmetic at college levels. In a threat certain to rile the City University's leadership and the State Legislature, he suggested he might withhold the city's portion of the community colleges' budget if they do not shut down their remedial programs and farm them out to private institutions. 
 That sounds, however, as if Mr. Giuliani has fired a warning cannon rather than proposed a realistic solution. He will need to demonstrate why he believes that a wholly new remedial approach would work better than existing remedial programs, and will have to explain what impact his approach would have on traditional open admissions policies in the community colleges.
This has been a year of budget surpluses at all levels. Earlier in the week, President Clinton took a cautious approach by proposing to set aside the first Federal surplus in 30 years for use in financing the long-term deficit in the Social Security system. By contrast, Gov. George Pataki is recklessly proposing to use New York State's surplus for a spending increase to bolster his re-election campaign.
Mr. Giuliani comes out somewhere between these two approaches. He declined to use the surplus to pay down some of the city's mountain of long-term debt, the most prudent fiscal approach. Instead he would simply close budget gaps projected for next year and the year after.
Because this is a state election year, the debate with the City Council over the budget could be especially lively. The Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, is running for governor, and he wants the city to set more money aside in a reserve fund that could be tapped in the event of an economic downturn in the years ahead. He also proposes to cut the city's personal income tax instead of the business and sales taxes that Mr. Giuliani wants to cut. But these will be quibbles over happy choices.
The Mayor's budget contains no new ideas for improving the productivity of the city's work force, including the use of civilians to replace deskbound police officers. But its priorities are generally sensible, there are very few egregious gimmicks, and the overall spending restraint reflects a sound stewardship of the city's finances.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Blair Opens an Inquiry Into Irish 'Bloody Sunday'
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said he was opening a new judicial inquiry into the "Bloody Sunday" killings of more than a dozen unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland in 1972. The event became a focus of Roman Catholic rage in the troubled province. A1 

Albright Presses Iraq
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright held talks with the French Foreign Minister and then spoke of France's preference for a diplomatic solution to the crisis with Iraq. But Ms. Albright and Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine issued coordinated remarks designed to insure that Saddam Hussein knows that the time for a diplomatic capitulation is now, American diplomats said. A6
 
Israel Ready to Retaliate
Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai said Israel would respond if Iraq attacked it in retaliation for an American military strike. Israeli officials say there is a low probability of an Iraqi missile strike and they see no imminent threat. But many Israelis have been unsettled by intense media coverage of the dangers posed by chemical and biological agents. A6
 
French Trial Suspended
The trial in France of Maurice Papon on charges of complicity in German war crimes ended its 58th session with a wave of controversy concerning the judge. Questions were raised whether the judge should step down after an unexpected assertion that he was distantly related to one of the surviving victims. The judge suspended the trial until Monday. A4
 
31 Die in Peru Avalanche
At least 31 people died when an avalanche caused by heavy rains obliterated part of a remote town in Peru's southern Andes, local officials and witnesses said. A river burst its banks some 400 miles southeast of Lima, setting off a landslide. It buried nearly 100 homes and forced hundreds of people to flee by running or swimming in the flood of mud and rocks, according to the witnesses and officials. (Reuters)
 
Explosion on Russian Sub
A naval captain was killed and at least four sailors were hurt in a gas explosion on a nuclear submarine in Russia's far north, the Russian navy said, adding that no radiation leaked. The submarine was undergoing maintenance at Zaozersk base at the time of the blast, which sent poisonous ammonia gas, used as a coolant, spewing as the workers were fixing an energy unit. (Reuters)
 
Couple Missing on Barrier Reef
An American couple is missing from a scuba-diving cruise to the Great Barrier Reef in Australia. A Queensland Emergency Services helicopter was scheduled to search the coastline on Friday for the divers, missing since Sunday, but an airplane search was called off, a police spokesman said. The police have indicated that the chances for their survival are slim. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A8-15
 
Judge in Clinton-Jones Trial Bars Lewinsky Evidence
A Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., ruled that lawyers representing Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton could not use any evidence involving the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky, a setback in helping them to make their case. The judge said that while information about Ms. Lewinsky might be relevant to Ms. Jones's case her participation in Ms. Jones's sexual misconduct trial could interfere with the criminal investigation being conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. A1
 
Negotiations between Ms. Lewinsky's lawyer and Mr. Starr have stalled, lawyers said, partly because she is not offering prosecutors as much detail about her conversations with President Clinton as she reportedly disclosed to a friend on secretly recorded tapes. A1
 
1 Killed in Clinic Bombing
An off-duty police officer was killed and a nurse was critically wounded in an explosion at a clinic in Birmingham, Ala. It was believed to be the first fatal bombing of an abortion clinic in the United States. A1
 
Sheep's Cloning Questioned
The credibility of the experiment reporting the cloning of Dolly the sheep from the cell of an adult ewe is being challenged by a leading biologist, and other eminent scientists agree that the experiment needs to be repeated before it can be accepted. A8
 
A Gene Linked to Baldness
Researchers said they had identified the first human gene ever to be linked to hair loss. The finding involved only a rare condition found in Pakistan, not the more common types of baldness. Still, they said, the gene appears to play a critical role in the formation of hair, and that understanding its function may help in devising better ways to prevent and treat various forms of baldness. A8
 
Navy Reconsiders a Discharge
The Navy said it was considering dropping its efforts to dismiss a sailor accused of homosexuality, after a Federal judge issued a permanent injunction barring his discharge. A8
 
A.F.L.-C.I.O. Offers Agenda
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. outlined a legislative agenda that would raise the minimum wage and require employers to pay at least 75 percent of workers' health insurance premiums. A10
 
Babbitt Defends Decision
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt testified in Congress that his department's decision in 1995 to reject a permit to build an Indian casino in Wisconsin was based on the merits of the case not political pressure. A10
 
Anti-Pollution Pact in Trouble
An agreement to reduce air pollution appeared to falter, as New York, Massachusetts and Vermont rejected auto industry demands that they relax their emission regulations so that manufacturers could produce one standard, cleaner car for every state but California. A11

Mayor Giuliani called for an overhaul of New York City's six community colleges, declaring that they should shift the responsibility for teaching remedial courses to other institutions, a policy that he said would reduce the number of students in the system by at least 75 percent. In proposing a $34.3 billion city budget, Mr. Giuliani also repeated his plan to eliminate the sales tax on clothing and footwear, and unveiled a proposal to do away with the tax on commercial rents in Manhattan south of 96th Street. U.S. Investigating Reuters
Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings, the news and financial data giant, paid experts to steal confidential information from the corporate computers of a major competitor, Bloomberg. A1
 
Greenspan Sees Asian Impact
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned that Asia's financial crisis would soon be felt in the United States. However, he said the resulting slowdown in growth would reduce any risk that inflation would derail the nation's seven-year expansion. Mr. Greenspan called the economy exceptionally healthy, but he also said he was not ready to conclude that inflation was no longer a threat. He left analysts and investors with the impression that interest rates would hold steady. D1
 
Banks and the Asian Crisis
A study prepared for the world's major banks concluded that after viewing Asia for years as a promised land for lending and investing -- despite growing signs of trouble -- Western financial institutions panicked last fall and shut down the flow of new capital to troubled countries. Data in the study provide the first concrete evidence of how the powerful and mercurial flow of international money propped up and then helped unravel the countries now in crisis. D1

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI BUDGET: THE POLITICS;
Beyond Budget, Mayor Looks to Larger Stage

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Wielding his steel pointer like a conductor's baton, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered an hourlong lecture yesterday on how his administration had transformed New York City's disastrous budget into a model of fiscal prudence. Then, just when another pie-chart display could have sparked audience rebellion, he energized the room by suddenly declaring war on the City University of New York -- a tangential budgetary issue at best.
It was the masterstroke of a teacher confident in his material and presentation, not unlike a history scholar reciting a few of the Draconian codes of ancient Greece. But yesterday's subject matter extended beyond the righteousness of a tight budget and the need to fix what the Mayor said was a flawed educational system. Beneath all the verbiage about "budget stabilization accounts" and "city-funded head counts," there seemed to be a subliminal message as well: 
 Wouldn't you like this intellectually brash ex-prosecutor -- someone ready to brawl at the drop of a moral tenet -- to run your state or country the way he runs his own city?
"No rocket science is required in this," said Fred Siegel, the author of "The Future Once Happened Here," an examination of large American cities. "This year, he looks at a wider audience. His budget is consistent with the logic of his State of the City speech, and positions him to market his success in New York City as a model of what he could do on a larger stage."
Mr. Giuliani has just begun his second, and -- because of term limits -- last four-year term; at this point, he usually responds to questions about his political future with just-happy-to-be-Mayor answers. But there is no doubt that the steps he takes now, beginning with yesterday's unveiling of a $34.3 billion preliminary budget plan, are intended to establish a public-policy template that could very easily be applied to a larger body politic.
It begins with the city's budget, his fifth. Mr. Giuliani proposed an increase of only six-tenths of 1 percent in spending, which is below the rate of inflation, as well as a series of tax cuts for small businesses, commercial rentals and people buying clothes and shoes.
More telling, perhaps, is his proposed use of a $1.2 billion surplus: to close projected budget gaps over the next two years and to bolster a so-called rainy-day fund to help the city respond to the inevitable conclusion to the current Wall Street boom.
Then, under his stated rubric that "everything is a budget issue," the Mayor shifted attention to the city's six community colleges, all of which operate under the CUNY umbrella. Because the city contributes about $110 million a year to CUNY, Mr. Giuliani found fiscal justification to blast an educational system that he says deludes many students into thinking they are prepared for higher learning.
He laid out a plan to have all CUNY community college students take a proficiency examination. Those who pass could continue in the two-year colleges; the rest, which he guessed would be about 75 percent, would take remedial classes overseen by some outside institution hired to do the job. Citing an extremely low graduation rate after two years, he said: "It cannot get worse. It can only get better."
In the past, the Mayor's austere policies, the kind best delivered through pursed lips, have been criticized as too moralistic, too severe. But on the budget plan, at least, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker; Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, and even H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller whose battles with the Mayor have raised the art of vitriol, all praised Mr. Giuliani for resisting the temptation to spend away the surplus.
Clearly enjoying their we-told-you-so moment, the Mayor and his advisers were quick to note that the administration's handling of the billion-dollar surplus, the second in a row for the city, stands in marked contrast to the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, which spent the city's last round of surpluses on social services and other programs -- not on closing budget gaps.
Beyond the history lessons, mayoral advisers also swiftly contrasted Mr. Giuliani's budget to that of Gov. George E. Pataki, whom the Mayor endorsed for re-election during a visit to Albany this week. Mr. Pataki ended his pattern of fiscal austerity by proposing a 7.6 percent increase in spending, which some critics say represents artless pandering in a gubernatorial election year.
Here are the comments of Raymond B. Harding, one of the Mayor's closest political confidants: "As part of restoring the fiscal soundness of the city, the Mayor resisted the temptation -- which the Governor did not -- during a period of surplus to come out with a Christmas tree financial plan. I can't think of a more responsible thing to do."
The implication, of course, is that Mr. Pataki comes off as somewhat less responsible than Mr. Giuliani (who, by the way, was unable to resist spending a little extra last year when facing an election of his own).
Mr. Giuliani was not about to waste yesterday's assembly of television cameras and reporters on budget matters alone. Pointing to a chart titled "Raising CUNY Community College Standards" -- one of 41 displayed during his presentation -- the Mayor laid out his assault on the CUNY system with jaw jutting. Of the conflagration almost certain to follow, he said, "I enjoy big battles" -- an understatement that prompted guffaws a bit too loud from his team of deputy mayors.
"He clearly sees it as a winner for him," said Kevin McCabe, the senior political adviser to the Council Speaker, Mr. Vallone. "And he's done this throughout his career here. He raises the bar to a level where it gets a lot of attention. He sets the parameters of the debate. And then he negotiates his way back to declare victory."
Whether Mr. Giuliani's budget withstands the five months of scrutiny and negotiation that lay ahead remains to be seen. The Citizens Budget Commission, a private fiscal-watchdog panel gifted in its ability to irritate the Mayor, has already characterized his fiscal prudence as an illusion. The same uncertainty surrounds his drastic education plan, given that it needs the approval of state officials and a CUNY board already girding for battle.
Even so, as he stood alongside his charts, the Mayor looked every bit the part of Mr. Giuliani the teacher, ready to dispense the castor oil in his drawer, eager to share a lesson plan with other, larger schools. As Mr. Siegel, the author, said, the Giuliani plan contains the following instruction: "My values are yours. I'm moving in your direction."

 BODY:

Bonds Rise Strongly On Greenspan Comments
Treasury securities surged after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said Asia's economic crisis would give the American economy "some breathing room from inflation pressures."
 
 The yield on the 30-year bond was driven down to 5.83 percent from 5.94. Page D7.
 
Mr. Greenspan's remarks also fueled gains in the stock market, where the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 8.03, to a new high, 985.49, and the Dow industrials rose 57.55, to 7,973.02. D7.
 
From lower fuel prices to more affordable mortgages, the Asian crisis appears to be generating enough pluses for the United States economy to dilute the minuses. A1.
 
Airtouch Revives Deal For U S West Wireless
Airtouch Communications revived a plan to acquire U S West Media Group's domestic wireless telephone operation. The new deal is worth $4.3 billion in stock, $1.5 billion more than the original deal, which fell apart when Congress closed a tax loophole. After the acquisition, Airtouch would become the nation's No. 2 wireless telephone company, trailing only AT&T. D2.
 
MCI Communications, which Worldcom is buying, said that profit before special charges fell sharply. D2.
 
Tobacco Chiefs Conciliatory
The chief executives of the nation's largest tobacco companies appeared before the House Commerce Committee, pledging to release secret company documents, combat teen-age smoking and acknowledge tobacco risks in an effort to gain protection from lawsuits. A15.
 
U.S. Inquiry on Reuters Unit
Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American subsidiary of Reuters, the news and financial information giant, commissioned computer specialists to steal confidential information from the corporate computers of a major competitor, Bloomberg. A1.
 
S.E.C. Opposes Market Closings
The Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., and other top financial regulators opposed a proposal by securities markets to suspend trading for the day if stocks fall sharply. Mr. Levitt told a Senate subcommittee that such a change could inspire more fear among investors. D4.
 
Korean Stocks Surge
South Korean stocks rallied to their best level in three months early today on a wave of optimism generated by a restructuring agreement with international banks on $24 billion in short-term Korean debt. D5.
 
Possible Threat to REIT's
Investors sold off shares of a handful of real estate investment trusts on a report that the Clinton Administration might propose to alter the way they do business. D4.
 
More Trouble at Waste Hauler
Waste Management said problems with misleading accounting went back to 1992, two years earlier than previously announced. D3.
 
Apple Clone Seller Shuts
Power Computing Corporation, until last summer one of the fastest-growing personal computer companies, has apparently gone out of business. The company auctioned the last of its assets at company headquarters. D3.
 
Marking Down Polo/Ralph Lauren
The stock of Polo/Ralph Lauren, one of the hottest initial public offerings of 1997, has fallen below its offering price -- despite the company's growth plans and impressive earnings estimates. Market Place. D7.

HEADLINE: Reuters Unit Is Investigated Over Theft of a Rival's Data

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the news and financial data giant, commissioned computer specialists to steal confidential information from the corporate computers of a major competitor, Bloomberg L.P.
The inquiry, under way for close to a year, has included an undercover investigation of the subsidiary, Reuters Analytics Inc., people who have been briefed on the case said. At least one confidential informant was said to have helped the Government obtain an array of evidence during the investigation, including audio recordings of executives. In the apparent scheme, Reuters was said to have obtained information from Bloomberg's operating code, which governs how the company's data terminals work. 
 The case has emerged at a time of increasingly heated competition in the financial data industry. The two companies -- far and away the largest in the business -- have been battling to increase the number of investment institutions that use their services to help decide which stocks, bonds and other investments to trade.
Already, the investigation has begun to reach the London headquarters of Reuters. During the summer, investigators were said to have begun examining the role of certain executives in London to determine whether they knew about the apparent scheme. Indeed, without the knowledge of those executives, investigators in recent months have examined their travel to the American subsidiary and their contacts with its executives, people who have been briefed on the case said.
Investigators have evidence that some of the data obtained from the Bloomberg corporate computers may have wound up on the desks of some executives in London, people who have been briefed on the inquiry said. It was not immediately clear whether such data could be recognized as coming from Bloomberg or whether the executives knew about its origins.
The evidence in the investigation indicates that some executives with Reuters Analytics were responsible specifically for overseeing the apparent scheme, people briefed on the case said. Indeed, industry executives said, a large part of the division's purpose was to develop a product intended to take over much of Bloomberg's business. But that effort was unsuccessful.
According to people who have been briefed on the inquiry, investigators have developed evidence that the scheme worked like this:
The Reuters subsidiary commissioned another company, whose identity could not immediately be determined, to conduct electronic break-ins of Bloomberg's computers. They would then obtain confidential data and later turn it over to Reuters executives.
The investigation, which was said to have been touched off by a former employee of one of the companies involved, is part of a new Government effort to crack down on industrial espionage by foreign companies. That effort began in 1996 with the passage of the Economic Espionage Act, which made theft of trade secrets a Federal crime. Despite that law, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said earlier this month that such espionage against American companies had increased, with the potential damage reaching $300 billion in 1997 alone.
In the Reuters investigation, prosecutors were said to have developed evidence that the analytics division, based in Stamford, Conn., used the scheme to obtain the operating code of Bloomberg's market data system, which one person briefed on the case described as "the Holy Grail" of Bloomberg's product. In essence, the operating system represents the central nervous system of the software on which Bloomberg built its business.
Bloomberg was made aware of the inquiry several months ago, people who have been briefed on the inquiry said, and has been secretly cooperating with the Federal inquiry. Federal agents were said to have been permitted to monitor Bloomberg's corporate computers, tracking at least some of the break-ins as they occurred. In a statement, Michael Bloomberg, the company's chairman and chief executive, declined to comment.
The existence of a grand jury investigation was disclosed yesterday in a news release by Reuters Holdings. In the short statement, Reuters said the analytics subsidiary was the subject of a grand jury investigation in New York and added that Reuters was cooperating with the inquiry.
Reuters said the investigation was focused on whether the subsidiary "improperly obtained access to, and used information from, Bloomberg L.P.'s product." The company also said it had hired an outside lawyer to conduct an internal investigation. It declined to comment further.
People involved in the case said that Reuters was notified of the criminal investigation on Jan. 21. American companies are required to disclose such information immediately. It was not immediately clear why Reuters delayed its announcement for eight days.
The disclosure sent shares of Reuters Holdings down 28 pence, or 4.5 percent, to 592 pence in London trading. American depository receipts for the company, which trade on the Nasdaq exchange, fell 5.8 percent, or $3.625, to $57.875.
Marvin Smilon, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, declined to comment.
The investigation could shake up the highly competitive world of the nearly $6 billion financial information industry. Some 15 years ago, Bloomberg was little more than an idea; the industry largely belonged to Reuters and the company now known as Dow Jones Markets. But both companies failed to notice the phenomenal growth of Bloomberg, which built its foundation on a squat terminal that sits on more than 75,000 desks worldwide.
As the years passed, Reuters remained the undisputed leader, offering a breadth of market information that remains unsurpassed. But Bloomberg, focusing on the needs of institutional investors and investment analysts, homed in on the business of providing historical data packaged with analytical software. That made the company's equipment almost a requirement on Wall Street, for bankers, traders and others who rely on that analysis.
"What Bloomberg did was come to the market and appeal to a new set of users who had been underserved," said Andrew Delaney, senior vice president with Inside Market Data, an industry publication. "Reuters noticed several years ago that Bloomberg was growing at an alarming rate, not only in North America but globally. It also noticed it wasn't growing at those same rates."
In response, Reuters decided to take on Bloomberg at its own business. It contracted with Capital Markets Decisions Inc., an American company, to develop Reuters Decision 2000, its own data and analytics service. Within the industry, Decision 2000 was nicknamed the "Bloomberg killer," because it was thought that the purpose of developing it was to capture Bloomberg's market and put the company out of business.
But relations between Reuters and Capital Markets Decisions broke down, and Reuters eventually bought the small company. After its purchase, the company was renamed Reuters Analytics, the subsidiary at the heart of the current investigation.
Decision 2000 never took off. But Reuters came back with a new product, Reuters 3000, which supplies historical data and analytical software that allows users to accomplish much of what they could do with a Bloomberg terminal. By the end of last March, Reuters had received orders for nearly 18,000 installations.
Now, prosecutors are keenly interested in Reuters 3000 and are said to be examining whether lines of code from the Bloomberg operating system were used in its development.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pat Turner, an employee of Reuters Analytics, was answering phones yesterday at the company's offices in Stamford, Conn. Federal prosecutors suspect the unit of stealing a competitor's confidential information. (Tom McDonald for The New York Times)(pg. D18)

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE SPEAKER;
Conservatives Quietly Find Ways to Talk Of Scandal

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Jan. 29

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested today that the White House was becoming "unstable," in part because of the sex scandal that threatens to engulf President Clinton.
Mr. Gingrich's comments amounted to the first partisan blow, however glancing, by Republicans who until today have been content to let the President suffer without any help from them, help that could lead the public to dismiss the issue as partisan grumbling. 
 Mr. Gingrich spoke in the context of the need for Republicans to develop a positive message:
"As things become more unstable, people are going to want to look to somebody who cares about the nation first, who is patriotic first, who is solution-oriented first," Mr. Gingrich told hundreds of people as the lead-off speaker at the 25th anniversary of the Conservative Political Action Conference.
"Between the financial crisis in Southeast Asia, the problems we now see developing in Iraq, the difficulties we see developing around the White House," he said, "people are going to want somebody who cares about America first and who's offering a positive sense of a long-term future."
By weaving this muted thread into his bolder theme -- that Republicans must learn to govern, not just sling darts -- Mr. Gingrich left barely a trace.
And so it went throughout a day of speeches by some of the nation's leading conservatives -- any references to the President's personal problems were brief and understated and in some cases non-existent.
One of the few who was direct, predictably enough, was one of the freshmen elected in 1994 under Mr. Gingrich's revolutionary banner. That lawmaker, Representative David M. McIntosh, Republican of Indiana, first said the President deserved to be presumed innocent until proven guilty, but then added:
"I categorically reject the notion that private morality is not related to public service. After all, if you'll cheat and lie to those you love, you'll cheat and lie to the American public. This is unacceptable."
Mr. McIntosh was strongly applauded.
Another speaker, Representative Helen Chenoweth, Republican of Idaho, also a sophomore, said she intended to start speaking out about "the crisis in the Presidency."
"Character does count," she said. "It's important that we stand up for the strong moral fiber of the United States of America."
But most speakers did not address the accusations that President Clinton was sexually involved with a young intern and then urged her to lie about it.
Those who did were fleeting, like Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief United States delegate to the United Nations. Discussing Mr. Clinton's responsibilities toward the public, Ms. Kirkpatrick added parenthetically, "He had more trouble exercising responsibility, I think, than we did."
Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a once and probable future candidate for President, told reporters after he spoke, "It's a national embarrassment," but Mr. Alexander refused to discuss the matter.
"I'm going to let the facts speak for themselves," he said.
Former Vice President Dan Quayle delivered his traditional speech about family values, which took on extra resonance in the current context. "America is hungry for creative, strong, and, yes, moral leadership," he declared tonight.
But it was Charlton Heston, the actor and top spokesman for the National Rifle Association, who was most graphic about the situation.
"Our President's recent troubles are dramatic proof that cultural war is not a clash over the facts, or even between philosophies," he said. "It's a clash between the principled and the unprincipled."
He added: "I'm not talking about whether he 'did it' or 'didn't do it.' I am talking about people who cannot comprehend moral absolutes, and a country that seems to accept it."
David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, which sponsors the conference, said that this group tended to attract economic conservatives more than social conservatives and that Republicans were smart to heed Mr. Gingrich's early advice to avoid discussing the President's sex life.
In fact, there were more questions from the audience about Mr. Gingrich's future than Mr. Clinton's. In response, Mr. McIntosh said that he, for one, was pleased that Mr. Gingrich was thinking about running for President because primary voters would force him to take more conservative positions than he has so far.

HEADLINE: Joseph Alioto, 81, Dies; Antitrust Lawyer Was San Francisco's Mayor in Boom Years

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

 BODY:
Joseph L. Alioto, the two-term Mayor of San Francisco during the city's most dynamic growth in the late 1960's and early 1970's and a lawyer who earned millions of dollars with the nation's largest civil antitrust practice, died yesterday at his home in San Francisco. He was 81 and had prostate cancer, but family members said he died of pneumonia.
Even in a city that prides itself on its colorful citizenry, Joseph Lawrence Alioto stood out, from his childhood as the son of a Sicilian immigrant working on his father's boats at Fisherman's Wharf to his law school days as a scholarship student and on through his rough-and-tumble political and legal careers. 
 Those careers brought him great rewards but they also eventually contributed to his estrangement from some of his children, the bitter breakup of his family law firm and a divorce from his first wife, who disappeared for a time in 1974 and returned to complain that she had been taken for granted as a political wife. It was the dark side of what in many ways is a classic story of immigrant success in America. Mr. Alioto's father, Giuseppe, had sailed from Palermo at the age of 9 and later found work on fishing boats in San Francisco Bay. As a young man, he married Domenica Lazio, the daughter of Sicilian immigrants. In fact, he was one of three Alioto brothers who married three Lazio sisters, and they and their many children lived in the same three-story apartment building, making it almost impossible for neighbors to sort out which child went with which couple.
Giuseppe Alioto next started his own wholesale fish business and his brothers opened restaurants. Joseph Alioto went on to graduate magna cum laude from St. Mary's College in Moraga, Calif., in 1937 and was awarded a scholarship to law school at Catholic University in Washington.
After graduating in 1940, he became an antitrust lawyer for the Government and then, when the United States entered World War II, he went to the Board of Economic Warfare, where he studied German, Italian and Japanese cartels to help determine which factories to bomb.
After the war, Mr. Alioto used his antitrust experience to represent movie producers Samuel Goldwyn, Walt Disney and Walter Wanger in suits against the studios and theaters that charged them with monopolistic practices.
From 1964 to 1966, he won more than $61 million in damages, mostly for clients challenging big companies in price-fixing cases. The fees made him wealthy and he invested in businesses through his company, Alioto Enterprises. Until Mr. Alioto came along, antitrust cases generally were brought by Government agencies. "We established the nation's laws that protect private entrepreneurs from monopolistic practices," Mr. Alioto told The San Francisco Examiner.
Mr. Alioto married the former Angelina Genaro of Dallas in 1941 and they had six children. He was little known as a candidate when he entered the 1967 race for mayor of San Francisco but he staged a whirlwind 56-day campaign to become only the third Democratic mayor of the city in 60 years.
He was elected largely with the support of labor unions and minorities, though he managed to draw the votes of many Republican middle-class homeowners.
Angela Alioto, who remained devoted to her father in the face of family turmoil and who followed him into politics as a member of the Board of Supervisors, remembered Mr. Alioto's entrance into politics in a recent interview. Her family would spend eight weeks every summer in Italy; her five brothers studied on their own in Perugia and, as the only daughter, she attended school in Florence under her father's watchful eye.
"I came home from the Dante Alighieri School one day in 1967," Ms. Alioto said, "and Dad called me over and said we are going back to San Francisco so he can run for Mayor."
The candidate Mr. Alioto was backing had died and his fallback candidate dropped out just before the deadline because of ill health. "I was the sucker of last resort," Mr. Alioto said.
Mr. Alioto won in a large field, getting 43 percent of the vote. In his first term he was a dynamo, working to improve race relations and embarking on an ambitious and controversial downtown building program that was to result in the construction of more than 100 high-rises in the city. Among the projects started during his administration were the Transamerica Pyramid and the Embarcadero Center.
In 1968, Mr. Alioto was regarded as a bright newcomer to the Democratic Party and he was chosen to nominate Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey that year at the Democratic Party Convention in Chicago; there was even talk of a Vice Presidential nomination. Though that never happened, Mr. Alioto was sufficiently encouraged to plan a 1970 race against the incumbent Ronald Reagan for Governor of California. But his hopes were dashed when he became the target of accusations.
In 1969, Mr. Alioto was described by Look magazine as "enmeshed in a web of alliances with at least six leaders of La Cosa Nostra." He denied the charges, dropped his plans to run for Governor and brought a $12.5 million libel suit against Look. After four trials he was awarded $350,000, which Ms. Alioto said contributed to Look's demise.
In 1971, Attorney General John Mitchell announced Mayor Alioto's indictment by a Federal grand jury in Seattle on nine counts of bribery, conspiracy and mail fraud. The charges dated to 1962 when Mr. Alioto was retained by the Attorney General of the State of Washington. Mr. Alioto denied any wrongdoing and in 1972 a Federal judge in Tacoma announced a directed order of acquittal for Mayor Alioto and the Washington officials.
Mr. Alioto was re-elected Mayor with a reduced vote in 1971.
His daughter said he would be remembered as a coalition builder. "He appointed the most minorities to all positions -- the first Asian, the first Latino, the first Filipino and the second African-American to the Board of Supervisors," she said. On Jan. 18, 1974, when Mayor Alioto was campaigning again for Governor, his wife, Angelina, became angered when he forgot to introduce her at a function in Palm Springs. She drove away and dropped from sight for three weeks. It turned out that she was touring the California missions while the police were searching for her.
At a news conference later at their 15-room mansion, Mrs. Alioto said, "I was frustrated over being used." She added, "I have to be here alone in this place with my housekeeper 27 nights a month and I feel neglected."
Mr. Alioto lost the Democratic nomination for Governor to Jerry Brown. He also lost his wife. The couple were divorced in 1977. Two years earlier, barred by law from seeking a third term as Mayor, Mr. Alioto returned to his family law practice at Alioto & Alioto. In 1978 he married the former Kathleen Sullivan, an unsuccessful Senate candidate in Massachusetts and a daughter of William H. Sullivan Jr., the then owner of the New England Patriots football team and one of Mr. Alioto's clients.
His sons John and Joseph left the family law firm in the early 1990's in but the children reconciled with their father as he neared death. In addition to his wife, Kathleen, his daughter, Angela, his sons John and Joseph, Mr. Alioto is survived by three other sons from his first marriage, Lawrence, Thomas and Michael; two children from his second marriage, Patrick and Domenica, and 11 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI BUDGET: THE BUDGET;
Giuliani Demands Community Colleges Drop Remedial Help

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for a drastic overhaul of New York City's six community colleges, declaring that they should shift the responsibility for teaching remedial courses to other institutions, a policy he said could essentially reduce the number of students in the system by at least 75 percent. He backed his proposal with a threat: If the colleges balked, he might withhold their city financing.
Mr. Giuliani said a vast majority of the students in the two-year colleges, which are part of the City University of New York, should not have been admitted because they were unprepared for college work. Renewing his attack on the standards at CUNY, he said the system should focus on only those who were ready for community college. 
 "There comes a point, after 15 years of tragically plummeting graduation rates and a total evisceration of standards, that somebody has to say: 'This isn't working,' " he said.
The Mayor, who prides himself on his bare-knuckled challenges to institutions that he does not control, appeared to relish picking a fight with the CUNY board, joking that its members might faint when they heard his plan.
Mr. Giuliani's proposal represented the latest salvo he has fired at CUNY, a few weeks after he said the system should end its longstanding policy of automatically accepting any city resident with a high school diploma and adopt an admissions examination instead.
Mr. Giuliani issued the proposal as he announced his preliminary budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The $34.3 billion spending plan hews to a cautious course, featuring relatively modest proposals for new programs, spending reductions and tax cuts.
The budget reflects the strong growth in profits on Wall Street, which has helped generate a $1.2 billion surplus in the current fiscal year that the Mayor wants to use to reduce shortfalls in the next two years.
Mr. Giuliani repeated his plan to eliminate the sales tax on clothing and footwear, which would require state approval; unveiled a new proposal to do away with the tax on commercial rents in Manhattan south of 96th Street, and said he would consider a plan from the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, to eliminate a surcharge on the city's personal income tax.
The Mayor also called for $429 million in budget cuts, including reductions in spending on cultural organizations and libraries, though if recent history is any guide, some of those will be restored in negotiations with the City Council, whose approval is required for the budget to become law.
While the Mayor can urge changes at the CUNY community colleges, he does not have much authority to have them adopted, because CUNY is run by the state, which provides about half of the system's budget. Mr. Giuliani can seek to exert leverage over the CUNY board, which is controlled by appointees of the Governor, mostly by trying to withhold the city's contribution to the system's budget.
Depending on the calculation method, the city pays 20 to 30 percent of the budget of the six community colleges, which serve 37 percent of the students in the CUNY system. State aid and tuition payments make up the rest of the budget.
CUNY reacted cautiously yesterday, saying in a statement that it favored raising standards but declining to directly address the Mayor's proposal. On a visit to Brooklyn, Gov. George E. Pataki said he had not yet seen the proposal, and offered no opinion on it.
Mr. Giuliani said the city should continue its current level of financing but divide the money between CUNY and other educational institutions that would teach remedial courses. He declined to give examples of what types of institutions might want to play such a role, or to say whether he was talking about private colleges or the kind of companies that prepare high school students for standardized tests.
"I don't have anyone in mind," he said. "I just think about all of the great schools that the city has. And maybe some of them would be interested in running some of these programs." He added: "This is going to take a year or two to really work out. I mean, it's an enormously complex thing."
Asked whether he would refuse to finance CUNY if it did not adopt his proposal, Mr. Giuliani said, "It may come down to that."
This is not the first time that the Mayor has threatened to withhold money from a state-controlled institution in an effort to push a new policy. Early in his first term, Mr. Giuliani withheld a city contribution to the budget of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, seeking to compel the authority to agree to a merger of the transit police and the city's Police Department, something that other mayors had favored but had been unable to accomplish.
Mr. Giuliani ultimately won that skirmish with the M.T.A.
Herman Badillo, the vice chairman of the CUNY board and an informal mayoral adviser, said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani had grown increasingly frustrated in recent months with the CUNY board's response to his proposals for toughening standards.
"What is going on here is that the Mayor has gotten impatient with the pace of what is happening," said Mr. Badillo, who supports the Mayor's position.
"The moment you hit someone in the budget, you are really forcing them to move," he added.
The Mayor, in presenting his overall budget proposals yesterday, pointed proudly to the spending figures, saying that excluding state and Federal aid, spending was increasing by only six-tenths of 1 percent on average, less than the local inflation rate of 2 percent to 2.5 percent.
He also said that because of his prudent fiscal policies, he expected the city would face smaller shortfalls over the next four years than he had originally anticipated.
"We're now going through some of the best times," Mr. Giuliani proclaimed, drawing a comparison between the city's current financial standing and the dire situation he said he inherited when he took office in 1994.
But some figures in the budget painted a somewhat different picture from the one the Mayor highlighted, particularly when the surplus was taken into account. Under the city's accounting rules, the surplus is tallied as being spent in the current fiscal year, even though the Mayor is using it to cover next year's expenses. As a result, the spending figure for next year is depressed.
When that accounting maneuver is corrected for purposes of comparison, the city's spending is expected to grow by 3 to 4 percent in the next fiscal year, which is not a sharp rise but is more than the one Mr. Giuliani emphasized.
The projected growth in spending is still less than the one in the current budget, which showcased large election-year increases approved by Mr. Giuliani and the City Council. The current, or 1998, budget, has an 8.8 percent increase in spending from city revenues, not including debt payments, according to figures provided by the Mayor's office.
The budget for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, includes a rise of 3.3 percent.
In another area, the Giuliani administration's projections for future budget gaps may underestimate their size, because they do not include the cost of wage increases that would be counted in new labor agreements with the municipal unions.
Sketching his plans for the surplus, Mr. Giuliani said he wanted to reserve 73 percent for reducing projected shortfalls in the next two years; 19 percent for new spending, mostly for educational and anti-drug programs, and 8 percent to make up for revenues lost to new tax cuts.
The Mayor had at least two other options.
He could have proposed spending the surplus on reducing the city's large long-term debt, which some independent budget experts said would be a judicious move. He also could have taken a path that the experts called riskier: funneling all the money to new programs. That would saddle the city with financing those programs annually, which would have increased the future shortfalls.
The experts did praise Mr. Giuliani for reserving most of the money for deficit reduction and not proposing many new programs.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Mixed Signals on Economy

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The rate of business activity in the New York metropolitan region slowed suddenly and sharply in January after a strong performance in 1997, a national business group said yesterday.
But the report, from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which surveys its members each month about corporate spending on goods and services, said the drop may turn out to be a fluke because the outlook for future activity took a sharp jump upward. 
 The report said the index of current business conditions fell to 50.4 percent in January, its lowest level in nearly two years and down from 62.1 percent in December. A reading of more than 50 percent indicates an expanding economy; below that suggests a contraction. The index tracks what purchasing managers said their companies spend on goods and services and their spending plans.
But when the purchasing managers were asked about their companies' outlook for business activity, all the indicators pointed toward an expansion. The association said the index of future activity was 78.9 percent, its highest level since January 1994, when the region was just climbing out of a deep recession. The organization had no explanation for the conflicting data, though one of the purchasing managers in the survey likened the January results to simply an "air pocket" of turbulence for the economy. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: W. Wood Prince, 83, of Chicago; Businessman Adopted by Cousin

 BODY:
William Wood Prince, a prominent Chicago businessman and philanthropist, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Chicago. He was 83.
Mr. Wood Prince, who was born in St. Louis as William Henry Wood, was a distant cousin of Frederick H. Prince, whose Prince Trust controlled the Union Stockyards and Transit Company and Armour & Company, among others. With no heir to his fortune, Frederick Prince legally adopted his cousin, who then took the Prince name. 
 After graduation from Groton and Princeton University, Mr. Wood Prince began his career as a clerk at the First National Bank of Chicago and worked his way up to bank officer in 1942. It was while serving as a captain in the Army in World War II that he was adopted. Upon his return to Chicago, he became a trustee of the Central Manufacturing District, which included the Union Stockyards, then the largest livestock market in the world.
At the stockyards, Mr. Wood Prince adapted new technology such as electronic weighing devices and air-conditioning in the huge International Amphitheater.
Mr. Wood Prince became president, chief executive and chairman of Armour & Company, the meatpacking and processing company that is now a part of Conagra Inc. He oversaw the replacement of hand ledgers with personal computers and doubled the research budget.
He left Armour in 1969 to oversee F. H. Prince & Company, a private holding company for his family's vast corporate and real estate interests. He was also a member of several corporate boards, including the First National Bank of Chicago, Commonwealth Edison and W. R. Grace & Company.
Mr. Wood Prince was a former world champion in squash and frequent golfer. He also loved art and was responsible for persuading his close friend Marc Chagall to create the Chagall mosaic, a landmark in a plaza outside the First National Bank of Chicago. He was also a trustee of the Art Institute of Chicago.
In addition to his keen business sense, Mr. Wood Prince was equally well known for his philanthropic activities. As a trustee of the Prince Charitable Trusts, he donated widely to many cultural, educational and environmental organizations.
Mr. Wood Prince was involved in several projects that sought to advance innovative technologies. He tried to develop technology that would allow new food products to be produced from a plant grown using sea water, and he initiated a cattle breeding project in the Bahamas in the hopes of introducing European cattle into the United States. In 1995 he co-founded Sky Station International, which hopes to use a stationary suborbital platform to handle broad-band wireless communication.
He received numerous awards, including the Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur, in recognition of his contributions to the French economy.
Mr. Wood Prince is survived by his wife, Eleanor; three sons, William and Alex, of Chicago, and Alain, of Lake Forest, Ill.; six grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 7, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Jan. 30 about William Wood Prince, a prominent Chicago businessman and philanthropist, referred imprecisely to the way in which he became heir to Frederick H. Prince, a distant cousin who legally adopted him. Frederick Prince indeed had offspring, but one son, Frederick H. Prince, was not interested in the family business and the other, Norman Prince, died in World War I. A reader's letter postmarked Feb. 25 pointed out the error.

HEADLINE: 4.3% Growth In 4th Quarter While Inflation Stayed Tame

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Economic growth accelerated in the fourth quarter of 1997 while inflation remained subdued, the Government said yesterday, capping a year full of statistical superlatives.
"All told, the economy is in the best shape it has seen since the early 1960's," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/ McGraw Hill. 
 Mr. Wyss and other analysts expect this year to be a good but not great one for the economy. Inflation will likely remain low, but Asia's financial turmoil is widely expected to be felt in this country, dragging down corporate profitability and economic growth.
From October through December, the nation's gross domestic product -- all goods and services produced in the United States -- expanded at a 4.3 percent annual rate, adjusted for inflation, the Commerce Department reported, up from the 3.1 percent rate recorded in the third quarter.
For the year, the economy grew by 3.8 percent, the fastest pace since 1988, when it expanded by an identical amount.
Inflation, meanwhile, remained in check, despite tight labor market conditions that many economists have predicted will put considerable upward pressure on prices. At 4.7 percent, the unemployment rate is at its lowest level since 1973.
In the fourth quarter, the Government said a price measure linked to gross domestic product rose by 1.5 percent, only marginally higher than the 1.4 percent rate recorded in the July-September quarter. For all of 1997, this inflation measure, the price deflator, rose by just 2 percent, the smallest increase in more than 30 years.
Analysts inside and out of Government had been expecting good news, but the report exceeded expectations.
"We have had an extremely strong performance," said Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "We have an expansion that is still going strong and one where there is no end in sight. But will this year match 1997's performance? My guess is not."
Indeed, expectation of a coming slowdown is so widespread that participants in financial markets largely shrugged off the stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter growth figures.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.52 points yesterday, after three days of strong advances. But in the bond market, highly attuned to the threat that strong growth breeds higher inflation, prices rose and interest rates moved lower.
Expectations that the economy will cool a bit in coming months were reinforced on Thursday when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told members of the Senate Budget Committee that the economic drag attendant to Asia's financial crisis would probably not be felt in this country until spring.
With the economy firing on so many cylinders currently, an Asian-induced slowing "would probably be helpful at this juncture," Mr. Greenspan added.
"The economy has enough momentum to offset many of the negatives that will be coming from Asia," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "There are a lot of positives that will continue to lift growth in the first half of the year, including low mortgage interest rates and continued low inflation. That means we are likely to continue to have good consumer spending activity and a healthy housing market."
For the year, most analysts are expecting growth of around 2.5 percent, a slowing that Federal Reserve policy makers would welcome.
Still, in the fourth quarter, slowing export growth and a surge in imports -- two important byproducts of the Asian crisis -- were not in evidence,
In fact, to the surprise of many analysts, exports rose strongly and import growth fell sharply during the final three months of the year.
"The sharp slowdown in imports is a puzzle," Mr. Wyss said. "We may have gotten a break because of the drop in oil prices and warm weather."
The rise in exports, which increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 11.3 percent, was also a bit quirky, Mr. Wyss said, because much of the increase was a result of a surge in aircraft shipments to foreign purchasers by the Boeing Company.
For the year, export sales jumped by 12.5 percent despite a strong dollar, the biggest gain in nine years. But imports rose 13.9 percent, the biggest increase in 13 years.
With the dollar remaining strong and demand in Asian markets likely to deteriorate, if not crumble, analysts expect a sharp increase in the trade deficit this year.
"It isn't showing up in the data yet, and won't for a few months," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University. "But talk to people who are running ships out of the ports of Los Angeles or San Francisco. They will tell you that loads coming into the country are almost three times bigger than the ones going out."
Mr. Ratajczak projects that the trade deficit will deteriorate by about $30 billion this year. A jump in lower-priced imports will likely help to lower inflation even further, he said. But he is forecasting that it will also contribute to a slowing in the overall growth rate, to 2.7 percent for the year.
Aside from a big increase in exports, technology-driven business investment and healthy consumer spending were the linchpins of the economy's performance last year.
Investment in equipment from computers to turbines soared by more than 12 percent in 1997, despite a 3.6 percent decline in the fourth quarter. It was the biggest annual increase since 1984. Analysts expect further gains this year.
Consumer spending, which accounts for roughly two-thirds of all economic activity, rose 3.3 percent last year, the biggest increase since 1994.
"Conditions for consumers are excellent right now," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan & Company. Coupled with wage gains, the steady decline in inflation has produced "faster real wage growth than at any time in a quarter century," Mr. O'Sullivan said.
