HEADLINE: Austin Rides a Winner: Technology

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 30

 BODY:
When cotton and cattle were king in Texas, Austin was never really part of the action. And when oil was the economy's linchpin, the deals were done in Houston and Dallas while this city basically remained, and proudly so, a laid-back college town on the edge of the pretty Hill Country.
But with high technology having officially passed energy as the state's biggest employer, Texas's capital city and its suburbs, home to more than 900 software companies and the largest concentration of microchip plants outside Silicon Valley, have been transformed in recent years. The region is growing faster than any other metropolitan area in the nation outside Las Vegas, and the city itself recently passed Seattle to become the 22d largest in the nation, with a population of 540,000. By the end of the year, census figures show, Austin should pass Boston and Washington in population. 
 And if the archetypal big-rich Texan of a generation ago was an oilman in his Cadillac, today it is arguably one of the "Dellionaires," the 20- and 30-something employees of the Dell Computer Corporation who got in on the ground floor of the concern, in the Austin suburb of Round Rock. The company's 32-year-old chairman, Michael Dell, who recently built what people call a "techno-palace" home in the hills west of Austin that some have compared to that of Microsoft's Bill Gates on Lake Washington in Seattle, is now the wealthiest Texan. With holdings valued at more than $4 billion, Mr. Dell is officially richer than Ross Perot.
Texas's latest boom is certainly not confined to Austin. Houston is the home town of the computer giant Compaq, which announced this week that it planned to buy the Digital Equipment Corporation for $9.6 billion in the largest acquisition ever in the computer industry. But nowhere in Texas is high technology fueling economic expansion more intensely than in the Austin area.
Here, though, in marked contrast to Texas's other big cities, there is decided ambivalence about the growth. Evidence of the boom times is almost everywhere, from the stalled traffic on Interstate 35 to the malls and office buildings sprouting north of town to the new houses that have given a Southern California feel to the western hills.
In elections last spring, a "pro-green" slate of candidates won the Mayor's office and all races for City Council seats, with an advertising campaign featuring banners that read: "Austin or L.A? Our City. Our Choice."
"Ten years ago, Austin made fun of Houston," Mayor Kirk Watson said, "and when people came here, one of the things they loved was, you could get anywhere you want" without hassles.
"Now we worry about the Houstonization of our traffic," said Mr. Watson, who served as chairman of the state air quality board under former Gov. Ann W. Richards.
Still, the city keeps growing, and for now at least, its overall quality of life -- the climate, the greenery, its growing reputation as "the live music capital of the world," as the city officially calls itself, because of all the night spots offering entertainment -- remains its great allure. Paradoxically, the qualities many Austinites are clamoring to preserve are precisely what are fueling the area's boom.
"What drove cities' growth in the industrial era was access to rivers and water and railroad lines and so forth," said Robert Barnstone, a real estate developer and former City Council member. "That was what a city needed to muscle its way to growth. But in the technological age, what matters is what's in people's brains, and a lot of the brightest people come here because they want the life style. Austin doesn't have a great river or a harbor or even a decent airport, but it has a great life style. And that is a commodity of the information age."
 
Interstate Traffic Turns Back Time
Austin actually is getting a big new airport, scheduled to open in the spring of 1999. Traffic is a more vexing problem, especially on Interstate 35, the main highway through town, which also happens to be the main highway carrying goods between the United States and Mexico in an era of expanding trade.
Traffic has more than doubled in the past decade over the Austin-to-San Antonio stretch of I-35, making that section the highway's most congested and accident-prone part from Mexico to Canada. Traffic on that corridor is slated to increase another 75 percent by 2010, and one state study concluded that if nothing is done, the typical travel time from San Antonio to Dallas would eventually take longer than it did 30 years ago, before there was an Interstate.
State highway planners are studying the feasibility of building a highway loop to bypass I-35 in the Austin area, and a regional coalition is advocating a passenger rail system that would ease commuter tie-ups by linking communities from well north of Austin to San Antonio.
Many things besides computer companies are responsible for Austin's boom, including the fact that the city has become a mini-Hollywood of sorts. In 1996, 34 films, 6 television movies and 25 television shows were produced in Texas, many of them in Austin and the surrounding Hill Country, according to the state film commission. The capital city is the setting for MTV's "Slacker" comedy hit series "Austin Stories."
Hollywood stars like Sandra Bullock and Madeleine Stowe have bought residential property in the area, and some filmmakers have managed to bypass Hollywood and make Austin their base of operations. These include Robert Rodriguez ("El Mariachi" and "Desperado") and Richard Linklater ("Slacker," "Dazed and Confused" and "SubUrbia."
"The very same qualities that allow us to brag that this is the live music capital of the world," said Mayor Watson, "are the qualities that have made us a focal point of the knowledge economy of the 21st century. It's that same kind of free-spirit, entrepreneurial, whatever-it-takes attitude, and a kind of live-and-let-live feeling as well. Whatever you're big enough to do, do it."
In truth, Austin's environmental and business communities have been at odds with each other many times in past years over what shape the city should take. But if the battle has been between pro-growth and no-growth forces, no one questions the outcome: growth won.
These days, there are certainly indications of growing cooperation. One is the election of Mr. Watson, who managed to run with the support of both environmentalists and many business groups, and who promised to act as a bridge between the two.
 
City's Environment As Economic Asset
And just this month, the Chamber of Commerce released a study of the region's economy that described a healthy environment as one of the area's prime economic assets, one whose preservation should be a paramount concern.
"I think that's the first time they've seen such clear proof that protecting the environment is in their economic self-interest," said Brigid Shea, executive director of the Save Our Springs Alliance, a seven-year-old environmental group formed out of an effort to protect Barton Springs, the magnificent 1,000-foot-long clear natural pool near downtown that is often described as the emotional soul of Austin.
Ms. Shea, a former Councilwoman, said she was optimistic that Austin's special character could be maintained in the face of rampant growth.
"What's happening right now is, we're trying to see if we can't marshal the intellectual resources of the high-tech community," she said, "the economic self-interest of the business community and the preservation instincts and the passion of the environmental community to grow smarter, to grow so that we don't foul our nest. I really think it can be done."
That sentiment is echoed by Daryl Slusher, a former political columnist and city-hall reporter for The Austin Chronicle, an alternative weekly newspaper, who last year ran for a City Council seat and won.
"There's been an impulse on the part of a lot of people over the years, including myself, a sort of grumpiness about all the new folks moving in, all the changes," Mr. Slusher said. "But I've come to accept that we're going to be a big city, and now I just want it to be the best, greatest city possible."
But many longtime Austinites say such optimism is delusional. Bud Shrake, the novelist and sportswriter, said the city had been all but ruined by growth, and compared the city's civic boosters to frogs stuck in a pot of water who simply do not notice as the temperature slowly heats toward the boiling point.
"Austin used to be a paradise," Mr. Shrake said. "But I've been saying for 30 years that every year it's gotten a little worse. People don't notice it, but we're just about dead here. We're becoming L.A."
Still others say that while growth has changed the city, it remains special.
"I think it stinks, but I'm still here," said Ray Benson, leader of the popular Western swing band Asleep at the Wheel. "It's still the best place in the world to live."
To be sure, it is not just recently that people in Austin have been wringing their hands over the changing city.
Nearly a decade ago, in an article about efforts to ward off development near Barton Springs, the executive editor of Texas Monthly magazine, Paul Burka, wrote: "Almost everyone in Austin remembers when it used to be a better place to live. The pangs of loss are not, as in Dallas and Houston, for the days when the sky was full of construction cranes and everybody had a deal working, but for things that are irretrievably gone: the view west from Mount Bonnell of pristine hills, now carved into subdivisions; the low-water crossings of a country lane, now turned into an outer loop; the prominence of the Capitol, now obscured by nondescript office buildings; the steep hill on the edge of town, now bulldozed into a stubby mesa topped by a graceless shopping mall."
The area is still beautiful in many ways, and that remains a huge drawing card, for corporate executives thinking about relocating their companies as well as people looking for a good place to live.
"You put people in helicopters and go out west over the water, the green and the lakes, and it's just a stunning sight," said Pike Powers, a local lawyer who has served in the State Legislature and as chief of staff to former Gov. Mark White.
Mr. Powers was instrumental in many of Austin's biggest economic-development projects, including its successful bid to become the home of two major computer industry consortiums, the Microelectronic and Computer Technology Corporation, known as MCC, and the Semiconductor Manufacturing and Technology Institute, or Sematech.
 
Without Aspiration, It Is Happening
A Dell computer advertisement boasts of its Austin base: "Could it be that Austin's laid-back life style and Hill Country vistas help us to see the world more clearly? Certainly our people think so."
The area keeps growing, too. The five-county Austin region's population is now about 1,050,000, more than double what it was 20 years ago.
Asked whether growth had been properly managed, Mayor Watson paused and offered a diplomatic answer: "It has not been managed so poorly that we are now in a position where we can't get a handle on the next 10, 15, 20 years. But it we don't do it right, we're in big trouble."
In any event, like it or not, this is no quiet college town.
"Austin is being dragged into being a big city, in some cases kicking and screaming," said Mr. Barnstone, the developer and former Councilman. "It does not have an image of itself as a great metropolis, or even the aspiration of a great metropolis. And yet it's happening, and you can see it all around."

Loop 1, shown here, parallels Interstate 35, the main highway linking the United States and Mexico. (Photographs by Matthew Sturtevant for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1398 words

HEADLINE: Inflation Whimpers. What's Next for Fed?;
New Stresses at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
When the Soviet Union collapsed, the makers of American foreign policy lost their lodestar. Similarly, the prospect of Federal budget surpluses after decades of deficits has transformed the debate over taxes and spending.
Now, Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve seem to have reached a turning point of their own for monetary policy. 
 Having been driven since the late 1970's by a single-minded determination to squeeze inflation out of the economy, the central bank is now confronting the possibility that it has won -- at least for now -- its battle for price stability.
But if the Fed and Mr. Greenspan, its chairman, no longer have to worry about bringing inflation down sharply, they face a formidable challenge in keeping it down and in keeping the economy on track amid powerful crosscurrents.
The Government's report today that the economy grew at a real 4.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter was just the latest evidence that the domestic expansion continues to be so buoyant that it threatens to reignite big wage increases. Yet the Asian financial crisis seems certain to dampen American exports and bring a flood of cheaper imports, forcing many companies to hold down prices. That global pressure would tend to restrain inflation and even -- in the view of at least some analysts -- put the world in danger of deflation.
"For most of the past 20 years, the challenges confronting monetary policy makers centered on addressing the question of how inflation could be brought down with as little economic disruption as possible," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech in Chicago this month. "Given the progress that has been made in reducing inflation, and the very solid economic performance that this low-inflation environment has helped to promote, a new set of issues is now emerging on the policy agenda."
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan has had to shift his sights from a single big target -- completing the process begun under his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker, of bringing inflation from double digits down to almost nothing -- to a welter of conflicting and often confusing pressures that could threaten a remarkable period of prosperity and stability.
"The sense in which it is harder," said Alan S. Blinder, a former Fed vice chairman who is a professor at Princeton University, "is that you now have a much more subtle task of fine-tuning, which Alan Greenspan is very good at."
Perhaps the clearest sign of how deep the uncertainties run even in Mr. Greenspan's mind came in a single sentence during his testimony to the Senate Budget Committee on Thursday. Stressing the need to "be vigilant to the re-emergence of destabilizing influences" on an economy he characterized as exceptionally healthy, Mr. Greenspan cited a very broad spectrum of possibilities. From one side, he fretted about higher inflation; from the other, he was clearly just as worried about the risk of pressing "the disinflation process too far, too fast."
Despite heady rates of growth -- the 4.3 percent fourth-quarter growth rate reported by the Government today was nearly twice what the Fed believes is sustainable without ultimately generating significantly higher inflation -- there is still almost no sign of widespread price increases.
The measure of inflation contained within the report on the gross domestic product today found that prices rose just 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter, leaving the figure for all of 1997 at 2 percent, the lowest since 1965. The more widely quoted Consumer Price Index, excluding volatile food and energy prices, registered a rise of just 2.2 percent last year, also the smallest increase in 32 years.
There is considerable debate among economists and even within the Fed about how much credit the central bank deserves for reducing the inflation rate. There is also widespread disagreement about whether prices are being held down only by a confluence of temporary factors such as intense competition in the computer industry, the cap on health care costs from the rise of managed care and the decline of import prices because of the strong dollar.
But now the talk has turned from whether the Fed should take advantage of any economic downturn to push the inflation rate lower -- so-called opportunistic disinflation -- to whether inflation has already been essentially eradicated.
A few economists are even worried about a deflation -- the broad decline in the prices of goods, services and assets -- that could make it extraordinarily difficult for some otherwise healthy businesses to meet their obligations and for many borrowers to pay their debts.
"We're now getting to a point where a relevant question becomes whether the Fed wants inflation to go higher or lower," Mr. Blinder said. "Relatively few people right now would say we want inflation higher, but if the C.P.I. were to drop another notch, to 1 percent, the question would become a very live one."
Given the imprecision of inflation gauges, the Fed must be very careful about any move to raise or lower interest rates, economists said.
"It is quite possible that the actual inflation rate is near zero or even below zero because inflation estimates are not foolproof," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation. "If they were to respond to the rising wage pressures by raising rates, there's a possibility the Fed could push the economy into deflation if it were already at zero inflation."
As a result, Mr. Sohn said, Mr. Greenspan is faced with a delicate balancing act.
"To some extent it's easier to slaughter inflation, as chairman Volcker did in the 1980's," he said. "You clearly know the direction you're going, and you have lots of room to maneuver if you make a mistake. That is no longer the case."
In many ways, the case for concern about resurgent inflation is clear cut. Unemployment, at 4.7 percent, is near a 25-year low. As employers struggle to find enough workers to help them meet strong demand, wage gains are starting to edge up, often the first step toward rising prices.
But consumer prices have hardly budged, largely because companies have been able to offset rising costs through productivity gains from heavy investments in new equipment and technology. Intense competition in many industries has also restrained price increases.
Although consumer confidence has fallen somewhat in the last month, it remains at historically high levels, suggesting that people remain willing to spend.
The Fed has responded by keeping the short-term interest rates it controls steady for nearly a year. Mr. Greenspan said on Thursday that in keeping the Federal funds rate steady at 5.5 percent even as inflation has declined, the Fed has consciously been allowing the inflation-adjusted, or real, rate to drift up.
But he acknowledged that strategy had had no significant restrictive impact on the economy because long-term interest rates have been falling.
Indeed, lower long-term rates may well be stimulating economic activity. They make it cheaper for people to buy homes and cars and provide an incentive to refinance existing mortgages, which allows homeowners to lower their monthly payments or take out cash to spend elsewhere. As a result, key interest-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing have remained robust.
Long-term rates have been falling in part because of declining inflationary expectations and in part because investors around the world have plowed money into United States Treasury securities as a haven during the Asian crisis.
The Fed and most private economists are now counting on the Asia crisis to slow the economy sufficiently to avoid a continuing buildup in inflationary pressures.
Many economists think the Asian crisis will slow the economy substantially this year, probably to around a 2.5 percent annual growth rate. "Such a moderation would appear helpful at this juncture," Mr. Greenspan said.
But in testimony today before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan raised a more worrisome specter, suggesting that growth might slow too much if the Asia financial crisis spreads.
There is "a small but not negligible probability," he said, "that the upset in East Asia could have unexpectedly negative effects on Japan, Latin America and Eastern and Central Europe that in turn could have repercussions elsewhere, including the United States."

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Economic Ups and Downs"
There are signs that the American economy is growing too fast, posing a threat of inflation. But the Asian financial crisis is acting as a brake on growth and even raising fears of deflation. This has left Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, with a quandary: Which way should interest rates go?
 
"THE DOLLAR"
A strengthening dollar will help pull in cheaper imports and hold down prices. Chart shows trade weighted dollar for the years 1995 through 1997.
 
"OIL PRICES"
Weakening demand in Asia is bringing down prices at American pumps. Chart shows oil prices (in dollars) from October 1997 through January 1998.
 
"PRODUCER PRICES"

HEADLINE: Ex-Chief Sues Federated: $16 Million Not Enough

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
When he retired as chairman and chief executive of the parent company of Macy's and Bloomingdale's last May, Allen I. Questrom received a $16 million thank-you from the board for a job well done. But like a disappointed paramour who expected diamonds and got chocolates instead, Mr. Questrom has sniffed at the payment and taken his affront to court.
In a lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Questrom said that his former employer, Federated Department Stores, owed him $47 million more in bonus pay for taking the retailer from bankruptcy to profitability in his seven-year stint. 
 Mr. Questrom argues that an investment bank hired by Federated undervalued the company in 1995, thereby shortchanging him millions of dollars that he had been promised for leaving his job as chief executive of Neiman Marcus to join the ailing retail chain.
The $16 million he did receive in May came on top of roughly $2 million he made in 1996 in straight pay. The previous year, Mr. Questrom received $13.2 million, which included an $11 million bonus, making him the highest-paid retailing executive at the time.
According to the lawsuit, when Mr. Questrom renegotiated his contract in 1995, he was promised that when he left Federated he would receive an incentive payment based on a valuation prepared by J. P. Morgan aimed at capturing how well the company was doing under his management. Morgan valued the company at $4 billion. The Seneca Financial Group, hired by Mr. Questrom to provide a second opinion, came up with $6 billion. And his suit contends that other investment banks came up with valuations similar to Seneca's.
At first blush, both valuations seem generous, given that the company's market capitalization was only about $2.4 billion in early 1995. But the complaint argues that the valuation was meant to be forward-looking and thus should have discounted some lingering costs from the acquisition of Macy's, among other things.
"All C.E.O.'s think their stock is underpriced when it suits them," said Graef Crystal, the San Diego-based compensation expert. "But economic theory says the market is the market."
A Morgan spokesman refused to comment yesterday, as did Mr. Questrom.
In the 1990's, Federated was practically synonymous with Mr. Questrom. He was thought by some to have waited a few months to file his suit to give his successor, James M. Zimmerman, time to settle in.
Still, the delay did little to lessen the lawsuit's sting. In a statement yesterday, the company said: "It was disappointing Mr. Questrom chose to take this action. The company contends his compensation, including $16 million in value-added incentives as determined by a third-party investment banking firm, was paid in accordance with his contract with the company. Federated will defend its position vigorously in court."

HEADLINE: Lionel Wilson, 82, a Mayor Of Oakland for Three Terms

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Lionel Wilson, who presided over a racial, cultural, economic and political revolution during three terms as the first black mayor of Oakland, Calif., then suffered shattering defeat when he sought another four-year term in 1990, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Oakland. He was 82.
His family said the cause was cancer. 
 When he stepped down as a judge in Alameda County Superior Court in 1977 to run for the part-time office of mayor, Oakland seemed to be a city ready for the revolution the 62-year-old Mr. Wilson had spent a lifetime preparing himself to lead.
As it had been even when his parents took him to Oakland from his native New Orleans when he was 3, the dingy city of some 350,000 across the bay from the gleaming spires of San Francisco was ruled by a tight-knit clique of moderate white Republicans and their downtown business allies.
But after a decade of white flight, declining population and urban decay, black leaders, emboldened by gun-toting militants in the radical Black Panther Party, had begun clamoring for change.
Four years earlier, the Black Panther leader Bobby Seale had shown such surprising strength in finishing second in the 1973 mayor's race that the three-term incumbent, John Reading, decided not to seek a fourth term in 1977, throwing his support to the Oakland school board president, Dave Tucker.
With the almost unanimous support of labor, the Black Panthers, other minorities, liberal Democrats and visiting celebrities, including Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Reggie Jackson and Jane Fonda, Mr. Wilson won a narrow victory in a run-off election.
For Mr. Wilson, who had become the first black judge in Alameda County when he was named to a municipal court in 1960, becoming Oakland's first black mayor was not the only noteworthy distinction of his election. As he liked to recall it, he was also the first person to win a mayor's election without the endorsement of The Oakland Tribune.
But then Mr. Wilson had been bucking trends all his life. At 5-foot-5 and 130 pounds, for example, he was small for competitive sports, but he had such drive, determination and natural ability that he became a fine basketball player and so accomplished at baseball that he played high-level semiprofessional ball before turning to a law career.
After graduating with honors from a predominantly white vocational high school, Mr. Wilson worked his way through the University of California at Berkeley as an economics major, then spent four years with the Army in Europe in World War II before earning a degree at the Hastings School of Law in San Francisco in 1949.
With only a handful of other black lawyers in Oakland, Mr. Wilson specialized in civil rights cases, provided free legal services to the poor and won a reputation for compassion and even-handedness that continued during his years as a judge.
If the city's white leadership had been alarmed by Mr. Wilson's election as mayor, he soon put it at ease. A fiscal conservative who made economic development a priority, over the next decade he stimulated a $1 billion downtown building boom that changed the face of Oakland's skyline even as he was changing the complexion of the city government, filling top posts with black, Hispanic and Asian officials, many of them women.
In a weak-mayor system, where the mayor has only one of nine City Council votes, Mr. Wilson was a master mediator who proved quietly persuasive in one-on-one meetings and was able to put together a working majority that enhanced his power.
Mr. Wilson became something of a folk hero to Oakland's poor black population, but as an epidemic of drugs and violence plagued Oakland's poor neighborhoods, his emphasis on downtown economic development became a political liability and he was criticized for neglecting impoverished neighborhoods.
By the time he ran for re-election in 1990, Mr. Wilson, whose third term had been extended 18 months by a charter change in the election cycle, was seen as an increasingly remote figure.
When he gave his reluctant endorsement to an abortive $500 million plan to lure the National Football League Raiders back to Oakland from Los Angeles, the issue became a symbol of his support of business. Mr. Wilson argued in vain that bolstering neighborhoods would be the next item on his agenda.
He finished third in the 1990 election, polling only 17 percent of the vote.
Mr. Wilson is survived by his second wife, Dorothy, three sons from his first marriage, Lionel and Steven, of Oakland, and Robin, of Sacramento; four brothers, Harold, Kermit and Warren, of Oakland, and Julius, of Castro Valley, Calif.; a sister, Marie Anderson of San Leandro, Calif., and several grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Loses Ground in January for First Time Since 1990

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
As January goes, so goes the year.
By that admittedly superstitious Wall Street dictum, the stock market is not in for an auspicious 1998. 
 After seven years of largely blissful beginnings, the Dow Jones industrial average recorded its first January loss, one that some market prognosticators believe may augur poorly for investors.
Yesterday, the Dow fell 66.52 points, to 7,906.50, closing just slightly below the level it began the year. The last time the Dow lost ground in January was 1990, a year when the blue-chip average slid 4.3 percent.
While the monthly loss was minuscule, less than two one-hundredths of a percentage point, it does represent a negative start to a year when many investors are already worried that economic turmoil in Asia could upset what has been one of the greatest bull markets in history.
"This was not a good month," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. "It was a bad month for Bill Clinton; it was a bad month for Asia, and it was a bad month for the stock market."
Of course, many dismiss what some traders call the "January effect" as nonsense. But in the last quarter-century, the blue-chip average has fallen seven times in January. On six of those occasions, the Dow ended the year with a loss.
If it's any consolation, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- which is considered a much broader barometer of stock prices -- ended the month with a gain of 1 percent.
Regardless what barometer is used, most Wall Street strategists agree the stock market has weathered a trying and volatile month.
In terms of trading activity, the month just ended was the second busiest in history, as more than 12.5 billion shares traded hands. In October -- when the Dow plummeted 554 points one day and gained 337 points the next -- more than 14 billion shares were traded.
It has been that kind of period for the market. Until this week, stock prices had been moving sharply lower on fears that the Asian crisis would erode corporate profits. But a batch of solid fourth-quarter earnings reports this week helped lift investor confidence.
"We started off the year with a big decline, and then we had a big rally," said Gail Dudack, chief investment officer at UBS Securities. "We were just pretty much flat in January. And that may be indicative of the kind of year we're going to have."
Ms. Dudack and many other strategists have reduced expectations for 1998, projecting corporate profits may grow by 5 to 8 percent in 1998 versus 11 percent in 1997.
Such a slowdown can already be glimpsed in fourth-quarter profits. With about 64 percent of the companies that make up the S.& P 500 reporting, profits are up about 10 percent, according to First Call Inc., which tracks corporate earnings. In addition, more companies are warning that first-quarter profits could be hurt.
"The question is: does the fourth quarter represent a trend downward and does that mean we'll suffer in the first quarter?" said Charles Hill, First Call's director of research. "We don't know."
Still, some point out that stock prices have held steady despite a flurry of troubling news from a White House scandal to economic turmoil in South Korea and Japan.
"The market's failing to proceed, but it's not breaking down," said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "A lot of investors are just switching back and forth trying to find the next horse to ride."
Besides the January effect, there are other signs of a downturn, however unscientific they may be. The Denver Broncos' Super Bowl victory, for example, is viewed with dismay by some investors because the team is in the American Conference of the National Football League, and "American Conference victories almost invariably portend a difficult year for the U.S. equity market," Mr. Wien said.
Yale Hirsch, the publisher of the Stock Trader's Almanac, however, says it's more important to heed the message of the S.& P. 500's January performance, which has an 89 percent accuracy rate for how the year will go.
"I watch the S.& P. 500," he said. "So I can't change horses midstream."
Besides, when indicators are just slightly off -- or contradictory -- they may have less meaning.
After all, Mr. Hirsch said, "I don't think kicking a field goal in the last minute is going to send our economy into a tailspin."

HEADLINE: As Newark Bounces Back, So Does Mayor

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 28

 BODY:
This time a year ago the political fortunes of Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, were bleak.
His police director had just been convicted of stealing money. His chief of staff was on trial on bribery and corruption charges, and was subsequently convicted. Elected and appointed officials in the city were the objects of streams of subpoenas for their financial records, and the United States Attorney in Newark, Faith S. Hochberg, was talking openly of her suspicions of corruption in the "highest levels of city government." 
 What is more, the city was coming up on the 30th anniversary of the 1967 riots, whose legacy of hopelessness was obvious in the vacant lots and boarded-up buildings dotting the city.
What a difference a year makes.
As Mr. James prepares for an expected announcement next month that he will seek a fourth term, Newark is suddenly seen as a reviving city. Exhibit A is the Performing Arts Center downtown, which opened last fall to rave reviews. And although the city continues its struggle to rebuild its economy and stem the flight of its residents to the suburbs, the lavish praise for the arts center has, at least for now, taken the spotlight off those problems.
The man who has been Mayor for 12 years, and for 16 years before that a major figure in the political ascendancy of blacks in the city, seems to be benefiting from this new positive feeling.
If Mr. James seemed subdued, even cloistered, amid the troubles of a year ago, the 61-year-old veteran politician is clearly his old, ebullient self today, one part cheerleader, one part real estate salesman and one part evangelist bending any ear he can to tell the good news of Newark.
And while many mayors seeking re-election favor appearances at ribbon cuttings, Mr. James has been a constant at the dynamiting of some of the city's long-vacant, high-rise public housing behemoths. It is typical of his ability to make a virtue out of necessity that he uses the occasions to tout city plans for a new wave of low- to moderate-income town house developments.
"I've changed Newark from a city you couldn't give away to a city that everybody wants," Mr. James said in a recent interview, leaving no doubt about who should get credit. "I think the voters will recognize the good work that I have done."
So far, two people have announced that they are running against Mr. James -- Ronald Rice, a veteran West Ward Councilman and State Senator, and Mildred Crump, a Councilwoman at large. Both seem somewhat torn between demanding that the Mayor share the credit with them for the good news about the city and highlighting Newark's myriad troubles, from its many vacant lots to its unemployment rate -- three times the state rate -- to its continued population declines.
Mr. Rice suggests that Newark's story is "a tale of two cities" in which the good news of downtown development exists alongside still depressed conditions in some neighborhoods. And he is quick to point out that the same analogy was used by Mr. James 12 years ago when, as an outspoken Councilman, he ran against and defeated Kenneth Gibson, the city's first black Mayor, who was seeking a fifth term.
"I supported him back then, but the old Sharpe James is gone," he said. "Ron Rice is more like the old Sharpe James."
The opening of the Performing Arts Center heads Mr. James's -- and everyone else's -- litany of signs of Newark's renaissance. He championed the project 10 years ago, when it seemed almost laughable to suggest that the city should be the site of the state's premiere cultural center. On opening night, there he sat, next to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, drawing applause and appreciation from a capacity crowd.
Nor is the arts center the only sign of Newark's revival. There is a planned Science Park with research and high technology laboratories, a new science high school, and housing centered around Essex County Community College, Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
There is also a proposed industrial park on the city's southern end, the quiet success of a middle-income town house development in the Central Ward and the popularity and profitability of the new movie theater complex, which Mr. James promised he would bring to the city when he first ran 12 years ago. That was the year the city's last two downtown movie houses went dark.
"Time on task is the key," said Saul Fenster, the president of the New Jersey Institute of Technology. "What happens is that you build and build and you reach a critical mass, and one day the perception hits that it is a beautiful town. That's just beginning to happen now for Newark, so I'm very positive about the city."
And as for those whispers of corruption that dogged Mr. James a year ago, few people mention that now. The United States Attorney's office would not comment on any continuing investigations, but privately some familiar with the office's workings, said the inquiries are continuing. Still, the fact that no charges against the Mayor have emerged is viewed by those in the corporate suites and those involved in local affairs as the equivalent of exoneration.
Donald Karp, the chairman and chief executive of the Newark-based Broad National Bank, put it this way, "I believe people feel that there has been an investigation of everything and everybody in the city," he said. "There have been some indictments and convictions but that all seems to be over."
Joseph P. Yeadon, the owner of an accounting firm in the city who is active in civic affairs, said that many blacks in the city saw the rumors as part of an effort to discredit a popular black politician.
"It was apparent that they were trying to get him," Mr. Yeadon said. "But nothing happened, and that has to translate into the view that he is clean."
Still there are those who see Mr. James as vulnerable on this point, among them his opponents who say, nevertheless, that they have no plans to focus their campaigns on the corruption investigations.
"But if he tries to bite me, I'll bite back," said Mrs. Crump.
Mr. Rice said, "If he gets ugly, I will take the gloves off."
While Mr. James says he is taking nothing for granted as he approaches the mayoral campaign, he does exude a certain serenity. In a recent interview, he marshaled copious statistics on the drop in crime in Newark (it fell 25 percent over last year), the number of new jobs (25,000 in 1997) and the number of new or rehabilitated housing units (3,000, in all five wards of the city, over the last four years). In addition, he says, the city has held property tax increases to just 6.4 percent over the last three years.
In a recent interview, he derided his opponents for criticizing his accomplishments as inadequate, "as if they had the cure for cancer and sickle cell anemia".
Such carefully constructed hyperbole has been Mr. James's trademark over the years, said Clement A. Price, a professor of history at Rutgers University.
"He is a cheerleader mayor who has perfected the rhetoric of optimism and boosterism as he has articulated the good news about Newark," Dr. Price said. "Once so many American cities have become poor and black, it has become hard historically to advertise their virtues to some. So his is a defensible strategy, because either a city aggressively articulates its own self image or it will be doomed to be given an image by others."
The Mayor has been careful to maintain support among the city's Hispanic and remaining white ethnic enclaves. He has an alliance with Steve Addabato, the powerful North Ward political leader, and has carefully supported Puerto Ricans like Councilman Luis Quintana, and appointed as his deputy mayor August Amador, who is of Portuguese descent.
Thomas Giblin, the Essex County Democratic chairman, as well as the New Jersey Democratic chairman, said that all the likely candidates are strong, black Democratic Party loyalists with good name recognition in a city where the black vote is crucial.
"And that vote will be pretty well split among them, and whoever can get the Hispanics and white ethnics probably has the edge," he said. "Mildred Crump could give him some problems because she hasn't been in office long enough to develop negatives, and sometimes that can be an advantage. Plus, she is a woman, and our statistics show that there is a 55 percent female vote in Newark."
Mr. James, ever the booster, walked along Elizabeth Avenue the other day, eager to point at the once grand apartment buildings plucked from near oblivion and drug dealers. In the last six years, the buildings have been limping back as developers, some with city tax breaks and some without, have been investing money and returning buildings to the tax rolls.
He rattled off the positives -- the clean, graffiti-free hallways, the security cameras, the pristine laundry rooms and the new day care centers. In one building's lobby, he suddenly stopped and, with mock drama, urged a visitor to stop a minute and look about. After a pause worthy of a canny pitchman, he spoke.
"You notice it is the middle of the day and the halls are empty," he said, a smile beginning to spread over his face. "This building is full of working people who are off at work now. All of this shows that if you do quality rehabilitation, you will attract middle class and working people who will take care of it."

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks a New Waiver Of Federal Food Stamp Limits

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today sought another waiver of Federal welfare rules passed last year that require able-bodied adults to work for food stamps, virtually guaranteeing that tens of thousands of needy New Yorkers will keep their benefits.
A similar waiver that the Pataki administration received a year ago expires at the end of next month. 
 The new eligibility rules for food stamps were enacted last year as part of the overhaul of the Federal welfare program. Those changes limit food stamp benefits to a maximum of three months a year for able-bodied, childless adults under age 50 who are not working at least 20 hours a week. But the law also allows a governor to apply for a waiver of the rule for local economies that do not have sufficient jobs to absorb the welfare recipients.
Mr. Pataki said that he was initially reluctant to seek a waiver because he felt that a combination of enticements and sanctions was necessary to nudge food stamp recipients into taking jobs. But, under pressure from Democratic lawmakers and advocates for the poor, he eventually sought the waiver.
The waiver would exempt food stamp recipients living in 37 localities across the state -- including entire counties, cities and villages, from rural upstate to the Bronx -- where the labor market is considered too weak to absorb welfare recipients. Those areas have an unemployment rate that is at least 20 percent above the national average of 5.6 percent for 1995 and 1996.
The Governor's decision to seek a renewal of the waiver drew praise today from advocates for the poor who have long asserted that there are not enough low-skilled jobs for welfare recipients. They estimate that 95,000 able-bodied adults receive food stamps now and that many of them will lose the benefits if the new waiver is not granted.
They also contend that poor communities would be hurt economically because thousands of "mom and pop" groceries depend heavily on food stamp business.
"We're happy that he is renewing what he did last year," said Mark A. Dunlea, executive director of Hunger Action Network of New York State. "We fought very hard for the original waiver."
But Mr. Pataki's decision did not sit well with some fiscal conservatives, key supporters of his within the Republican Party. Many of them are already disenchanted over the Governor's recent $71.9 billion budget proposal for the coming fiscal year because they say it abandons the fiscal conservatism that marked the first half of his term.
Tom Carroll, the president of Change New York, an anti-tax group that was one of the Governor's earliest supporters, said he grudgingly accepted Mr. Pataki's decision to seek the waiver last year, given that counties apparently needed more time to place recipients into jobs or publicly run workfare assignments.
But, he said, there is no longer any reason to waive the work requirements.
"There is no justification for giving people a second free pass on this," Mr. Carroll said. "These people have an obligation to give something back to society, either in work or community service."

HEADLINE: Black Art Show's Goals: Recognition and Buyers

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
One part black art survey and one part eclectic art bazaar, the National Black Fine Art Show returned to the Puck Building in SoHo yesterday for its second annual show.
The fair bills itself as the first major black art fair in the United States, and last year, its sponsors said, it attracted 10,000 people. This year there are 41 booths representing galleries from the United States, Africa, the Caribbean and Canada. Each booth exhibits from a handful of artists to about 15. 
 Many kinds of art are for sale, from Haitian primitives to sophisticated sculptures to landscapes to photographs to traditional African works. There are the contemporary masters of many mediums, including Faith Ringgold's narrative quilts, Benny Andrews's oil-and-collage figurative works and the African diaspora photographs of Chester Higgins Jr., a photographer for The New York Times. There are also esteemed names from the past, including Horace Pippin, Romare Bearden and Henry Owassa Tanner.
In between are many more artists who are less well known. Indeed, the wide range of art at the show led a critic to say in The New York Times that "the ratio of kitsch to real art is far too high."
But the very range of work appeared to appeal to the variety of tastes among those in attendance yesterday. And the fair has attained a word-of-mouth status as a mandatory event among devotees of black art.
"It's wonderful," said Donita Hood, who described herself as a beginning collector from Baltimore. "I'm enjoying all the stimulus. They have high-end all the way down to $500 pieces. There's quality here. You just have to know what you're looking for."
Ronald Ollie, an avid collector who also attended last year's show, called the fair "very impressive." Mr. Ollie, a resident of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, said the the diversity of the fair was typical of most art fairs and made it attractive.
There are two driving ideas behind the fair, said its organizer, Joscelyn Wainwright of Wainwright/Smith Associates, a producer of cultural events. One is to educate the public about the large amount and diversity of black art and to introduce it to a wider audience. The other is to present a venue in which artists can sell their work.
"We have a whole group of artists -- contemporary and historic -- who are doing work of extremely high quality, not just in Afro-centric imagery but in landscapes and photographs, and not getting recognition for various social and economic reasons," Mr. Wainwright said. "White America, for the most part, when they think of black art they think of Afro-centric images, things they wouldn't necessarily feel comfortable with in their homes and offices. "There is black art, however, that is not even readily identifiable as black."
"People in African-American communities are the least aware of work coming out of their communities," he added.
Mr. Wainwright said there had been an almost "complete absence in major venues" of black artists, although one occasionally sees an artist of the stature of, say, Bearden.
While there have been many museum shows and special exhibitions featuring black artists, Mr. Wainwright said, there have been far fewer opportunities to sell their work.
Last year's fair was profitable, Mr. Wainwright said, but he declined to name figures. He said some major galleries that had taken a "wait-and-see" attitude about the inaugural show were eager to particpate this year after watching the show become a marquee event, attracting celebrities like Oprah Winfrey and Ed Bradley.
The fair is sponsored by Graham Gregory Bozell, a company that works with corporations seeking to market to African-Americans.
Essie Green, owner of the Essie Green Galley in Harlem, said the fair allowed her to show the uninitiated her gallery, in a Sugar Hill town house, and to meet with other art dealers.
"This gives me a chance to see and dialogue and move among other dealers of fine art in a way that I can't do unless I travel around the country," Ms. Green said. "There's no medium for that for the black dealer."
On Thursday night, the fair began with a three-hour preview that attracted 600 art collectors who paid $45 to browse and sip champagne.
"A lot of us didn't expect this to work this well," said an excited Benny Andrews, an artist who said there were six galleries representing his work. "I've met a lot of collectors."
Arlene Case, whose paintings were shown by the Sepia Gallery of Quebec, said: "The time has definitely come. Shows like this are the way black artists will be recognized." She said she sold several pieces to Ms. Winfrey last year.
Constance Brown, an owner of the 22-year-old Wendell Street Gallery in Cambridge, Mass., said the fair was evidence that black artists were moving into the mainstream. "In magazines there are more articles about African-American painters and their importance to the art scene," Ms. Brown said. "When we first started, we had to drag people in to see Bearden and Andrews."
In addition to the exhibition, which continues through Sunday, the Museum of African Art plans to hold a lecture series today on topics that include collecting African art, the importance of framing and negotiating prices. The proceeds from each $20 seminar are to benefit the Boys and Girls Clubs of America.
The show runs until 8 tonight and is open from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. tomorrow. Admission is $10 and children under 16 are free when accompanied by an adult.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward Chiwara's sculpture called "In My Heart," foreground, at the National Black Fine Art Show at the Puck Building in SoHo. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)(pg. B15)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
America's Multiple-Choice Quiz

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ZURICH

 BODY:
The U.S. faces a Hamletesque choice in dealing with Iraq today. It comes down to this: 2-b or not 2-b, that is the question. Does the Clinton Administration have an option 2-b? Everything hinges on that.
Let me explain. The Administration has three basic options in dealing with Iraq: Option 1 is to finish the 1991 gulf war, which stopped short of removing Saddam Hussein. In this option, the U.S. would invade Iraq, occupy Baghdad, unseat Saddam, establish a new Iraqi regime and rid Iraq of all its weapons of mass destruction and the equipment for rebuilding them. This is the most sure-fire way to eliminate the threat posed by Saddam to his neighbors and his own people. Option 1 is also the most costly way. The U.S. would have few allies for such an invasion, although the Iraqi people would probably hail it as a liberation. For now, there is no support in the Administration or Congress for Option 1. 
 Option 3 (we'll save Option 2 for last) is to go to the other extreme. That is, acknowledge that neither the U.S. nor its allies have the stomach for any occupation of Iraq, but also acknowledge that the U.N. weapons monitoring regime in Iraq now has gaping holes in it. With all of the palaces and special sites being unilaterally declared off limits to the U.N. by Saddam, no one can be sure anymore that the U.N. inspectors are preventing Iraq from building weapons of mass destruction and the missiles to deliver them.
Therefore, Option 3 is: When you've got lemons, make lemonade. Approach Russia and France and tell them that the U.S. is ready to lift all economic sanctions on Iraq immediately if the two of them can persuade Saddam to accept a total, and permanent, weapons inspection regime. And if that doesn't work then simply lift the economic sanctions on Iraq anyway (they're only hurting the Iraqi people, so the argument goes), accept that the U.N. weapons monitoring regime is over and deal with Saddam henceforth through conventional deterrence. That is, make clear to him that any use of weapons of mass destruction would result in Iraq being vaporized. Deterrence did manage to keep the Soviet Union at bay for 45 years of cold war, and Moscow had 30,000 nukes. The risk in this strategy is that a rearmed Saddam, who managed to make the world blink, would be a highly destabilizing force in the region, even if he was deterred from using his worst weapons.
In any event, it seems that the U.S. doesn't have the military will for Option 1 -- occupying Iraq -- and it doesn't have the political will for Option 3 -- which would require a huge climb-down from all of the Administration's rhetoric that Saddam must go before sanctions are lifted. So we are left with Option 2 -- bombing Iraq in order to knock out as much of Saddam's weapons-making capability as possible, and, if lucky, also getting him.
The problem with Option 2 is that, if he survives, Saddam will respond by ordering the U.N. weapons inspectors permanently out of Iraq, and Russia and the Arabs could announce that since the U.S. has unilaterally bombed Iraq, outside the U.N. consensus, they will unilaterally reopen their economic ties with Baghdad. It would just be a matter of time then before Saddam was back building new weapons -- only without the nosy U.N. inspectors around, and with fresh money pouring in from a breakdown of sanctions.
Then what does the U.S. do? Does Washington have an Option 2-b? Does it have any way to insure that after a massive bombing of Iraq it can maintain its strategic objective of preventing Saddam from acquiring weapons of mass destruction -- without having to bomb him again and again, which would have serious diplomatic risks for U.S. diplomacy in the Middle East and at the U.N.? Some U.S. officials talk about making all of Iraq a no-fly zone as Option 2-b. That might hurt Saddam. But what if France and Russia don't play along?
I don't believe there is an Option 2-b. There is only Option 2 -- bombing Iraq, over and over and over again, until either Saddam says uncle, and agrees to let the U.N. back in on U.S. terms, or the Iraqi people eliminate him.
So, 2-b or not 2-b? There is no question. There is no 2-b. There is only Option 2, over and over and over again until Saddam relents. Given the problems with the other options, we may have no choice but to go down this road. Once we do, however, we better have the stomach to stay the course.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE;
Chelsea Clinton Returns For Weekend With Father

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Chelsea Clinton flew home from college on Thursday night to spend the weekend with her father, the President, while her mother, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is in Switzerland to attend an economic conference.
Miss Clinton, a 17-year-old freshman at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., plans to stay in Washington for several days, said Marsha Berry, the First Lady's press secretary. Classes are in session at Stanford, and Miss Clinton will probably miss a few days of schoolwork, Ms. Berry said. 
 "They have been looking at this weekend as a chance to spend some time with her dad for several weeks now," Ms. Berry said. "I wouldn't read anything into it."
Mr. Clinton, his daughter and several of her friends from high school plan to spend the weekend at the Presidential retreat at Camp David in Maryland.
Mrs. Clinton said earlier this week in a television interview that she had spoken with her daughter several times since the accusations that Mr. Clinton had an affair with a White House intern broke 10 days ago.
"I have told her that this was the kind of thing that would happen," Mrs. Clinton said on the NBC "Today" show on Wednesday. "And she has seen many, many examples of it in her very short life. So it's not a pleasant experience. But it's given her sort of the grounding to be able to see what this is and get through it."

HEADLINE: Poking Education's Sore Spot

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's threat to withdraw the city's contribution to remedial education at the community colleges of the City University of New York touches a sensitive area that is emerging as one of the biggest issues in higher education in the United States: what to do with the millions of students who enter college each year unprepared for college-level work.
The issue is particularly critical in New York City because CUNY has a much higher proportion of students who need remedial classes than most institutions around the country. About 87 percent of the students entering CUNY's six community colleges in the fall of 1996 failed at least one of the university's placement exams in reading, writing or mathematics and had to take high school-level remedial classes. Nationally, 41 percent of freshmen at public two-year colleges took at least one remedial course in 1995. 
 Though the problem is greatest at two-year community colleges, a national survey by the United States Department of Education in 1995 found that nearly a third of all college freshmen were required to take at least one remedial course in reading, writing or mathematics. The same study also found that more than three-quarters of colleges and universities nationwide offered remedial courses.
"The education of the so-called remedial student is the most important educational problem in America today," Alexander W. Astin, director of the Higher Education Research Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles, said at a conference on college remediation at Stanford University earlier this week. "Providing effective remedial education would do more to alleviate our most serious social and economic problems than almost any other action we could take."
Twenty or 30 years ago, many of these students simply would not have gone to college. But the pressures of the economy and the job market mean that workers today need better credentials and more skills to hold decent-paying jobs. So these new students have flooded into colleges, helped, in New York City, by the open admissions policy that allows anyone with a high school diploma or the equivalent to attend community colleges.
To Mr. Giuliani and other critics, such remedial work represents a distraction for colleges. On Thursday, the Mayor proposed removing remedial work from CUNY's community colleges, leaving them to focus their resources "on a community college education that is a really good one." He has also argued for more stringent standards in the high schools.
But experts in educational policy see the remediation as a necessity, a fundamental means of improving student skills. As an urban university in New York City, CUNY's six community colleges, with 65,000 students attract a large number of immigrants, many of whom are not yet proficient in English.
Half of the students come directly from city high schools, where they may have been poorly prepared. The other half includes new immigrants, older graduates of city high schools or high school graduates from schools in other cities.
"It's easy to say these students have been educated once, and should just go away," said David Pierce, president of the American Association of Community Colleges, based in Washington. "But to say that doesn't change the fact that they still have deficiencies that need to be addressed. Community colleges pride themselves in being instruction and learning focused, and the remedial courses are done with the same quality as other courses."
Some critics contend that Mr. Giuliani is more interested in politics than in the education of disadvantaged students and sees CUNY as a handy punching bag, in part because he does not control it. He names only 5 of the university's 17 trustees; the Governor names 10, and the students and faculty each have 1 representative.
"He doesn't care about education; he wants control," said Edith Everett, a CUNY trustee who was not one of the Mayor's appointees. "If there are problems here -- and we know there are -- the way to improve things is not to take pot shots, but to sit down and talk."
CUNY officials themselves concede that their system is not perfect, and they have been seeking ways to improve it. CUNY's senior colleges, for example, at the direction of the trustees, have been raising their own admissions standards and directing students who need more than one or two terms of remedial work to go to the community colleges, instead.
Last year, the trustees set up a committee headed by Herman Badillo, the Mayor's chief education adviser, to recommend ways to improve remedial education. But the committee, to meet soon, has been largely inactive.
Faculty members from both Herbert H. Lehman College and Bronx Community College attended the Stanford conference on remediation this week, to talk about their approaches and to examine others. The meeting, which was financed by the United States Department of Education and the Ford Foundation, examined five successful programs, including a writing program at the University of California at Berkeley and a course in critical thinking at CUNY's Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College.
A common theme at the conference and in the field is the difficulty in providing remedial education: in motivating students, in teaching skills that many students failed to learn in their high school years, in teaching students how to think.
For CUNY, as well as for many colleges in Texas, California and other states with large immigrant populations, the effort consists largely of teaching English to adults, which some say should not be counted as remedial but is typically lumped in with other remedial efforts.
But even as they seek to improve the results, education experts caution that the success of remedial programs cannot be judged by simple measures like the college graduation rates that Mr. Giuliani cited. He noted earlier this week that only 1 percent of the students in CUNY's community colleges graduated in two years, and only 16 percent in four years.
Those figures are accurate. But supporters of community college education point out that graduating in two or even four years is not the goal of many community college students. Some enroll to take a course or two. Others progress slowly while they work or raise families.
Still others attend community colleges for fewer than two years, often to perfect their English, and then move on to senior colleges; those who transfer to four-year colleges in fewer than two years are not included in the community college's graduation rates.
"Degree completion is not the sole reason people go to community colleges," said Clifford Adelman, a senior research analyst at the Department of Education.
"They are extraordinarily flexible institutions and they do a good job," Mr. Adelman said.
Even within CUNY, the graduation rates vary considerably, depending both on the students who attend the college and on the programs they are offered. The Mayor, for example, pointed yesterday to the Borough of Manhattan Community College, where fewer than 1 percent of the students graduate in two years.
By comparison, at CUNY's Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, the two-year graduation rate in recent years ranged from 5 to 10 percent, and the three-year graduation rate 17 to 24 percent.
Nationally, 23 percent of two-year college students who started in 1989 received either a community college degree or a bachelor's degree within five years.
Whether the system can do better by turning to private companies and other colleges to run remedial programs, as the Mayor has suggested, is an open question.
Some educators are skeptical, contending that students do better if they attend both remedial and mainstream classes at the same time. Others, including private companies that teach remedial classes, say their early work at a handful of colleges is showing good results but acknowledge that so far the data is limited.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Support for Hussein Is Said to Deepen in Iraq
Many diplomats, business executives and residents of Baghdad say that despite the hardships imposed by the embargo, political support for President Saddam Hussein is growing. A1 

France moved closer to acceptance of military action unless Iraq allowed inspections of suspected chemical and biological weapons sites to resume. A6
 
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright expressed skepticism about a diplomatic solution, but her Russian counterpart asserted after their meeting in Madrid that the negotiating process was just beginning. At the United Nations, China called for a peaceful solution. A6
 
Pacific Skies May Open
The United States and Japan agreed to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries, ending one of their largest trade disputes. Some airlines will see their restrictions removed, and airlines from any nation will be allowed to team up and offer the same flights. But the pact did not set aside more landing slots for the new flights at Narita airport, outside Tokyo. A1
 
The Party Grows in China
As China shifts toward market economics and flirts with consumerism, university students are flocking to join the governing Communist Party. Whether seeking power and personal gain or drawn by the party's philosophy, they have helped to raise party membership to an historic high of 58 million, 10 million more than in 1989, the year of the massacre at Tiananmen Square. A1
 
The State Department reported that China took "positive steps on human rights" in the last year. The department's previous annual report on human rights found that all dissent against the Government had been "effectively silenced." A5
 
New Clashes in Kenya
A new round of tribal clashes has broken out in Kenya's Rift Valley, claiming at least 80 lives in the last two weeks. The police said the killings were the work of cattle rustlers. But opposition leaders and clerics said the violence was part of a drive to force Kikuyu people out of the fertile Rift Valley, which is a political stronghold of President Daniel arap Moi. Most Kikuyu voted against Mr. Moi in last month's election. A3
 
Drug Link in Mexican Inquest
The gangland-style execution of a federal police commander in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, across from El Paso, Tex., has upset a Government inquiry into the disappearance of scores of people. The police officer had ties to narcotics traffickers, according to Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar. He said he intended to appoint new prosecutors and detectives to carry out the sensitive investigation. At least 90 people, including several Americans, have vanished in the border city since early 1994. A3

Ex-White House Worker Defends Her Credibility
Linda R. Tripp, the former White House worker who secretly taped some of her conversations with the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky, issued a statement defending her credibility and accusing the White House of a "smear" campaign. She also asserted that she had witnessed Ms. Lewinsky receiving an early-morning phone call from Mr. Clinton. The grand jury heard testimony from Evelyn Lieberman, the former White House deputy chief of staff who had Ms. Lewinsky transferred to the Pentagon, and from Bob Weiner of the President's drug control policy office, who had called Maryland Democratic officials concerning the legality of Ms. Tripp's taping. A1
 
Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones have been unable to find credible new witnesses willing to swear that they had a sexual relationship with President Clinton, witnesses and lawyers say. In pretrial depositions, at least five women have denied rumors of such a relationship. Only two women have described affairs with Mr. Clinton, and their accounts were known before the Jones lawsuit was filed. Two other women have provided sworn depositions describing encounters that echo aspects of Ms. Jones's claims. A1
 
Gambling, On Line
Bookmakers have set up operations in Central America and West Indies countries like Antigua, where they have created jobs for local residents, and, often using the Internet, have rapidly built an offshore sports book industry that gaming analysts say is taking in 1 to 5 percent of the $100 billion that is illegally bet on sports each year in the United States. A1
 
Abortion Clinic Blast
More than 100 investigators in Birmingham, Ala., interviewed witnesses and searched a four-block area for clues in the bombing of an abortion clinic on Thursday that killed an off-duty police officer. The clinic's head nurse was in critical condition with with wounds to her face, abdomen and legs. Investigators were considering the possibility that the bombing might be linked to explosions in Atlanta over the past two years. A7
 
Tax Credits for Efficient Cars
The Clinton Administration is proposing generous tax credits for consumers who buy advanced cars that use emerging technologies to go two or three times as far on a gallon of gas as today's models. The credits would lower an auto buyer's Federal income tax bill by $3,000 to $4,000, substantially cutting the net cost of vehicles that are likely, at first, to be more expensive than today's models. The subsidies, which would begin in 2000, are at the center of a $6.3 billion package to fight the threat of global warming caused by emissions from burning fossil fuels. A11
