HEADLINE: With Technology, Island Bookies Skirt U.S. Law

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The reggae bands were warming up on Sunday evening for their daily ritual of entertaining the American tourists who line the beaches of this Caribbean island. But in the cozy back room of a modern house that once served as the Chinese embassy, past the lazy dogs in the yard and the bicycles in the driveway, Bob Eremian was entertaining Americans in a different way.
It was two hours before the start of Sunday's Super Bowl game in San Diego, and Mr. Eremian, in short pants and bare feet, was sitting in front of three computer screens, overseeing a sports betting operation that would take more than 10,000 bets on the game before the day was over. "They're calling from all over the U.S. today," he said, as the 25 telephone operators seated in front of him quickly logged bets into their computers. "That's what people want to do," Mr. Eremian said. "Bet on sports." 
 Wagering on sports is illegal everywhere in the United States, except for Nevada and Oregon. But over the past two years, a small number of bookmakers have packed up their lists of customers and traveled south, along with some first-time bookies, to take refuge in tiny West Indies countries like this one. Licensed by the local government and using advanced technology to communicate, set odds on games and record wagers, they have created hundreds of jobs for local residents and rapidly built an offshore sports book industry that gaming analysts say is taking in1 to 5 percent of the $100 billion that is bet illegally on sports each year in the United States.
Of the approximately 60 offshore sports books in operation throughout the Caribbean and Central America, 25 are based in Antigua, according to local officials, who in 1994 created a free trade zone where the bookies can operate without paying corporate taxes. The gambling operations are spread around the region. Just off the northern coast of Venezuela, in Curacao, several sports books operate within a block of each other.
"They've grown like wildfire," said Jeff Brown, a co-owner of Bettorsworld.com, a Connecticut-based company that tracks and rates the offshore sports books. A few of the offshore bookies operated in the Caribbean for several years without any local sanction, but the Internet and the willingness of local governments to license them have given rise to a new, competitive breed of bookies. They once were rude and nasty, "just like the local bookie," Mr. Brown said. "But now they're becoming a real customer-service business."
Many of the sports books and other offshore companies also operate on-line casinos, which allow customers to bet on interactive games, like slot machines, blackjack and poker. The sudden growth of the offshore sports books and on-line casinos has exposed a nebulous area in the Federal law against using telephone lines for gambling, and caused a host of opponents to push for new laws banning Internet casinos and offshore sports books from doing business in the United States.
Critics include the operators of casinos in the United States, who loathe the thought of gambling dollars leaving the country, and the heads of professional and college sports leagues, who fear that further legitimizing of sports betting will undermine the integrity of their games. Opponents of both types of offshore gambling say the on-line casinos pose a greater threat to consumers than the sports books because it is too difficult to regulate or gauge the fairness of interactive casino games.
"We need a new tool to prosecute the same old activity," said Senator John Kyl, Republican of Arizona. Mr. Kyl introduced legislation last year that would expand the current laws to include Internet gambling, and implement fines and jail terms for bookies and their customers. The bill passed the Senate Judiciary Committee and is expected to be heard by the full Senate early this year. The House Judiciary Committee is scheduled to consider similar legislation next week.
Several state attorney generals, meanwhile, have also begun to attack sports betting and on-line casinos on the basis that while it may be legal to bet on sports in the country where the bookies are located, it is not legal in the states where the bets originate. Despite requests from state attorney generals to put an end to the offshore betting operations, the Department of Justice so far has not acted.
"We have no jurisdiction," said John Russell, a Justice Department spokesman. "The offense has not been made on U.S. soil."
In recent weeks, Florida's attorney general, Bob Butterworth, reached an agreement with Western Union to stop wiring money for the offshore companies, which have used the wire service as one of their primary means of receiving betting money from gamblers and disbursing winnings. The bookies say the Western Union ban has only inconvenienced them, and now they have to depend more on bank wires, cashier's checks and overnight mail. Mr. Butterworth has also appealed to publications to stop accepting advertisements from the bookies.
The offshore operators contend that existing Federal law does not apply to the Internet, and that while accepting bets is illegal in the United States, they are accepting bets from their base outside the country. "It's a gray area," Mr. Brown said. "That's why they've all set up offshore."
While most of the sports book operators, like Mr. Eremian, were bookmakers long before they left the U.S., some entrepreneurs moved here to start booking bets for the first time.
Many of them use World Wide Web sites to take wagers. Customers must first set up an account by transferring money through a wire, cashier's check or credit card debit. The telephone operations give their customers toll-free numbers and personal identification numbers to access their accounts and place bets. Those who access their account on-line use a password.
All of the sports books insist they operate with total legitimacy. They advertise in major publications like Pro Football Weekly, on the Internet and on sports radio stations. They subscribe to electronic information services provided by major American companies that provide the latest point spreads on games via satellite. And they try incessantly to overcome the long-held notion that sports bookies are mob-tainted and as crooked as the roads that wind through the mountains of their adopted homeland.
"We are not a bunch of scam artists," said Jay Cohen, who in 1996 left his job as a stock trader on the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco to move here and open World Sports Exchange, an on-line sports betting company. Since last March, his list of customers, people who have opened a gambling account with an average deposit of $1,000, has grown from 30 to 2,000, he said. "We're licensed down here and we have a good reputation with our customers," Mr. Cohen said. "People are more comfortable with us than with the illegal bookmakers. They know that when they win, we pay."
The bookies have begun to mount their own lobbying effort in Washington, and are currently searching for a sponsor of legislation that would legalize and regulate their industry. "We are more than willing to pay taxes and do everything by the book if the Government would just let us do it," said Christine Walton, a spokeswoman for Global Sports Connection, a sports book based in Costa Rica. "People are going to bet on sports no matter what, and as long as the government keeps us offshore and operating in this gray area, they won't see any tax revenues."
Officials with the sports books note that they do encourage their customers to pay taxes on their winnings to the United States Government, but the companies themselves are currently under no obligation to report customers' winnings to the Internal Revenue Service.
The mounting opposition in the United States did not appear to dissuade bettors on Sunday, when most bookies here were boasting of record-setting business. Forty-five minutes before the kickoff for the Super Bowl, at World Wide Telesports, one of the largest sports books on the island, Anique Goodwin paced back and forth from her bank of computer screens to the screens of the 38 phone clerks, or "sports consultants," as the company calls them, seated throughout the room. At a rate of nearly 4,000 calls per hour, gamblers from all over the world, but mostly from the United States, were lighting up the telephone lines and wagering as much as $25,000 on the game. "This is it," Ms. Goodwin said. "The biggest day ever."
Ms. Goodwin should know. She started with the company three years ago when it first opened with just 50 customers. She is now the director of operations, in charge of setting the odds on games for 2,000 customers, and hiring and training the phone staff. In other words, Ms. Goodwin is the chief bookie, a most unlikely role for a 21-year-old Antiguan who knew nothing of football when she took the job. "When I started I didn't know a single team," she said. Now, she handles the calls from the company's biggest and shrewdest bettors. "I take all the wise guys," she boasted.
Started by Billy Scott of Toledo, Ohio, World Wide Telesports has become what Antiguan officials said they hope all of the sports books become: a major employer. Located inside a sprawling office on the fifth and top floor of the island's tallest office building, the company has 85 employees, including marketing, accounting, and systems departments. All of the department heads are Antiguans, and the all-female staff of phone clerks start at $5 per hour, comparable to the wages paid in the island's predominant industry, tourism.
"These girls are intelligent and knowledgeable," said Jessica Davis, a 27-year-old native of North Dakota and the president of World Wide Telesports. "We call them sports consultants because they can tell you anything you need to know about betting on a sport. And most of them have never even seen a live football game."
All of the sports book operators refuse to discuss their corporate structures and revenues, but Mr. Scott, 56, said he has earned enough to recently relinquish his stake in World Wide Telesports and retire to the nearby island of St. Martin. Some of his "close family members," he said, have retained a share of the equity in the company, and the rest has been divided among a group of local directors. "We're very comfortable," Mr. Scott said.
To receive a license, applicants must pay the government $75,000 for telephone gambling operations and $100,000 for on-line companies. (The fee for telephone operations is lower because they employ more Antiguans.) Charles Fernandez, chairman of Antigua's free trade zone where the bookies operate, said that over 200 local residents work at the sports books and the funds from licenses have enabled the government to open a computer training school that currently has 180 students enrolled. The presence of the Americans has also stimulated the economy, he said, helping to reduce unemployment to the single digits.
Still, there are some Antiguans who bemoan the proliferation of the betting parlors. "Take that stuff back to the U.S.," suggested a 40-year-old gift shop owner, who requested anonymity.
A member of the British Commonwealth, Antigua has a population of 70,000, barely enough to fill most professional football stadiums in the United States. Over 95 percent of the natives are black, and most white residents work either at the hotels or the sports books. Although many of the bookies and their families have found that life as expatriates here is hardly paradise -- there are hurricanes, frequent water shortages and power outages -- the idea of booking sports without being harassed keeps them here for now.
"The reason I'm here in this country is because I can't do what I want to do in the U.S.," said Mr. Eremian, 45, who worked for 11 years as a bookie in Boston before moving his wife and four children here in 1996. "It feels great. I don't have to worry about the police coming and breaking the door down."
Still, Antigua is remote and underdeveloped, and bookies work long hours in front of their computer screens protecting themselves against wily bettors. "My wife hates me," Mr. Eremian said. "And my children complain that they never see me, even though we live right across the street."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At top, two of the web sites for companies that accept bets on games like blackjack. Above, telephone clerks in Antigua taking bets before the Super Bowl last Sunday. (Brett Pulley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Monitors Praise Giuliani's Spending Plan

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a preliminary $34.3 billion city budget, most outside monitors who watch the city's finances reacted positively to his proposals, saying they struck a prudent balance between spending and revenues.
Some advocates for social programs, however, questioned Mr. Giuliani's handling of the city's $1.2 billion surplus and said that the Republican Mayor continued to favor the city's wealthy at the expense of its poorest. 
 Most independent analysts also raised doubts about a central claim in the budget: That it would keep city spending below the rate of inflation by increasing expenditures by just sixth-tenths of a percent. The actual growth would be 3 to 4 percent, the analysts said.
The Mayor's budget for the fiscal year beginning on July 1 was received more favorably than were the budgets during his first term, which many independent experts criticized for relying heavily on fiscal gimmicks. This week's proposal was a departure both from Mr. Giuliani's austere budgets in the first three years of his first term and from the increased spending in the 1997 election-year budget.
"It's a fairly restrained budget," said Richard J. Raphael, executive managing director at Fitch IBCA Inc., a bond rating firm.
Some analysts, including the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit, nonpartisan group, criticized the Mayor for not using the surplus to retire long-term debt, instead earmarking about three-quarters to help close projected budget gaps in the next two years and the rest to pay for new spending and tax cuts. Yesterday, though, others said that while chipping away at the city's heavy long-term debt might be fiscally ideal, it was politically impractical.
"That was actually a very reasonable balance between political reality and good fiscal management," said Ester R. Fuchs, the director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy, who was an adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins in the 1993 mayoral campaign.
Some advocates, however, questioned Mr. Giuliani's priorities. Among his tax cuts, the Mayor trumpeted the elimination of the tax on clothing as benefiting low-income New Yorkers who spend a disproportionate amount of their earnings on clothes. But Glenn Pasanen, associate director of City Project, a coalition of social-service groups that monitors the budget, said the other big tax cuts, on commercial rent on buildings in Manhattan below 96th Street and on co-ops and condominiums, favored the wealthy.
"With this surplus, why not use some of it for a job-creation program to match the Mayor's rhetoric of getting people off welfare?" Mr. Pasanen said. "You could do a one-year program so that it would not become a recurring expense."
On one issue, though, almost all analysts agreed. Mr. Giuliani, who has often boasted that he has kept increases in city spending below the rate of inflation and described it as one of his most important fiscal achievements, said that spending for the next fiscal year would rise by only six-tenths of 1 percent. But analysts said that the increase was actually between 3 and 4 percent. The higher figures can hardly be described as profligacy, but they do exceed the rate of inflation, which now hovers locally from 2 to 2.5 percent.
At the heart of the issue is how the city handles its current $1.2 billion surplus. Mr. Giuliani wants to use it to close projected deficits during the next two years. But under the accounting rules that the city follows, it must spend all the money it receives in a given year by the end of that year. So the Mayor's office registers that spending as part of the current fiscal year, but most analysts say for purposes of comparison it should be counted as spending in the new fiscal year to reflect growth in spending accurately. The accounting rules, they say, artificially depress next year's spending.
"He's not lying," said Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office, which the Mayor wants abolished. "But the devil's in the details. You can see how you can manipulate numbers in different ways to serve your purpose. In our analysis, we won't be showing a 0.6 percent increase. Maybe we'll make some reference to it to show that it's misleading."
Yesterday, in a news conference following Ramadan services at the Malcolm Shabazz mosque in Harlem, Mr. Giuliani bristled at criticism of his plan. "Garbage," he said, waving his hand to chase the thought.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: SPLENDOR AND RUIN -- A special report.;
As Hussein Builds, His People Struggle to Live

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 29

 BODY:
On a small hill overlooking Baghdad's zoo, where most of the animals have perished from hunger, a stupendous new palace is rising. It is a massive, brooding, domed extravaganza, the latest and perhaps grandest of the monuments that are steadily remaking the city's skyline to the glory of Saddam Hussein.
Bricks at archeological reconstruction sites bear inscriptions hailing him as a new Al Mansur, the Caliph who founded Baghdad in the eighth century. A recent arts festival in Babylon was subtitled "From Nebuchadnezzar to Sadaam Hussein." Portraits of the two hang together in Babylon, where Nebuchadnezzar, one of the greatest of ancient Babylonians, ruled in the sixth century B.C. 
 To burnish his reputation as a leader of Muslims everywhere, Mr. Hussein has just broken ground for the largest mosque in the world.
No one knows how Mr. Hussein can pay for these projects, after seven years of crippling economic sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. Even as he builds his imperial Baghdad, there is another Baghdad, where people plot how to pay the next grocery bill.
Ahmad Adnan, a 10-year-old suffering from diabetes, was in Saddam Central Children's Hospital for treatment. He was too shy to tell a reporter what he would like from the vendor's stall outside that was crowded with teddy bears, toys, cookies and candy that no one was buying.
Dr. Kasim al-Taai leaned down and asked Ahmad to tell him what he really wanted.
"One egg, please," Ahmad whispered in the doctor's ear.
Despite the oil embargo, Mr. Hussein seems stronger than ever. In two weeks of interviews here with Iraqis, United Nations officials, diplomats and Asian and European business executives, many say they believe that he may even be picking up political support in this period of unaccustomed hardships, especially among the young who have been well indoctrinated in the schools. Mr. Hussein has been in full control for nearly 20 years, and for a decade before that was a rising star in the Arab Baath Socialist Party, which came to power in 1968.
Many Iraqis, publicly at least, direct their anger at the United States, rather than at their President.
"Do you think we wanted to invade Kuwait?" one unusually outspoken Iraqi remarked. Then he added, "But was that enough that our children should be dying even now?"
It is all but impossible to gauge public opinion, though, because Iraqis seem to be under scrutiny at all times by a vast network of security agencies with outposts in most neighborhoods. "Please don't take pictures here," a taxi driver begged a reporter who was dropped off at a well-known restaurant. "They will take down my number and come to my house tonight to ask what I am doing with a foreigner in my car."
By many accounts, Mr. Hussein rules by a potent combination of terror and secrecy. He and his party apparatus permit no dissent. In 1995, he held a referendum on his presidency. Those who watched the process say that before the vote, Baath Party workers combed every neighborhood, going door to door to ask if the household had ration cards, a subtle message that the family's subsidized food might be in jeopardy if adults failed to vote. Rumors were deliberately circulated about the sophisticated methods the Government had for detecting negative ballots, even if cast in secret.
As television cameras moved in on the day of the vote, people were seen holding their ballots aloft and chanting, "Naam, naam, Saddam!" or, 'Yes, yes, for Saddam!" The President won 99.96 percent of the vote.
Mr. Hussein is rarely seen in public. Most of his appearances are on government television, and no opposing view comes from satellite television, which is forbidden. It is said that probably no more than a dozen people know where he is at any time. United Nations weapons inspectors have been told that he moves from palace to palace from night to night.
Ambassadors based in Baghdad never meet the President -- with the exception of Russians. Envoys present their credentials to a vice president or other official. Neither Richard Butler, the chief United Nations arms inspector, nor his predecessor, Rolf Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat who is now Ambassador to Washington, were ever given the opportunity to talk directly with Mr. Hussein.
 
The Economy
Signs of Hardship Are Everywhere
The economic collapse of Iraq has gutted the intelligentsia, once one of the most highly respected in the Arab world. If any sector of society outside the military might have formed a political opposition, the Iraqi middle class would have been the only hope, a diplomat said.
"It has now been totally destroyed," this envoy said of the middle class. It is a sentiment heard everywhere in Iraq.
An Iraqi professional now earns a base pay of 3,000 dinars a month, or about $2 at the unofficial exchange rate, for government work, which includes hospitals and universities. Just over two pounds of chicken cost 1,100 dinars. Eggs are about 1,200 dinars a dozen and sugar 500 dinars for a kilogram or 2.2 pounds. Fresh fruit and vegetables, now arriving with greater frequency in the markets, are priced beyond the reach of most families.
Iraq's supply of drugs ran out in 1994, and doctors at Saddam Children's Hospital tell of children who die of curable diseases because, they say, the United Nations Security Council sanctions committee has refused to allow them to import some of the crucial medicine they need. Already-malnourished children are vulnerable to infection, yet the hospital cannot maintain sterile isolation wards.
The signs of hardship are clear everywhere in Baghdad. What is less clear is to what extent Mr. Hussein is compounding the suffering created by the embargo, either through his grandiose palace-building, weapons programs and other government projects or for propaganda purposes, to try to convince the world to ease up on the sanctions.
Years before the embargo was even imposed, though, Mr. Hussein's Government had made economic policy choices that have now come back to haunt the 22 million Iraqis. From 1968 until the late 1980's, his Baath Party gave government a large role in the economy and relegated the private sector largely to minor industries, crafts and petty trade. Some experts believe that Mr. Hussein was ambivalent about letting a strong economic middle class develop in the private sector.
What is now Iraq was part of the ancient Fertile Crescent, but despite the fact that the country still has some of the best land in the region, little effort was made over the last few decades to develop agriculture.
Instead, Iraq relied on oil wealth. "We became oil junkies," an Iraqi intellectual said. Need something? Just pick up the phone and call Switzerland for watches, Paris for cosmetics and a score of countries for processed foods or even fresh produce that could have been grown locally.
"Energy is still used with great abandon," said Denis J. Halliday, the United Nations official in charge of distributing food and medicine under the "oil for food" program. Like Americans, Iraqis leave on lights and air conditioners and, in the cold of winter, turn on several electric heaters in a room.
Iraq's eight-year war with Iran also drained the treasury, leading to heavy borrowing. A quarrel over Iraqi debt to Kuwait was one of the reasons Mr. Hussein annexed it, prompting the Security Council to impose the sanctions.
With oil sales banned, the per capita gross domestic product of Iraqis plunged from more than $2,900 to about $60 annually. The value of the Iraqi currency, the dinar, worth more than $3 in 1989, dropped sharply. Now $1 buys 1,500 dinars at the bazaar money-changers' rates of exchange, or 450 dinars at the official rate.
Mr. Hussein has compounded currency problems by printing money without adequate backing, causing inflation to soar. This has hit those with fixed incomes hardest. Among the victims are government employees, the majority of salaried workers in Iraq.
Once the hard currency stopped flowing in, foreigners who had worked in jobs ranging from nursing to sanitation and who had been paid with hard currency from oil vanished, leaving Iraqis seemingly incapable or unwilling to do these jobs themselves.
Garbage is piling up in many neighborhoods, on vacant lots and streets, worsening health problems caused by the lack of medicine -- Iraq ran out of its stores of drugs in 1994 -- and by a breakdown in water and sanitation systems.
 
The People
Selling, Emigrating Or Just Surviving
At the Department of Antiquities and Heritage, custodian of Iraq's extraordinary ancient Mesopotamian sites and the priceless artifacts they contain, Mouad Said, the director general, is dangerously short-staffed.
"Many of my employees prefer to work in the bazaar," he said. "A lot of our brains are also emigrating out of Iraq, to teach or work in other Arab countries, in Europe, the U.S., Australia, New Zealand -- everywhere."
Buying and selling, mostly selling, is the only money-earning pastime now left to many Iraqis who remain. Antique stores have become pawn shops full of family treasures: watches, jewelry, cameras, silverware, china, even souvenirs from trips abroad. Along the roadsides, impromptu markets have sprung up where people trying to maintain their dignity come to sell their clothes, a chandelier, the furniture.
The Iraqi middle class, large and well educated by the standards of most of the developing world, has fallen in recent years, and fallen hard.
"Ten years ago I did whatever I wanted," said Baydaa Ihsaan, who is in charge of international relations -- or what is left of them -- for the General Federation of Iraqi Women. "I realized my dreams. I got my degree."
"Now you can't do what you want." she said. "There will always be a block in your way. You can almost not survive. The embargo has stopped almost everything in my life."
"Just catching a cold or the flu now are things that terrify me," she continued. "Life is like a nightmare. One day you have everything in your life, and the next day you open your eyes and there is darkness."
Ms. Ihsaan, 29, and other women her age said they are unable to think of marriage and a family, and are forced by circumstances to stay in their parents' homes to contribute to earnings and to share in what resources they can muster.
"The whole world is to blame," she said, echoing other youthful voices, some too young to remember how Iraq got itself into this predicament.
At the University of Baghdad's College of Arts, Lena Ali, a lecturer in English, said many people were "going back to religion" in a society that is socially conservative but was never militantly Islamic. Christian churches are strong here, and Iraqi Christians of various rites are among the better off and sometimes most influential people. Tariq Aziz, the Deputy Prime Minister and Mr. Hussein's liaison with the outside world, is a Christian.
The search for solace in Islam is being encouraged by the Government, Iraqis say. It is beginning to cause some concern in Christian families, a number of which have left the country. And it is undermining Iraq's once-promising potential to be a center for modernizing, reformist Islamic studies, a scholar said.
Scholarship in all fields has suffered from a lack of books and contacts with the world of learning. The Security Council sanctions committee has not allowed universities to import teaching materials, said Abdul Latif al-Jumaily, head of the English literature department and Ms. Ali's boss at the College of Arts.
Iraqi scholars and medical specialists, considered among the best in the Arab world, once attended seminars and professional meetings around the globe. Now they cannot afford to travel or are forbidden to do so. Too many intellectuals joined the brain drain by going to conferences and never returning, a writer said. Iraq has apparently computerized a list of scholars with higher degrees who are barred from travel as a result. In the hospitals, doctors are not permitted to resign.
To leave Iraq costs hundreds of dollars in exit fees. But growing numbers of people are selling everything they own to move. Universities in Yemen, Malaysia and North African countries including Libya bid for their services and offer salaries in the thousands of dollars a month.
Those who stay make do with second-hand clothes and two or three jobs just to support their families. Cars with cracked windows and threadbare tires are the norm for many; they are used judiciously so that they will not collapse completely. During the boom years, Iraq built highways all over the country as good as those in the United States, and many Iraqi families bought cars or pickup trucks.
"We have to lead a dog's life," said Professor Jumaily, who teaches day and night courses, including basic English-language courses for which there is a skyrocketing demand. "We don't have time for research. With our noses to the grindstone, who can think?"
His colleague, Saad Hasani, a popular literature professor, is more bitter.
"I fail to see why literary works are being denied to us," he said. "Books are not the tools of war. This is not a matter of war; it's a matter of malice."
 
The Well-Off Few
Petty Mafias Are Getting Rich
Diplomats and other foreigners who have known Iraq over several decades say the society has experienced a total inversion of values with the impoverishment of the professional middle classes. The people who matter now are the buyers and sellers of prohibited goods -- the smugglers and business tycoons with connections to the President or, increasingly, one of his two sons, Uday and Qusay.
Some people are getting very rich in Iraq. Their spacious homes are being built in prime land along the banks of the Tigris, which runs through this sprawling city. They have expensive imported cars and no shortage of food or medicine. They travel back and forth to Jordan pretty much at will. Some also have lavish houses in Amman, Jordan, where a leading Iraqi trader was recently assassinated in his home along with the second-ranking diplomat at Iraq's Embassy and half a dozen other people.
At every level in Iraq, petty mafias are consolidating their power over monopolies of one kind or another. At the last major hotel still functioning with any semblance of international service standards, one clan has cornered the car-service market and shakes down or physically threatens any other driver who tries to do business with hotel guests. All such mafias are assumed to have connections in the President's family or the state security services.
"We are returning to tribalism, violent tribalism," an Iraqi said. All around, added a foreigner, "there is a sense of decay."
At the Saddam Central Children's Hospital, Dr. Dhia al-Obaidi, a pediatrician, has not recovered from the shock of seeing his once-comfortable world collapse around him, though he is politically powerless to do anything about it. Proud Iraqis dread slipping backward into a third world existence. Children begging on the streets are a sign that this is already happening, other Iraqis said.
"We feel like they put you first into a big castle, then all of a sudden you are in a small cottage," Dr. Obaidi said. "Imagine a child of 4 years or 5 years or 7 years -- he has never seen an airplane in the sky."
"We have two big rivers," he said. "We have oil. It should not be like this. We ourselves cannot live like in India, between two trees or along the side of the road."

HEADLINE: Food Aid for Cubans Backed by Helms

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, endorsed a legislative proposal today to provide increased food and medicine to needy Cubans.
The proposal, announced in Miami on Thursday by the Cuban-American National Foundation, could provide $100 million worth of goods if Havana promises that the aid will not be diverted to Government stores or Communist Party officials. Some aid could be provided under Washington's assistance programs. 
 "This is a worthy proposal based on sound principles," Senator Helms said. He was one of the authors of legislation approved in 1996 to deter foreign investment in Cuba.

HEADLINE: At China's Colleges, a Rush To Party, as in Communist

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
In an era of business deals and fervent consumerism, when the M.B.A. is hot among graduating seniors, why do more and more of the better college students yearn to join a seemingly outdated club -- the Communist Party?
At Beijing University, the country's most eminent school, which draws an elite student body from around the country, 10 percent of the 8,733 undergraduates are now party members. That proportion is up from 5 percent in 1991, when the party was in low repute after the violent crackdown on students demonstrating in favor of democracy in Tiananmen Square in 1989. 
 More than 20 percent of the Beijing University students have sought to join, and applications are increasing each year, party officials say. But it is not easy to get into this exclusive club.
The numbers of applicants and members are also climbing at other leading universities, the officials say. Nationally, the Communist Party's total membership has grown to a historic high of 58 million, up from 48 million in 1989 and 4.5 million back in 1949, when the People's Republic of China was founded.
There are two explanations for the party's continuing growth.
One is offered by Wang Dang, 20, a junior at Beijing University who had started his quest for membership while still in high school in the southern coastal province of Zhejiang.
Bright-eyed, brimming with enthusiasm, he said: "This is an outstanding party with an outstanding purpose, to change society for the better. It's attractive to anyone who is searching for higher ideals in life."
The other explanation is offered by a longtime party member now in his 60's, a disaffected "liberal" who spoke on condition of anonymity: "People my age joined the party for ideals. Now, most of them are joining because they want power and seek personal gain."
The elder's view is shared by many students who tend to be openly skeptical of the motives of those who join the party, noting, among other things, that a party card helps graduates from the provinces get jobs that allow them to live in Beijing.
What is certain is that even today, membership in the all-powerful party can bring enormous advantages. For those who seek a career in government, it is indispensable. For the large numbers who will end up working in state-owned companies, a party card is required for advancement to senior management positions.
Even many leading private businessmen join because membership can open doors with government and party officials who control vital information and authority.
"The Chinese Communist Party has become a network of bureaucratic elites," said Suisheng Zhao, a professor of politics at Colby College in Maine and editor of the Journal of Contemporary China. Young people are joining, he said, because of "the power of party membership to enhance their career in the bureaucratic system."
The party itself is less monolithic and demanding of its members than it used to be, noted Kenneth Lieberthal, a professor of politics and business at the University of Michigan, "and therefore it can actually be attractive for people who want to bring about better governance."
But he added: "A substantial portion of the most exciting and potentially lucrative positions in China's marketizing economy are disproportionately available to those who are party members. The party has become the establishment of the most rapidly growing -- and perhaps the most rapidly changing -- country on earth."
Whether a growing share of less-than-committed cadres will help the party keep its monopoly on political power is also a matter of debate.
The party elder said that with so many people falsely claiming to believe, "it creates an environment of lies, and this will eventually erode the power of the party."
Roderick MacFarquhar, an expert on Chinese politics at Harvard University, said it was clear that most new members mainly want to further their careers. "Recruits of this type only further adulterate the ideological nature and esprit de corps of the party, and indeed are a symptom of how far that degeneration has already gone," he said.
But Dr. Zhao of Colby noted that rising party membership reflects the pragmatism prevailing in China today. "This pragmatism could help the party hold its power as long as it does not worry about ideological correctness or grass-roots discipline."
Illustrating the advantages of membership, a woman in her 30's who did not join the party, and works in the state-run broadcast industry, said party members in the radio and television networks get first shot at foreign assignments and covering big stories like the return of Hong Kong to China. A capable non-member could become a senior editor, she said, but could never reach senior management of the work unit.
Another woman in her 30's who joined the party at her first job, with a government company, said her reasons were as much psychological as practical. "You have to be an outstanding worker," the woman said. "And it is the only thing you can join to get any recognition."
The party has for years had a public goal of attracting younger and better-educated members. In pursuit of that aim Hou Xuezhong, who is vice director of the Organizing Department of the Beijing University Party Committee and also director of the university's party school, has been one very successful cadre.
He took over university-wide recruiting in 1991, when, as he recalled in an interview, "there was much confusion of minds, so fewer students applied." He had previously served in the party committee of the university's physics department. (All the academic departments have their own party committees or divisions).
The party does not just accept anyone, Mr. Hou said, and it usually takes applicants more than a year and a half of meetings, study of the elusive Deng Xiaoping Theory, self-criticism, essays, group outings and closely scrutinized behavior to get in. He rattled off the qualifications:
"You have to believe the final state of society will be Communism, that's the most important thing. You have to study hard and work hard. You must believe that the Communist Party can lead China toward reform and opening up. You must be willing to follow the party rules: the individual must follow the collective, the minority must follow the majority, the lower level must follow the upper level. You must care about the masses, and serve the people."
Mr. Hou acknowledged that some applicants had less than pure motives, but he insisted that intense education, and a close watch on the students' behavior among their peers, helped to insure that opportunists were weeded out.
The students joining today have only known the party of the Deng Xiaoping era of loosening economic controls. They were grade-school students in the year of Tiananmen Square. The two students introduced by the university as showcase examples of young Communists, at least, seem to be bubbling with idealism.
Mr. Wang said he had become an admirer of the party when he witnessed the benefits of economic reforms for his own family. With the opportunity to rent land and pursue rural enterprises, he said, his father and grandfather, longtime farmers, were able to break their bonds to the earth and escape poverty. Mr. Wang is majoring in international relations and wants to go to graduate school but is not sure whether he will pursue business, government or academia.
The second student, Yu Huaidong, also a 20-year-old junior, is a sociology major from Shandong Province, in eastern China. He says he joined because he wants to do something for society and after graduation he hopes to work in poverty-stricken areas of central or western China.
Further explaining his aims, Mr. Yu cited a saying of Confucius: "First you perfect yourself, then you perfect your family, then you perfect society, then you perfect the world."
Asked whether he realized that until recently the party condemned Confucian thought, Mr. Yu said: "I'm not worried that the Communist Party will return to the old times. China was backward, and they were feeling their way. Now, after the reforms and opening up, the Communist Party knows how to seek the socialist goal."
Asked about 1989, when many Beijing University students were embroiled in the pro-democracy demonstrations that were crushed by the Communist Party, the two young members shifted uneasily. Finally Mr. Wang said he felt that while many of the students were probably acting out of good intentions, the problem had been with the student leaders, who had hidden objectives and were not truly democratic.
"I believe that the actions of the Government were basically correct," he said, and without the actions taken, "we could not have had the progress we have had in the last 10 years."

HEADLINE: Pact on Air Traffic By U.S. and Japan To Lift Restrictions

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The United States and Japan ended one of their largest outstanding trade disputes today by agreeing to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries.
The framework agreement will add service between more cities in both countries, remove restrictions on five carriers -- United; Northwest; FDX Corporation, formerly Fedex; Japan Air Lines, and All Nippon Airways -- and loosen restrictions on other American carriers as well as allow new American airlines into the market. 
 The pact may also push down fares, Administration officials say, but it is unclear by how much.
Under the agreement, allied airlines will be allowed to jointly offer the same flights, known in the industry as code sharing, whether the carriers are American, Japanese or from third countries. The accord also confirms the rights of cargo carriers to transport freight through Japan to other destinations.
Absent from the agreement, however, is any plan for increasing the number of landing slots for the new flights at Narita international airport outside Tokyo.
The dispute that ended today goes back to the last days of the American occupation of Japan, when the two countries reached an air agreement. Japan has complained that, because the country was so weak at the time, the agreement was negotiated unfairly. The United States, for its part, has insisted that Japan remove barriers to air service passing through the country en route to other Asian destinations before any broader agreement could be reached.
Today's accord comes at a time of relative calm over trade issues with Japan. It is also a time of growing tension over Japan's economic strategy in the Asian crisis.
Clinton Administration officials described the agreement, which has been under negotiation for 12 months, in expansive terms. Daniel Tarullo, the Deputy Assistant to the President for International Economic Policy, said this was "an agreement that will change the face of trans-Pacific air travel."
Among the results, he said, would be "a dramatic increase in air services, both passenger and cargo, across the Pacific" and job growth in the aviation industry and in other industries in cities around the United States that would gain service to Japan for the first time. The United States and Japan are the world's No. 1 and No. 2 economies, Administration officials pointed out.
But some airlines were not so sure. At Northwest, which enjoys limited rights now and would gain more, Michael E. Levine, the executive vice president for marketing, said that in the current economic environment, with a soft economy in Japan and a crisis in much of the rest of Asia, the effect of the agreement would be "relatively little."
"Because there are no net new slots, there is not going to be a lot of net new service," he said, referring to landing spots at Narita, where the international Japanese aviation market is highly concentrated. Administration officials countered that FDX Corporation has unused slots at Narita, and said the airline could sell them to other American carriers.
And, they said, the Japanese agreed to allow the slots to change hands among American companies as a commercial transaction. Northwest complained, however, that most of the landing slots occur very early in the morning, which would require departures from American cities after midnight, and are too early to appeal to travelers in Japan.
Mr. Levine called the agremeent "a set of mercantilist adjustments that obviously favors some carriers and doesn't favor other carriers, creates a few new opportunities but doesn't fundamentally change the marketplace."
The agreement will allow Delta, American and Continental the right to fly 90 more round-trip flights a week to Japan, nearly tripling the number of flights they can send, and will allow the United States to let one more American carrier into the market now, and another in two years.
Those three carriers are now limited to 46 flights a week among them; the new agreement gives them an additional 90, not counting service between Japan and two popular American tourist destinations, Guam and Saipan. The carriers with the oldest access rights -- United, Northwest and FDX, operating under an agreement signed in 1952 -- have almost all restrictions lifted. Charter flights will also increase.
The Clinton Administration contends that the additional capacity will push down fares, but Mr. Tarullo and others would not say by how much. They said, however, that the benefit to American passengers would be about $300 million a year, because of lower fares and better service, and that American carriers would see an additional $1 billion in revenues. And the balance of trade on aviation, already $5 billion annually in favor of the American companies, would rise by $1 billion, the Administration said.
About 80 percent of the passenger traffic between the United States and Japan is Japanese. American carriers handle about two-thirds of the flights.
Service between Japan and the United States mainland is now limited to 12 cities, but that will probably increase. Besides Tokyo and Osaka, however, it is not clear how many Japanese cities will become popular destinations for flights from the United States.
Another step intended to make travel easier is code sharing, in which two airlines match up their schedules and list each others' planes in their computers, allowing a passenger to buy a ticket on a single flight that may be operated by one carrier for part of the way and another carrier for the remainder. For example, an American carrier could strike a deal with an airline in Japan or in China, allowing the American carrier to sell a ticket from the mainland United States to a city in China, with a stop in Japan and a change of planes there to an aircraft operated by a different carrier. Code sharing among American carriers would simplify travel from smaller cities in the United States to Japan.
The Japanese Government is considering partial deregulation of fares for its domestic airline industry, and under the agreement today will consider deregulating the fares for international flights. The agreement also allows United States airlines to own travel agencies and other ticket distribution companies in Japan, which are a traditional method of discounting there.
If the agreement brings more Japanese tourists to the the United States, the economic effects could extend well beyond the aviation industry. Japanese tourists spent more than $19 billion in this country in 1996, more than twice the amount of tourists from any other country, according to Government figures.
United Airlines said it would more than double its six flights a week from Chicago to Tokyo after the new agreement. And FDX will be able to fly cargo through Japan to points beyond. American negotiators maintain that FDX already had that right, under the old rules, but Japan had disputed it. Two other American cargo carriers, Polar Air Cargo and UPS, would also gain such rights.
The agreement will last for four years. But the newer airlines would receive permission for another 35 flights, if the agreement is not supplanted by a further loosening of restrictions. The Transportation Department will choose the additional carriers. Trans World Airlines and USAirways are likely candidates.
The pact could result in international realignments. In an era of code sharing, experts on the airline industry say American Airlines is likely to pair up with Japan Air Lines. All Nippon Airlines may end its agreement with Delta and sign on with United instead. Northwest, which just bought a big part of Continental, will be able to funnel more passengers into its trans-Pacific flights.
A big question is how landing rights at Narita will change hands. FDX, people familiar with the talks say, has been asking a high price for its slots, but other airlines say that if FDX is not using them, they will revert to the Japanese Government and that FDX should therefore lease them for small sums.

HEADLINE: Senate Candidates Flaunt Campaign Bank Accounts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The clamor over the financing of Federal elections may have left the impression that politicians would recoil at being linked to aggressive fund-raising. But the pronouncements yesterday by the rival camps in the New York Senate race showed once again that candidates would rather be perceived as harvesting bushels of contributions than as having a sparse crop.
The campaigns of the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato, and two Democratic contenders went out of their way yesterday to promote their latest fund-raising totals, maintaining that the figures demonstrated the strengths of their candidacies and evincing little fear that voters would tie them to the campaign finance inquiries in Washington. 
 "Campaign has over $9 million on hand," read the headline on the news release issued by Mr. D'Amato's aides. The release from the campaign of Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, announced, "Schumer reports close to $8.5 million in the bank." And the campaign of another Democrat, Mark Green, sought to put the best face on its far lower totals, noting that Mr. Green had already spent $2 million last year in winning re-election as New York City's Public Advocate.
The braggadocio underscored how, with Election Day still nine months away, the campaigns are focused on establishing their credibility with the political cognoscenti, and one of the clearest ways of doing that is by flaunting their treasuries.
"In modern American political campaigns, particularly in New York, economic viability precedes political viability," said Jeffrey B. Plaut, a partner at Global Strategy Group, a political consulting firm not involved in the Senate race. "Voters don't pay attention to this or care about this. But the people who fund campaigns and support them, the institutional players, look for a certain amount of money, given the candidates' profiles, in order to make judgments about how the campaign is going."
According to fund-raising statistics released yesterday in the race, which could be the most expensive Senate contest in the country this year, Mr. D'Amato continued to lead all candidates in collecting money. He has raised a total of more than $14.5 million, including $3.3 million in the second half of 1997. Mr. Schumer has collected a total of more than $10 million, including $2.7 million in the second half of 1997.
Mr. Green trailed far behind, having raised a total of $1.55 million, with $600,000 coming in the second half of 1997. Mr. Green has $700,000 in the bank, his campaign said. The other Democrat, Geraldine A. Ferraro, entered the race earlier this month so she did not have to file disclosure records due today at the Federal Election Commission.
The records filed by the D'Amato campaign showed that he had spent $3 million in the second half of 1997, mostly on television commercials, fund-raising and direct mail efforts -- an unusually high total so early in the race. In that same period, Mr. Schumer's campaign spent $875,000, although it purchased a spate of commercials this month that are not reflected in the figures.
Asked about their efforts to promote their fund-raising, advisers to the candidates said that they were merely interested in letting the public know about their achievements.
"Chuck is running a grass-roots campaign, and his war chest comes from literally 50,000 individuals who think it's time to retire Al D'Amato," said Hank Morris, Mr. Schumer's consultant.
The D'Amato campaign appeared so intent on demonstrating the Senator's financial strength that it noted in its news release that at this point in the 1992 contest, he had collected far less -- a total of $5.8 million, with $3.1 million in the bank.
"We believe that the people support Senator D'Amato's campaign because of his hard work on behalf of middle-class New Yorkers, and are proud of the support that we have received," said Kieran Mahoney, a D'Amato campaign consultant.
Part of what is happening is a bit of gamesmanship. The Schumer campaign, for example, hopes that potential donors, realizing that the Green and Ferraro campaigns lag in fund-raising, will conclude that the two do not have a chance of winning the Democratic nomination, so they will back Mr. Schumer.
The Green and Ferraro campaigns tell potential donors that their standard bearers may not be able to raise as much money as Mr. Schumer, but that they are better known and will thus prevail. "His record of service and accomplishments for New Yorkers is worth millions of dollars," said John Siegal, counsel to the Green campaign.
Ms. Ferraro's aides declined yesterday to say how much she has collected so far, but said that the response to her candidacy had been overwhelming, seeking to allay doubts about whether she can raise enough to be a viable candidate. "Things are going great," said David Eichenbaum, Ms. Ferraro's campaign manager.
All the talk of fund-raising bothers advocacy groups that want to reduce the role of money in elections by overhauling the campaign finance system. "It's a sad testament to what elections are about these days," said Rachel Leon, executive director of Common Cause New York. "It's something that they should be ashamed of, rather than proud of."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
This Year, a Record-Setting Sum Is Within Reach

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
As The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters the final month of its annual appeal, the tally of donations points to what could be the most successful drive ever.
By yesterday, the fund had received $4,830,466, compared with $4,171,567 at the same time last year. That puts this year's donations about $660,000 ahead of last year's. With 28 days until the end of the appeal, at least $253,086 more must be received to surpass the record total of $5,083,551 that was collected during the 1991-92 drive. 
 "The seven charitable agencies receiving funds for the neediest cases all over the city have asked me to express their gratitude to Times readers for making the campaign so far this year such an extraordinary success," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund.
"The agencies point out that thousands of impoverished New Yorkers -- especially the working poor -- have been sinking into hopelessness, and contributions from readers have been helping them stay above the poverty line," Mr. Gelb said. "Our wish now is that the contributions will come in at the same pace so that we can make this a banner year."
This is the 86th year in which readers of The Times have contributed in response to daily articles about orphaned children, homeless immigrants and hungry New Yorkers who have nowhere else to turn. It was an encounter with a homeless immigrant at Christmas in 1911 that convinced Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The Times, that people would give money to help ease the suffering of others if they knew about their struggles.
When the man, an unemployed Dane, told Mr. Ochs his story, the publisher handed him a few dollars for lodging, and his card. A few days later, the man showed up at The Times and Mr. Ochs gave him a job in the circulation department. "I would like to say he became an executive," Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, Mr. Ochs's daughter, said in a 1986 interview, "but unfortunately he died young." The publisher never told anyone the man's name, but from then on, he became known as "the Christmas Night man."
Inspired by the experience, Mr. Ochs asked a reporter to delve into the files of the city's largest charities and write unsentimentalized accounts of the 100 most compelling cases. On Christmas Day in 1912, The Times published "The 100 Neediest Cases"; in response, 117 donors gave a total of $3,630.
Last year, 12,518 donors gave $4,921,909, and because The Times pays all administrative costs for the fund, every dollar reached those in need.
Many of those who have responded are first-time contributors like Margaret Sedilis of East End Avenue in Manhattan, who sent $100 to honor her mother, Cynthia. "I do not remember a time that my mother did not send a check to the Neediest Cases," she wrote.
Others are like Kathy Porder of the Upper West Side, who sent $150 that would otherwise have been spent on Christmas presents.
Gregory Simon of Chappaqua, N.Y., decided to send in $550 -- one-tenth of the jackpot he won in an office football pool.
Werner and Erika Bloomfield of Kew Gardens, Queens, were moved by the accounts of people not so different from themselves. "As immigrants who came here more than 50 years ago, we would appreciate if you could use this money to help struggling immigrants," wrote Mrs. Bloomfield, who sent $100.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: IN PARIS;
Backing U.S., France Warns Iraqis to Yield on Arms Inspections

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Reinforcing American threats of military action, France warned Iraq tonight that it faced "very grave consequences" unless President Saddam Hussein allowed United Nations inspections of suspected chemical and biological weapons sites to resume.
French officials said that after a half-hour telephone conversation with President Clinton tonight, President Jacques Chirac agreed to use his own channels to convey the seriousness of the situation to Iraq. They also said he would use French influence with Russia and China to seek support for a strong United Nations resolution that would urge Iraq to cooperate with the inspections. 
 Mr. Chirac's spokeswoman, Catherine Colonna, said that the French objective remained "finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis by trying for unanimity in the Security Council," and that France still preferred diplomacy to the use of force.
But Mr. Chirac and other officials have shifted France's position close to acceptance of military action against Iraq if Mr. Hussein continues the confrontation. "We prefer diplomacy, but there are other options," a diplomat said this afternoon.
Another French official said, "We have always believed that a military operation carries many risks, but the ball is in Saddam Hussein's court, and we still think that intensified diplomatic efforts could get him to change his position."
According to Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, Mr. Clinton told the French leader that "the time for diplomatic solutions was quickly running out."
"The two Presidents agreed that the situation with respect to the status of U.N. mandates in Iraq is a serious one now and they needed to continue to consult closely as we continue to contemplate additional steps," Mr. McCurry said in Washington.
The French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, said after meeting on Thursday night with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, "I understand that all options are open, and this is why it is necessary to intensify the search for a diplomatic solution."
Yves Doutriaux, a spokesman for Mr. Vedrine, said before the conversation between the two Presidents today that "there has been no change in France's position." But American officials said France had now made clear that it is willing to be closely associated with American warnings to Iraq, even while hoping that force would not have to be used.
"The French have said what they have to say in a more helpful way than ever before," an American official said. "They are also aware of the value of unanimity in the Security Council." Russia, which has a permanent seat in the Council, said again today that it was opposed to the use of force in the current crisis, as is China.
In October, France, Russia and three other nations abstained from a United States-supported Security Council resolution threatening new international sanctions if Iraq did not cooperate more fully with inspections to insure that it stopped making or trying to make nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and destroyed all stocks and factories. These would be in addition to the economic sanctions imposed after the war in the Persian Gulf in 1991.
Iraq then tried to bar Americans from the inspection teams, and American officials said the split in the Security Council had encouraged the confrontation.
France, siding with Russia, argued then that American implacability toward Mr. Hussein was driving him to defy the United Nations resolutions. If Iraq knew that complying would get the economic sanctions lifted, the French argued, it might have a reason to cooperate.
That remains France's position today, with Mr. Hussein again defying the inspection process. But French officials now say they share American irritation with his behavior.
"We don't understand what he thinks he is doing," an official in the decision-making process said. "We believe the Security Council should show great firmness and make clear to the Iraqis that they can't dictate to the international community."
After talks with Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations in Paris on Tuesday, Mr. Chirac said he supported doubling the amount of oil Iraq is allowed to sell, now $2 billion worth every six months, to pay for food, medicine and civilian needs. Officials said he mentioned this proposal to Mr. Clinton in the telephone conversation tonight.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Tax Credits for Fuel Savings

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is proposing generous new tax credits for consumers who buy advanced automobiles that use emerging technologies to go two or three times as far on a gallon of gas as today's models.
The credits would lower an auto buyer's Federal income tax bill by $3,000 to $4,000, substantially cutting the net cost of vehicles that are likely, at first, to be more expensive than today's models. The subsidy, which would start in the year 2000, is meant to jump-start the mass production of exotic cars, trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles using novel technologies that are still on manufacturers' drawing boards. 
 The subsidies are the centerpiece of a $6.3 billion package of tax credits and research subsidies intended to fight the threat of global warming caused by emissions from burning fossil fuels. The package is part of President Clinton's budget request for the 1999 fiscal year.
Other parts of the tax proposal are intended to encourage owners of homes, factories, power plants and others to adopt solar power and other energy-efficiency technologies. One provision would give a $2,000 tax credit for the purchase of an energy-efficient new home.
The President is to submit his budget proposal to Congress on Monday, and he will discuss the energy-related tax incentives in his Saturday morning radio address, White House officials said today.
If Congress approves the tax subsidies -- which is by no means assured -- the measures could help make the new types of cars more affordable and help halt the recent American trend away from fuel-efficient vehicles.
Auto makers have already been tinkering with vehicles that would use hybrid gas-and-electric engines or even more efficient fuel cells instead of ordinary internal combustion engines, and several makers have said that such cars could become available in the next few years. Toyota has already introduced one model, the Prius, in Japan.
The $3,000 tax credit would begin in 2000 and would apply to any car that gets double the mileage of the average car of similar size. The $4,000 credit would begin in 2003, and would go to those who buy cars with triple the normal mileage. Both credits would phase out in later years, giving the most incentive to the earliest buyers.
To qualify for the proposed $3,000 tax credit, a midsized car would have to get about 45 miles a gallon.
Ari Fleischer, the spokesman for Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, responded skeptically to the President's proposal.
"As worthy as it sounds and may be, it is terribly complicated," Mr. Fleischer said of tax credits to stimulate specific economic activities. He said Mr. Archer was committed to steps that would simplify, not further complicate, the tax code.
The automotive tax credits would cost about $660 million over the next five years, officials said.
A spokesman for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association declined to comment on the plan, saying the car makers had not had a chance to examine its details.
Environmental advocates welcomed the proposals.
"We call on the Congress to recognize the broad economic and environmental benefits," said Howard Geller, executive director of the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy.
Mr. Geller also urged Congress to finance the research and development initiatives and approve the tax incentives.
The package also includes research subsidies to spur innovations in solar power, energy efficiency, and alternative fuels that give off less carbon dioxide than oil and coal.
A Clinton Administration official said that among the tax credits would be significant subsidies for owners of homes and businesses who install solar systems on their roofs, either to heat water or to generate electricity.
In another incentive for businesses, the Administration will propose investment tax credits to reward companies that install highly efficient equipment that generates electricity as well as capturing heat for industrial processes.
And it will propose expanding a tax benefit through which employers can subsidize workers' commuting expenses by paying mass transit fares, just as many workers receive free parking as a tax-free benefit.
The Administration will also propose extending an existing tax credit for electric utilities that generate power with windmills. The subsidy is due to expire.
In all, the tax credits would amount to an estimated $3.6 billion in lost revenues over the five years beginning in October. In addition, the Administration is calling for $2.7 billion in new Federal spending on energy conservation and related research over the five-year period.
The research subsidies would be focused on about five areas, an Administration official said.
These include efficient technologies for heating and cooling buildings, including advanced household appliances; further research into advanced automobile technologies; other transportation-related research, like fuel efficient heavy trucks and transit programs; conservation technologies for energy-intensive industries like steel, paper, and chemicals; and technologies involving renewable energy sources.
