SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 5; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1869 words

HEADLINE: With Freedom, Cairo Intellectuals Find New Stress;
Pressures Squeeze Islamic Scholars As Well as Leftists and Liberals

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
For Arab intellectuals here, this is a time of opportunity, danger and above all, change. While many say that never have they known such freedom of thought as in Egypt today, they also complain that threats from militant Islamists as well as official, collegial and economic pressures have silenced independent voices and weakened what was once the Arabs' most luminous intelligentsia.
"There is a vast amount of commotion and ferment amid utter stagnation," said Tahseen Bashir, a scholar and former diplomat. "Arab leftist thought has reached a cul-de-sac and so has that of the Islamists. There is now a deep void in Egyptian intellectual life," and because of Egypt's central role in Arab political and cultural life, he says, "a vacuum in intellectual life throughout the Arab world." 
 Under President Hosni Mubarak, privatization and globalization have spurred economic growth and opened up Egyptian society. But with that, intellectuals have a less prominent role, Mr. Bashir said. What he calls the bureaucracy's "Mameluk mentality," referring to the military oligarchs who ruled between the 13th and 16th centuries, and Egypt's corrupt "moneyed culture" impede modern intellectual as well as economic development.
Despite economic reforms, Egypt's continuing poverty, too, has taken a toll. University professors now earn less than servants, about $300 a month. Whereas at the dawn of independence, in the 1920's, thousands of books were published in Cairo, along with 200 newspapers and journals, 60 of them in foreign languages, only 375 books were published last year in a country of 63 million people. Mohammed Sid Ahmed, a leading leftist thinker, said intellectuals now read Al Ahram, once Egypt's most important newspaper, "mainly to see who died."
Egyptian Islamists, too, have found themselves shipwrecked. Once courted by the Government or used to counter leftist critics, Islamists are now increasingly on the defensive. "The Islamists themselves are split over such key issues as the use of violence, how an Islamic state should be governed and the treatment of women," Mr. Bashir said. The massacre of more than 60 Western tourists in December at Luxor by young Islamists, some of whom turned out to be middle-class university students, shocked peaceable Egyptians who abhor brutality and worsened an existing split in the militants' ranks.
Many Egyptian-based members of the Gamaa Islamiya, or the Islamic Group, intensified their call for a truce with President Mubarak, while adherents abroad rejected compromise. (From his American prison cell where he is serving a life sentence for his role in the World Trade Center bombing plots, Sheik Omar Abdul Rahman, the Islamic Group's spiritual leader, endorsed a cease-fire.)
The massacre, or "accident," as it is often called, also drove intellectuals more firmly into the Government's fold.
"It was a dreadful tactical error" for the Islamists, said Lutfi Kholi, a prominent leftist thinker, "in that it united the masses and intellectuals with a state that has occasionally oppressed them both."
 
Competing Trends, Both Exhausted
 As Mr. Bashir sees it, the current intellectual void, or "suspended animation," reflects the exhaustion of two intellectual trends that have competed throughout much of Egypt's modern history: liberal thinkers represented by the late Taha Hussein, the Arabs' most articulate champion of a modern secular future, who argued in the mid-1920's that Eygpt, the world's oldest nation-state, was an integral part of Mediterranean culture, or the West, and those who followed Hassan al-Banna, the founder of the Muslim Brotherhood, established in Egypt in 1928 and today the world's largest Islamist network.
Banna's Muslim Brotherhood sought political salvation not through the West, whose institutions and laws Egypt's 19th-century ruler Mohammed Ali had imported to Egyptian society, but through a return to the laws and precepts of Islam.
For Islamists, as they later came to be called, Arab greatness could be reclaimed only through a return to and revival of Islam and its caliphate, whose rulers presided over the medieval world's most vibrant empires and innovative cultures.
After Gamal Abdel Nasser's 1952 military coup, the Islamists were crushed and the liberals withered. Arab nationalism and socialism became much of the Arab world's secular religion. Leftists had their heyday under Nasser, the embodiment of pan-Arabism, who gave intellectuals a designated role as the explainers of the new faith.
But the 1967 military defeat by Israel, Anwar el-Sadat's lonely peace with the Jews and finally, the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran all weakened the left. "The death knell," Mr. Bashir said, "was the Soviet Union's collapse and the 1991 gulf war, which pitted Egypt, pan-Arabism's standard-bearer, against fellow Arab nationalist Iraq."
After Nasser, Sadat, who had once been editor of Al Ahram, had little use for the men of letters, especially those who opposed him. There was no room for them in Sadat's Infitah, or economic liberalization. Intellectuals, proselytizers of the discredited pan-Arab nationalist faith, no longer had a function. Said Mr. Bashir, "The government no longer provides intellectual dynamism and sense of mission as Nasser did."
Meanwhile, the siege of Egypt's secularists, which began in 1992 with the assassination of Farag Foda, a writer and human rights activist, and nearly claimed the life of Naguib Mahfouz, a cultural icon and the only Arabic writer to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, has continued despite a drop in the number of terrorist attacks. Religious extremists who advocate violence still try to punish those who deviate from Islam's "straight path," as they define it, with charges of heresy and apostasy, crimes punishable by death under sharia, or Muslim holy law, which since the mid-1980's has been the main source of Egyptian law.
A group of self-appointed guardians of the faith, the Islamic Research Center of Al Azhar, a branch of the Government's seat of Islamic learning, which is empowered to judge the merits of works that concern religion, has targeted Sayed al-Qimany, a 50-year-old secularist who has written 10 books on Islamic history "as it actually is," he said in an interview, "as opposed to what the Islamists would like it to be."
In August the Government's arts police removed Mr. Qimany's latest book, "Rabb Al Zaman," or "God of Time," from bookshelves after the clerics charged that the book violated Egyptian law by defaming Islam. What he wrote, Mr. Qimany says, is that Islam's third caliph, Othman, "was a weak, unpopular ruler who let his brother brutalize Egyptians" in the seventh century. Citing sources also used by Al Azhar, he also wrote that Othman had issued his own, self-serving version of the Koran, which Muslims believe contain the actual words of God.
 
A Secular Author Wins in Court
 While western scholars have analyzed religious texts as historical documents for more than a century, similar efforts in many Arab countries are still considered heretical and punishable by law. But Mr. Qimany contested the issue in Egyptian court and won.
In September, a high court ruled that the book did not insult or mock Islam and ordered it returned to bookstores. But the Islamists responded by issuing their own books, one of which denounces Mr. Qimany as "more dangerous than Salman Rushdie," the writer who faces constant death threats for his work. So Mr. Qimany is now constantly guarded by the Egyptian police and lives apart from his wife and children to protect them.
But he vows to continue challenging the Islamic orthodoxy. "The Islamists will not ultimately win here, but to stop them we may need 1,000 Farag Fodas," he said."I'm ready to pay that price."
Last summer, Article 19, the London-based anti-censorship group, accused the Egyptian Government of encouraging Egypt's intolerant militant trend by competing for legitimacy "on the Islamists' terms" and trying to co-opt Establishment clerics by letting them "ban books and censor films and endorse violent attacks on secularist writers." But Mr. Kholi argues that Egypt has recently taken a "much firmer stand" against Islamic literalism and intolerance.
Mr. Kholi, however, has his own problems, which reflect another source of pressure facing intellectuals who depart from received political wisdom. In January 1997, he was among nine well-connected Egyptian intellectuals who met in Copenhagen with 42 Palestinian, Jordanian and Israeli counterparts to push for cultural exchanges among those who favor territorial concessions by Israel in exchange for peace with the Arabs. But this leftist-led effort to establish normalization of discourse infuriated not only Egyptian Islamists opposed to peace with Israel but also pan-Arabists on the left who remain bitterly opposed to Sadat's peace. Their insistence on boycotting Israel is often the sole remnant of pan-Arabism, an ideology that some liberal Egyptian intellectuals say evolved into a cover for despotism at home.
Among the most stinging of critiques came in the pages of Al Ahram from Mr. Kholi's close friend and once leftist ally, Mohammed Sid Ahmed. Mr. Sid Ahmed said he denounced the Copenhagen group not because he opposed peace with Israel or cultural normalization in principle, but because President Mubarak was using the intellectuals to placate an Israel whose new leaders seemed intent on sabotaging peace and humiliating the Arabs. "This is not cultural exchange," Mr. Sid Ahmed said. "It is a state game."
Because Mr. Sid Ahmed wrote a book in the early 1970's, "After the Guns Fall Silent," which envisaged what peace could mean for Arabs and Israelis, Mr. Kholi does not question his friend's motives.
But he has been stunned by the relentless savageness of the attacks; there were three in a single day in Cairo newspapers in January.
Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a university professor and human rights activist, notes that despite their troubles, Egyptian thinkers are better off than their colleagues in, say, Algeria, where intellectuals are targeted for throat slittings by Islamists and figure disproportionately among the estimated 70,000 Algerians killed in the civil war between religious extremists and the autocratic, military-backed Government.
Indeed, the campaign against secularists, along with wars and political oppression, have driven many of the finest Arab minds not only from Cairo but also from Beirut, Baghdad and Damascus to the West, leading Abdelrahman Munif, a Saudi novelist who found shelter in Syria, of all places, to describe Paris as the "capital of the Arabs."
Mr. Ibrahim says the location of intellectuals no longer matters as much as it once did. "Satellites cross national borders and every point of view can now be heard on them," even, he asserted, on those owned by conservative Saudis and other wealthy gulf Arabs.
With such changes, some now argue that the problems of Egypt's intellectuals are peculiarly Egyptian. Still, intellectuals such as Mr. Bashir insist that what happens in the self-professed "mother of the world" resonates as strongly as ever in other Arab capitals.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 4, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday in the Arts and Ideas section about freedoms and limits in intellectual life in Egypt misidentified the newspaper of which Anwar el-Sadat was editor. It was Al Gomhuriya, not Al Ahram.
